column2: RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 2 -Plans to expand and modernize Raleigh-Durham Airport have alarmed conservationists because a new runway would encroach on Umstead State Park. The controversy will go to a vote on Tuesday, when voters will decide whether or not to approve bond issues to finance the expansion program.

IN its American debut, the new Orchestre de Paris, led by Charles Munch, proved to be "a big orchestra with a big sound," according to Harold C. Schonberg. "Right now it is a fine orchestra and it plays with assurance and virtuosity, but the nuances present in the top orchestras are still missing."
A YEAR TO GROW. By Felice Holman. Illustrated by Emily Arnold McCully. 100 pp. New York: W. W. Norton Co. $3.95.
BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 2 -- The Soviet occupation has stimulated the patriotic sentiments of Czechoslovakia's 300,000 gypsies.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- It is rare these days for museums to accord an entire private collection, no matter how extraordinary, the honor of a separate permanent installation. The usual practice in handling such gifts is to divide the contents of the collection by period, medium and quality, and thus incorporate the work into the museum's existing exhibition facilities.

Am I wrong about this, or do all Pinter plays seem better in retrospect than they do in the theater? Not that they fail to hold attention in the theater. They hold attention as a beached clam does, with the shell opening ever so slightly to permit viscous living matter to emerge warily and lick its way about the sand, testing an unknown environment.

ARTISTS' organizations, if they are worth their salt, have a difficult time of it. Some, like the Impressionists of the 19th century, are not organizations in the true sense of the word, but loose confederations of artists who share a common point of view and who join together for the specific purpose of bringing their work before the public.

BUCHAREST -- The first thing about Rumania is to get the rumors straight. Today this country no longer shows signs of feeling menaced by Soviet pressures or threats of intervention -- at least for the nonce. Its leaders state this plainly, and certainly travel to the capital and in the Danubian south seems to confirm their observations.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Roman Catholic and Protestant demonstrators clashed here today, scuffling and throwing firecrackers at one another. A large force of policemen brought the outbreaks under control.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Bill Main ran for touch-downs of 23 and 20 yards today and Oregon State pounced on Stanford fumbles in the mud and rain for a 29-7 victory.

POINTE-A-PIT. RE, Guadeloupe -- Until the 1960's, Guadeloupe and Martinique, the chief islands of the French Antilles and each an overseas department of France, seemed content to let the rest of the world go by. Hotels were few and mostly uninspired. Then these islands stirred from their lethargy.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A Russian physician has performed an appendectomy on himself in a submarine in the middle of the Pacific, according to Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.

Ships, sea gulls and lighthouse beams will be among the nautical trappings decorating the Plazaa's Grand Ballroom Nov. 19 for The Lighthouse Dinner Dance to aid the New York Association for the Blind.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Jim McCullough kicked a 38-yard field goal with 12 seconds to play today to cap a Georgia comeback and give the seventh-ranked Bulldogs a 10-10 tie with Houston.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 2 -- In the same way that a pilot goes back into the sky after a bad flight or a fighter goes back into the ring after a rugged match, Syracuse began to regain its confidence today.
AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Led by a five-touchdown performance by Little All-American candidate Bill Foye, Amherst erupted for a 42-6 victory over Tufts before 5,500 fans at Pratt Field.
EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Nov. 2 -- East Rockaway came up with a rarity when it registered two safeties in the first period today, but Horace Mann rallied to win, 14-4.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Fritz Habermas and Karsten Otto each scored one goal today in sparking Quinnipiac College to a 2-0 soccer victory over Adelphi University.

LITTLE FALLS, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Russ Strait threw two fourth-period passes to rally Ridgewood and tie Passaic Valley, 19-19, today. Bob McIlvaine and Don Durheimer caught the touchdown tosses that erased a 19-7 deficit.
Americans will have more choices to make next Tuesday than deciding whether to vote for Nixon, Wallace or Humphrey.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Ross (the Hoss) Montgomery slashed Baylor's defenses for 177 yards and three touchdowns today to lead Texas Christian to its first Southwest Conference victory of the season, a 47-14 rout of the Bears.
IRONHEAD. By Mel Ellis. 151 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart Winston. $3.95.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va. -- This historic city has a new attraction geared around an old mode of transportation. A replica of a hand-drawn ferry is making the same 310-foot trip across the Rappahannock River that George Washington used to take as a schoolboy more than two centuries ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 -- The UGI Corporation is investigating with other utilities the feasibility of building a 250,000-kilowatt power generating plant near Nanticoke, Pa., at a cost of $55-million.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 2 -- Virginia has passed its 1968 third-quarter mark with increases in nine major economic indicators over the similar period last year.

WASHINGTON -- Why is there a committee called Citizens for Humphrey-Muskie and also a committee called Citizens for Humphrey and Muskie? Because an antique law sets limits on the amount of money that any individual may give to any one political committee, but no limits on the number of political fund-raising committees that may be created.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 2 -One of the main concerns of Suffolk County Republican and Democratic leaders next Tuesday will be whether the Conservative party, which made large gains in the election last year, will be able to keep its momentum.
DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Alhambra Son won the $12,500- added Motor City Handicap today at Detroit Race Course. The race was for 3-year-olds and up foaled in Michigan.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Ted Alflen and Dave Buddington led Springfield College to a 28-7 victory over Wagner College today.

How much time does the typical pilot in private aviation spend in the sky in a year, and how skilled is he? Is he a rich man who can afford high fees? A young man with only passing interest in aviation? Or an older, steady user of the airways?
SYRACUSE -- Unhappiness is a city policeman.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Eleven South Vietnamese senators sent a telegram today to Richard M. Nixon saying his election to the presidency was "keenly awaited for the safeguard of South Vietnam."

THE American Shakespeare Festival of Stratford, Conn., long criticized in some quarters for its failure to achieve a specific image, is going to make another try. At the behest of its executive producer, Joseph Verner Reed, it has named Michael Kahn artistic director, a post it has not filled for years.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 -- In comparison with the gigantic scale of the recently concluded Olympic Games, a Grand Prix auto race is a small undertaking, an anticlimax. A few posters advertising tomorrow's running of the Gran Premio Mexico are listlessly displayed in shop windows.

HONG KONG, Nov. 2 -- The meeting of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party that took place between Oct. 13 and Oct. 31 appears to represent another move to stabilize conditions in the country and to consolidate the party's authority after two years of purges, dissension and violence caused by the Cultural Revolution.

The Making of Modern English Society, Vol I 1530-1780. By Christopher Hill. 256 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $6.95.
The third generation of computers came on the scene some four years ago with a bang and the business world is still recovering.
TROY, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Worcester Tech held off a late surge by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institue today to score a 23-21 victory at '86 Field.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 2 -- The bombing halt could rebound against Vice President Humphrey, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay said here today.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Oklahoma registered a 35-20 victory over Kansas State today in a hard Big Eight football battle in the rain.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Nov. 2 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew said last night that some elements at the Democratic National Convention felt more affinity for "totalitarian dictatorships" than for America.

NIAMEY, Niger -- At night, the liveliest place in this sleepy, charming capital city is Harry's Club, a discotheque that gives 25 per cent discounts on its $2 drinks in a bid to lure Peace Corps volunteers. By day, however, the National Museum is where the action is.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 2 -The state official in charge of Minnesota tourism says the state is "right on target" in its campaign to bring $1billion in tourist dollars to Minnesota by 1972.

JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Nov. 2 -- Robert R. Gilruth, director of the Manned Spacecraft Center at Houston, implied today that nothing had happened during the recently completed Apollo 7 space mission to "preclude" orbiting the moon on the next American space flight in December.
The 9,000-member instructional staff at the City University will vote Dec. 4 and 5 for which union they want to represent them in contract negotiations.

THE QUAKERS. Written and illustrated by Kathleen Elgin. 96 pp. New York: David McKay Company. $3.95.

FOUNDATIONS, and properly so, very rarely create, preferring to support existing organizations rather than build new ones. However, in 1966, the Rockefeller Foundation made a four-year grant amounting to a total of $370,000 to build up a modern dance repertory company in Salt Lake City.
ROME, Nov. 2 -- Pope Paul VI has sent messages expressing his hopes for success of the current efforts to end the Vietnam war to President Johnson and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam.
MONTVALE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- Undefeated, once-tied Pascack Hills rolled up 341 yards rushing today and went on to its fifth victory, 25-0, over Glen Rock. Butch Goette scored on runs of 5 and 26 yards.
AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Don Zwisler and Dan Ruff led the Akron University Zips to a 46-0 football victory over Illinois States today.
WESTFIELD, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Westfield, with its coach, Gary Kehler, hospitalized, upset Nutley today, 34-0. Westfield rolled up 352 yards while holding Nutley to 77 yards.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Coach Don Shula of the Colts said today that their receiver, Gail Cogdill, would replace the ailing Alex Hawkins as a reserve flanker. Cogdill was waived by Detroit without explanation this week after eight years with the Lions.

ONE of the most charming little American folk subcultures now being incorporated into the pop stream might, for lack of a better generic name, be called "swamp music." This loose label is used here to describe a mixture of white and black Mississippi Delta blues, music of the Louisiana Arcadians, Cajun-rock, bayou backwater ballads, and -- to toss in one more bit of regional American exotica -- the music called "zydeco."

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Leo Hart, Duke's sophomore quarterback, shattered a porous Georgia Tech defense today with accurate passing and expert guidance of a powerful running attack to post a 46-30 victory for the underdog Blue Devils.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Riot police were called to quell disorders in a Washington slum today after a white policeman shot two Negro women, one of whom reportedly had chased him with a butcher knife.

PRAGUE, Nov. 2 -- A scientist from the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences' observatory suggested today that "very dangerous," radiation from a solar radio storm might have forced a premature ending of the orbital flight of the Soviet manned space vehicle Soyuz 3 last Wednesday.

Eighty per cent of the city's truant officers have been truants themselves during the school strike in the sense that they have been staying away from work with fellow members of the United Federation of Teachers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- About 3.4 million workers have won an average of 7.5 per cent in immediate pay increases in major contract settlements so far this year, the Government reports.
Tradition, believes Bradford Smith Jr., is a nice thing provided it doesn't get in the way of new opportunities.

THE active career of Napoleon Bonaparte, bracketed as it was between the years 1793 and his death in exile in 1821, is extremely difficult to compress into a form likely to be digestible by the young. This fall five books and a documentary compendium are published, each of them, in one degree or another, attempting to introduce the First Empire to the young, either wholly or in part.
DENTON, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Steve Ramsey's passing led North Texas State to a 55-34 Missouri Valley Conference victory over Cincinnati today. Ramsey threw five touchdown passes.
The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to 312.8 in the latest week, from 311.4 a week earlier. A year earlier it was 299.3.
President Thieu's last-minute refusal to participate in the Paris peace talks is a serious setback, but it cannot be allowed to stop the quest for an end of the Vietnam war.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 -- Fordham's Club football team gained its fifth victory in six games tonight by defeating Louisiana State University of New Orleans, 14-6, before 3,786 fans at City Park Stadium. The triumph was Fordham's fourth in a row.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 -- Israeli officials confiscated 15 Arab-owned shops in East Jerusalem today for what they described as security reasons.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Pennsylvania's bubble burst today as Harvard, on the pinpoint precision of both its defensive and offensive elevens, defeated the Red and Blue, 28-6, at Harvard Stadium and remained undefeated after six games.

MONTREAL, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Montreal Expos of the National League announced today they would operate a Vancouver franchise in the Pacific Coast League on a joint-owner-ship basis with the Seattle Pilots of the American League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Kremlin analysts, minutely studying the campaign statements of the major Presidential aspirants, are believed to be having a hard time forecasting what they may face in the way of military policy from the next Administration.
The names of 2,650 people in New York City have been stricken from the voter registration rolls by the State Attorney General's office on evidence they are ineligible to vote.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- In a significant move toward university reform, the Berlin Institute of Political Science at the city's Free University gave its students full power for the first time this term to participate in equal force in the department's planning and decision-making.

KINGSTON, Pa., Nov. 2 -- Gwladys Groskin chose Ch. Kyi-Chu Friar Tuck, a Lhasa Apso, as the best in a field of 734 days at the 23d annual Back Mountain Kennel Club show in the 109th Field Artillery Armory, Kingston, Pa.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 2 -His sleek chestnut body straining, for a too-brief period giving an indication of his greatness, Romulus Hanover was a few strides short tonight and finished out of the money in his first race since last May.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The quadrennial Herbie Awards of the Political Critics Circle were distributed here last night at a gala $1.89-a-plate dinner. For the first time since the society's founding none of the Presidential candidates walked off with a major award.
HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- William J. Carroll, who received a new heart in a transplant operation Aug. 31, was discharged from Methodist Hospital today and returned to his home in Scottsdale, Ariz.

The Baltimore Colts make their first appearance at Yankee Stadium today, playing the Giants, since the memorable "sudden death" championship game 10 years ago. The Colts won that game and they are expected to win today.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Mike McMahon, a halfback and Bob Luckey, the quarterback, each made two touchdowns today as undefeated Bronxville won its sixth game of the season, 32 -- 18, over Tuckahoe.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A reserve tailback, Jim Lydic, getting his first starting call, scored a pair of touchdowns today to power Colgate to a 27-11 football victory over Lehigh.
LUGANO, Switzerland, Nov. 2 -- The United States team today defeated Rumania, 2 1/2-1 1/2, in the eighth round of the finals of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

NOME, Alaska -- This storied Gold Rush capital of the Arctic is bedding down for another winter of ice, snow, cold and tourists. Winter is a long season in the Arctic, for it begins the end of September and continues through May.

INSCRUTABLE: After a year and 50,000 miles of campaigning, Richard Milhous Nixon remains to all but his closest associates an inscrutable figure, leaving both friends and critics alike groping for the inner -- or, as Humphrey acidly puts it -- the "real" Nixon.

PARIS -- President de Gaulle gave the southern anchor of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization a gentle tug during his state visit to Turkey that ended last week. From the sidelines, the anchor seemed stronger than before the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia, but weaker than, say, five years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Aristotle Socrates Onassis today ordered three 255,000-ton tankers from Harland and Wolff, the Belfast shipbuilders. The order is worth 25-million ($60-million) and is one of the biggest oil tanker orders ever placed in the British Isles.
GREENSBORO, N. C., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Morgan State's 31-game winning streak, the longest in the country, was broken today as North Carolina A. and T. defeated the Maryland football team. 7-6.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 2 (AP) -- William and Mary put together its most consistent football offensive of the season today and upset Villanova, 33-12, behind the running of Terry Morton and Mark Parkenham.
CAIRO, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- The authoritative newspaper Al Ahram warned today that the United Arab Republic could retaliate for the Israeli raid into Egyptian territory Thursday night.

THE feeling that comes over an editor at the end of another publishing year in children's books is very much like the exhaustion of having shopped in a supermarket for a large family. You've put in your time, trudged the aisles, seen and sampled the merchandise on the shelves, maybe even squeezed a few tomatoes.

AS most children admit, the shudders accompanying a ghost story are, at least in part, shudders of delight. In naming the nameless and granting specific forms to a shapeless unknown, the literature of suspense and horror allays anxieties and resolves hidden conflicts. Unfortunately, the once-revered ghost story seems to be disappearing, while the tale of suspense, confined largely to the pulp forests of popular literature, has become mired in its own stereotypes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Herbert R. (Reg) Ingraham, an associate editor of the Kiplinger Washington Letter, died today in a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 62 years old and lived in Bethesda.

SAINT PLACIDUS, venerated since 1588 in the canon of the Roman Catholic mass, lived in the sixth century and was elevated to sainthood because he was miraculously saved from drowning as a boy. Placido Domingo, whose patron saint is Placidus, was 22 when he had reason to recall the saint's ordeal.
OMAHA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command said today that his command needed an entirely new intercontinental ballistic missile as well as a new manned weapon system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner gazed bemusedly as a troop of bearded students with shoulder length hair and knee high boots strolled through the main entrance of the staid Massachusetts Institute of Technology, of which he is provost.

JAKARTA Indonesia, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Adam Malik said yesterday that Indonesia would mediate in the Sabah dispute between Malaysia and the Philippines if both countries requested her to do so.

SPOILER: Behind his thumping third-party appeal to the murkiest instincts of the nation -- a know-nothing crusade that is a reminder that politicians need not shape public opinion to thrive, only reflect it -- there has been a dreamy counterpoint for George Corley Wallace in his campaign for the Presidency. Vibrations on a secret frequency have been telling him he could win, if not this year then another.

ELMONT, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Elmont climbed past Carey in the race for the South Shore Division 3 title with a 14-0 victory today. Quarterback Gary Marangi solved Carey's defense for both touchdowns and picked up over 100 yards rushing for Elmont.

DAYLILIES are increasing in popularity at a rapid rate because anyone and everyone can grow them. Few perennials are as versatile. Daylilies will grow in sun or shade, in good soil or poor, in climate moist or dry. Though good soil, adequate moisture and sun produce the best plants and the most flowers, this perennial is exceedingly durable.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Peddie handed The Hill its fifth loss of the season today, 20-12, as Rick Babula threw a touchdown pass and scored himself on a 25-yard pass interception.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Harry Rassman made three touchdowns and kicked three conversions today for a season total of 72 points, as undefeated Pleasantville won from Alexander Hamilton, 33-13,, for its sixth victory.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Almost as if driven by the grimy wind sweeping across the Gary plant of the United States Steel Corporation, the white steelworker walked by the outstretched hand of Senator Birch Bayh, grumbling as he headed for the plant gate, "He loused things up on gun control."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- Influential Communists here are convinced that greater political and economic liberalization is Yugoslavia's best defense against the long period of repression that is feared to be developing in the Soviet bloc.

The color ebbs, the leaves fall, and now November comes rustling down the valley, last summer's shade reduced to a brittle crispness underfoot. There will be a full and frosty moon tomorrow night, and only one more full moon before year's-end. But there are no finalities, even now. Change and partial summary, but not finality.
The Parke-Bernet Galleries continue to have what is probably their biggest season to date. Four sales are on the schedule this week, and one of them will have both morning and afternoon sessions.

An army of 125,000 citizens working temporarily as press reporters will collect, tabulate, tally and distribute through a sophisticated computer system the vote in all 50 states of the United States in Tuesday's national and state elections.

HARTFORD, Nov. 2 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff and Edwin H. May Jr. appealed for votes today, as their campaign drew to a close, using the arguments that have become familiar during their campaign for the United States Senate.
The Columbia varsity soccer team remained in Ivy League contention by defeating Cornell, 2-1, yesterday at Baker Field.

ALAN HOVHANESS had a new work played on Friday in Carnegie Hall by the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, and one of the many interesting things about it was its opus number. The work was "Fra Angelico" (Op. 220).

About 60 high school students who participated in Columbia University's summer project to held under-achievers from slum areas began returning to Columbia last week for morning classes that will continue until the teachers' strike ends.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Motoring in South America is settling down to a respectable adventure. My husband and I recently drove about 1,000 miles in 25 days through Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and Venezuela, and, while the trip cannot be recommended to those who require expressways and air-conditioned motels, we found it to be far from the harrowing experience that reports during the past few years have indicated.

CALGARY, Alberta, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Max Conrad, the flier, is scheduled to leave tomorrow on the second leg of what would be the first around-theworld flight over the poles in a light piston-engine plane.
MILTON, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Groton School warmed up for its traditional meeting with St. Mark's next Saturday by defeating Milton, 20-6, today for a 2-3-1 won-lost-tied record.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Floral Park clinched at least a tie for first place in North Shore Division 4 by defeating Locust Valley, 21-0, today. Brian Peterson scored touchdowns to cap 65 and 60-yard drives.
WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Bob Wilson, a leading scorer in the prep ranks, saw limited action today as his school, Loomis, defeated Kent, 16-0.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Arkansas' sophomore quarterback, Bill Montgomery, engineered three second-half touchdowns today to keep the Razorbacks' Southwest Conference title hopes alive with a 25-22 victory over Texas A. and M.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 2 -Kansas City will be a hub of international aeronautic communications when the Federal Aviation Administration opens a major facility here next spring.
The hotel industry will face a big headache next year when the new jumbo jets, each carrying some 400 passengers, are scheduled to make their debut.

Whenever a society is afflicted by doubt and disorder and citizens succumb to irrational fears, as in the United States today, a demagogue is sure to emerge seeking power by exploiting public passions and offering glib solutions to complex problems. Such a man is George C. Wallace, Presidential candidate of the American Independent party.

THE public school system of New York City is on the brink of collapse. No compromise between the teachers' union and the school board is likely to resolve the fundamental conflicts between the school staff and the advocates of black community control. Until the basic political framework of public education in New York City is altered, strikes and boycotts -- or both -- are likely to recur on an annual basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- As many as 30,000 urban dwellers could be permanently housed in floating communities near major coastal oities, according to a recent study sponsored by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Contending that banks were encouraging personal bankruptcies by the indiscriminate distribution of credit cards, senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he would ask Congress to impose Federal controls in the credit card field.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 31 -- The Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia has had little effect on the neutrality policy of Sweden, the Soviet Union's Baltic neighbor. Swedish officials believe it will be possible to enjoy nearly the same relations with Moscow as before.

AKRON, Nov. 2 -- A statewide poll conducted by The Akron Beacon Journal said Richard M. Nixon should not be concerned over winning Ohio's 26 electoral votes. The poll gives him a commanding lead over Vice President Humphrey, with George C. Wallace a distant third.
MANILA, Sunday, Nov. 3 -- The anti-Huxbalahap campaign in central Luzon entered a new phase today as military operations ceased and an all-civilian effort against the dissidents got under way.

GESNERIADS will be discussed by James Wyrtzen on Wednesday at the Horticultural Society of New York Essex House, 160 Central Park South. The lecture will begin at 7:30 P.M. It is free to members and one guest.

MAN IN MOTION. In every sense, Hubert Horatio Humphrey is the liberal enthusiast. Quick of wit yet glib of phrase, gay yet compassionate, experimental and excitable, he has lived, preached and profited from a seemingly inexhaustible faith in the perfectability of man and the American system. He has made a career of idealism.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados -- This is one of the few island retreats that has retained, through the current tourist boom, its Caribbean-English flavor. In spite of its many concessions to today's visitor, the island has kept its own identity.

The Village of Ossining ordered 4,000 extra ballots yesterday to comply with a Federal Court order directing that all of its registered residents be permitted to vote on whether to change the system of village government.

JERUSALEM -- For many months after the six-day war last year, life along the Suez Canal cease-fire line was one long, hot bore. Israeli and Egyptian soldiers would shout at each other just to relieve the boredom.
WILLIAM C. HANDY, the Negro jazz musician and composer who is often called "father of the blues," will be honored on a United States postage stamp to be issued next year.
The Long Island University soccer team set up a possible three-way tie in the Metropolitan Conference yesterday by blanking City College 2-0, at the winners field in downtown Brooklyn.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Trenton State captured its fourth victory of the season at Sprague Field before 6,233 fans tonight by downing Montclair State, 15-7.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars said today that it would boycott Veterans Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery Nov. 11, as it did last year. The group's commanderin-chief, Richard Homan, said that the organization with 1,450,00 members, "has discontinued our participation in the Veterans Day ceremonies at Arlington because the Department of Defense continues to bar the rank - and - file veteran from burial at Arlington."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 1 -- Thirteen thousand employes of Tinker Air Force Base at Oklahoma City will receive raises this Sunday. And these raises, averaging 20 cents an hour, may re-elect Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, a Democratic fixture in Washington for 30 years.
MIAMI, Nov. 2 -- The Castro regime has started a vigorous propaganda campaign whose aim seems to be to keep Cuba's large military and security apparatus in line politically.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Hempstead, which had a 12-game winning streak halted by Roosevelt last week, today was upset by Malverne, 12-0. A blocked punt late in the fourth period gave Malverne a chance to win its fourth straight and Cal Cunningham capitalized by passing 10 yards to Steve King for a touchdown.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Woodland Junior High School was damaged early today by small fires set in five locations in the school.
A badly wounded man with a long police record was carried into the Bellevue Hospital emergency room early yesterday morning by two men who left before they could be identified.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Ivan Jelic, 24 years old, was executed here today after President Tito refused his appeal for clemency. He was sentenced to death in July on charges of having planted two bombs at the Belgrade railway station, injuring 14 persons.
CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Briarcliff defeated Croton today, 14-13, as Doug Gardner threw two touchdown passes to Ross Connolly for the winners.

THERE was an abundance of joy in Wall Street and business circles, though no explosive market reaction, after President Johnson's momentous decision last Thursday to halt completely the bombing of North Vietnam.

BALDWIN, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Baldwin upset highly regarded East Meadow, 14-13, today when it marched 56 yards in 12 plays to score following East Meadow's go-ahead touchdown in the fourth period. Jim Lynch carried it over from the 2-yard line and Keith Raitano, who scored Baldwin's first touchdown, kicked the extra point.
Most issues traded on the over-the-counter market and the American Stock Exchange fell last week in comparatively quiet trading.

TWO o'clock on a Sunday afternoon. One of those glass cages overlooking the noise and smoke of midtown Manhattan the people at the Hilton call a hotel room. Jose Feliciano is playing quiet guitar clusters on the phonograph and Patty Duke, exchild star, is smoking a cigarette and eating scrambled eggs in her bare feet.

TEANECK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Larry Mulloy scored four touchdowns and Ed Whalen three today as Bergen Catholic romped to a 58-0 victory over Teaneck. It was Bergen Catholic's fourth triumph in six starts.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Worchester fell behind Deerfield by a touchdown in the first period today, then rallied for a 34-15 victory that ran its undefeated streak this season to six games. The loss was the home team's second in five contests.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Purdue stuck to a ground game, roiled to a 17-point lead in the first half and coasted to a 35-17 victory over Illinois today. The triumph kept Purdue in the race for the Big Ten football crown.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The anticruelty society is trying to pass the buck. The buck was pulled out of the Chicago River near the Loop Friday. Now we can't find anyone who will take it," the society said yesterday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A sophomore quarterback, Larry Lawrence, ran for four touchdowns and led Iowa to a 35-28 victory over Minnesota in a Big Ten football game today.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- George C. Wallace said today that the tumultuous reception for him in Chicago last night "bears out what I have been saying -- that our movement is strong all over the country."
NEWARK, Nov. 2 -- East Side scored three times in the fourth quarter to beat a city rival, St. Benedict's, by 40-20 today.

SUEZ, United Arab Republic, Oct. 29 -- The belly dancers have long since been evacuated westward across the desert but the coffeehouses stay open late even on nights when Egyptian and Israeli shells scream above the minarets.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- An "Ezzard Charles Appreciation night," honoring the former world heavyweight champion who is now seriously ill, will be held at the Sherman Hotel in Chicago on Nov. 13.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The University of Illinois will try to determine whether labels on pesticides get their message across to the public, the Agriculture Department has said in announcing a $50,000 research contract for the two-year project.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The Bridgeport and Fairleigh Dickinson soccer teams battled to a 3-3 tie in double overtime today at Fairleigh Dickinson Field. Bob Cowell scored two goals for the home team, while Charlie Egervari tallied twice for Bridgeport.

Despite a bloody civil war that has brought heavy destruction to its Eastern Region, Nigeria is continuing to keep her economic house in fairly good order and is prepared to push the build-up of the country.

The engineer at the Xerox Corporation generally credited with having transformed xerography from a laboratory curiosity to a successful commercial process is being succeeded on Dec. 1 by the engineer at Ford Motor Company who had been in charge of Ford's research on an all-electric auto.

WALTHAM, Mass., Nov. 2 -- The acting New England division engineer of the Army Corps of Engineers said this week that a proposed dredging of Penobscot Bay, near Belfast, Me., would be postponed pending a decision on an acceptable site for dumping the material.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 -- The relationship between the South Vietnamese Government and the United States mission continued to deteriorate today after President Nguyen Van Thieu declared that his government would not participate in the Paris talks next week.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2 -- Ground fighting grew more intense in South Vietnam yesterday as allied units fought sharp battles with both North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces.

EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said last night that the United States should withdraw its troops from South Vietnam if its President, Nguyen Van Thieu, would not agree to a peace settlement.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Mamaroneck defeated Scarsdale, 26-6, today for the Tigers' sixth victory in seven games. The winner was tied with Port Chester and Lakeland for the lead in Division B of Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Conference.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Dan Carretta, a senior quarterback from Wantagh, L. I., raised his total of touchdown passes this season to 13 today as he led Canterbury to a 49-16 rout of Suffield. The victory was the sixth for undefeated Canterbury.

WASHINGTON -- "Making peace with Hanoi," said a high and weary Administration official last week, "is like spinning three roulette wheels all at once and the right number has to come up on each of them at the same time."

MIAMI BEACH -- Few people seem to know it, but late fall is one of the best times to visit resort. The weather usually is dry and comfortable, hotel rates are just a little higher than the low summer levels and the entertainment calendar is just gearing up for the winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Servicemen and war veterans were in a crowd of about 400 persons staging anti-war protests today at the campaign headquarters of Richard M. Nixon and Vice President Humphrey.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The City Commission's new ordinance to ban obscenity in books, magazines and records for those under 17 years of age is so specific in describing anatomical features and acts that may not be portrayed that the Miami Herald reports the definition is unprintable.

PRAGUE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Despite a fast rise in national income this year, an increase in private consumption and the growth of industrial and agricultural production, there are a number of bottlenecks in the Czechoslovak economy, affecting chiefly the building trade, the home market and also export trade.

Thirty members of the New York National Guard have been accused of yielding to the temptation of a motel's soft beds, tiled showers and Satur-night television instead of sticking it out in their tents on a weekend training exercise.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Bill D. Moyers, publisher of the Long Island newspaper Newsday, appealed today for a contemporary education aimed at the nation's young Negroes. Mr. Moyers, former White House press secretary, spoke at inauguration ceremonies for Dr. Benjamin F. Payton as president of predominantly Negro Benedict College in Columbia.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 2 -- A 19-year-old amateur boxer, whose name was unknown to most Americans two weeks ago, has suddenly been seized upon by the two major Presidential candidates as a symbol of the things that are right with America.

ROME, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- About 200,000 persons are ill with 'Mao Tse-tung flu" in Rome alone, and the epidemic is expected to grow in the next few weeks, the Health Ministry said today. The influenza virus got its nickname because it is believed to have originated in China and to have spread through Asia toward Europe via Hong Kong.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Democrats who had been hoping to realize a modest political profit from the bombing halt in North Vietnam began wondering today whether the ensuing international controversy might not instead cost them votes next Tuesday.
The Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria will be the setting next Sunday for the annual dinner dance aiding the National Tay-Sachs and Allied Diseases Association.
An international football match between Australia and the New York Gaelic All-Stars will be played today at Gaelic Park, the Bronx, starting at 3 P.M.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- The East German Communists said today that it was their "duty" in the name of European security to intervene against a West German party convention scheduled to open in isolated West Berlin tomorrow.

EL PASO, Tex., Nov. 2 -- Richard M. Nixon, who has said at every stop this week that he would not indulge in "personal charges" against his opponents, wound up his formal speechmaking today with a harsh attack on both Hubert H. Humphrey and Edmund S. Muskie.

PLAINEDGE, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Hicksville's quarterback, Brain McAuley, had one of his poorest passing days today (2 for 8 for 27 yards), but Hicksville's ground game made up for it in a 34-0 victory over Plainedge. Hicksville rushed for 242 yards compared to 44 by Plainedge.

EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 2 -- Steve Sogge's 3-yard touchdown pass to Bob Klein with 1:13 left gave Southern California's top-ranked Trojans a 20-13 victory today over Oregon before 33,500 in a Pacific Eight Conference game.
FOR many years there has been much debate over the ability of a trout to survive capture and release.
POMFRET, Conn., Nov. 2 -- Jeff Stone's two touchdown runs paced Pomfret to a 30-25 victory over Moses Brown today.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Hackensack gained a 13-12 victory over Englewood today on a touchdown made as the final gun sounded.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Undefeated Smithtown (6-0) moved a step closer to the Suffolk League. One championship when it defeated a major rival, Brentwood, by 13-0 today.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Nov. 1 -- Republicans throughout the South have spent most of the last months explaining over and over that a vote for George C. Wallace would amount to a dangerously ineffective protest.

NEW PROVIDENCE, N. J., Nov. 2 -- New Providence won its fifth in six games today by defeating Caldwell, 20-0, as Bob Tatti, Tony Rubbo and Paul Gravlin scored the touchdowns. Gravlin's tally came on a 53-yard pass from Bob Woodruff.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Port Washington, which had averaged better than 37 points a contest in winning its first five games this season, almost hit its average on the nose today in crushing Garden City, 39-13.
FAST ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2 -- An Upsala College homecoming crowd of 6,000 saw the Vikings score in every period today and defeat Lycoming College, 39-8, in n Middle Atlantic Conference football game.

MUCH has been written about the amazing total output of John Creasey, most of it understandably wrong. Understandable, because until recently Creasey himself did not have an accurate count of how much he has written under his own name and his various pseudonyms.

ATHENS, Nov. 2 -- The Athens police warned tonight that they would tolerate no demonstrations at the funeral tomorrow of former Premier George Papandreou, who was done of Greece's most popular politicians and a foe of the present army-backed regime.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Nov. 2 -- The only unscored-on defense in Nassau County scholastic ranks was as good as ever today as Lawrence whipped Valley Stream Central, 32-0, for its fourth victory in a row.

Allen Jr. had failed.

There was a candlelight parade on Fifth Avenue early last night for the Humphrey-Muskie ticket. About 500 persons most of them of high school and college age, took part. They gathered at 7 East 52d Street and marched to 59th Street.

TORONTO, Nov. 3 (AP) -Russ Jackson scored one touchdown and passed for another and Don Sutherin kicked three field goals today as the Ottawa Roughriders beat the Toronto Argonauts, 31-9, and finished first in the Canadian Football League's Eastern Conference.

LISBON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Vital respiration equipment for former Premier Antonio de Oliviera Salazar was flown from London today in an attempt to prolong his life. Tubes for the respirator, which has helped Dr. Salazar breathe since his stroke Sept. 16, were rushed here on a Portuguese airliner. Hospital sources said he could no longer breathe without the respirator.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Elgin Baylor scored 40 points to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 127-109 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight. He also grabbed 14 rebounds and passed for 12 assists.

A Urugayan travel agent was found murdered early yesterday morning in his seventhfloor room at the New York Hilton Hotel. No money or valuables were found in the room, which showed signs of a fierce struggle.

BOSTON -- The full cast of the new musical "Zorba," which has been playing here before moving to Broadway Wednesday, was called on stage at the Shubert Theater to listen to a performance of the latest "notes."

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 3 -- The final Gallup poll of the 1968 election campaign was released today and gave Richard M. Nixon 42 per cent of the popular vote, Hubert H. Humphrey 40 per cent and George C. Wallace 14 per cent, with 4 per cent undecided.

Richard M. Nixon is a strong favorite to win the Presidency tomorrow despite a late rally by Vice President Humphrey that has tightened the race considerably, a national political survey indicated yesterday.

Mrs. William D. Hardin of Short Hills and Mrs. Sheridan R. Smith of Summit are cochairmen for the event.

SEATTLE, Nov. 3 -- Coach Red Holzman shook up the New York Knickerbocker line-up tonight and although the new pattern didn't exactly solve all problems, it did snap a threegame losing streak and produced a 122-108 victory over the Seattle Sonics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A high official of the Federal Reserve System has conceded, in effect, that 55 years after its founding the nation's central bank still does not know how monetary policy works.
SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 3 -After a scoreless first half the Manhattan Football Club drove for three touchdowns today to defeat the University of Scranton, 20-0.
Seven hundred cheering landlords, chanting "Dump Lindsay," overwhelmingly approved a "job action" beginning Dec. 17 unless the city eases its rentcontrol law.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The expansion of the United Nations enclave by adding a three-acre strip of park on a pier along the East River and a city block to the south is being proposed to the General Assembly.
CAIRO, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -The United Arab Republic tonight reviewed measures to prepare the nation for war.
MADRID, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Hundreds of policemen occupied the campus of Madrid University today to prevent renewed outbreaks of violence.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- A West German exporter who sells plants making hydrogen by the water electrolysis method says it is tougher now to do business in Eastern Europe -- particularly in Czechoslovakia.
MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Montreal Expos announced today they had acquired West Palm Beach of the restructured Class A Florida State League as a farm affiliate.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 4 -- A dynamite blast that threw tons of earth into the air today signaled the formal start of construction of the $827-million Tarbela Dam on the Indus River, 70 miles northwest of Rawalpindi, Pakistan's interim capital.

The primary duty of every American citizen eligible to vote is to cast his ballot today. We recapitulate below the recommendations this newspaper has made for the guidance of voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Asterisks denote incumbents, although in some cases district lines have been changed since the last election.
A New York City voter in today's election must have registered during central or local registration periods this year -- or be registered under the Permanent Personal Registration system.
PRAGUE, Nov. 4 -- The Dubcek forces in the Czechoslovak Communist party have opened an offensive against pro-Soviet conservative factions a week before a session of the party's Central Committee.
A service to inform high school seniors about college admissions has been opened, Walter J. Degnan, president of the Council of Supervisory Associations, announced yesterday.
Justice Abe Fortas took a calm and lighthearted view yesterday of election year criticism of the Supreme Court, confident that "the Nine Old Men" will survive the latest round of recriminations.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The National Liberation Front has rented a mansion crowned by two weathervanes with appropriate symbolism for the Vietnam talks -- one a dove and the other a dragon breathing fire.

While the New York Jets appear destined for their first Eastern Division championship in the American Football League the Western Division title might be determined by a survival of the fittest. Of the three teams separated by one-half game, both the division-leading Kansas City Chiefs and the Oakland Raiders possess a quarterback with a damaged leg.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 4 (AP) -- More than 80 policemen stood in a line-up again today to be seen by 20 persons who said they were witnesses or victims of police brutality and misconduct during the city's racial disorder last July 3.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Israeli policemen today began taking possession of 15 stores in the Arab quarter of Jerusalem. They acted as Arab store-owners continued a strike begun Saturday as a protest against Israeli rule.
LISBON, Nov. 4 -- The Portuguese navy received today a 1,700-ton destroyer escort vessel, built under a mutual assistance agreement with the United States.
Eddie Belmonte, the 26-year-Old jockey from Santurce, Puerto Rico, suffered a broken right shoulder in a spectacular spill at Aqueduct yesterday.
The Federal Trade Commission, Washington, is expected to issue a consent order soon involving Burlington Industries, Inc., the country's largest textile producer.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The man who is Canada's 10th heart transplant patient was identified today as John Parkinson, 53 years old, of Montreal. A spokesman at Royal Victoria Hospital, where the operation was performed yesterday, said he was doing "very well."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Coach John McKay of the University of Southern California expressed disappointment today that his unbeaten Trojans might be losing ground to Ohio State as the nation's top-ranking collegiate football team.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Detroit Tigers, who went on to win the World Series, had the best record for home games, road contests and night games in the American League last season, according to unofficial statistics issued today.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Commission against Discrimination ruled today that it had no jurisdiction in cases of people who are discriminated against because they wear beards. Mrs. Erma Ballantine, chairman of the commission, said she agreed that a bearded theology student "had been discriminated against" by an official of the Boston School Department who refused to take his application for a job as a substitute teacher.

A gala benefit preview of "The Art of the Goldsmith and the Jeweler" after a buffet dinner at the Ground Floor will take place tomorrow from 9 P.M. to midnight at A La Vielle Russie, 781 Fifth Avenue.

BY the bushel or by the pound, this season's apple crop continues to provide crisp, juicy fruit for pies and desserts and for mincemeat and preserves to enjoy all winter long. Here are recipes calling for apples.

Six shows will give Election Day matinees today. They are "Curley McDimple," "Golden Rainbow," "Maggie Flynn," "Mame," "You Know I Can't Hear You When the Water's Running" and "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown."

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A nuclear test of low yield was conducted underground today by the Atomic Energy Commission at the Nevada test site. The blast had a maximum yield of 200 kilo-tons, or the equivalent of 200,000 tons of TNT.
ISTANBUL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The 18,000 ton Soviet helicopter carrier Moskva sailed through the Turkish Straits today on her way back to the Black Sea after a month's stay in Mediteranean waters.
Scattered antiwar demonstrations were staged in various parts of the city yesterday, as youthful radicals prepared for protests today against an election they termed "a fraud."
ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 1,776 of 2,332 applicants had passed the written test for admission to the bar at the examination held on July 18 and 19.

The Brick Presbyterian Church's 25th annual Christmas Fair will be held Nov. 21 and 22 in Watson Hall, Park Avenue and 91st Street. Proceeds will benefit the charitable program of the Women's Association of the church.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Some 300 students staged a three-hour demonstration at San Fernando Valley State College in suburban Northridge today, occupying two floors of the institution's administration building.

The City Commission on Human Rights reported yesterday that its community action staff had found "no evidence" that any city, state or Federal funds had been used in the production of "hate literature" distributed during the teachers union strike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Additional contracts for production of M-16 rifles have been announced by the Pentagon.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 4 -- Yale College went coeducational today -- but only for a week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi wrote President Johnson congratulating him on the "wise and courageous decision" to halt the bombing of North Vietnam, the Indian Embassy said today.

"THE GRAB BAG" is a repulsive trio of plays of a type that has made pornography a dirty word. For some inscrutable reason best known to its producer -- a man apparently known as Thespis -- it opened at the Astor Place Theater last night. Grab it I didn't.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Because many Americans tend to grow wider as they grow older, a nutrition group has recommended a cut in their daily calorie intake.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Edward G. Lenney, the convict who says he helped murder Gabriel (Johnny the Walk) DeFranco, was forced under cross-examination today to read a statement he once made saying he knew nothing of the slaying.

Capt. Charles G. Reid, master of the luxury cruise liner Argentina, jumped out of a window of his spacious quarters last Wednesday when the vessel was plying Caribbean waters, the ship's owners reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) - Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a last-minute appeal issued tonight for the Presidential candidacy of Richard M. Nixon, urged voters not to be turned away from the Republican nominee by the Vietnam bombing halt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Vice President Humphrey and his Republican rival, Richard M. Nixon, have now issued their respective "position papers" on Latin America. Each has outlined the policies he would pursue in the hemisphere if elected President.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A New York banker expressed hope that the American President who will be elected "will give us the economic policies we need to put us back on the right track."

Newmark Co. Real Estate, Inc., has appointed Harry Licht to a vice presidency. Mr. Licht, a specialist in sales, investments and property assemblies, had been with Charles F. Noyes Co. for the last three years.
Randy Stevens, 184 pounds, of the Virgin Islands, used an effective left hook last night to pound out a unanimous 10-round decision over Curtis Bruce, 176, of Newark, at the Audubon Ballroom.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Max Elbin, the president of the Professional Golfers' Association, has written a letter to all 1968 tournament sponsors in which he said they would risk losing their places on the schedule if they continued to delay decisions on signing with the P.G.A.
"IF we cannot achieve an Arab solution, then we must have a Jordanian solution."

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Negro students staged sit-ins at several Chicago public high schools and disturbances at several others today. They threatened to carry protest demonstrations into Election Day, when many schools are used as polling places.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- British Overseas Airway Corporation announced plans today for a new, shorter route to Japan over the top of the world.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 4 -- The Yale Law School held an Abe Fortas Film Festival tonight.
The election of Theodore Schlesinger and of Melvin C. Holm as members of the board of trustees of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York was announced yesterday.

Election results will be provided by WQXR AM and FM direct from the news room of The New York Times. Coverage will begin at 7 o'clock tonight and will continue on the hour and half hour throughout the evening.
EUGENE, Ore., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- An explosion damaged two offices of the Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps on the University of Oregon campus early today.

Cigarette smokers are considerably more likely to suffer from gum disease and lose their teeth than persons who have never smoked, according to a study of 7,000 persons published in the current Journal of the American Dental Association.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 4 (AP) -- President Johnson urged action today against noise from all sources -- from jet engines to starlings and from lawn mowers to rumbling trucks and bathroom facilities.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A committee of lawyers said today that William Bradford Huie, the author, and the publishers of Look magazine could be in contempt of court because of an article on James Earl Ray in the current issue of Look.
Six buses brightly painted with heraldic designs began cruising Fifth Avenue yesterday morning to draw attention to an exhibition of medieval art from private collections at the Cloisters.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation shocked the industry yesterday with a 22 per cent reduction in the price of a major type of steel.
Irving Jacobson, Sancho Panza in "Man of La Mancha," since the musical hit opened here on Nov. 22, 1965, has resigned. His role will be assumed tonight by Joey Faye.

Construction costs throughout the country climbed 3 per cent on the average in the 12 months ended Oct. 31, according to a detailed survey covering 158 cities in the continental United States and 33 in Canada.
The two-hour trip from Staten Island is "hard on the children" but the James W. Lambertons prefer that to having their children miss school.
A Coast Guard cutter reached the burned-out hulk of a Norwegian tanker yesterday but was unable to learn what had happened to most of her 33 crewmen because of high winds and seas 35 feet high.
Increased production costs caused a small decline in third-quarter earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

SEATTLE, Nov. 4 -- Coach Red Holzman tried something different last night as his New York Knickerbockers snapped a three-game losing streak. And although it worked, not even Holzman knows if it is the real answer to his nagging problems.

Meredith Monk, a choreographer of the Judson Church avant-garde, makes things easier for the squares. For those too dim to walk out of a nonevent in which barriers between public and performer are being fashionably destroyed, she clears the auditorium of seats and gently urges her audience to mill around, talk, walk.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 25 -- According to the astrologers most in vogue here, recent changes in the path of the planet Jupiter point clearly to the conclusion that there are about to be important changes for the better in Burma.
The City Planning Commission was confronted yesterday with the largest single-year request for capital funds ever submitted here for transit purposes -- $250,050,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Attorneys for Dr. Benjamin Spock said today in a statement filed in the United States Court of Appeals that the conviction of the pediatrician and three others on antidraft conspiracy charges violated their constitutional right to free speech.
Jam sessions, long a basic and indispensable part of jazz, now are becoming popular in rock as well.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Recent economic evidence indicates that the nation has "turned the corner toward price stability," President Johnson was told today.
TRENTON, Nov. 4 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes said tonight that taxes would have to be raised if three bond issues totaling $990-million were defeated by the voters tomorrow.
For a while there back in the spring a lot of Seagram billings seemed to be dribbling out of Doyle Dane Bernbach. Today there's some dribbling in. About $3-million -- a big dribble.
LISBON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Doctors said today that they had introduced electric shock treatment of the heart in their efforts to keep former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar alive.

Twelve years of work by Prof. Edgar Johnson of City College began to pay off yesterday when the manuscript of his book, "Sir Walter Scott," received the first American Heritage Biography Prize of $20,000.
The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a sweeping reorganization of its passenger-car and truck manufacturing operations.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Vice President Humphrey ended his exhausting and often disheartening quest for the Presidency today with a triumphal lunch-hour motorcade through downtown Los Angeles and a final television appeal.
An 11-year-old boy who drove a golf ball 150 yards into the knee of a fellow golfer has been held liable for damages, in the same degree as if he were an adult.
One of the most serious problems in the education of the city's Negro schoolchildren is "a lack of educational enrichment in their homes," a conference of local Baptist ministers was told yesterday.

The Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that the 10 per cent Federal income tax surcharge had reduced its net income for the first nine months so that share earnings declined to $2.10 from $2.13 in the like 1967 period.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The wife of a bank executive from Middletown, Conn., choked to death on a piece of steak while eating dinner with her husband. Dead on arrival at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale was Mrs. William Langley, 52 years old, of Middle Haddam, Conn

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Approximately 5,300 United Auto Workers walked out of the Fisher Body Fleetwood plant in Detroit today in a dispute over production standards. Fleetwood makes bodies for all Cadillacs, except the Eldorado, and General Motors was expected to lay off some 2,000 workers on the Cadillac assembly lines.

CLARKSDALE, Miss., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Marshall Bouldin 3d, 44- year-old Clarksdale artist, said today he had been commissioned to do a portrait of Richard M. Nixon's daughters. He was selected by Patricia Hitt, co-chairman of the Nixon-Agnew campaign committee, to paint the portrait of Julie and Tricia Nixon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Voters across the country will take stands tomorrow on a variety of state and local issues ranging from open housing laws to legalized lotteries.

MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Three men wearing black stockings over their heads beat the owner of a restaurant here today, tied up the victim, his wife and an employe, and escaped with an undetermined amount of cash.

LUGANO, Switzerland, Nov. 4 -- The United States team defeated Argentina, 2-1, today with one game adjourned, at the end of the 10th round of the finals of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

The News Election Service, which compiles and reports nationwide election results, protested last night to the clerk of Cook County, Chicago, Edward Barrett, over his refusal to accredit representatives of the service to polling places in his jurisdiction.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 -- Records crumpled in October as the four automobile manufacturers reported 885,358 retail sales of American makes, a record for any month and far ahead of the 664,848 deliveries a year ago.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 4 -- During a night and morning of wild intermittent shooting in and around the capital, King Hussein's security forces rounded up and arrested the members of a commando organization described as being affiliated with the Baathist regime of neighboring Syria.

NOTRE DAME fans may not know it, but Marty Domres of Columbia is the outstanding quarterback in the nation. That is, if you believe all the praise that was heaped on the tall Columbia athlete at the New York football writers' luncheon yesterday.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4, (Reuters) -- The Supreme Soviet parliament has been called into session Dec. 10, the press agency tass reported today. It is expected to approve the budget and economic plan for 1969.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Israel and the United Arab Republic exchanged new charges of aggression in the Security Council today while their Foreign Ministers discussed the shaky prospects for peace talks with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations mediator for the Middle East.
Both principal candidates for Vice President talked during the campaign about how they would hope to cure big city problems, and they revealed sharply conflicting concepts.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau disclosed today that he discussed Vietnam, Nigeria and the Middle East with Secretary General Thant of the United Nations at a two-hour private meeting in New York last Saturday.
The Washington Senators are reportedly about to be sold to two Minnesota businessmen for approximately $10.5-million.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 4 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan today dismissed the possibility of a Soviet attempt to open the Suez Canal by saying that Egypt would veto such a move as long as Israel held the east bank.
CAIRO, Nov. 4 -- President Nasser's creation of a new Peoples Defense Force will bring dangers, as well as advantages, to his beleaguered regime, in the opinion of many Arab observers here.
WARSAW, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, prevented from travel abroad since he angered the Polish authorities in 1965, left by train today for a visit of a month or so to the Vatican.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Lycoming County commissioners have ruled that Little League Baseball, Inc., is a tax-exempt organization, but must pay real estate levies on property not directly associated with the playing of baseball.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- French and Soviet Communist leaders met today in an attempt to restore Communist unity despite their differences over Czechoslovakia.
ELMIRA, N. Y. (AP) -- Brian Truhn, a 21-year-old Ithaca College senior in his first football season, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage apparently suffered during a game last Saturday.

The election of two new vice presidents of the New York office of Booz, Allen Hamilton, international management consultants, was announced yesterday. They are Hadley C. Ford, associated with the company since 1965; and Francis J. Melly, who joined the organization in 1967.
The United Fruit Company, which has been the target of takeover attempts by several companies in recent months, plans to merge with a highly diversified industrial producer, Textron, Inc.

The State Division of Human Rights announced yesterday that the wages of a Yonkers landlord had been garnisheed following his refusal to pay compensatory damages to a Negro woman against whom he discriminated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Europe and the Far East will receive live television coverage of United States election results totaling almost 40 hours, the Communications Satellite Corporation said today.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, said today that if he were Vice-President and seriously opposed a position of his President on a national issue, he would have "no other ethical choice than to resign."
TOKYO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Philippines' flyweight champion, Erbito Salavarria, fought to a draw with Japan's top-ranking flyweight, Yoshiaki Matsumoto, in a 10-round bout today.

IT is apparent, after only six home games, that Ranger fans in Madison Square Garden will be seeing two distinct types of play. The kind they have seen most thus far has not been satisfying, although the results have been.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 4 -- The first day of renewed talks on Rhodesian independence with British negotiators here today produced no sign of progress toward breaking the deadlock.
The city is closing its Operation Hippie Free Store, which has been open since June at 14 Cooper Square to aid what the store director called "voluntary dropouts from society."

A brief free-for-all broke out at the Grace Line terminal at Port Newark yesterday, bringing the first violence to the four-day-old wildcat strike of longshoremen. The stoppages have made idle one-third of the shipping in the port of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization began selling bookplates today to raise funds to combat world illiteracy. The actress Myrna Loy launched the $100,000 drive by making the first purchase.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Army reported today that through suggestion from within the service over the lest 25 years it had "netted more than half a billion dollars in measurable benefits." The Army said its suggestion program last year produced a net savings of $64-million.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin today received Ambassador Nguyen Tho Tian of North Vietnam and had a "warm and friendly talk" with him, it was officially announced.

One of the most bizarre and hotly contested Presidential election campaigns of the century comes to an end today, with public opinion polls suggesting that the Republican candidate, Richard M. Nixon, and the Democrat, Vice President Humphrey, might run a virtual dead heat in the popular voting.
Two newlyweds going off on a honeymoon to St. Thomas and a busy executive hurrying to a luncheon date were among the first passengers yesterday to use Manhattan's newest heliport.

SINGAPORE, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A shipping consortium is being formed in Singapore that will cut by about 25 per cent the freight rate being charged by the lines of the Far East Freight Conference on Singapore and Malaysian exports.

FULLERTON, Calif., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Fresco Thompson, the general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball club, was reported in serious condition tonight at St. Jude's Hospital after suffering a relapse following surgery for a pancreas ailment.

SAIGON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- United States reconnaissance pilots ranging over North Vietnam have detected numerous military truck convoys moving toward South Vietnam since the bombing halt began last Friday, military sources said today.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The Swedish Hockey Federation, faced with a threatened strike by their national team, today reduced suspensions imposed on four players after a brawling match against Canada here last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- If you're one of those people who remember clearly that Harry S. Truman won his upset victory in 1948 without carrying New York State, forget it while you're watching this year's election returns.

Political organizations and candidates, in search of a Senate seat, 43 electoral votes and other election prizes, took to the airways and the sound waves in New York yesterday, in final appeals to undecided voters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- United States officials said today that the National Liberation Front, in its statement yesterday, underlined what apparently is the primary Communist objective at the Paris talks -- overthrow of the Saigon Government and the creation of a regime friendly, to North Vietnam.
THE all-patterned room that erupted as a fad in the late fifties and settled down to play a dominant role in decorating in the present decade, now appears destined to last well into the seventies.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- All over Europe, it seems, people are busy dancing George Balanchine's ballets. New York can be proud of its adopted citizen. On my way from London, where they were dancing "Apollo," to Berlin where a new production of "Ballet Imperial'' is imminent, I not only took in "La Valse" in Amsterdam but here in Paris the other night saw the Vienna State Ballet dance "Serenade" and "Four Temperaments."

The retirement of Dr. Harry A. LaBurt, director of Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens since 1943, was announced yesterday. Dr. LaBurt will continue as a consultant. Dr. Irwin M. Greenberg, deputy director of Bronx State Hospital, is to be appointed director of Creedmoor.

The appointment of Richard M. Bressler as vice president and treasurer of American Airlines, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Bressler formerly was manager of corporate financing of the General Electric Company.
PRINCETON, Nov. 4 -- Princeton University's faculty voted overwhelmingly tonight to approve a report urging coeducation.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 4 -- In and out of trouble since he squandered his wealthy family's fortune at the gaming tables as a young man, the Hungarian Communist novelist Tibor Dery, at the age of 74, is once again the subject of scandal.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The 30th annual standardbred sale opened today with 123 horses selling for $309,200, an average of $2,513 a head. The total and the average set opening-day records.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Tennis with anyone, including a Negro, appears to be on the way on Washington's country club circuit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Justice Department announced today that it had won its first suit to enforce provisions of the new Federal Clean Air Act.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Robert Lee Carr, 25 years old, one of the nation's 10 most wanted fugitives, was arrested today by Federal agents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced. Carr and Michael Lynn Clark, 20, who also was arrested, escaped from the county jail in Sunbury, Pa., on Sept. 16.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. J., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Authorities canvassed neighborhoods across a five-county region in southern New Jersey today seeking information on 13 apples with razor blades embedded in them that were handed out to Halloween "trick-or-treaters."

SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Tony Conigliaro, attempting to make a comeback as a pitcher after his career as an outfielder was ended when he was struck on the head by a pitched ball, hurled three innings for the Boston Red Sox farm team in an instructional league game today and was charged with a 3-0 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies.

HARTFORD, Nov. 4 -- A teachers strike went into its second day today, but the Board of Education said it was less effective than on Friday, when it began.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- After an uneasy spell at the National Theater, Sir John Gielgud has returned in magnificent form to the West End in the part of a die-hard headmaster entangled in a subversive end-of-term charade.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Finnish Premier Mauno Koivisto, was host to Soviet officials at a luncheon here today as he concluded a twoweek vacation in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Candidates for political office, from President to dog-catcher, will have spent between $250-million and $300-million by the time this year's campaign bills are paid.

GIL Hodges has quit smoking, climbing stairs, watching the Late Show and gaining weight. But, at the age of 44. just six weeks to the day since he suffered a heart attack, he has not quit managing the New York Mets -- and doesn't think he will.
Election Day facts for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

HOPEWELL, Va., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Missy, a two-and-one-half-year-old German shepherd, whelped 17 puppies today, the largest litter on record for a German shepherd, according to the American Kennel Club. The purebred puppies were all alive, but Missy's owners were scouting the area for other female German shepherds to help nurse the puppies.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 4 -- South Korean troops killed 11 North Korean infiltrators in incidents Friday and yesterday, the Counterespionage Operations Command announced today. Four South Koreans were killed and one was wounded.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The police went on special election alert today after fires swept two polling places, a terrorist bomb damaged a Texaco pipeline, a business location was razed by a mysterious fire and 80 guns and hundreds of rounds of ammunition were reported stolen from a sporting goods store.

A fact - finding committee made up of officials of all the broadcasting unions will meet at 11 A.M. tomorrow to discuss the week-long strike of staff musicians against the three major television networks.

QENA, United Arab Republic Nov. 1 -- Slashing the air with a switch, a soldier chased off a gang of laughing urchins while their turbaned elders peered gloomily through the twilight at what had been Qena's pride.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Although Mr. Meany said the article disclosed "new and vitally important" facts, the Chamber of Commerce has been holding labor seminars around the nation for the last year, in which it openly advocated sweeping changes in the nation's labor laws.
