DONGHA, South Vietnam, Nov. 3 -- Six American marines, clad in camouflage uniforms, their faces smeared with matching grease paint, slipped from a helicopter near here and disappeared into the surrounding undergrowth at 11:30 A.M.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An explosive charge rocked the occupied west bank town of Hebron today, killing an Arab boy and wounding two other Arabs, the army said. The charge was planted outside the sacred cave of the Machpelah.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 4 (AP) A Navy court of inquiry will reconvene this week, probably on Wednesday, to reopen its investigation into the loss of the nuclear submarine Scorpion and her 99-man crew. The court is expected to examine photographs of the Scorpion's wreckage, which was found in more than 10,000 feet of water, 400 miles southwest of the Azores by the oceanographic research ship Mizar last week.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The manager of the Toronto travel agency that unwittingly helped James Earl Ray get a Canadian passport, is facing prosecution for violation of affidavit procedure, the House of Commons was told today.

A 46-year-old heir to a textile fortune obtained an annulment in court here yesterday after testifying that he was drunk for 10 months before he realized he had married a 52-year-old former telephone operator.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 5 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu alluded frequently to future peace negotiations by the South Vietnamese Government as he urged the nation last night to '"maintain our friendship" with the United States."

ATLANTA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- More than 250 Negroes are seeking political offices in 11 Southern states -- primarily in Alabama and Mississippi -- in tomorrow's election, according to the Southern Regional Council.

CAIRO, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian Industry Minister, Dr. Aziz Sidky, met engineering experts from about 50 Western companies today to discuss the financing of Egypt's proposed $60-million oil pipeline bypassing the blocked Suez Canal. Work on the pipeline from the Gulf of Suez to the Mediterranean may begin early next year and the pipeline may be operating before the end of 1970.
In eight years time, computers have joined campaign promises and conventions as a unique but pertinent part of political Americana.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- In the waning moments of his campaign, Vice President Humphrey got his chance to debate Richard M. Nixon -- if only for a moment, only on one issue and only from separate network television studios 12 miles apart.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The four top-seeded men professionals in the South American open tennis championships reached the fourth round today with easy victories over Argentine opponents.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- George Meany urged union members today to vote for Vice President Humphrey and avert "a big-business plot to destroy the labor movement."
THE team to represent North America in the 1969 world championship in Brazil will be a strong one and a young one, with only one player over the age of 40.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- A six-member delegation of the National Liberation Front received a shouting, flag-waving welcome from sympathizers here today as it arrived to take part in the expanded negotiations on Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Two paper-bag manufacturers were named today in a civil anti-trust suit filed by the Justice Department.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 4 -- More than 1.2 million Connecticut residents are expected to vote tomorrow in an election that most political observers have predicted will be close.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The first United States postage stamp to honor the memory of an Indian chief was issued here today following ceremonies at the National Portrait Gallery. The six-cent stamp shows the head of Chief Joseph, leader of the Nez Perces tribe in Oregon.

THE slight young man in the python jacket planted himself defiantly in front of a wall of Robert Indiana's "Love" and, with a slightly malevolent grin, demanded, "Photograph me here. It symbolizes everything about the way I haven't been treated in America." The unloved young man was the designer Ossie Clark, enfant terrible of British fashion and, at age 26, one of the most talked-about talents in the phantasmagoric world of clothes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Without mentioning his name, South Vietnam's observer at the United Nations accused Vice President Humphrey today of publicly insulting the Saigon Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Manufacturing inventories rose far less in September than in August while new orders boomed, the Commerce Department reported today.

Ron Swoboda, outfielder for the New York Mets, left New York by plane Monday for San Francisco en route to Vietnam to tour American military installations with three other major league baseball players.
Stock prices closed slightly lower on balance yesterday after a late recovery had trimmed losses posted in earlier trading.

Fifty-four high school students trooped into the Ugolino room of the Metropolitan Museum of Art behind Miss Blythe Bohnen yesterday and settled down on the marble floor. Following her instruction to "look for the main movement, the gesture." they began sketching Canova's white marble statue, "Perseus Holding the Head of Medusa."
The question arose yesterday whether the first National Horse Show at the new Madison Square Garden would also be the last.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Fourteen teachers at the L'Ouveture Elementary School remained away from their jobs today because of what they called "emotional duress" following the stabbing of a substitute teacher at the school last week.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Hungarian officials and citizens laid wreaths at the graves of the "martyrs" of the 1956 revolt today, the government press agency M.T.I. reported. Today was the 12th anniversary of the Soviet repression of that uprising.

Dr. Karl Menninger, the psychiatrist and author, has won the international service-award of the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry "for his significant role in relating psychiatry and religion, social issues, industrial problems and the law."

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 4 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors today unwillingly approved a year-end appropriation of $6.4-million to cover an anticipated deficit in the county's authorized welfare budget of almost $60-million.
SAVAGE SLEEP. By Millen Brand. 465 pages. Crown. $6.95.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Billy Casper, professional golf's top money winner this year, said today that the newly formed breakaway pro golf organization would play in only two tournaments on the Professional Golfers' Association tour next year.
Steel production declined last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was the first drop since the week ended Sept. 28.
BERLIN, Nov. 4 -- Led by radical leftist students protesting a disbarment hearing for a lawyer who has defended them, about 500 youths battled the West Berlin police today.
RICHMOND, Nov. 4 -- Virginians in 41 locatlities will decide tomorrow whether mixed alcoholic drinks may be sold legally within their boundaries.

The Metropolitan Opera will give a nonsubscription performance of Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" on New Year's Eve. The cast will include Roberta Peters, George Shirley, Frank Guarrera, Fernando Corena and Jerome Hines.

Tucker Frederickson continues to be in disfavor with Al Sherman, the coach of the Giants. Because Frederickson seems to generate violent emotions a number of fans were asking about him yesterday at the Allied Chemical luncheon in the Americana for which an embarrassed Frederickson played host and even on the telephone.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- American medical schools are being asked to make sweeping changes in the way they educate physicians for tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- In his final appeal to the nation, Richard M. Nixon declared today that the election of "new men" with "fresh ideas" was necessary if the nation was to avert what he called a "diplomatic disaster" at the Paris talks on Vietnam.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Communist guerrillas killed three Thai villagers and wounded four persons, including a government official, last week, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today. He said the guerrillas terrorized villages near the Laotian border.

SEATTLE, Nov. 4 -- A decision of profound interest to the new Seattle club and all major league baseball, concerning the site of a proposed domed stadium here, is due Nov. 15. And the repercussions may be startling.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, suggested today that West Germany was using the bombing-halt development in Vietnam "to shift the conflict situation from Asia to Europe."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The Vietnamese-language daily newspaper Dong Nai has been suspended for three days for printing a photograph of President Ho Chi Minh of North Vietnam, a South Vietnamese Government spokesman said today.
The National Horse Show, which bears a striking resemblance to an elderly matron who has trimmed down to svelte proportions, starts an eight-day run in Madison Square Garden today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Efforts to save West Driefontein -- one of the world's richest gold mines -- from complete flooding were set back today when water gushed into a previously unaffected shaft.

The election of Andrew C. Britton to the board of directors of Philip Morris, Inc., diversified tobacco company, was announced yesterday. He has been vice president of the corporation since 1957 and last year was named senior vice president for operations for tobacco and gum in the country.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 4 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland wound up his election campaign today by accusing Chicago Democrats of playing rough and Ho Chi Minh of playing politics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Prices for mortgages continued to drift downward, with a corresponding rise in yields, at the latest Federal National Mortgage Association "auction," the agency disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

The bond market will decline if Hubert H. Humphrey wins the election today. It may rise if Richard Nixon is elected, but the gain won't be large. If the decision is thrown into the House of Representatives, prices could drop sharply.

The top price for the Wednesday and Saturday matinees of "Fiddler on the Roof," now in its fifth year, will go up on April 14. The highest price on Wednesday will be $6.25 instead of $5.80; on Saturday $7.50 compared to the present $6.10.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The prospect that the House of Representatives may be required to elect the next President was brought closer to reality today as major political polls indicated a popular and electoral vote "too close to call."
ATHENS, Nov. 4 -- A special military tribunal today opened the trial of 15 Greeks accused of participating in an attempt to kill Premier George Papadopoulos Aug. 13.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Parker MacDonald, experienced wing, will be player-coach of the Memphis South Stars, the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The nation's railroads requested fast action today on proposed freight-rate increases ranging from three to 10 per cent. They said an interim three per cent increase last June wasn't enough.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon's campaign treasurers turned in a sheaf of finance reports today, nine days after the deadline set by law. They denied Democratic charges that they were trying to hide a "record-breaking rate of spending."

Louis H. Bean, an economist and political analyst, who was one of the very few to predict President Harry S. Truman's 1948 triumph, said last night Vice President Humphrey would defeat Richard M. Nixon in both the popular vote and the electorial college.

BIELLA, Italy, Nov. 4 -- The death toll from floods and landslides near this town in the Alpine foothills in northwestern Italy officially stood at 91 today and it was feared that the total would go higher.

John O'Keefe, former vice president of Myers-Fisher, public relations agency, has been appointed director of public information of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, it was announced yesterday by William Schuman, center president.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Newsmen and printers went on a 24-hour general strike today to protest the closing down of two daily newspapers, two radio stations and a bimonthly newsmagazine by the military Government.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- Pravda, the newspaper of the Soviet Communist party, accused some Czechoslovak party leaders today of helping those who threaten the party's existence by creating a right-wing faction. This is the Soviet term for the party's liberal wing.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Cass (Mama) Elliott, who was recuperating from tonsilitis, admitted to Beverly Glen Hospital today for treatment of hepatitis. Her illness was expected to force the postponement of a Carnegie Hall appearance scheduled for Dec. 28 until mid-January.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Britain's gold and dollar reserves dropped by 4.83-million ($11.6-million) in October after large repayments on foreign loans, the Treasury announced today.
Because of the teachers strike, many parents here have tried to have their children admitted to schools on Long Island, but few have succeeded.

MIAMI, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A self-styled "black nationalist freedom fighter" hijacked to Havana today a National Airlines jet flying from Houston to Miami with 65 persons aboard. The plane was returned eight hours later with only its crew.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Sunday night before election the big trucks back up to the Consolidated Campaign Warehouse here and, in the dark, begin unloading and storing all the gear used in the Presidential campaign.

DIXVILLE NOTCH, N. H., Tuesday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- This little mountain hamlet near the Canadian border in northern New Hampshire was one of the first in the nation to vote today, and for the first time the Presidential vote was split.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Pentagon today listed the names of the following servicemen as having been killed in Vietnam:

Twenty-seven members of the New York National Guard who are accused of leaving or trying to leave their bivouac area on a weekend training exercise may be punished at the company level, it was decided last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The oldest members of both the Senate and House are among at least 38 Congressmen who will not be back for the session starting Jan. 3.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 4 (UPI) -Dr. Hampton Kent Snell, transportation professor at the University of Texas, shot a 19-year-old youth today, who, Dr. Snell said, kicked in his front door. The youth, David Walton, was listed in fair condition. The professor said teenagers had harassed him for some time and vandalized his mountain top home. "They have attempted to park in my driveway, and I just turn on the lights."

Directors of the Essex Wire Corporation announced yesterday a special stockholders meeting for Dec. 18 in the company's Fort Wayne, Ind., headquarters to vote on a recapitalization plan and a change in the company's name to Essex International, Inc.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Defense spending would rise sharply under a Nixon administration, according to figures released here yesterday by the Republican candidate's staff.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The mother of John Chrestman, University of California, Los Angeles center, who suffered a neck injury in the U.C.L.A. Tennessee game Saturday, said today her son was showing improvement.

IT'S no secret: Continental Can Company is on the acquisition trail. And, what's more, the world's largest packaging company has a quarter of a billion dollars in the kitty that it would like to put to work.

Stan Getz is a deceptively casual musician. When he steps up on the bandstand in the Rainbow Grill, slinging his tenor saxophone into position as he walks, his manner seems uterly offhand. His first few notes have an equally random sound, as though he were making up his mind what to play.

ATLANTA, Nov. 4 -- Using virtually the same speech he began with more than a year ago, former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama ended his third-party Presidential campaign here today with a familiar forecast of victory.
BRASILIA, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth II and her entourage sailed south along the Brazilian coast to Rio de Janerio today for an official welcome and a 24-hour visit in this capital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- Hollywood, which completely ignored the New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, was very much in evidence at the 12th San Francisco International Film Festival that closed last night at Masonic Auditorium.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The harness horses will swing into action in six nonbetting races here at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow morning. There also will be the regular night program -- this one with the usual betting -- starting at 8 o'clock.
SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay said today that he would resume bombing of North Vietnam immediately "if I were in control."
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie flew from Maine to California today to participate with Vice President Humphrey in a downtown ticker tape parade and on a national telethon.

No matter who is elected President today -- if anybody is -- the year may not prove to have been a total loss. Nobody is wildly enthusiastic about any of the candidates, and some have started asking themselves whether what we have is really worse than what we're going to get.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Mrs. Roberta B. Knowlton, Democratic candidate for Mayor, said today that her plan for the Board of Education envisioned the appointment of four new members, but not to represent the interests of the Fourth Ward only.

CONNECTICUT hunters have two new public areas in which to test their skills this season: The Guilford permit tract, with the Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game and the Guilford Sportsmen's Association, Inc., as its co-sponsors, and the West Thompson flood control area.

OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's official holdings of gold and United States dollars were down slightly at the end of October compared to the end of September, the Federal Department of Finance announced today.

CAMP LAMSON, South Vietnam, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- A senior South Vietnamese general said today he believed President Johnson ordered a halt to the bombing of North Vietnam to help Vice President Humphrey win the United States Presidential election.

Leonard Bernstein will be the piano accompanist for Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, the German baritone, in a program of songs by Gustav Mahler on Friday evening at Philharmonic Hall. The recital will benefit the United States Committee for UNICEF (United Nations Children's Fund).

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A Federal appeals court ruled today that evidence against Leon Bearden, who was accused of attempting to hijack a plane to Cuba, was so ever-whelming the legal error cited in his appeal was "harmless beyond reasonable doubt."
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A Republican candidate for the Missouri House of Representatives was arrested and charged with creating a public disturbance by using abusive language in a police station.
Entries for the Robert H. Bishop 3d playwriting contest will be received until Nov. 30 at the American National Theater and Academy, 245 West 52d Street. Prizes of $2,000, $700 and $300 are offered.
Two former officials of Yale Express System Inc., now bankrupt, were convicted last night in Federal Court on charges of false statements about the company's financial condition in 1963 and 1964.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Colgate University said today that a committee of seven students planned to establish a $100,000 scholarship fund in tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The scholarships are to be awarded annually, beginning next September, to qualified Negro students who are in financial need.
ONE THING about being Mrs. Pancake America is that you have to put up with a lot of wisecracks. And guffaws. And having people call your husband "Mr. Flapjack."

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., in the midst of a talent search for a new chief executive officer by the time of its annual meeting next month, announced yesterday a 33 per cent decline in earnings for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31.
LUGANO, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- The United States and Yugoslav teams drew, 2-2, today as the Soviet Union clinched a victory in the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell Trophy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- French and Soviet Communist leaders today ended two days of talks aimed at reconciling the two parties despite their differences over the invasion of Czechoslovakia. There was no indication of the results.

Overseas National Airways announced yesterday it has placed an order for three jet aircraft with McDonnell Douglas Corporation at a cost of $24-million. One of the aircraft ordered is a 250-passenger DC-8-G3 and the other two are DC-9-30 planes.

WASHINGTON, Nov 5 (UPI) -- Ambassador Bui Diem of South Vietnam joined Ambassador Agha Hilali of Pakistan and 115 foreign correspondents today on a Government-sponsored tour of Washington voting places.

HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., Nov. 5 (UPI) -- A 25-year-old tugboat worker drowned here today when he slipped, hit his head on the side of the boat and fell into the Hudson River. The police said John Leiching, of Port Ewen, N. Y., lost his footing as he was helping to unhook the tugboat from a pier at 4:45 A.M.

WILMINGTON, Del., Wednesday, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Republicans swept to victory in Delaware yesterday, with Richard M. Nixon winning the state's three electoral votes and Russell W. Peterson, the Republican challenger, defeating Democratic Gov. Charles L. Terry Jr.
There is at least one steam-shipman around who believes that ship-passenger business is picking up and has a future.

TOYAMA, Japan, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals hammered five home runs but needed a ninth-inning rally, highlighted by Orlando Cepeda's second homer of the game, to beat the Yomiuri Giants, 9-7 today.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 5 -- Premier Levi Eshkol said in Parliament today that the Jordan River would be Israel's security frontier in any peace settlement with Jordan.

The Five Towns Music and Art Foundation will hold its annual art exhibition preview and dinner dance on Saturday night in the Lawrence (L.I.) Village Park House. The show will be open to the public from Sunday through Thursday from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

WILMINGTON. Del.. Nov. 5 (UPI) -- The voters on Bread and Cheese Island did not go to the polls today. The polls came to them.

The Allegheny Power System, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first nine months. Operating revenues were $174,202,762, against $162,373,992 in the 1967 period.

The Alexander Hamilton Life Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it earned $251,987, or 8 cents a share, in the nine months ended Sept. 30, compared with a net operating loss of $496,007 in the same period last year.
A rehabilitation counselor in the Commission for the Blind is charging that the State agency, devoted to opening opportunities for the blind, discriminated against him because of his own blindness.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Wednesday, Nov. 6 -- The Popular Democratic party, once allpowerful in Puerto Rico, has apparently lost the governorship.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 5 (Reuters) -- United Nations command and North Korean armistice officers had their longest meeting today since the end of the Korean war in 1953.

HILLSIDE, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Chester A. Meisky, 81 years old, of 593 Conant Street, who has not missed voting in a general election in 60 years, was first in line when the polls opened here today in Hillside High School.

The staff director of a non-sectarian committee appointed last April to study the educational system in the Archdiocese of New York has resigned because his proposal for a fiscal study of the system was rejected.

The box-office sale of tickets for the incoming "Dear World" at the Mark Hellinger Theater -- from 8 A.M. to midnight on Monday and yesterday -- brought in an estimated total of $53,960. Normally Broadway box offices operate from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.

Australia, never before represented in a National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, made its debut a rousing one last night by winning one event and placing third and fourth in another in the featured international jumping.

LOS ANGELES, Wednesday, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, who could vote for his running mate, but not for himself, flew to the side of George C. Wallace in Alabama yesterday to await the voters' response to their third party Presidential campaign.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The United States freighter Empire State, with 45 crewmen and a cargo of military equipment for South Vietnam, was drifting in high seas east of Tokyo today after its boiler exploded and fatally injured one American, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency reported.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 5 -- An AWOL soldier from Fort Dix, N. J., was shot and killed last night by the police during an alleged burglary.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Allegheny Airlines said today it had adopted a new in-flight food service system that keeps steaks hot and ice cream frozen for several hours, ready for instant serving.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- The Danes' favorite election candidate was Richard M. Nixon, according to a Gallup Poll published yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 5 -- Wisconsin's voters retained a Democratic Senator and a Republican Governor in today's election.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Richard M. Nixon won Kentucky's nine electoral votes today as George C. Wallace drained support from Hubert H. Humphrey in the Presidential race.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 6 -- Following are excerpts from a transcript of remarks by Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew in the ballroom of the Statler-Hilton Inn shortly after Richard M. Nixon made his victory statement this morning:
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 6 -Richard M. Nixon carried Nassau County yesterday by 50,108 votes, far short of the plurality expected by the Republicans.

Richard M. Nixon, bringing to a climax an amazing personal comeback, has been elected President of the United States eight years after he first sought the office. A Republican, he joins Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, those patristic heroes of the Democratic party, as one of only three men in the nation's history to be elected to the White House after having been defeated in a previous try for the Presidency.

RICHMOND, Nov. 6 -- Charles Munch, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra from 1949 to 1962, was found dead this morning in the John Marshall Hotel. The 77-year-old conductor was to have led the Orchestre de Paris here tonight.

Election returns for the New York State Legislature confirm what appears to have been a nationwide voting pattern -- the big cities remain largely Democratic while the suburbs swing increasingly over to the Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- "It is a day for visiting the sick and burying the dead," Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today. "It's gray everywhere -- all over the land."
IN the September-October issue of Audubon magazine, Hal Borland, a naturalist, dashes cold water on those who would make longrange weather prophets of insects, birds and animals.
Richard Michael Clurman, chief of correspondents of the Time-Life News Service, has been named board chairman of the New York City Center of Music and Drama, Inc.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Southern voters took some traditional threads more than a century old, wove in a lot of new material with an altogether different look and produced a rather psychedelic political fabric in yesterday's elections.
The stock market greeted the election of Richard M. Nixon as President with an initial burst of buying enthusiasm yesterday, then tapered off to close with a moderate gain.

The frustrating election upon us grows out of our electoral system, which has become woefully unresponsive to today's political realities. These realities dictate that fundamental structural changes be made in that system to guarantee the continuance of a working democracy.

OSWALD JACOBY of Dallas, nonplaying captain of the 1969 North American world championship team, captured from Charles Goren in 1962 the title of the man with more master-points than anyone else. Jacoby now plays less than he used to, and he has relinquished his title.

The biggest money package ever offered by the New York Shipping Association -- one that calls for an hourly increase of $1.01 in employe wages and benefits over a three-year period -- was rejected yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association.
The Midwest Stock Exchange is exploring the possibility of permitting qualified employes of its member firms to sell life insurance to the public.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Francois Duvalier has sent congratulations to former President Eisenhower and President-elect Richard M. Nixon on Mr. Nixon's victory. The Haitian ruler said he hoped Mr. Nixon would base his program on General Eisenhower's "constructive policy."

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission for authority to use 70 additional satellite circuits for handling telephone calls between this country and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- State Department officials read news reports of Prince Sihanouk's remarks on the prisoners with interest, but said there would be no comment until a formal message from Cambodia was received.

With scattered returns from Tuesday's balloting still being tabulated, Richard Nixon is credited with 302 electoral votes, only 32 more than the 270 majority essential for election. He narrowly won in Illinois and in Missouri, which may still swing back to the Humphrey column after the counting of absentee ballots and the checking of returns.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The Mecklenburg County police were trying to find the husband of a young New York bride found shot to death near here yesterday.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange turned sharply lower yesterday on lack of buying interest and profit taking. Some leading issues closed with marked declines.
Henry Fried, a 68-year-old millionaire contractor, pleaded not guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to charges of bribing former City Water Commissioner James L. Marcus.

Experiments and calculations at the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., have indicated that it should be possible to discover a new, long-lived element closely related to platinum, but far heavier.
The body of a former convict was found in the back seat of a rented convertible at 130 Bleecker Street, near West Broadway, at 2 P.M. yesterday by the police. He had been shot three times.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Gay Brewer Jr. of Dallas, the 1967 United States Masters champion, fired a six-under-par 67 today for the opening-round lead in the Wills Masters golf tournament.
Don Trull, one of the hottest quarterbacks in the American Football League, is coming to Shea Stadium in two days, and the Jets are responsible for having given him his chance in the first place.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- Defense Minister Andrei A. Grechko declared in a speech from the top of Lenin's Tomb in Red Square today that the Soviet armed forces did not seek to capture foreign territory but instead sought to safeguard peace, socialism, freedom and independence.

ONLY one new bidding system has gained widespread acceptance in the last decade. Howard Schenken's Big Club, introduced in 1963, is now firmly established in the tournament world, and his new book on his system, published last week by Simon Schuster at $4.95, contains a number of significant advances.
Striking stokers who operate the Sanitation Department's 11 refuse incinerators defied a temporary restraining order yesterday and continued their work stoppage into the second day.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 7 -- There is a growing awareness here that if the Vietnam talks in Paris make progress they will amost inevitably lead to a new round of peace negotiations on Laos.

TOKYO, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Japan Air Lines, Ltd., may consider purchasing giant Russian jetliners if the Soviet Union agrees to let Japanese planes fly over Siberia on the Tokyo-to-Moscow route, a spokesman for the Japanese line said today.
More than an inch of rain fell on the city yesterday and the downpour was not expected to end until early today.
Stanley Steingut, the Democratic leader of Brooklyn, indicated yesterday that he intended to fight, if necessary, for election as minority leader of the Assembly.
The Armco Steel Corporation, in line with its policy of expanding outside the steel pipe field, said yesterday that it had begun a program to capitalize on the growing market for plastic pipe.

Abe Lastfogel, president of the William Morris Agency says: "For many years my association with U.S.O. has made me increasingly conscious of the effectiveness of this wonderful, necessary and evolving organization.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 7 -There was guarded hope among Arabs today that President-elect Richard M. Nixon would bring about a change in United States policy in the Middle East.
"We have weathered some strong efforts from our adversaries on Herald Square," declared Leonard Blackman, president of E. J. Korvette, the other day.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 7 -- European businessmen and bankers expect President-elect Richard M. Nixon to adopt tough anti-inflationary policies in efforts to improve the American balance of payments.
The Plaza's Grand Ballroom will be the setting next Friday for the 15th annual Chrysanthemum Ball, a benefit for the charitable projects of the Greek Archdiocese Cathedral Philoptochos Society.
THERE is a remarkable amount of candor and camaraderie existing between Columbia's youthful football coach, Frank Navarro, and his players.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- The Beatles are planning to give three concerts in London next month -- their first in two years.
HONOLULU, Nov. 7 (AP) -- George Archer, who said all his bounces were "lucky ones," posted an eight-under-par 64 in the $125,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament today for a one-stroke lead.
Several of the country's largest retail chains yesterday reported substantial increases in sales for October, helped to some degree by an extra shopping day compared to the year-ago month.
PARKE, DAVIS CO., a perennial take-over candidate, was back in the showcase yesterday as two massive blocks put the stock at the top of the active list.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday in quiet trading.
Each year about this time, Victor Hugo-Vidal, rider and horsemanship instructor extraordinary, undergoes a metamorphosis and becomes the velvet-voice announcer of the National Horse Show.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 7 -- To relieve overcrowding at the Union County Jail here, Jerome Epstein, chairman of the Union County Board of Freeholders Jail Study Committee, said today he would seek to rent cells at the new Bergen County Jail in Hackensack. Mr. Epstein said he would arrange a meeting with Bergen officials to discuss the plan, which would house the prisoners on a per-diem cost basis.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A Government report estimates that more than half of the drugs most widely used by the elderly are still under patent and therefore free from competitive pricing.

One hundred agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night for an alleged draft evader and members of a crowd who had freed him from custody by attacking four F.B.I. men.
Two more heart transplant patients, including the only one in Russia, have died and the latest patient of Dr. Michael E. deBakey of Houston showed signs of rejecting his new heart yesterday.

The Weatherhead Company, a Cleveland-based producer of fluid transmission devices, made its first public offering of common stock yesterday as private shareholders disposed of 1.15 million shares valued at $28,175,000.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 7 -- Young Charlie Pasarell sat, stony-faced and motionless, in the catacombs of the Caribe Hilton Hotel last night while an artist painted his portrait. It was a canvas also depicting Arthur Ashe who, now finished, had earlier sat for hours while the painter worked.
PNOMPNEH, Cambodia, Nov. 7 -- A spokesman for the Na tional Liberation Front said today that the Saigon Government's refusal to participate in the Paris talks was "blackmail."

DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Employes of the Detroit International Bridge Company walked off their jobs at the Ambassador Bridge today in a contract dispute. The workers are employed as toll collectors, traffic guards, maintenance men and janitors.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Bulls ended a four-game National Basketball Association losing streak tonight by scoring a 120-105 victory over the Seattle Supersonics.

WARSAW, Nov. 7 -- The Polish Communist regime today celebrated the 50th anniversary of the recovery of Polish independence in ceremonies playing down the role of Marshal Jozef Pilsudski, whom many Poles regard as the founder of modern Poland.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 7 -- Nevele Pride, the 1967 harness horse of the year, who undoubtedly will receive the same award this season, has been retired for the season, his owners, Louis Resnick of Ellenville, N. Y., and Nevele Acres, said tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Red Berenson tied a National Hockey League record tonight by scoring six goals as the St. Louis Blues smashed the Philadelphia Flyers, 8-0.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Milos Milosevic shot and killed the fifth wife of Mickey Rooney, the actor, then committed suicide, Jan. 30, 1966, according to the police.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 -- The South Vietnamese military command said today that 107 enemy soldiers had been killed in a two-day battle in the rice paddies of the Mekong Delta.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Final figures of the recent All-American Quarter Horse Congress sale here disclosed today that it would be the highest average sale in the nation this year.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, who won re-election to a third term Tuesday by his biggest margin ever, said yesterday that the victory had vindicated his rejection of the Conservative party and its ideology.
The election of W. Graham Claytor Jr. as a director of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York was announced yesterday. He is president of the Southern Railway System.
DENVER, Colo., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Denver choked off a bid by the surging Dallas Chaparrals tonight to score a 98-95 victory, the Rockets' second in two nights after dropping their first four outings.

SUCEAVA, Rumania -- While Nicolae Ceaucescu, Rumania's resolute little boss, is philosophically an orthodox Communist, he doesn't believe in any ideological pope. He insists there is no one in any "Socialist" capital from Moscow on down who has the right to say "Le Marxisme c'est moi."

"Does the military junta know what it wants?" This blandly ironic question put by Caretas, a national weekly magazine, and similar criticisms of the ruling Peruvian military in the Lima press, is apparently more than the thin-skinned generals can bear.

Fairleigh Dickinson Jr., president and chairman of the board of Becton, Dickinson Co., a medical-surgical equipment concern, has been elected to the board of the New Jersey Television Broadcasting Corporation.

GLOBE, Ariz., Nov. 7 (AP) -- One man leaped to safety but two were carried 1,000 feet to their deaths today when a car left a scenic highway and fell into the Salt River. Johnny Reed of Springdale, Ark., survived the accident.
"Maggie Flynn," "Golden Rainbow" and "We Bombed in New Haven" have added Sunday matinees to their schedule, beginning Nov. 17, Nov. 24 and Dec. 1, respectively.
The election of William F. Rueger as senior vice president was announced yesterday by Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. Sylvania is a subsidiary of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation.

More than 500,000 subscribers over 65 who are covered by the Greater New York Blue Cross and Blue Shield Senior Care program will be notified by mail in next few days that their benefits are being increased and their rates reduced.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The trustees of California Institute of Technology have approved in principle a proposal to admit women as undergraduates, the school announced today. The proposal calls for enrollment of women as freshmen and for upper class transfers on the basis of the same academic qualifications that apply to men.

National Aid to Visually Handicapped, a volunteer organization, yesterday presented two New York City hospitals with libraries containing 200 large-type books for the use of patients with visual difficulties.

THE signal success of American athletes in the Olympic Games at Mexico City is now a historic fait accompli. Savor it while you can. There may not be another. SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Two North Korean patrol boats seized four South Korean fishing boats and their eight fishermen today in the Sea of Japan 100 miles east of Seoul, the police reported. They said the seizure had occurred in the same area where 42 fishermen aboard five boats were abducted Oct. 30.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The featured address in Red Square today was considered by observers here as the mildest in years, omitting the usual direct attacks on the United States and not even mentioning Vietnam.
A member of the City Planning Commission charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had "no real housing to policy" and "no commitment to planning."

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The Downeast Yankee, a campaign plane no longer buoyed by Vice-Presidential hopes, today carried Senator Edmund S. Muskie and member of his family back to Washington.
The recovery in wheat and corn prices continued yesterday with gains of more than a cent a bushel for nearby deliveries.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- A murder mystery that started five weeks ago in the deceptive low-key fashion of a police novel by Georges Simenon has developed into a classic French "affaire," bringing to light seamy aspects of society and spreading an air of scandal.
Interest rates, despite all the talk this week about a Nixon bull market for fixed-income securities, moved upward yesterday.
An exhibition of paintings, graphics and sculpture by 30 contemporary black artists will travel across the country after its closing at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts on Nov. 24.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- John Freeman, Ambassador-designate to the United States said today he had changed his once-critical views of Richard M. Nixon.

ROME, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Several thousand anti - Vietnam war marchers clashed with the police today following a rally led by former Premier Ferrucio Parri, leader of the Italian underground in World War II. The police broke up the march.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A search for a new way to pick a President will be given high priority in the 91st Congress.

BERLIN, Nov. 7 -- A 29-year-old woman hit Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger in the left eye shortly before noon today at the closing session of his Christian Democratic Union's national congress in West Berlin.

Joseph E. Giaquinto has been elected to the new post of vice president in charge of operations of A.B.C.-TV, a division of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., it was announced yesterday. He is a veteran of 25 years with A.B.C.

Sir Patrick Dean, the British Ambassador to the United States, told American businessmen yesterday that last November's devaluation of the pound sterling was showing results and that he was "guardedly optimistic" about his country's economy.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A national expansion program that includes the immediate addition of 25 hotels and inns and 100 compact restaurants is planned by the Cleveland-based Stouffer Restaurant and Inn Division of Litton Industries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The Defense Department issued today a draft call of 26,800 for January, the highest quota for any month since last May.
Mayor Lindsay told the city's landlords yesterday that they must adopt a "more enlightened and far-sighted policy on rent increases."
ROCHESTER, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Eastman Kodak Company said today it had granted broadened benefits for 70,000 employes in the United States, including 45,000 in this city.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The President of the General Assembly, Emilio Arenales, who underwent brain surgery Oct. 22, returned to preside at today's meeting, looking fit, smiling broadly and promising to return gradually to his full schedule of duties.
The Coast Guard cutter Absecon yesterday gave up its search for 25 seamen who abandoned the crippled Norwegian tanker Etnefjell in rough North Atlantic waters last Thursday.

Colin Davis has come up with something new in the way of visual orchestra-conductor relationships for the New York Philharmonic concerts he is conducting this weekend at Philharmonic Hall. Ordinarily, players sit and conductor stand, but for Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3, Mr. Davis sits and the violinists and violists stand.

THERE is a new book called "Seven Days to Sunday -- Crisis Week with the New York Football Giants," by Eliot Asinof (Simon Schuster). It is a good book so applicable to the moment that the vast family of Giant fans by reading it would come to understand better the herit age and character of this team plus the personality of Al Sherman.
Favorites took the first four races at rain-whipped Aqueduct yesterday, but even Dominick (Tiger) Pinto knew the prosperity couldn't last.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Nov. 7 (AP) -- About 70 students employed in two Northern Michigan University student dining halls staged a wildcat strike last night to support demands for higher wages. DETROIT, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Alex Delvecchio scored twice tonight to lead the surging Detroit Red Wings to a 5-2 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

PRAGUE, Nov. 7 -- Anti-Soviet demonstrators fought the Czechoslovak police in Prague all afternoon today and into the night as crowds burned at least 10 Soviet flags and attacked a Soviet Army jeep.

TOKYO, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Three Japanese fishing boats and 14 crewmen were captured by the Soviet Union in northern Pacific waters in the last 10 days, the Foreign Ministry said today.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The John F. Kennedy Memorial at Runnymede, damaged by a bomb last month, will be repaired at a cost of $1,200. Trustees of the memorial meeting here today authorized the work.
ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Regents scholarship and qualification test has been rescheduled for Nov. 20 for high school students in New York City, the State Education Department announced today.
"Dames at Sea," previously scheduled to open Dec. 8 at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, has been postponed to Dec. 15. The musical is a spoof of the Busby Berkeley films of the nineteen-thirties.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- An amateur musician today paid the equivalent of $52,800 for a Stradivarius violin at Sotheby's. The auctioneers said the price was a world record.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 -- Japan's business and financial community appeared somewhat glum today at the prospect of having Richard M. Nixon as President of the United States.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- The New York Rangers went up to San Francisco this morning, where they will play Oakland at the Cow Palace tomorrow night, leaving behind them a Los Angeles hockey community dazzled by their nonperformance in a 2-0 loss to the Kings last night.

ALTHOUGH Charles Lamb was clearly wrong in suggesting that Shakespeare's "King Lear" is unactable, the play is infernally difficult to stage with anything more than fitful success. The National Labor Relations Board has brought an action against the National Maritime Union based on an unfair labor practices complaint filed by a seaman who has been an active dissident in the union.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 7 -- Investigators from the British Columbia Securities Commission and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police are sifting through a truckload of documents seized in a raid on the headquarters of 46 interrelated financial, trust and mortgage companies.
A student organization at Columbia College has exercised its new authority over dormitory regulations by eliminating restrictions on hours when students may have women visitors in their rooms.
The Board of Estimate yesterday postponed a decision on allowing cable television to originate programs at least until its Dec. 5 meeting.

ATLANTA, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Theater Atlanta, currently presenting the satirical musical "Red, White and Maddox," won a second reprieve today in its struggle to stave off eviction.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 7 -- George Thomson, Britain's representative, held the second private meeting of the current talks with Prime Minister Smith this afternoon. PARRIS ISLAND, S.C., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A 22-year-old Marine drill instructor was given a dishonorable discharge and a two-year-prison sentence today after he pleaded guilty to mistreating Marine recruits.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Aides of President Johnson and President-elect Richard M. Nixon met today at the White House for the first time since Election Day and began laying plans for an orderly transfer of power on Jan. 20.
CLOSTER, N.J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The local election in the Borough of Closter has produced two mayors instead of one.

The American Professional Golfers, a group of touring pros who split with the Professional Golfers' Association last August, announced yesterday the signing of contracts for 19 tourneys for 1969, with purses totaling $2,305,000.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon lengthened his popular vote margin over Vice President Humphrey yesterday as statisticians continued to labor over the election results.
