WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Johnson received the annual White House Thanksgiving turkey today, a 40-pound bird from North Carolina. The turkey was sent by the National Turkey Federation and the Poultry and Egg National Board, which has donated a bird for the last 23 years.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Burton B. Roberts, a Democrat, who was elected District Attorney of the Bronx on Tuesday, was appointed to that post today by Governor Rockefeller so that he can serve until his term officially begins in January.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- South Vietnam has protested to the International Control Commission over the shelling of the town of mytho despite the bombing halt over North Vietnam ordered by President Johnson.
DESHLER, Ohio, Nov. 7 -- Vicki Lynne Cole, 13 years old, remembers the day Richard M. Nixon came to this village in the flat Ohio farm country and spoke from the back of his campaign train.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- A group named the Ad Hoc Committee to Bring War Atrocities Home announced today that a 3-month-old puppy will be burned with napalm on Vietnam Day at the University of Cincinnati.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Pat Hogan won the feature pace today at Freehold Raceway. Owned by Anthony O. Bruno of Margate, Fla., and driven by Robert Schilling, the winner crossed the finish line in 2:11.4 and paid $9.20, $3.60 and $3.60 for $2 across the board.
I. M. Pei, the city planner and architect, has been hired by Columbia University to plan its future growth on Morningside Heights for decades to come.
ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Perry B. Duryea Jr., scheduled to move up next January to the post of Speaker of the State Assembly, conceded today that a state tax increase was likely next year.
WINSLOW HOMER has always seemed to me the most contradictory of important American painters. Half the time he is an artist of strength and sensitivity, half the time he strikes me as an obvious bore.
TOKYO, Nov. 7 -- Student radicals wearing steel helmets were thrown back by massed Tokyo policemen tonight as they attempted to storm the residence of Premier Eisaku Sato.

The New York branch of the Urban Coalition has set up two satellite corporations designed to provide loans and technical assistance to minority-group businessmen in the city's slums, Saul Wallen, its president, said yesterday.

Burling Industries, Inc., said yesterday in Greensboro, N. C., that it had agreed to a Federal Trade Commission order not to acquire additional domestic textile-mill concerns for 10 years without prior F.T.C. approval.
The Board of Estimate yesterday approved the mapping of four acres in the Bronx near the confluence of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers for use as a park site.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Pennsylvania State University, whose Nittany Lions have played to capacity crowds this season, plans to increase the capacity of its football stadium by 2,000 seats.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintains a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.

The National Association of Theatre Owners will honor Abraham Schneider and Leo Jaffe, Board chairman and president, respectively, of Columbia Pictures, at the organization's convention in San Francisco on Monday.
McCann-Erickson has announced the election of Daniel Stern and Laurel Cutler, creative directors, and Edward M. Gallagher, a management officer, as senior vice presidents.

LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A burly man with a pencilled-on mustache allegedly kidnapped the 11-year-old daughter of a bank president today and collected $50,000 ransom without taking the girl out of her parents' home.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Soviet commentators unanimously concluded today that Richard M. Nixon won the United States Presidential election because of a protest vote against the Democratic party.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The response of the United States delegation to the United Nations to the Soviet anniversary was correct but cool.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patricia Lawford has replaced her brother, Senator Robert F. Kennedy, as a trustee of President Kennedy's estate. Mrs. Lawford, former wife of Peter Lawford, the actor, was approved as a trustee by a probate court judge, John V. Mahoney, on Sept. 19.

WHAT happened off stage at last night's performance of "II Barbiere di Siviglia" at the Metropolitan Opera may turn out to be more important than what happened on. For this revival of the Rossini opera, after a three-year absence from the company's repertory, was being videotaped during the performance for possible use by television networks.

BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- John Kenneth Galbraith, a leading member of the Americans for Democratic Action and a professor at Harvard, proposed today that a national primary be held to select Presidential candidates.
Mayor Lindsay was applauded last night as he discussed the school crisis with the congregation of the Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6 -- The 46-year-old chairman of President-elect Richard M. Nixon's successful drive for the farm vote said today that he had not been approached about becoming Secretary of Agriculture but that he regarded the job as an "opportunity."

The annual bazaar for the benefit of Childville, Inc., will be held Monday and Tuesday from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. at Flatbush Terrace, Brooklyn. The sale of clothes, toys, household goods, greeting cards and Christmas decorations will help in the care of emotionally disturbed boys and girls residing at Childville.
The Mobil Oil Company announced plans yesterday to begin drilling in Mid-November the first of two exploratory wells on the North Slope of Alaska on land it holds with the Phillips Petroleum Company.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Michel Debre warned today that danger signals were intensifying in the Middle East just as the prospects for peace in Vietnam were improving.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 7 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon will make no trip to South Vietnam or anywhere else overseas, his associates said today, unless he is asked to do so by President Johnson.

LUGANO, Switzerland, Nov. 7 -- The United States team was upset by East Germany today, 2 1/2-1 1/2, and fell to fourth place after the 13th and final round of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Mrs. Oliver Lazare of the Metropolis Country Club was elected president of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association today at the annual meeting at the Apawamis Club. She succeeded Gail Wild of Greenwich C.C.

An eight-year legal battle with international implications was decided yesterday by Federal Judge Walter R. Mansfield, who held that the East German Zeiss Company had infringed on the United States trademark of the West German Zeiss Company.
Four men, including a former assistant Queens district attorney, were convicted early yesterday by a jury in Federal Court of mail fraud in which businessmen lost $250,000 in a mortgage loan scheme.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The French Communist party and the Kremlin are reported to have accepted the fact that they are in fundamental disagreement over Czechoslovakia but will continue to work closely together for Communist unity.
The consolation of defeat in a Presidential election is that the defeated candidate can finally be set apart from the controversial issues of the campaign and judged for what he is as a human being.

The victory of City Councilman Edward I. Koch in the Seventeenth Congressional District is all the more significant because that district, which includes most of the residential East side, has consistently sent Republicans to Congress ever since Bruce Barton was elected in 1937 to fill the vacancy caused by the death of its last Democratic representative, Theodore G. Peyser.

MISSION, Tex., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Officials at the Southwest Screwworm Eradication Laboratory said today that they had found the first documented case of screwworms in a human being in the United States. A laboratory spokesman said that a 41-year-old Atascosa County woman was admitted to a San Antonio hospital several days ago in a coma-like state and that tests showed she was suffering from screwworms.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The United Arab Republic today rejected Israel's new formula for a settlement of the Middle East refugee problem. The rejection came in a memorandum delivered to Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary.
The Armco Steel Corporation filed suit in New York Federal District Court yesterday seeeking to block the proposed establishment of a foreign trade subzone in New Orleans.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Nov. 7 -- Mayor Paul Amico today said he would appoint a bipartisan committee of town councilmen to investigate legal procedures for seceding from Hudson County and joining Bergen County. Voters in Secaucus, which borders on Bergen County, on Election Day adopted by an 8-to-1 majority a nonbinding referendum calling on the town officials to take steps to separate Secaucus from Hudson County.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 7 -- The probability of a narrow defeat for Senator Wayne Morse mounted today as the count of Oregon's absentee ballots moved slowly forward.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Tomas Koch of Brazil upset Fred Stolle of Australia, 6-3, 6-2, 0-6, 6-3, today and advanced to the semifinals of the International South American tennis championships.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Former Gov. William W. Scranton reaffirmed today that he was not available for any appointment in the Nixon Administration.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A 19-year-old marine, who has refused to eat food for 11 days in the Camp Pendleton brig, has been transferred to the United States Naval Disciplinary Command at Portsmouth, N. H.

As a means of putting a financial squeeze on the city's striking teachers, Mayor Lindsay has ordered the Board of Education to withhold general distribution of semi-monthly salary checks due at the end of last month to 63,000 school system employes.

"What You Didn't Know, Papa," a new satirical comedy by Robert Shulman, a concert pianist, will be presented Tuesday at the Frances Adler Theater, 23 West 73d Street. The next production, opening on Dec. 3, will be "The Triumph of Robert Emmet," a historical drama by Bache McEvers Whitlock, who has oil interests.

LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- The Conservative party retained the House of Commons seat of New Forest, South England, today. Patrick McNair-Wilson won a special election that showed a 14 per cent swing from the ruling Labor party.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu extended an invitation to President-elect Richard M. Nixon tonight to visit South Vietnam to "make an on the spot assessment of the war."

LANSING, Mich., Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Gov. George Romney said today that he will travel to Washington Saturday to celebrate his wife's birthday and to visit former President Dwight D. Eisenhower at Walter Reed Hospital.
The stock market followed a mixed course yesterday, as investors continued to appraise the results of Tuesday's elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson offered transition assistance today to the incoming First Lady, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, volunteering to take her through the White House whenever the Nixons end their vacation.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- The 1,550-ton Greek cargo ship Gerasimos L. capsized in the North Sea tonight and monitored radio reports said that 11 of her 19 crew members had been picked up.

GROSSMONT, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Plans to set a dog afire next Wednesday on the Grossmont Junior College campus to dramatize opposition to the Vietnam war were announced today by Ken Happel, spokesman for the committee, a group affiliated with the Students for a Democratic Society.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Premier Eisaku Sato announced today that he would be a candidate Nov. 27 for a third two-year term as head of the ruling Liberal-Democratic party. Former Foreign Minister Takeo Miki and Shigesaburo Maeo are challenging him.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 -- A student strike marked by small fires and a minor explosion continued today at San Francisco State College.

Laurence Gandar, editor of The Rand Daily Mail of Johannesburg, has with courage and intelligence, and in the face of official harassment and pressure, warned the Nationalist Government of the long-run perils of its apartheid policy and argued brilliantly the case for gradual integration of the black majority in South African society.

ATHENS, Nov. 7 -- There was dancing and singing today in the streets of Gargaliani, a town in southwest Greece that is the ancestral home of Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew -- better known there as Anagnostopoulos.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Morris A. Schapiro, the dealer and underwriter of bank stocks, proposed today a 13 1/2 per cent reduction in the commissions charged on stock transactions.

The resignation of the Rev. H. Carl McCall as deputy administrator for operations of the city's Human Resources Administration, handling antipoverty programs, was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the administration's head.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

Five Negro reporters will discuss the effect of the Presidential election on nonwhites on the WABC-TV series "Like It Is," on Sunday at 4 P.M. Participants will be Nancy Hicks and Thomas A. Johnson of The New York Times, Hugh Wyatt of The New York Daily News, Ed Cumberbatch of Newsweek magazine, and George Barner of The Amsterdam News.
WITH circumnavigation of the world by sailboat becoming more and more commonplace, an around-the-globe sailor needs a gimmick to make a name for himself these days.

As its first major move since taking over Oct. 1, the new high command of "new" Schenley Industries has announced that its ad agency setup will be almost completely changed on Dec. 1. Its house agency, the Kleppner Company, will be disbanded.

The state's Atomic and Space Agency said yesterday that Cornell University was moving to sell its $20-million Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory to private industry even before it has been determined if such an action would be legal.

MADRID, Nov. 7 -- A series of carefully prepared political gestures by the United States and a substantially lowered price demanded by the Spanish have raised hopes of ending the deadlock over renewing United States rights to bases in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- Democratic Congressional leaders promised today to cooperate with Richard M. Nixon when he becomes President, but observers foresaw inevitable partisan collisions between the Democratic 91st Congress and the Republican White House.

Maurice Peress will conduct the benefit performance of "Candide" at 8 P.M. Sunday at Philharmonic Hall. New material for the score has been composed by Leonard Bernstein. Proceeds will go to International Child Health.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Romunda Hanover, consigned by the Hanover Shoe Farms, brought a record price of $115,000 for a standardbred yearling today as the 30th annual four-day standardbred horse sales ended.

SINGAPORE -- In their public pronouncements during the last few months, the Cabinet Ministers of this three-year-old island republic have dwelt incessantly on Singapore's chances for "survival" and "prosperity."
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The New Orleans Buccaneers crushed the Houston Mavericks, 132-91, tonight.
Jack R. Goldberg, the city's Social Services Commissioner, attacked as a "conspiracy" yesterday the "rent revolt" that organized welfare recipients have threatened to start Dec. 1.
NIIGATA, Japan, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals continued their home run barrage -- belting four out of the park today -- and held the Yomiuri Giants to two hits, scoring an 8-1 victory.
The Plaza's Grand Ballroom looked like a garden in Puerto Rico last evening for the Daiquiri Ball, an annual benefit for the Girls Club of New York. Rums of Puerto Rico sponsored the event.

ROME, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The police reported today that the archives office of the Vatican Ecumenical Council had been ransacked overnight. The burglars took a locked cash box, typewriters, recording equipment and other valuables.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- The General Assembly voted today to strengthen sanctions against Rhodesia, extend them to include Portugal and South Africa, and demand that Britain use force to bring down the regime of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $650-million, up 9 per cent from the year-earlier $598-million. Total retail store sales last week were about $6,858,000,000, up 10 per cent from $6,225,000,000.

Lou Russo and Joe Wisotski of the Castle Hill Athletic Club upset Joe Danilczyk and Art Reyer of the Rockaway Handball Club, the defending champions, 21-15, 21-5, yesterday to gain the final of the United States Handball Association one-wall championship at the Brownsville Boys Club.

JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 7 (AP) -- The cashier of Southern Michigan Prison in Jackson has been charged with embezzlement. Charles Shean, 59 years old, of Pleasant Lake, was charged on five counts of embezzlement of funds totaling $5,572.
BOSTON, Nov. 7 -- Democrats in Massachusetts gained such firm control of the state legislature in Tuesday's election that they took away Gov. John A. Volpe's veto power in the Senate.

Even now we are doubtful that the influence of the pollsters on American politics is an entirely healthy one, but the accuracy with which they were able to forecast the outcome of this year's Presidential election strengthens their contention that they have managed to develop a reasonably exact science.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Department of Commerce liberalized in two ways today its regulations on foreign direct investment by American companies.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation reopened a modernized ticket office yesterday and officially began operating its $100-million computer system.
Representative James H. Scheuer, a Reform Democrat in the Bronx, has begun to campaign for the Democratic nomination for mayor.
A union seeking to represent workers at state mental hospitals threatened yesterday to start a series of strikes on Nov. 18.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The French press yesterday confirmed the welcome given by the audience at the Champs-Elysees theater to the Alwyn Nikolais Dance Theater of New York on its first Paris appearance. Tuesday night's applause was warm, friendly and appreciative, but not delirious, and that fairly sums up the critical reaction also.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The "Sunday pint" made new inroads into Wales today.
NEWARK, Nov. 7 -- The trial of Dominick A. Spina, Newark's Police Director, on charges of willful neglect of duty ended today with an order of acquittal by Superior Court Judge Samuel A. Larner.

The Building Trades Employers Association of the City of New York, a private organization, has announced the appointment of Robert J. Cutting as secretary. Mr. Cutting succeeds W. Arthur Riehl, who is retiring after 18 years in that post.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Professionals who provide health care services were accused by the California Justice Department today of cheating the state's Medi-Cal program of $6-million to $8-million a year.
ROME, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI proposed today that a code of behavior for newspaper editors and publishers be adopted to reduce the amount of crime news reported in the world press.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The United States trounced Britain, 59-7, in basketball, but the British forged into a big lead with 12 gold medals today after the third day of the Wheelchair Olympics.
The recent "unmerger" trend intensified yesterday as a number of proposed corporate marriages were terminated abruptly.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7 (UPI) -- The United States Steel Corporation, spurred by rising imports of foreign-made steel, urged its 200,000 employes today to follow a "buy American" policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Association of American Railroads reported that freight traffic, bolstered by a seasonal upsurge in grain loadings, in the week ended Nov. 2 rose to a record 16.2 billion ton-miles, an increase of 9.6 per cent above the comparable week of last year.

MONTREAL, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Bobby Rousseau's third goal of the game early in the third period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a National Hockey League game tonight.

A major store and office building will be erected by the Empire Realty Company on the site of the Howard Johnson's restaurant on Queens Boulevard, between Junction Boulevard and 62d Drive, in Rego Park, Queens.
SAIGON, Friday, Nov. 8 (UPI) North Vietnamese troops shelled two Marine outposts near the demilitarized zone yesterday, American military spokesmen said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7 (AP) -- A resolution to remove the Chinese Nationalists from the United Nations and admit the Chinese Communists in their place was introduced today by 15 countries.
A new class of mammoth tankers, which promises to make the Suez Canal obsolete, has entered service with the arrival of the 312,000-deadweight-ton Universe Ireland at Bantry Bay, Ireland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Private businesses in 50 cities have placed 84,000 "hard-core" unemployed persons, most of them Negroes, in jobs since last spring, President Johnson was told today.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson proposed yesterday that a State Democratic Council be established to develop new party programs and policies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Department of Commerce liberalized in two ways today its regulations on foreign direct investment by American companies.
A new class of mammoth tankers, which promises to make the Suez Canal obsolete, has entered service with the arrival of the 312,000-deadweight-ton Universe Ireland at Bantry Bay, Ireland.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Private businesses in 50 cities have placed 84,000 "hard-core" unemployed persons, most of them Negroes, in jobs since last spring, President Johnson was told today.
Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson proposed yesterday that a State Democratic Council be established to develop new party programs and policies.

Chuck Green, a vaudeville dancer who started out before World War II, offered a nostalgic, enjoyable glimpse of rarely seen tap routines during last night's program at Cooper Union Great Hall, where he was listed as guest artist with Leticia Jay.
The Granite Equipment Leasing Corporation marketed yesterday 80,000 units consisting of five common shares and one warrant and priced at $220. E. F. Hutton Co., Inc., managed the offering.
ATHENS, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Mr. and Mrs. Onassis cruised the Aegean Sea on their yacht Christina today.
In the balloting for top 2-year-old filly, Gardenias are a girl's best friend.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- JoAnn Prentice, Clifford Ann Creed and Candy Phillips shot 37's under difficult conditions on the front nine of the Pharaoh's Country Club course today to tie for the lead in the curtailed first round of the $12,500 Corpus Christi Civitan open.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 8 -- The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community said today that the trade balance of the six member states "has of late shown a distinct tendency to deteriorate."

ALBANY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Traffic accidents took 254 lives in New York State during September, 41 fewer than in the same month last year. The State Motor Vehicle Department reported, however, that the year's death toll of 2,215 through September was ahead of last year's rate of 2,085.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 8 -- A Federal grand jury has refused to indict nine unidentified highway patrolmen in the slaying of three Negro students last Feb. 8 in Orangeburg.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The levels of the Great Lakes surrounding Michigan will fall from one to three inches in the coming month, the United States Army Corps of Engineers said today. The drops will be a a result of a normal season fluctuation, the weekly report said.
OPA-LOCKA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Governor Agnew, accompanied by his wife, flew into the Opa-Locka Airport tonight. They left immediately by car for Key Biscayne.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday arrested Peter C. Wong of Hong Kong in connection with a $200,000 bill-of- lading swindle in California. According to the F. B. I., a San Francisco Federal grand jury indicted Mr. Wong Wednesday on 14 counts of forging 14 bills of lading for shipments of merchandise purportedly bought in the Orient, but in actuality never made.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 8 -- In the lovely old State House where General George Washington resigned his commission to the Continental Congress on Dec. 23, 1783, Spiro T. Agnew made ready today to surrender his commission as Governor to take on the duties of Vice President of the United States.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- "I am not a man of the past," says Jean Monnet. "It is difficult for me to talk about my life; I am concerned with where I am going, not with where I have been."

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Baskets by Jimmy Walker and Dave Bing, with less than two minutes to play in overtime, enabled the Detroit Pistons to defeat the San Francisco Warriors, 122-118, tonight in a National Basketball Association contest.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan refused today to grant Louisiana's request for the extradition of Edgar Eugene Bradley to face charges that he had helped plot the assassination of President Kennedy.

In walking from Grand Central Terminal to his office at 300 Park Avenue South each day, Albert Shanker has not found in the last two weeks the outstretched hands of Negroes and Puerto Ricans that he says were evident in the earlier days of the teachers' strike.
THE HAGUE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart of Britain called today for a European summit conference to discuss ways of making joint decisions on foreign policy and defense.
LAKELAND, Fla., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The Second District Court of Appeals here upheld today the conviction of Dr. Carl Coppolino in the 1965 poisoning death of his first wife.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 8 -- Alain C. Enthoven, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis, has retracted what he described as an error he made on the strategic implications of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintains a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.
TORQUAY, Australia, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia moved into the final of the Torquay lawn tennis championship today with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis.
"In the desert a little bit of water is very, very nice."
COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Long Island Ducks exploded for five goals in the second period and three in the third tonight to rout the Syracuse Blazers, 8-1, in an Eastern Hockey League game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today that among those killed in recent action in Vietnam was Sgt. 1st Cl. John J. Zimulis of Brooklyn, N. Y. He was in the Army.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- House Speaker John W. McCormack interprets the 1968 Congressional election results as a mandate to continue the policies of Democratic Congresses.

SYDNEY, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Peter Townsend of Britain had birdies on three of the last four holes today and carded a course record eight-under-par 65 in the Wills Master golf tournament. He held a three-stroke lead at the halfway point.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 8 (Reuters -- Jean Rey, president of the Common Market's Executive Commission, today called again for the admission of Britain and three other candidates, Denmark, Norway and Ireland. He said there should be an end to the community's outdated veto system.
A wildcat strike of about 40 workers of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company in Southampton, L. I., spread to the company's main office at 67 Broad Street yesterday.

By any standard one could apply, the concert at Philharmonic Hall last night was a major musical event. Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau and Leonard Bernstein appeared together to present a program of songs by Mahler, and you can hardly get more major than that.

Crocker Nevin, president and chief executive officer of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, was elected yesterday to the board of directors of its parent holding company, Marine Midland Banks, Inc., the company announced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Before he leaves office early next year, Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, will probably recommend major Federal construction aid programs for school districts that are trying to desegregate.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania has announced that Andrew Heiskell, chairman of Time Inc., will receive the Wharton School Alumni Society's Gold Medal Award of Merit. The medal is awarded annually "for distinguished leadership in the promotion of public understanding of business and personal contribution to the progress of American business."
The American Stock Exchange turned in its strongest performance in almost three months yesterday as the list made a broad advance on moderate trading.
Dr. Kurt R. Schmeller became the youngest college president in the city yesterday when, at 31 years of age, he was inaugurated as the third president of the Queensborough Community College.
College football will present its version of the split "double-header" today as the season reaches the point-of-no-return stage.
An emergency 2,000-man sanitation force has been ordered to work tomorrow to remove the backlog of garbage and trash piling up as a result of a three-day strike by incinerator stokers.

Sponsors of the Willoughby House Settlement, which serves the Fort Greene area of Brooklyn, will benefit from their 36th annual luncheon and card party Thursday in the Philharmonic Cafe at Lincoln Center.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8 -- Sir Ivor, the 3-year-old who will carry the silks of Raymond Guest in the $150,000 Washington D. C. International, remains the strong choice to take the mile-and-a-half turf event on Monday.
LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A nationwide police search began today for a runaway 18-year-old youth after it was learned that a cancerous tumor on his left hand must be treated immediately.

A training program of the Brotherhood of Marine Officers and the United Fruit Company in which 12 high school graduates spent two years as apprentice engineers aboard United Fruit ships has had its first graduate, Dennis Sullivan, who recently passed the examination for third assistant engineer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Johnson accepted today the resignations of Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler and Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Bandits with shotguns ambushed two armed guards of a check-cashing service today in the stairwell of a factory, killing one and critically wounding the other. The Bandits fled with at least $30,000 in cash.

Buddy Rich took his band into the psychedelic world of Fillmore East last night and found a home. Mr. Rich's was the first traditionally oriented big band that has appeared at the Second Avenue rock haven. Sandwiched between a relatively new New York group, The Children of God, and the celebrated Steppenwolf from San Francisco, Mr. Rich's band drew cheers, whistles and so much applause and enthusiastic shouting that he was forced into an encore.
BUFFALO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- School is so full of misery you can write a book. So the eighth-grade class at Public School 52 wrote one.

In a story on capital spending yesterday, it was erroneously stated that an earlier estimate of 1969 expenditures by Lionel D. Edie Co., Inc., indicated a rise of about 6 per cent. The Edie estimate on the gain from 1968 to 1969, as published on Sept. 22, was "about 7 per cent" and was based on contemplated expenditures next year of $69.1-billion, compared with $64.4-billion in 1968.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation yesterday joined several other producers in cutting the price of hot-rolled carbon sheet by $25 a ton, effective last Monday.

BARTOW, Fla., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- John J. Sweet, a former Boston bookmaker, was found guilty today of first-degree murder in the death of a citrus millionaire, Charles Von Maxcy, and sentenced to life in prison. A recommendation of mercy from the jury saved Sweet from the death penalty.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following procedures were had yesterday:

THE career of the English sculptor Anthony Caro constitutes one of the most interesting -- because one of the most paradoxical -- episodes in the art history of the nineteen-sixties. Mr. Caro has been the central figure in the development of current English sculpture.

Premieres of "Sweet Eros" and "Witness," a double bill, and "Yes Yes, No No" have been postponed. The former, which was to have opened Nov. 19, has been set back to Nov. 21 at the Gramercy Arts. "Yes Yes, No No" has been switched from Dec. 18 to Dec. 23 at the Astor Place Theater.
The Metropolitan Opera will give the season's first performance of Bellini's "La Sonnambula," with Joan Sutherland as Anuna, on Monday, Dec. 2, the start of the 12th week of the Met season.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 8 -- The army was called in and a dusk-to-dawn curfew was imposed today in Rawalpindi, the interim capital of Pakistan, following two days of widespread rioting by students in which one student was killed.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Xuan Thuy North Vietnam's chief negotiator, said tonight that Hanoi could not accept South Vietnam's demand for merging the North Vietnamese and National Liberation Front delegations at the expanded Vietnam talks here.
A spokesman for 20th Century-Fox confirmed yesterday that Joseph Strick had been released as director of "Justine," the movie version of Lawrence Durrell's "Alexandria Quartet."

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Sixty admirers of the late Adm. Richard E. Byrd set out today on a $26-day around-the-world journey that will take them over both poles in a memorial gesture to the Polar explorer.

SWANQUARTER, N. C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The sheriff of Hyde County, C. J. Cahoon, said tear gas was used today to get Negro demonstrators out of the Welfare Department offices in this eastern North Carolina community.

NEWARK, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Two 3-year-old boys were burned to death early today when a fire engulfed their second - floor apartment at 71 16th Avenue, in Newark's Central Ward. The victims were identified as Steve Charles and Edward Donaldson, believed to be related.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Paul Robert Ferguson, 22 years old, pleaded not guilty yesterday at his arraignment on a charge of murdering Ramon Novarro. the movies' old-time matinee idol. Municipal Judge James B. Di Giuseppe ordered him jailed without bond and set a preliminary hearing for Nov. 15.

MANDALAY, Burma -- The Burmese Kings believed they were fulfilling a prophecy of the Buddha when they built their last capital here. Lord Buddha had picked the site, they thought, because it was "the center of the universe.

STAVANGER, Norway, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The bodies of two crewmen from a capsized Greek freighter were taken from the stormy sea off southwest Norway tonight. Their deaths brought to four the number of known casualties when the 1,550-ton Gerasimos-L foundered. Three seamen are still missing. Fourteen others were rescued, but two died later.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 8 -- President Chung Hee Park said today that South Korean troops would not withdraw from South Vietnam until after North Vietnamese forces had left the South and peace had been completely restored there.

Ninety-one judges -- fifty justices of the Supreme Court, a Surrogate for Kings County, and forty Civil Court judges -- were elected Tuesday by the voters of New York City. It is safe to say that not one voter in 100 had any personal knowledge of the ability or character of the long list of individuals for whom he so blindly voted.
Ernie Koy was going home yesterday, so he selected his outfit with special care: brown slacks, white shirt, green tie, green socks. . . .
JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 -- Two Israeli border policemen were sentenced today to life imprisonment for the murder last year of two Arab workmen in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River.
The new president of a West Side synagogue proposed last night that Reform Judaism change its name to "Contemporary" Judaism.
MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The season's first snow fell here today.
ATLANTA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Lou Hudson's 29-points paced the Atlanta Hawks to a 114-101 National Basketball Association victory over the San Diego Rockets tonight.

The Fairchild Hiller Corporation announced yesterday it had been awarded a contract approximating $175-million for the manufacture of the wing control surfaces of the Boeing 747 jetliner. The contract covers 201 aircraft and it runs through 1971.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- The police scuffled today with hundreds of pupils chanting revolutionary songs in a protest outside a high school here while elsewhere in France students staged scattered strikes, sit-ins and other demonstrations.

An attempt by Mayor Lindsay to get the teachers' union to call off its strike in return for the right to bring about the closing of any city school where the safety or security of teachers is endangered has fallen through.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- A high-ranking Orthodox churchman said today that the former Mrs. John F. Kennedy and Aristotle S. Onassis were partners in a valid marriage and were to be regarded "not as sinners but as Christian spouses deserving of all due respect."

GILBERT AND SULLIVAN and the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company are so entwined in the public mind that to criticize the company is taken in some quarters as an indication that the critic doesn't actually care all that much for the composers.

STEEL issues, which enjoyed fleeting popularity recently, are still taking a licking in the wake of a $25 a ton trim -- 22 per cent -- in the price of hot-rolled steel, which Bethlehem announced on Monday.
"MISS MARTIN fell down in hysterics,/ And there she did wriggle and shake./ While every man swore he was poisoned/ By eating Miss Foggerty's cake."*

The Hempstead Bank of Hempstead, L. I., and, the Mantinecock Bank of Locust Valley, L. I., announced yesterday that their directors had agreed in principle on a merger, subject to approval of state and Federal banking authorities.

JULIE NIXON may have had the most original reason for purchasing a do-it-yourself crewelwork kit showing the official or great seal of the United States during a visit to Dallas early last month, but she wasn't the first nor the last to buy the kit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- High United States officials appraised cautiously today President Thieu's proposal that South Vietnam take the leading allied role in the Paris talks.

STAMFORD, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The 70-year-old owner of a small drug store here was beaten to death today after a holdup that netted three assailants an undetermined amount of money. The victim, Alfred Ferrante, was found stuffed into a telephone booth in the Clarke's Hill Pharmacy. Three men were seen fleeing from the store about 10:55 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The National Ballet of Washington offered an unusual and vigorous new program of American dance tonight. The main attraction was a revival of Doris Humphrey's "The Shakers," a modern-dance work being given for the first time by a classic ballet company.
Three major lumber associations reported an increase of 8.6 per cent in the production for the week ended Nov. 2, compared with the level in the corresponding 1967 week.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 8 -- Gov. Harold Hughes saw his 9,734-vote lead over state Senator David Stanley dwindle today to 5,665 in his race for United States Senator.

The Plaza's grand ballroom went Hawaiian last evening for the Fan Ball. Flowers for the decor -- 15,000 miniature orchids donated by Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Lindsey -- arrived by plane from Hawaii in the morning.

WNBC-TV (Channel 4) will present a daily program on English literature for high school and junior high school students, starting Monday. The program, entitled "School at Home: English Literature," will be televised from 1 to 1:30 P.M. for the duration of the city school strike.

A major reorganization of the Brooklyn-based Eastern Area headquarters of the Military Traffic Management and Terminal Service will be completed this month, according to Col. Edwin B. Owen, area commander of the Army-Navy-Air Force organization.

MOSCOW, Nov. 9 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny congratulated Richard M. Nixon today on his election as President of the United States and expressed the hope that peace would be strengthened by an improvement in Soviet-American relations.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 8 Canadian Press) -- MacMillan Bloedel, Ltd., reported today a 15 per cent drop in net earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30, despite an increase of about 2.5 per cent in gross revenues.
With four major pop concerts around town last night, only half a house turned out at Carnegie Hall for the program by Albert King, Odetta and Paul Butterfield.

Patrolman Robert W. Schmidt, who directed traffic at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue for 22 years before his death last July 31, was honored yesterday with the dedication of a bronze plaque engraved "In Memory of Smitty the Cop."
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The Warsaw Convention limiting airline liability in crashes was declared unconstitutional today by Judge Nicholas J. Bua of the Cook County Circuit Court.
An early winter snowstorm swirled into northern New York yesterday and was blamed for at least one death and scores of power failures.
The Metropolitan Museum began its Young Artists Series last night in Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium with a piano recital by Lois Carole Pachucki.

THE Jets are favored to extend their winning streak to four games, which would tie the club record set in 1965, in their Shea Stadium game tomorrow against the Houston Oilers, but the Giants are an underdog to the Cowboys in Dallas.
ATHENS, Nov. 8 -- The Athens headquarters of Olympic Airways promised tonight to "prosecute ruthlessly" the hijackers of the Boeing.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The abuse of pep pills, tranquilizers and the hallucination-inducing drugs such as LSD has "assumed the proportion of an epidemic" in the advanced nations, Sir Harry Greenfield, chairman of the International Narcotics Control Board, said today.

LOURDES, France, Nov. 8 -- The Roman Catholic Church of France decided today that the use of artificial contraception "is not always guilty." It left it to each believer to decide whether it would be sinful in his or her case.

"The Elevator," a comedy by Nelly Vivas, Colombian playwright, will be presented tonight at Cafe Four, 522 East 12th Street. Performances will be repeated Thursday through Sunday nights through Dec. 15.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A landscape painted by the late Sir Winston Churchill was bought today for $17,640 by Arthur Murray of New York, the former dancing teacher. The picture of four Belgian nuns walking in a garden at Le Beguinage, Bruges, was sent for auction at Christie's by Miss Grace Hamblin, Churchill's former secretary.

Tdo titans of college club football -- Fordham and Manhattan -- will meet today in the Battle of the Bronx. The game will start at 1:30 P.M. at Gaelic Park in Riverdale. Both club teams have won five of six games.

Two women students at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism received scholarship awards last night at the Front Page Dinner Dance of the Newspaper Women's Club of New York, held at the Americana Hotel. The winner of the $1,500 Anne O'Hare McCormick Award was Karen Rothmyer, 25 years old, of New Bedford, Mass. Melinda Vercini, 20, of Trumbull, Conn., received the $300 Mary E. Watts Award.

CAPE KENNEDY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The satellite Pioneer 9 was launched into orbit around the sun today and joined three others in a network to warn of solar radiation storms that could endanger astronauts on the moon.
The rush by the nation's largest banks to diversify through one-bank holding companies turned into a stampede yesterday. These were the developments:
ATHENS, Nov. 8 -- A haggard army deserter told a Greek military tribunal in Athens today that he had attempted to kill Premier George Papadopoulos last Aug. 13 to "free my country from tyranny."
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday the election of Donald K. Ballman as senior vice president. He formerly was vice president for marketing, purchasing and distribution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- President Johnson had breakfast today with Vice President Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie and discussed the future of the Democratic party in light of the defeat by the Republicans.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- University students voted tonight to continue a four - month - old anti - Government strike. A leader of the Student Strike Committee asserted that there would be no further talks with the Government until the students jailed during the strike were released.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The United States asserted today that the United Nations financial crisis was deepening and called on the Soviet Union and France to contribute an amount equal to the funds they have withheld from peace-keeping operations such as the one in the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, former commander of the South Vietnamese I Corps, said today that his country's refusal to participate in four-sided peace talks in Paris resulted from its opposition to "international political maneuvers likely to favor the Communists."

Francis T. P. Plimpton, president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, participated yesterday in the dedication of Plimpton Hall, the new dormitory at Barnard College named for his father, George Arthur Plimpton, a founder of Barnard. The 15-story building, at 121st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, houses 280 students.
WATERLOO: Day of Battle. David Howarth. 239 pages. Atheneum. $7.95.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The impending retirement of Deputy Postmaster General Frederick C. Belen was announced today.

MADRID, Nov. 8 -- Robert F. Wagner, United States Ambassador to Spain and former Mayor of New York City, has sent a note to the city's top labor leader urging him to speed a solution to the teachers' strike.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he thought the closeness of the vote in the Nixon-Humphrey Presidential race reflected "the total exhaustion of 1968."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Miss Gail Hoff, an immunologist for Princeton Laboratories, Inc., at Princeton, N. J., will soon receive a patent for her widely used method of diagnosing infectious mononucleosis, the so-called kissing disease.

DEMOCRACY is beginning to work in fashion. It's not necessary to lunch on peanut butter sandwiches for a year to afford a label that will impress people. Fashion no longer trickles down from the top. It happens at all prices, from modest to sublime.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The women's singles final in the South American Open Tennis Championships was prevented from becoming an all-American test today when Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of Britain ousted Julie Heldman of New York, 6-4, 6-1, in a semi-final match.
The Coast Guard said yesterday that the full air and sea search for survivors of the burned tanker Etnefell continued yesterday and would resume today.
HONOLULU, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Ken Ellsworth, playing in his first professional tournament, posted a five-under-par 67 today and it stood up for the halfway lead at 133 in the $125,000 Hawaiian open.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- A Federal judge imposed sentences ranging from 2 to 3 1/2 years today on the self-styled "Catonsville Nine," a group of Roman Catholics, including two priests, who marched into a local draft board office last spring, removed 378 records from the Selective Service files and burned them with napalm.
THE galleries at Knoedler Co., 14 East 57th Street, have suddenly taken on the air of a pavilion in a princely villa devoted to the indulgence of an 18-century hobby, the collection of small bronzes.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Stevenson Hall, a social and dining facility with open membership, was dedicated by Princeton University today to the late Adlai E. Stevenson, class of 1922, and to principles of fraternal equality.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last Monday's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.

"Claudine," a play by Don Kvares as adapted by Robert Schroeder, will be given a series of performances, starting next Friday, at the Mannhardt Theater Centre, 254 La Guardia Place. The cast will include Renata Mannhardt, David Scott Milton and Carol Gutenberg.
Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., for the 39 weeks ended Sept. 28.

It takes a certain courage to preface a recital of keyboard music by Brahms, Ravel and Bartok with the brooding, emotionally elusive "Klavierstucke" (Op. 11) of Arnold Schoenberg. At her Carnegie Recital Hall concert last night, however, Anne Chamberlain rose to the challenge, assembling the shifting dynamic colors and straying tonal patterns into an impressively unified conception.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Jim Brown, the former professional football star, was arraigned today on an assault charge and a hearing was set for next Friday on a motion to dismiss the case. Mr. Brown, now an actor, is accusd of striking a sheriff's deputy and resisting arrest in an investigation of a fall by a fashion model, Eva Maria de Bohn Chin, at his apartment in West Hollywood on June 9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Further discussions of the two-tiered price system for gold and the purchase of South African gold are simply "not on the agenda" for the forthcoming visit of Secretary of Treasury Henry H. Fowler with key finance ministers of Western Europe, a high Treasury official said today.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- The athletes have departed, but there still is competition here. In progress is the Cultural Olympics, in which the competition is mind to mind instead of body against body.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A Federal judge fined the Plumbing Fixtures Manufacturers Association of Washington, D.C., and five company executives a total of $150,000 yesterday on charges of conspiring to fix prices.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Truck traffic across the Ambassador Bridge linking Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, ceased today as picket lines set up by striking bridge employes on the United States side began to take effect.

STOCKHOLM, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Five young Soviet soldiers, reported to have been shocked by the hostile reception they received in Czechoslovakia after the Aug. 20-21 invasion, are believed to be hiding in Stockholm, the police said today.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers called its members out on strike at Revere Copper and Brass Company plants across the country last night to support new contract demands.

OPULENCE displayed in gold, diamonds and other precious materials from the 13th to the 20th century may be glimpsed in a visit to the benefit exhibition at A la Vieille Russie, dealers in art objects at 781 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Secret Service details protecting the unsuccessful candidates in the Presidential election will be withdrawn by the end of this week, a spokesman said today.
"You know I don't care about the money, Phil," said Mrs. Gertrude Goldberg at Aqueduct yesterday as she congratulated P. G. Johnson. "I just want you to keep your record going."

A boutique full of Christmas gifts, to be open for a week beginning Tuesday, will be called the Ark and will benefit the adoption service of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

YORK, Pa., Nov. 8 (UPI) -- A 177-acre farm five miles south of here may become the first public park in the nation to be named for President-elect Richard M. Nixon. It would be donated by Bob Hoffman, president of the York Barbell Company and seven-time coach of the Olympic weightlifting team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today that "the near brush with catastrophe" in Tuesday's election points up a need to change the Presidential election system.

LISBON, Nov. 8 -- The Cardinal Patriarch of Lisbon has threatened a dissenting parish priest with suspension from his priestly offices if he does not make a public retraction of his controversial views by next week.

Good Sieglindes do not grow on trees, not even trees as formidable as the one in the first act of the Met's Metropolitan Opera's "Die Walkure." Thus the debut of Hildegard Hillebrecht, a German soprano who was suddenly called upon to replace the indisposed Gundula Janowitz, promised to be more than normally interesting.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that there was a "minor" hazard in new IND subway cars because of their sloping ends, which it said could be dangerous for passengers walking from car to car.

The Department of Agriculture yesterday revised downward its estimate of the 1968 cotton crop. Based on conditions at the start of this month, it forecast a crop of 10,912,000 bales, about 159,000 below the month-ago prediction.

BOSTON Nov. 8 (AP) -- Bob Rule, a 6-foot-9-inch second-year man, outplayed Boston's player-coach, Bill Russell, in the second half tonight in leading the Seattle Supersonics to a 114-112 National Basketball Association victory over the Celtics.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov 8 (UPI) -- The New York Rangers visited San Francisco and played the first National Hockey League game in Cow Palace history tonight, defeating the Oakland Seals, 3-2, Friday night.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- The New York Knickerbockers lost a 16-point lead, made up an 11-point deficit, then were beaten on the game-end seesaw tonight as Jerry West made two free throws with three seconds to play to give the Los Angeles Lakers a 102-100 victory.

Doug Hardin, a skinny symphony in red, wearing red shoes, a red shirt, red and white trunks and even a red beard, led Harvard to its second straight team victory in the Heptagonal cross-country championships yesterday.

AMHERST. Mass., Nov. 8 (AP) -- About 150 Negro students marched on the administration building at the University of Massachusetts today to present a list of 21 demands to John Lederle, president of the university.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Harry Anderson, San Jose State College head football coach, announced his resignation last night, effective at the close of the current season.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Following are excerpts from the text of the pastoral note of the French episcopate on the encyclical "Humanae Vitae". The unofficial translation is from a text to be published here tomorrow in the Catholic daily newspaper, La Croix.
CAIRO, Nov. 8 -- Highly-placed informants said today that the Soviet Union has quietly passed word to Cairo that it is ready to defend the Aswan High Dam, if need be, against Israeli attack.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- "Come home, all is forgiven," United Air Lines said in effect today to stewardesses who had protested their dismissal for an offense under the company's former rules: committing matrimony.

GENEVA, Nov. 8 -- The United States pledged an additional $2.5-million today for the Red Cross relief program for Biafra and federal-held territory in Nigeria after a United Nations official warned that a catastrophe was ahead.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Mr. Fowler left today on a five-day trip to reassure European trading partners that the dollar's future was stable.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- John Lennon's wife, Cynthia, was granted a divorce today because of the Beatle's adultery with Yoko Ono, a Japanese artist. The petition was uncontested. Mr. Lennon was reported to be camping on a hospital floor to be near Miss Ono, who is expecting their baby in February and is threatened with a miscarriage.

ROME, Nov. 8 (AP) -- High school and university student unrest swept across Italy today, while labor unions prepared for mass strikes later this month. Most of the student demonstrators requested use of school facilities for debates on how to reform the antiquated school and university structure.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Seventy protesters arrested during a sit-in at Moses Hall on the University of California campus here on Oct. 24 were sentenced today to 10-day prison terms and each was ordered to pay the school $300 to cover damages.
THE SEANCE AND OTHER STORIES. By Isaac Bashevis Singer 276 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $5.95.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Having largely solved its budget problems, the Patent Office has increased its weekly output of patents from 1,000 to 1,250 and hopes to keep it there through next June 30.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- John Arden, reluctant as ever to present his work through orthodox theatrical channels, has staged his latest piece, "The Hero Rises Up," at the Roundhouse, a converted engine-shed belonging to the Centre 42 arts movement.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu put forward a proposal today to end his boycott of the Paris talks on Vietnam by placing the United States and the National Liberation Front, or Vietcong, in subsidiary negotiating roles.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Oueen Elizabeth II arrived here today by air from Sao Paulo on the last part of her 10-day state visit to Brazil. The weather refused to cooperate in the city's efforts to greet the Queen and her husband, Prince Philip.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon's popular vote margin over Vice President Humphrey was reduced yesterday as additional results of the Tuesday election were tabulated.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 8 -- Aides of Richard M. Nixon suggested today that the President -elect would have run up a much larger plurality if the Vietnam bombing halt had not been ordered by President Johnson shortly before the election.

A seaman who has been politically active in opposition to the leadership of his bargaining representative, the National Maritime Union, was described in a National Labor Relations Board hearing yesterday as a troublemaker.

New York City has just made a significant step toward improving its physical future by adopting a modern building code. Despite one serious omission, the new code will be a great advance over the creaky, obsolete one that was enacted in 1897 and received its last major revision more than thirty years ago.

By a narrow margin the voters of Puerto Rico have broken the long dominion of the Popular Democratic party and rebuffed the Commonwealth's greatest statesman, Luis Munoz Marin. In electing Luis A. Ferre Governor on his fourth try, a plurality embraced Mr. Ferre's argument that it was time for a change -- but what kind of change it seeks is by no means clear.

How long will Alexander Dubcek be willing, or able, to remain as the Kremlin's captive surrogate in Prague? This question arises naturally in the wake of such melancholy events as the use by Dubcek's police of clubs and chemicals against the students demonstrating against the demeaning celebration in the Czech capital of the 51st anniversary of the Russian Revolution.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 8 -Representative Robert Packwood clinched his victory over Senator Wayne Morse today as a late trickle of absentee votes made it arithmetically impossible for Mr. Morse to catch up.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- To the sunbathers on the beach in southern France, the sight of the hawk-nosed Englishman constantly peering through his binoculars may have seemed a little unusual.
A gong shattered the pre-dawn silence, and Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Townley dropped to their knees beside their 4-year-old son Brian on the floor of a former gymnasium on Chicago's West Side.

The American Jewish Congress asked Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday to investigate the reasons for the fire bombing of Yeshiva Torah Vodaath and Mesivta, 425 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn, Halloween.

It takes a lot of brass for a group of musicians to bill themselves as "the World's Greatest Jazzband." That is the official name of the 10-man group that has moved into the Riverboat under the joint leadership of Yank Lawson and Bob Haggart, both of whom were stars of Bob Crosby's Orchestra in the 1930's.

"Beautiful Dreamer," a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will be performed by the Poor People's Theater at Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 64th Street on Nov. 22 at 8 P.M. The play, in pantomime, tells the story of the civil rights movement from Montgomery, Ala., to Memphis.

Management of Magnetics, Inc., Butler, Pa., maker of industrial control systems, is taking a new approach in an effort to defeat a tender offer early this week from Hale Brothers Associates, of San Francisco, a privately held investment firm.
HONG KONG, Nov. 8 -- Communist China's official press agency, Hsinhua, commenting on the United States elections, described the Democratic and Republican parties as "jackals of the same lair."

TRENTON, Nov. 8 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes defended Robert J. Burkhardt, the Democratic state chairman, today as recriminations surrounding Vice President Humphrey's narrow election loss in New Jersey continued.

OPA-LOCKA, Fla., Nov. 8 -- In an amiable display of bipartisan unity, President-elect Richard M. Nixon and the man he defeated for the Presidency three days ago, Vice President Humphrey, met here today to exchange assurances of support.
The last time Lee J. Cobb played Shakespeare he was a fledgling actor at the Pasadena Playhouse in California more than 35 years ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey will be entitled to a Government pension of $19,450 when he leaves office Jan. 20.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Bruce Reynolds, the last of the suspects in Britain's great train robbery, was arrested today after a five-year search. The hunt ended early this morning in Torquay, a fashionable resort town on the Devon coast.

Consul General Rehavcan Amir of Israel has presented a medallion to former Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican of New York, in appreciation of his service in promoting good relations between the United States and Israel, it was announced yesterday by the Israeli Consulate here.
DETROIT, Nov. 8 -- The automobile industry objected today to Government proposals that safety information be made available to the public with each new car.

As the Paris peace talks move hesitantly but inexorably toward bargaining on substantive issues, the overriding question no longer is whether there will be a political settlement in Vietnam but whether non-Communist forces as represented by the Government of President Thieu can survive such a settlement.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A man found shot to death was identified today as the Rev. Charles Billups, 41 years old, a former aide to the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- Jeff Fort, a leader of the Blackstone Rangers who is under indictment for contempt of Congress, has been hired as the $9,000-a-year "youth coordinator" for a South Side community organization.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Malcolm Moos, president of the University of Minnesota, said today the school was interested in having Vice President Humphrey as a professor of political science. He said no one had yet talked to the Vice President about his possible interest, Mr. Humphrey taught political science at Macalester College in St. Paul for two years before starting his political career.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- A South Vietnamese general announced today a major expansion of the pacification program in the I Corps area, the five northern provinces stretching from Danang to the demilitarized zone.
Radio station WMCA announced yesterday that it would create an electronic ombudsman to watch over the public interest.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Eldridge Cleaver and five other Black Panthers must stand trial for attempted murder and assault stemming from a gun battle with the Oakland police, despite the contention of the six that the grand jury that indicated them did not represent the Negro community.

SOME bridge hands have a nightmarish quality. The player feels afterward that every move he made was wrong. All the players but dummy had this feeling on the innocent-looking part-score deal shown in the diagram, which was played in the recent International Team Trials in Atlantic City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- The Maritime Administration has wasted money in outfitting vessels reactivated for use in Southeast Asia, the General Accounting Office has told Congress.

A divinity student who said he had "divorced" himself from the Selective Service system even though he was entitled to a deferment went on trial yesterday in Federal Court on charges of refusing to be inducted into the armed forces.

It was ladies' night in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night when young women of the British and American teams gained the first two places.

Today is the big day for prep school football, the day when hundreds of years of tradition are wrapped up in games throughout the East. It's the day when thousands of alumni, young and old, suddenly halt their normal routines and wonder who will win -- Exeter or Andover, Lawrenceville or The Hill, St. Mark's or Groton, Deerfield or Choate and so on throughout the Northeast.
A little bit of Christmas came to the Americana Hotel's Georgian Room last evening with red, green and tinsel lending splash to the Horse Show Ball.

The streets in front of the schools in Ocean Hill-Brownsville are empty now as the scene of the conflict has shifted to other places where officials are meeting in an effort to resolve the present dispute.
PARIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Two Italians demonstrated against the Greek military regime today by hijacking a Greek jetliner half an hour after it left here for Athens and forcing it back to Orly Airport.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 9 -- Waves of United States B-52 Stratofortress bombers struck at strongholds and staging areas yesterday and today in an area near the Cambodian border where the enemy was reported to have massed thousands of troops for a big offensive.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov 8 -- A 2 per cent sales tax was recommended by the County Executives of Nassau and Suffolk today to help finance proposed record budgets for next year totaling almost a half-billion dollars.
The London Stock Exchange staged a recovery yesterday, gaining a major part of Thursday's losses.
Robert Riesner, the 40-year-old president of the J. M. Fields discount-store division of Food Fair, Inc., will become president of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., on Monday.
Sweeping powers to reduce dangerous air pollution, including the halting of all incineration and the elimination of unnecessary automobile traffic, were assumed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 8 -Donald Dell, who can ignore the roulette wheels and dice tables when he saunters through the casinos here, lost the big gamble today.

TOKIO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- North Korea described President-elect Richard M. Nixon today as a "notorious war maniac" who will "go one step farther than the Johnson-Humphrey clique in pursuing vicious and shameless aggression."

TEL AVIV, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Italy's 24 - year - old paralyzed swimmer, Roberto Marson, won three gold medals in men's events at the Wheelchair Olympics today, taking the spotlight away from a Briton who set a world mark in the breast-stroke event.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A fire last night damaged the 14-story Traymore Hotel on the Boardwalk, forcing the evacuation of about 1,000 guests. No injuries were reported. It was controlled shortly after midnight, after burning for two hours. Fire officials said it started in a storage room filled with mattresses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Supreme Court today rejected a bid by Albert Shanker to delay his trial before a judge on charges of criminal contempt for defying a court order to end the strike of New York City school teachers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 9 -- Five persons were wounded last night when enemy shells fell on the city of Cantho in the Mekong Delta in what a United States military communique termed an "indiscriminate attack."
Abandoning the stop-and-go pattern of the first two post-election sessions, the stock market roared into full speed ahead yesterday in a broad, sustained rally in active trading.
