The film, which was shown at the New York, San Francisco and Venice film festivals, is to be released here, in Los Angeles and elsewhere next month.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintain a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.

David Zucker has been elected president of the Metropolitan Region of the United Synagogue of America repre senting 157 Conservative Jewish congregations in this area. Mr. Zucker, founder of Danbar Press, succeeds Dr. Morris Fond.

Chief Justice Earl Warren asserted last night that "one of the most urgent necessities of our time" is to resolve the growing friction between the "daring of youth" and the "mellow practicality" of the more mature.

Francois Couperin was 300 years old yesterday. The event might have passed unnoticed had not Albert Fuller programed a number of the French composer's harpsichord pieces on his concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- John Roland scored from the 1-yard line with 47 seconds left to play today as the St. Louis Cardinals rallied from a 21-0 half-time deficit to tie the Pittsburgh Steelers, 28-28.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Chartchai Chionoi of Thailand retained his world flyweight championship today with a unanimous decision over Bernabe Villacampo of the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- President Johnson attended church today where both he and Richard M. Nixon were defended from the pulpit. Mr. Johnson heard the Rev. George R. Davis tell the congregation at the National City Christian Church that the United States was "serving God's purpose" and that Mr. Johnson could be proud of his "stewardship" to the nation.

The Brooklyn Philharmonia inaugurated its 15th season on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with the most unenterprising program imaginable: Beethoven's "Consecration of the House" Overture, the Bruch G minor Violin Concerto and Tchaikovsky's Fourth Symphony.

Scarpia in Puccini's "Tosca" is such a cleverly written part that it is virtually impossible to go wrong -- a baritone with presence and sufficient vocal weight can always make some sort of effect. Roy Samuelsen made his debut with the New York City Opera in the role yesterday afternoon and created a character that went far beyond these minimal requirements.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 9 -- Some of this country's highest officials are expressing the opinion that Jordan is about to begin a new phase of intensifying military preparations and commando activities.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Mount Holyoke College presented honorary degrees today to Mary V. Gaver, professor in the Graduate School of Library Service at Rutgers; Alma Smith Jacobs, head librarian of the Great Falls, Mont., Public Library since 1954, and Francis Keppel, president and chairman of the board of General Learning Corporation in New York.

The Department of Justice has attacked, as likely to have a "significantly adverse effect on competition," the proposed merger of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, Hartford, and the Connecticut National Bank of Bridgeport.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Minnesota Pipers, the defending American Basketball Association champions, won the fifth game in their last six starts tonight by crushing the New York Nets, 118-96.

OLSO, Norway -- The four Scandinavian countries, prosperous but frustrated by the continuing economic division of Western Europe, are seeking new sources of dynamism in closer cooperation among themselves.

TOKYO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Phil Gagliano hit a homer in the ninth inning today to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 victory over the Yomiuri Giants. The National League champions now have a 9-3 won-lost record in their scheduled 18-game series in Japan.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Plans for a demonstration outside the Washington office of the Secretary of State on Jan. 20 have been announced by the Rev. Paul Lindstrom of the Remember the Pueblo Committee.
St. Francis Prep won the scholastic division of the national scholastic and collegiate canoeing and kayaking championships Saturday at the Sebago Canoe Club in Brooklyn.

PRAGUE, Nov. 10 -- Bitter anti-Soviet demonstrations erupted in Prague today for the second time in four days and heavy Czechoslovak police contingents were needed to assure the safety of Soviet military personnel, including an army song-and-dance group.
GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- International trade will show a "significant improvement" over last year once all the figures are in for 1968, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade predicted today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 10 -- The New Zealand team of Denis Hulme and Bruce McLaren won their second consecutive Canadian-American Challenge Cup here today.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 -- Late last week financial markets were buzzing with rumors that Karl Blessing, chairman of the Bundesbank; Karl Schiller, West German Economics Minister, and Franz Josef Strauss, Finance Minister, were planning a secret meeting in Westphalia to decide on revaluation of the mark.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Authorities said today a dropped cigarette apparently caused a blaze that forced the evacuation of 100 patients at the Cloverbottom Hospital and School last night. The mental patients, some bed-ridden and some in wheelchairs, were evacuated by hospital staff members and volunteers.

The nation's near-miss on an electoral deadlock has made plain the need for Congressional action to rule out more such flirtation with disaster in Presidential elections. Both Senator Bayh of Indiana and Representative Celler of New York plan hearings on electoral reform; democracy will be the gainer if no paralysis of will impedes action by their Congressional colleagues when a reform plan is presented.

PANAMA, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A 25-year-old housewife gave birth to quadruplets, all boys, in Santo Tomas Hospital yesterday, hospital sources said today. The sources said the babies, who ranged in weight from one pound 13 ounces to three pounds one ounce, were in delicate condition.

The sponsors of a plan to transform the area of the Fulton Fish Market into a slice of 19th century New York contend that two skyscraper builders are working to "bust" their project so the builders can put up office buildings there.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The New York Rangers scored twice in the first four minutes of the second period tonight to break a 1-1 tie, then went on to hand the Chicago Black Hawks a 4-2 defeat.
CAIRO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Cairo press expressed the belief today that an alleged plot by three Yemenis to assassinate President-elect Nixon had been fabricated to influence him against the Arabs.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- A thin layer of snow melted into the grass this morning while most of the candidates for tomorrow's Washington D.C. International engaged in light drills as final preparations for the $150,000 invitation event.
WUNSIEDEL, West Germany, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A West German textile merchant has been arrested on suspicion of being a war criminal, the police reported here today.
BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Manuel Santana, one of the world's leading amateur players, won the Spanish tennis championship, defeating Manuel Orantes, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, 6-2, today.

Paul O'Dwyer refused to comment yesterday on suggestions that he consider running for either Mayor or Senator next year because, he said, "all Democrats must give top priority to broadening, unifying and strengthening the party."

Mr. and Mrs. Igor Oistrakh were the performing musicians at Hunter College Assembly Hall on Saturday night. He was the star of the evening, but she did much of the hard work. Mr. Oistrakh is a Soviet violinist, the 37-year-old son of David Oistrakh, one of the greatest violinists in the world.

PNOMPENH, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- The Cambodia Government has protested strongly against alleged United States air raids into Cambodian territory last Wednesday that it said caused the death of three Cambodian civilians.
THE Fowler Dance Group gave a performance at the Kaufmann Concert Hall yesterday afternoon. Idly I wonder why.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 10 -- The $7,500 award of the Estes Kefauver Union of the Free was presented to Clarence K. Streit of Washington last night at a convention of Federal Union, Inc., for his efforts to create a union of the United States and Western Europe.
"Abraham," a 75 - minute color film depicting the Biblical story, was given its first public showing Saturday night at Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens.

SAN JUAN, Nov. 10 -- Although a loser on the court, Ramanathan Krishnan, India's star Davis Cup player, was a winner today, at least in the view of one of his countrymen after the Madras businessman and tennis star was summoned to Presbyterian Hospital here.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- In the tropical green atolls of the Maldive Islands, there will be a parade and festive ceremonies tomorrow when the smallest of the 125 member states of the United Nations shifts from a sultanate to a republic.

Abraham Straus, a division of Federated Department Stores, has announced the appointment of Herbert Solomon as manager of the A. S. store in the Smith Haven Mill, Suffolk County, L. I., and Joseph Vales as manager of the Babylon, L. I., store.
The credit markets are scheduled to handle a slightly below-average volume of new corporate and tax-exempt bond issues this week. Federal agency financing will increase substantially.
GLORIA CONTRERAS seemed too good a choreographer to be committing the errors that marred her dance company's concert Saturday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

PROVOLONE, homemade sausage and salami and imported prosciutto hang in traditional style under a striped canopy behind the counter at the sparkling new Salumeria Sbarro, 1245 Second Avenue (between 65th and 66th Streets).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy led more than 4,000 singing, cheering Roman Catholic laymen today in a demonstration of support for 40 Washington priests disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle because of their dissent to the Papal ban on artificial birth control.

Milovan Djilas, a former Vice President of Yugoslavia who was imprisoned for nine years because of his anti-Communist and anti-Tito writings, has won the Freedom Award, Freedom House announced yesterday.

This account of events between the Paris peace talks' start in May and President Johnson's announcement Oct. 31 of a halt in bombing of North Vietnam was compiled from dispatches by Gene Roberts in Saigon, Hedrick Smith in Paris and Bernard Gwertzman in Washington.

Revlon, Inc., had record sales and operating earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, but profit margins narrowed under the impact of higher costs of doing business and the surcharge tax, the report disclosed over the weekend.

SANA, Yemen, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A Yemeni charged with his two sons in New York with plotting to assassinate President-elect Nixon, was remembered here today as "a man of good manners who cared nothing about politics."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Walt W. Rostow, special aide to President Johnson, discounted today both Saigon's boycott of the Paris talks and the attacks on South Vietnamese cities, conveying a sense of serenity in the Administration about future peace efforts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- It is unlikely there will be any subsequent tremors to the earthquake that shook up residents of 22 states yesterday, according to the Rev. Donald Roll, director of seismological studies at Loyola University.
The election of Mortimer M. Caplin as a director of Thomas J. Deegan Company, Inc., management counsel, was announced over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Presidents of two major higher education associations said today that the effect of the Government's elimination of draft deferments for graduate students had not been nearly as great as expected.
Cordova, Alaska, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The pilot of an Alaska Airlines 727 jetliner collided with a moose yesterday shortly after landing. None of the 31 passengers and six crewmen were injured.

LISBON, Nov. 10 -- Premier Marcelo Caetano of Portugal allowed the leader of the democratic opposition, Mario Soares, to return from exile today.
HONOLULU, Nov. 10 -- (UPI) -- Lee Trevino, the National Open golf champion, overtook George Archer on the final nine holes today and won the $125,000 Hawaiian international open with a total of 272.

CHARLESTOWN, Mass., Nov. 10 -- John T. Gardiner was appointed associate director of the John F. Kennedy Family Service Center, Inc., today. Mr. Gardiner joined the center in 1966 as project director of the summer youth employment and counseling program and later was named program analyst to develop a comprehensive health, education and manpower program for Charlestown.

The prospects for an early agreement to end the teachers' strike appeared to improve as Mayor Lindsay intensified negotiations with top officials of the United Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education.

Rain poured off the yellow fisherman's hat and ankle-length raincoat of Catello Barone yesterday as he emptied a garbage can into a Sanitation Department truck parked on Pierrepont Street near Henry Street in Brooklyn Heights.

A major musician and pianist with the unforgettable name of Alexander Slobodyanik made his New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. He is Russian, blond, in his mid-20's and fully in charge of his instrument as well as what he chooses to play on it.

As a result of favorable Neilsen ratings released Friday, the National Broadcasting Company will retain all but one of its current prime-time television shows in their present time slots, at least through the end of the current season.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 10 -- James Earl Ray dismissed his attorney, Arthur J. Hanes, tonight only 36 hours before he was to come to trial on a charge of murdering the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
An arbitration pane has ruled in favor of the Schine hotel interests in a long dispute over the sale to the Realty Equities Corporation of $75-million worth of Schine properties.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 10 -- A cough confined Gov. Spiro T. Agnew to the Executive Mansion today.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 10 -- If President - elect Richard M. Nixon is called "the boss" in the White House, it will be because of a chic strawberry blonde who for 17 years has been the protective "girl Friday" loyally and reverentially following "the boss," as she calls him, through his political travails and triumphs.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Thirsty residents in three counties of Wales lifted beer mugs in pubs today for the first time they have done so on Sunday in 88 years.

A wintry storm lashed the South with snow and rain yesterday and pointed northeastward up the Appalachian Mountain chain. The Alabama mountains got up to 6 inches of snow.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP) -- More than 500 production workers at the Revere Copper and Brass Company plant returned to work today after ratifying a proposed new contract. The action ended a strike started Thursday night by members of the United Automobile Workers.

Dr. Edwin Etherington, president of Wesleyan University and a former president of the American Stock Exchange, will be guest speaker.

The investigation into the case of three Yemeni Arabs charged with having plotted to assassinate President-elect Richard M. Nixon focused yesterday on tracking down their contacts with other Arabs in the United States and abroad.

CURACAO, Netherlands Antilles, Nov. 11 -- The contribution that a ton of general cargo makes to a port city's economy has increased to $18.64 a ton, the American Association of Port Authorities was told today.

A program to provide the prepayment of most dental costs will be started next spring by Blue Cross and Blue Shield in New York State. A 16-year-old Brooklyn student was arrested yesterday for the fatal shooting of 71-year-old Nathan Appelson during an attempted holdup on Sept. 26 in an elevator at the Bushwick-Hylan Houses. Arrested at his home for the crime was George Anderson of 311 Patchen Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Paul H. Douglas, chairman of the National Commission on Urban Problems, said today that the public was going to have to change what he called its hostility to government-backed housing for poor people.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Policemen with heavy clubs charged a procession of students shouting slogans today in the northern city of Lahore.
The Edward Palmer Chorale from Palm Beach, Fla., which sang at Town Hall last night, has to its credit a warm, full tone. But that's about as far as its credit goes.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Howard Hughes, the billionaire, plans to concentrate on developing property valued at $175-million he has acquired in this gambling center rather than make additional purchases, his aides said today.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange are enjoying another boom year in share volume and profits. Wall Street has continued to increase its sales force but it has been slow in dealing with the unprecedented backlog of paperwork that its salesmen have generated.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -Following is the official White House transcript of remarks of President Johnson and President-elect Richard M. Nixon following their meeting at the White House today:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- William C. Doyle, national commander of the American Legion, says that the transfer of national holidays to uniform Monday observance is a distortion of history in the interest of "the almighty dollar."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A veterans' spokesman accused the Labor Department today of downgrading the Veterans Employment Services in "a slap in the face" to the nation's 27 million war veterans.

Drastic difficulties require drastic countermeasures, so Coach Red Holzman intends to try a drastic remedy for his New York Knickerbockers -- a ball-control game. The Knicks returned home yesterday from an unsuccessful six-game trip with a 5-10 won-lost season record and a four-game losing streak, and it was clearly time to try something.

Warren H. Dickerson has been promoted to vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York. Also appointed were Mrs. Janet C. Gill as assistant secretary and Thomas J. Taylor as assistant treasurer.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 11 -- The police were questioning today a 22-year-old student who fired two pistol shots yesterday during a public meeting in Peshawar, where the speaker was President Mohammad Ayub Khan.
Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello has recommended to Mayor Lindsay that the city and Board of Elections introduce a computer system for drawing election district lines.

ATLANTA, Nov. 11 -- Slowly accumulated election returns from local races throughout the South showed today that in last week's voting Negroes won at least 70 additional offices, including seven new state legislative posts.
President Johnson has approved a Civil Aeronautics Board decision to grant a permit to South African Airways to engage in service between the Republic of South Africa and New York via Rio de Janeiro.

Joseph Fuchs is one of those admirable musicians who always manage to send one away from a concert marveling more at the works played than at the performer's skill. His Carnegie Hall violin recital last night, in which he had Artur Balsam as his similarly talented pianist, put such composers as Bach, Franck and Mozart well in the forefront of our attention, and seldom permitted straying.
MARK PERKINS, a little tailback at Hobart, a little college, put a big number in the college record book last Saturday when he carried the ball 61 times against Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

YORBA LINDA, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- A group of civic leaders will meet Thursday to try to purchase the small white house here that was the birthplace of President-elect Richard M. Nixon to make it a museum. William Hurless Barton, a car dealer, who is a distant relative of Mr. Nixon, today said: "Everybody in town is behind this museum concept and we're getting plenty of support from outside visitors, as well."
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov 11 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth II arrived from Rio de Janeiro today on the second leg of a tour of South America. It was the first state visit of a ruling British monarch to Chile.

Dr. Herrman L. Blumgart of Boston was named recipient yesterday of the first James B. Herrick Award of the American Heart Association. He will receive the award at a dinner at Bal Harbour, Fla., on Nov. 22. The award was named for an early Chicago cardiologist.

Across this busy, churning land, trapped by their own pride, fear and confusion, there are five million Americans whom life is passing by. They are the physically and mentally disabled who are not being rehabilitated.

PERCY FOREMAN, counsel for the defense, climbed to his feet with ostentatious effort and moved his 225 pounds, encased loosely in an expensive dark suit, very slowly to the bench. He stopped at the court recorder's table and filled a paper cup with water.
GENEVA -- In Switzerland, a country internationally known for its banks, the average citizen prefers postal checks and money orders to personal checks for paying his household bills.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -President-elect Richard M. Nixon assured the world today that the Johnson Administration would speak for his Administration as well as its own in foreign affairs during the next two months.

Leaders of the cosmetic and perfume industries will attend a luncheon at the St. Regis Sheraton Roof tomorrow at which Mala Rubinstein will receive the Humanitarian Award of the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital in Denver.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it had launched an unmanned spacecraft, Zond 6, toward the moon.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- Catholic Relief Services, an American agency, predicted today that reserves of starch foods in Biafra would be exhausted by December or January.

Judy Garland has been hospitalized since last Thursday with blood poisoning, her physician disclosed yesterday. The physician, Dr. Harold E. Klinger, said Miss Garland, who is 45 years old, was in "adequate condition" and would remain at LeRoy Hospital, at 40 East 61st Street, for several more days of treatment for her condition, which he said was caused by an ulcer on her heel.
LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 11 -- A missing 18-year-old youth with a malignant tumor on his left hand has been found and returned home after a four-month seach.
Striking incinerator firemen continued to defy a temporary restraining order yesterday as refuse collections were further delayed because of the Veterans Day holiday.
The nation's space agency will announce this morning its plans for Apollo 8 -- and barring an unexpected change of mind, the plan will call for the astronauts to orbit the moon in late December.

THE poverty-stricken white people who live in the barren West Virginia and Kentucky coal-mining areas of Appalachia were graphically if somewhat diffusely depicted last night on National Educational Television's "Journal" over Channel 13.
HARTFORD, Nov. 11 -- The possible renewal of a teachers' strike here tomorrow was avoided today at a special meet-of the City Council.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 11 -A wall safe containing $23,619 in cash, jewelry and securities was reported stolen Saturday night or Sunday from the Pioneer Country Club and Hotel at Greenfield Park.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 11 -- The trial of James Earl Ray will apparently be delayed at least two months to give his new attorney, Percy Foreman of Houston, time to prepare a defense against the charge that Ray assassinated the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A letter from an employe at Fort Totten in Queens to the United States Commissioner of Education has prompted the Government to ask New York State if it would establish schools for Federal employes' children affected by the New York City school strike.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- An Assistant Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service said today that he deplored the use of a "very large amount of money" and technology for heart transplants that benefit only a few of the nation's sick.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The American Legion marked its 50th anniversary today with a luncheon and reception for representatives of the 17 nations that have been wartime allies of the United States.
" The halo around economists," William C. Freund, economist for the New York Stock Exchange, remarked the other day, "has in recent weeks become a bit tarnished."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- James W. Riddleberger, a retired career ambassador, has provoked a controversy within the Foreign Service by charging that political influence was applied to obtain the promotion of a ranking State Department official to career minister status.

Kathy Kusner is reported "doing fine" after she suffered a fractured tibia in her right leg when her horse, Fru, stumbled and threw her Sunday night during the international jumping competition at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

LAWNSIDE, N. J. -- It has taken Lawnside just over 100 years to turn from a cluster of cabins hiding runaway slaves into a prosperous community of 2,500 people governed by one of the country's few all-black administrations.
An explosion early today shattered the windows and battered the doors of the 25th Precinct station house at 148 East 126th Street in East Harlem.
Third-quarter earnings of the United Aircraft Corporation rose to a record although sales declined, the company reported yesterday.

WIESBADEN, Germany, Nov. 11 (AP) -- West Germany's September surplus in trade with the United States rose 12.3 per cent to $49.4-million, from $43.1-million in August. For the first nine months this year, the Federal Statistics Office reported a West German surplus of $336.9-million, in contrast to a deficit of $224.9-million in the 1967 period.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- Sir Ivor, Ireland's representative in the $150,000 Washington D. C. International, flashed a thrilling closing effort today to win the 17th running of the famous 1 1/2-mile event on the turf.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Abba Eban, Israel's Foreign Minister, chastised the Foreign Ministers of the United Arab Republic and Jordan today for "breaking off the peace dialogue" on the Middle East by going home last week.
The marriage of art and technology, which has not always been a happy one, received encouragement yesterday from three model couples at the Museum of Modern Art.
The eavesdropping methods used in obtaining the 1966 bribery conviction of L. Judson Morhouse, the former Republican state chairman, were upheld yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Nov, 11 -- Manlio Brosio, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that no warning by the organization could have restrained the Soviet Union from invading Czechoslovakia.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Central Bank of Iceland announced today the devaluation of the Icelandic krona.
Barge commerce for the first nine months of 1968 was up 4.2 per cent over the comparable period in 1967, according to the American Waterways Operators, Inc.

Two young women, Mrs. Frank Chapot, riding White Lightning, and Carol Hofmann with Salem, contributed heavily to the victory the United States Equestrian Team acquired at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
TOKYO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Moscow radio tonight hailed the election of Mr. Yara in Okinawa as "a victory of democratic forces."
Leonard Levy has been elected a vice president of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc. Mr. Levy will continue as president of Riverdale Drapery Fabrics, a division of United Merchants.
Efforts to end the city school strike were frustrated yesterday by the rejection by leaders of the teachers' union of a new proposal by Mayor Lindsay.
The election of Arthur A. Rosenthal, 53 years old, as president of Cap-Roc, Inc., button manufacturer, succeeding Neil O. Broderson, was announced yesterday.
The Pan American Sulphur Company received a merger proposal yesterday, from a third suitor, the Gulf Resources Chemical Corporation, involving stock worth in excess of $213-million.

PIKEVILLE, Ky., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A miner was killed and another injured in a slate fall at the Wallace - Leftus Coal Company mine about 20 miles from here. The dead man, identified as Otis Thacker, of Pond Creek, was hit by a slab.

Michael Schulz, resident director at the Negro Ensemble Company, will make his debut as a Broadway director with "Does a Tiger Wear a Necktie?," due Feb. 25 at a theater to be named. Scenery for the Philip Rose production of the Don Petersen drama will be designed by Edward Burbridge.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Computers can help humans enrich the quality of their lives, but they "can never handle our destiny or even make simple decision of morality," Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, said today.

In addition to nearing their first Eastern Division title, the New York Jets have survived Arctic training for the likely American Football League championship game on Dec. 29 at Shea Stadium. The last pro football title game in New York was in 1962, when the Giants lost to the Green Bay Packers as icy winds swirled through Yankee Stadium.

The marine designing company of George G. Sharp, Inc. of New York has been named by the Naval Ship Design Command to prepare drawings and specifications for a nuclear-powered guided missile frigate, the DXGN.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 11 -- The scheduled Veterans Day burning of a puppy with a napalm bomb on the University of Cincinnati campus failed to materialize here today.

SPIROS ZAKAS settled back yesterday morning against the plump pillows of what he calls his "love-in chair." The see-through, plastic- framed chair is a bit too tight for two, and too wide for one. Mr. Zakas, a 27- year-old designer, sat in a comer of his new showroom talking about his past and plastic's future in furniture.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Nov. 11 -- The United States World Cup soccer team defeated Bermuda, 2-0, today before 3,500 persons at National Stadium to win the first round of the North American-Central American-Caribbean elmination series.

LIDO BEACH, L. I., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- A human foot and a thigh bone have been washed up on the sand here. But the Nassau County police said today that they had been unable to trace them to any missing person. The discoveries were made by 13-year-old Jeanne Rafferty while she was playing in the sand at the foot of Biarritz Street.
Adelphi defeated Manhattan, 5-1, last night in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate hockey game at Riverdale Rink in the Bronx.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Mayor Floyd McCree, a Negro, lost his bid for re election when the new Flint City Commission elected Donald R. Cronin, a real estate dealer, to head this industrial city. Mr. Cronin won on a 7-2 vote, with two votes going to his fellow commissioner, Carl Mason.

MIAMI, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An ocean-engineering skin diver died today 165 feet under water in the Atlantic, and a companion who tried to rescue him was stricken with the bends. The victim was Berend H. Joost, 34 years old, of the University of Miami Institute of Marine Sciences.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 11 -- Arthur Robert Ashe Jr. looked solemnly through horn-rimmed glasses at the blackjack dealer in the casino early today, pushed forward a stack of $5 chips and said:

The election last weekend of the opposition Socialist party leader as Chief Executive of the Ryukyu Islands thrusts a key issue in Japanese-American relations to the forefront of problems confronting the new Nixon Administration.

Terry McQuade of the St. John's University Athletic Association won the 3 1/2-mile American Legion-sponsored Muche-Struck Memorial run yesterday at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island. McQuade, a sophomore, was clocked in 17 minutes, 9.2 seconds in a field of 40 starters.

The formation of Glenn, Green Waddell, a new investment banking firm, was announced yesterday by B. Duke Glenn Jr., Roger E. Green and John C. Waddell, formerly members of the corporate finance department of R. W. Pressprich Co., Inc.

The appointment of Donald Q. Devine as senior vice president of Tankoos Co. to direct the expansion of the real-estate company's new national office-renting department has been announced by S. Joseph Tankoos Jr., the company's president. Mr. Devine is a specialist in commercial leasing and has been a vice president of Collins Turtle Co., and the Cross Brown Company, real-estate concerns prominent in the commercial field.
Prices were very firm in active trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 11 -The election of Chobyo Yara, backed by Socialist and leftist parties, as Chief Executive of the United States-administered Ryukyu Islands was confirmed today with more than 90 per cent of the votes counted.
When a hotel man can't find a room, you know business must be good.
One of the world's fastest cargo ships -- speedier than the average passenger liner -- is scheduled to make her debut at Los Angeles on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- State Department officials said today that Mr. McNamara had advised them of his brief stop-over in Moscow more than a month ago, but had asked that no appointments with Soviet officials be requested.

The head of a civic group urged the city yesterday to shut down commercial blood banks on skid rows because their donors included alcoholics and narcotics addicts who, he said, frequently had hepatitis.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 -- Listening to a concert in the Viceroyal National Museum is like listening to a concert in a famous room in Venice with the great Tintoretto paintings. You can't listen to the music for looking at the surroundings for listening to the music.
A 42-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday after he allegedly fired four shots from a .22-caliber rifle from the window of his furnished room in the Midwood section.

A 28-year-old man was fatally stabbed by three young women dressed in men's clothing after an argument as to who should have been served first in a restaurant early yesterday, according to the police.
Many of the nation's commodities exchanges were closed yesterday but the few that were open were busy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Experimental fast train service between Washington and New York faces such trouble that the Federal financial aid may be cut or withdrawn, Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd has warned.
TOKYO, Nov. 11 -- The Jap anese Government and the ruling Liberal Democratic party were shocked by the victory of Mr. Yara in the Ryukyuan election.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 -- An Israeli military man who is well placed in the Government was talking on the telephone with an army colleague last week when news was received of Richard M. Nixon's election.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -A researcher at the University of Chicago says that older persons show definite psychological changes about a year before death occurs.
Steel production rebounded 4.6 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
CALCUTTA, Nov. 11 -- James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, today dedicated India's most modern semi-automatic automobile engine manufacturing plant at Uttarpara, near here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today it planned to send a civilian pilot-engineer on a rocket-powered flight of the wingless HL-10 lifting body this Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- President Johnson awarded a Presidential Citation today to Seal Team One for heroism and aggressive action against the Vietcong in the mangrove swamps of Vietnam. Seal teams are specially trained commando-like units of the Navy.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Terry Hanratty, senior quarterback of Notre Dame, will undergo knee surgery tomorrow and will be sidelined the rest of the football season, Coach Ara Parseghian said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -More than 300 priests from 33 states called on the country's Roman Catholic bishops today to intervene in the dispute between Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle and dissident Washington priests over birth control.
The election of Harry Orenstein as vice president-administration, a new senior-management post, at Schenley Industries, Inc., was announced yesterday.

Joseph A. Nowicki, president of the Affiliated Appraisal Company of LaGrange, Ill., has been elected president of the Society of Real Estate Appraisers for 1969. He is presently senior vice president of the 18,500-member society.

DANVERS, Mass., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Richard Cardinal Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, says he may not resign in January after all. The 73-year-old prelate had announced his retirement because of controversy surrounding his defense of Jacqueline Kennedy's remarriage.
Two boys died last night in a fire in a two-story brick house at 501 Alabama Avenue, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 11 -- Billy Haughton, who might be referred to as the "Gulliver of harness racing," returned from Italy late this afternoon and tonight enjoyed his finest moment in about 90 hours.
Two off-duty policemen who were moonlighting as taxi drivers yesterday morning shot two persons who held them up. One of them -- a woman -- was killed.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Orbach are the parents of a son, born yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital. The child has been named Christopher Ben. Mr. Ohrbach is starred in the musical, "Promises, Promises," soon to reach Broadway. His wife is Marta Curro, an actress.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The central bank has ordered Chile's 21st minor currency devaluation of the year. The Government, meanwhile, announced a 26.9 per cent rise in the cost of living during 1968.
Jacob I. Gottlieb has been promoted to president of J. M. Fields, Inc., the discount-store subsidiary of Food Fair, Inc., Philadelphia.
MILAN KOFOL needed only to walk from his home on Emily Avenue in Elmont, L. I., to the school field and watch the football team practice and his impressions of American football changed considerably.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 -- Air pollution and the common cold, are they related?
SEATTLE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Boeing Company said today it had awarded a $175-million contract to the Fairchild Hiller Corporation to manufacture wing control surfaces for the 747 jumbo jet.
ATHENS, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Alexandros Panaghoulis, the chief defendant in an alleged plot to assassinate Premier George Papadopolous, asked a Greek court martial today to sentence him to death.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Roy Wilkins was asked today to resign as director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The request was made by the presidents of three N.A.A.C.P. branches, who called him "the No. 1 Uncle Tom in America."
SAN ANTONIO Tex., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- A special fact-finding committee will look into the conflict between 68 priests and the Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, Archbishop of San Antonio, officials said today.

The full forces of the state government must be brought into play to counteract the "negative policy" of the City of New York in port development, a report prepared for the New York Shipping Association-International Longshoremen's Association Container Royalty Fund said yesterday.

STORRS, Conn., Nov. 11 -About 100 University of Connecticut students took over administrative offices today in a homey occupation to protest disciplinary action begun after a demonstration against campus recruiting by the Dow Chemical Corporation.

Four persons stripped off their clothes on Reade Street near Lower Broadway yesterday and handed out copies of an "open letter" to President-elect Richard M. Nixon that said that "anatomic explosions are better than atomic explosions."
BARNSTABLE, Mass. -- Lew Schlotterbeck moved in on the pointing setter and a gaudy cock pheasant rose shouting from the grass, flew into a fence and fell to the ground, expiring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A Congressional investigator and the General Accounting Office sparred in public today over how to pinpoint the profits realized by contractors on billions of dollars in military orders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- It was Armistice Day -- and Veterans' Day too -- in every sense this afternoon when the Nixons went to lunch with the Johnsons, to look over the Presidential homestead and to examine the real state of the accounts on the nation's business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- President Johnson today appointed two businessmen to the Public Advisory Commission on Trade Policy. Their terms will expire Dec. 31. The appointees are William M. Allen of Seattle, president of the Boeing Corporation, and David Corcoran, president of Sterling Products International in Rhode Island.
" Helping Out" and "Secrets," a double bill by Mrs. Patricia Cooper, will open Thursday at the Loft Theater Workshop. Ann McIntosh is directing both.

Customs collections at Kennedy Airport set a record high of $24,010,611 last month, Michael Stramiello Jr., Regional Commissioner of Customs, said yesterday. During October last year, collections totaled $17,692,104, the previous monthly high in the last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -The nation's Roman Catholic bishops moved today toward a possible effort to ease the consciences of Catholic couples who cannot accept the papal ban on artificial contraception.

The applicable meeting between President Johnson and President-elect Nixon yesterday was made possible by their shared views on Vietnam and their mutual recognition that the country cannot drift rudderless through two months of interregnum.
It is difficult to say which occurs less frequently: the 300th birthday of Francois Couperin, or a duo-harpsichord recital. Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the latter celebrated the former.

A homeowner's insurance program designed to provide protection against inflation was announced yesterday by the State Farm Fire and Casualty Company. The coverage, to be introduced on Dec. 1 in Illinois, automatically increases with the escalating value of the property.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 11 -- The United States Savings and Loan League has decided not to revive its fight for enactment of legislation creating a system of hybrid thrift institutions called Federal savings association.
A facsimile edition of the first draft of T. S. Eliot's "The Waste Land" will be published by Harcourt, Brace World on Sept. 26, 1969, which would have been the poet's 81st birthday.

The design of a fully equipped theater built of fiber glass, which can be transported by plane or truck, will go on exhibition Nov. 20 at the Lincoln Center's Library and Museum of the Performing Arts. Models of the theater's interior and exterior will be shown.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- An hour-long parade of 3,000 French soldiers and troop detachments from the United States and other countries that were allied with France in World War I provided the highpoint today for two days of celebrations here marking the 50th anniversary of the 1918 Armistice.

Robert (Sonny) Carson, the militant former leader of Brooklyn CORE charged yesterday police harassment in connection with his arrest last week on charges of grand larceny. and criminal possession of a stolen car.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara paid a surprise visit today to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin. The subject of their conversation, which lasted an hour and 45 minutes, was not made known.

A series of avant-garde films sponsored by the Film Makers Cinematheque will be shown on Tuesdays at 5:30 and 7 P. M., starting today, at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street. Two movies by Kenneth Anger, "Eaux d'Artifice (1953) and "Inauguration of the Pleasure Dome" (1945-46) form the first program. Jonas Makas, program director of the Cinematheque, will discuss the films with the audience after each Tuesday screening.

The Penn Central Company announced yesterday that two new high - speed passenger coaches, equipped with Westinghouse Electric propulsion and control equipment, are now being tested on its line in an effort to determine whether certain modifications have corrected a short-circuiting problem that had delayed the inauguration of three-hour train service on the railroad's New York to Washington, D. C. run.
GOTEBORG, Sweden -- Big oil tankers are emerging from an avant garde Swedish shipyard these days almost like toothpaste being squeezed from a tube.
DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -Hospital costs will continue to rise, Dr. Dwight L. Wilbur, president of the American Medical Association, said today at a news conference.
PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 11 (AP) -- The 102d annual convention of the National Grange opened today with fraternal ceremonies. Business sessions will be held later in the convention running through Nov. 19.
YOU have to be quite a woman to offer a one-woman show. Vinie Burrows, who has brought her program "Walk Together Children" to the Greenwich Mews Theater, is, luckily, quite a woman.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintain a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.
OBINIOFIA, Nigeria, Nov. 11 -- Ibo tribesmen were reported to have fled this area, but the first Red Cross food truck to Obiniofia caused a stampede.
GALE Industries, Inc.'s return to the ranks of traded issues today may be a stormy affair.
CALCUTTA, India., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A strike by petroleum company employes caused a severe gasoline shortage in Calcutta today. Bus companies curtailed service and many private cars were immobilized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Washington will soon be inundated with happy Republicans. Once the real estate agents have finished plucking them, they will be less happy. Then they will begin learning about Congress, and soon they will no longer be happy at all.
Detectives raided three locations in Chinatown last night and arrested 11 men in connection with an alleged Chinese lottery known as bok-a-pu.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 -- Premier Levi Eshkol said in Parliament today that the factors that led to the six-day war last year were present in the Middle East again.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Arnold Winick, buying as the agent for Morrie A. Moss, a financier of Memphis, paid $290,000 tonight for a 5-year-old mare in foal to Buck-passer.

Elmo Roper, a senior consultant to the marketing and public-opinion firm of Roper Research Associates, was elected yesterday as a director to three mutual funds of the Value Line group. Managed and sponsored by Arnold Bernhard Co., Inc., the three funds are Value Line Fund, Inc., Value Line Income Fund, Inc., and Value Line Special Situation Fund, Inc.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 11 (AP) -- At a festive ceremony today, Rhodesia's whiteminority Government raised its new flag, which replaced the British Union Jack.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Howard A. Zeller ruled today that an Ithaca court judge had exceeded his authority in ordering The Ithaca Journal to withhold the publication of the names of two teen-agers accused of petty larceny.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Eighteen persons perished and 12 were gravely injured in two separate passenger bus-truck collisions on Turkish highways today.
Cornell University's "Mr. Potato Chip" is now trying to improve the flavor of ready-made french fries.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Three hundred students rioted in the narrow streets of Old San Juan here last week. They stopped as soon as the director shouted "Cut!" and the motion picture camera ceased grinding.
DORADO, P. R., Nov. 11 -Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew, his family and several friends arrived tonight for a few days rest and recreation.
THE MAN FROM NEW YORK. John Quinn and His Friends. By B. L. Reid. 708 pages. Oxford. $12.50.

An overwhelming proportion of Americans favor revision of the Constitution to provide for direct election of the President and abolition of the Electoral College, according to a poll by Louis Harris Associates.

The Fire Department responded yesterday to its 200,000th alarm this year. Officials said that this compared with 172,000 alarms answered during all of 1967. In 1962, the department reported, calls exceeded 100,000 for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Presidential press secretary, George Christian, said today that questions on the shelling of South Vietnam by enemy gunners should be referred to Gen. Creighton W. Abrams in Vietnam.

The appointment of Alan Raphael as president and member of the board of the Midway Company, Lodi, N. J., was announced yesterday. The company, which produces missile sections for the Defense Department and fabricates sheet metal components for the aerospace industry, is a subsidiary of the Coffee-Mat Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -The firing of artillery, rocket and mortar barrages from the demilitarized zone against American military units yesterday has spurred a debate in the Johnson Administration.

Growing preference for polyester and cotton blended fabrics in place of all-cotton print cloths has led M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., to undertake a $6-million modernization program in its mill at Honea Path, S. C. The facility there, known as the Chiquola manufacturing division, will change production from printcloths to wide polyester-cotton blends for sheets and pillow cases to be sold under the Wamsutta and Pacific brand names.

The rise in welfare rolls across the nation was described yesterday by two Columbia sociologists as "chiefly a political phenomenon" rather than mainly a result of family disintegration or unemployment.
The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism has named six men and three women as advanced science-writing fellows for 1968-69.

Rich Buzin, the rookie offensive tackle of the New York Giants, said yesterday, "They better not start counting their money yet." Buzin was referring to the cocky Dallas Cowboys, who were quite confident until they met the Giants that they were headed for the National League championship and possibly the Super Bowl, goals that can reward each player with $25,000.

Daniel Gutman, former dean of the New York Law School, is expected to be recommended today for appointment as counsel to the special City Council committee that will investigate the Human Resources Administration.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Fifty-two students at Wellesley College are in the midst of a four-day partial fast for peace in Vietnam. The girls started abstaining from solid food at midnight yesterday and say they expect to continue through midnight Thursday. A spokesman said they would partake only of liquids during the period.

The Board of Education has opened "interview conferences" to determine if four Negro teachers from Junior High School 271 in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district should be formally charged with a breach of professional conduct.

SCOTT EATON was still in something of a daze as the plane sped through the darkness, bringing the slightly shell-shocked Giants back to New York from Dallas the night before last. They had just engineered a coup of monumental proportions by sabotaging the highly favored Cowboys, 27-21, in what has to be regarded as the upset of the year.

The start of a new service from the United States Gulf ports to Brazil and Argentina was announced yesterday by the Coral Line. The service will get under way later this month with the sailing of the Monsun from Gulf ports.
ROME, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Paul VI issued a strong new warning today to Roman Catholic liberals against trying to change "indispensable structures" of the church to suit their own ideals.

A call for members of the food business to involve themselves in the "environmental problems" of the communities in which they operate was issued yesterday by W. B. Murphy, president of the Campbell Soup Company.

Half a century after the chill November day when a young Texan sounded the solemn notes of Taps in France to signal the end of World War I, the nation paused again yesterday to honor the dead of its wars.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Meadow Stable's Gay Matelda put on a burst of speed at the halfway mark today to take command of the $25,000-added Jersey Belle Handicap, then drew away to score a five-length victory over Inge at Garden State Park.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- The current ballet week at the Deutsche Oper is mostly one man's work, and an impressive piece of work it is. The new program sums up neatly Kenneth Macmillan's achievement since he became director there two years ago.

One delay has followed another in the city's fight against air pollution, and now officials concede that the city's own buildings will not comply with requirements for upgrading incinerators by the Dec. 20 deadline. New York ranks as one of the most polluted cities in the nation, and yet the fight against air pollution, which should have been an all-out war, limps along as a left-footed affair marked mostly by strategic retreats.

Botany Industries, Inc., has made a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service for alleged tax deficiencies in 1958 and 1959 that also would affect subsequent years, Michael Daroff, chairman and president of Botany, announced yesterday.

David A. Seiffer, an English teacher at the William M. Niles Junior High School in the Bronx, has been awarded the $2,500 Sam S. Schubert Foundation fellowship in playwriting at New York University. Last year, Mr. Seiffer won second prize of $300 from the Four Winds Press for his short play, "If I Ruled the World."

CHILLICOTHE, Mo., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A Continental Trailways bus slipped off a snow-covered highway and overturned early today. Nobody was injured seriously. The police said that the bus, bound from Kansas City to Chicago, went off U.S. 36 a mile west of here, slid down a 10-foot embankment and rolled over on its right side.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, routed the San Diego Rockets, 134-113, in the finale of a National Basketball Association double-header at the Garden tonight.
Higher prices for polyethylene film used in bread over-wraps and bag making were announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. The higher schedules will go into effect Dec. 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- University administrators were urged today to expel student extremists who try to foment campus revolutions.
The Inland Steel Company and the A. O. Smith Corporation said yesterday that they were discussing a joint venture in powder metal and glass fiber reinforced plastics.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Japan's exports reached the second highest level in history in October, totaling $1,223,658,000, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced today. The October total was an increase of 3.3 per cent over the September level and up 36 per cent since October, 1967.

WARSAW, Nov. 11 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist party leader, rebuked Western Communists today for having condemned the invasion of Czechoslovakia. He said they had no right to dictate policy to the Soviet party and other ruling parties.

FULTON, Mo., Nov. 11 -- A tall form moved slowly through the unfinished sanctuary of the Church of St. Mary Aldermanbury, brought stone-by-stone from London and reconstructed here in memory of Winston Churchill, as a soggy autumn :snowfall dappled the 300-year-old church walls today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- George Christian, White House press secretary, today discounted a report that President Johnson was actively considering a meeting with Soviet leaders before he leaves office Jan. 20.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 -- Enemy soldiers in the demilitarized zone shelled United States marines yesterday for the first time since President Johnson stopped the bombardment of North Vietnam 11 days go.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 11 -The New York Nets of the American Basketball League obtained Bob Verga, the former Duke standout, from the Denver Rockets today for a fourth-round choice in the college draft.

ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The Cornell chapter of Students for a Democratic Society has called on Cornell University to remedy Ithaca's housing shortage by financing 1,500 low-income housing units, building housing for 75 per cent of its students and granting an across-the-board raise to its nonacademic employes.

Former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court Tom C. Clark and his son, United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark, will receive honorary degrees of Doctor of Law from the New York Law School, it was announced yesterday.

Sixty rifles and shotguns were stolen over the weekend from a gunsmith in Ozone Park, Queens, the police reported yesterday. The burglary was discovered by Albert Barritz when he opened his store at 97-19 101st Avenue at 6:30 A.M.

SWAN QUARTER, N. C., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Twenty chanting Negro students marched into a room of the Hyde County courthouse today to protest a cut in welfare payments, and the police hurled smoke grenades inside and slammed the door shut.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Oakland Oaks, taking advantage of New Orleans's court errors and fouls in overtime, defeated the Buccaneers, 136-127, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The Nassau County Fire Marshal's office is investigating suspicious fires that broke out in the Massapequa High School early today.

ROME, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- The Italian trade deficit in September this year totaled 55 billion lire ($8.8-million), compared with one of 46 billion lire ($7.36-million) in September, 1967, according to provisional figures issued by the Central Institute of Statistics.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk rejected today a conciliatory note from Secretary of State Dean Rusk aimed at obtaining the release of 11 United States soldiers held here since July.

DETROIT, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Both the Soviet Union and Communist China have troops and missiles poised along their common border, Harrison E. Salisbury, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, said today.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Nov. 12 -- A thief shattered the show window of an art gallery here early today and stole a painting by the American artist Winslow Homer. The oil painting, "Boy in a Boatyard," was valued at $30,000.

Dorothy Kirsten made her first appearance in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Puccini's "Tosca" last night, and it is a pleasure to report that she was pleasing both to look at and to listen to. This is no small compliment for a soprano who made her debut with the Chicago Opera House in 1940 and came to the Metropolitan in 1945.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Senate Democrat in charge of inauguration operations stepped aside today in favor of Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois, the Republican leader.

South Street Seaport has acquired and hopes to bring back to New York the only known surviving wooden square-rigged American merchant ship -- the Charles Cooper. For the last 102 years her Connecticut oak and chestnut timbers have been well preserved in the frigid waters of Port Stanley in the Falkland Islands.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- District Judge Paul Larrazolo denied today a defense motion for a mistrial in the kidnapping trial of Reies Tijerina and nine of his followers.

WOMEN are ready to look sexy again. Designers are convinced of it. That's the reason they're giving for their growing concern with soft, clingy dresses that slither around the body, encouraging women to slink. They've eliminated all the linings, interfacings and stiffening that women have become accustomed to ever since Christian Dior built bras and petticoats into his dresses back in the nineteen-forties.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Thailand must take further precautions against infiltration of Vietcong from Cambodia, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today. He did not say what they would be.
"This is some day," commented a damp student of form yesterday as he watched the rain sweep across Aqueduct. "Someday has to be the hunch bet in the race. I like his figures anyhow."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Retail sales dropped once again in October for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported today.

The appointment of three executive vice presidents at the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation were announced yesterday by Lawrence S. Phillips, president. They are Stanley C. Gillette, William Hellman and Robert F. Reilly.
Dr. Fager was named horse of the year by sports writers and broadcasters in the United States and Canada, according to a poll released yesterday by Turf and Sports Digest.

Genesco, Inc., leading apparel manufacturer and retailer reported yesterday lower net income despite record sales and pre-tax earnings for the first quarter ended October 31. Earnings per share also hit a record.

Hofstra will meet Fairleigh Dickinson and Army plays Harvard in first-round matches of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament Monday. Hofstra and Army were selected yesterday, along with Brockport State and Hartwick, as the New York area teams for the championship.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to purchase 1,282,948 shares of common stock of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company valued at more than $59-million.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense Department as having been killed in Vietnam:

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Malcolm Moos, president of the University of Minnesota, said today the school was interested in having Vice President Humphrey as a professor of political science. He said no one had yet talked to the Vice President about his possible interest, Mr. Humphrey taught political science at Macalester College in St. Paul for two years before starting his political career.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Nov. 12 (Agence France-Presse) -- Gabon and Equatorial Guinea have decided to esttablish diplomatic relations at ambassadorial level. The Gabonese ambassador to Cameroon will be accredited to Equatorial Guinea, the former Spanish Guinea.
A small electronics company in Troy, Mich., that showed a loss of $714,210 for the fiscal year ended June 30, rocked securities trading yesterday.
HEBER CITY, Utah, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Forest Service crews cut today a 74-foot spruce that will become the nation's Christmas tree on the White House lawn in Washington.
The nation's oldest indoor track and field competition, the New York Athletic Club meet, will not be held next year, apparently as a result of the black-power struggle.

Pearl Bailey and Cab Calloway, stars of "Hello, Dolly!," last night completed their first year in the musical hit. The show was written by Jerry Herman (music and lyrics) and Michael Stewart (book). It has been running here since Jan. 16, 1964.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The change of Administration here will coincide with the passing of a generation of official Kremlinologists that has dominated United States diplomacy with the Soviet Union for three decades.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey will be entitled to a Government pension of $19,450 when he leaves office Jan. 20.

The mock check for $25,000 on the clubhouse wall has a special meaning to three of the New York Jets who walk past it. Don Maynard, Bill Mathis and Larry Grantham can remember when lesser checks than $25,000 bounced as erratically as a fumbled punt.
Inglewood, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Bill Flett's two goals in the second period led the Los Angeles Kings to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over the Oakland Seals tonight.

The Police Athletic League will benefit from a supper dance on Nov. 22 at the Rainbow Room after a theater party at "Zorba" in the Imperial Theater. Mrs. Charlotte Ford Niarchos and Mrs. John Mosler are co-chairmen of the evening.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Clem Haskins, scoring 29 points, led the Chicago Bulls to a 115-108 victory over the San Diego Rockets tonight in the National Basketball Association.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A 28-year-old beautician filed a suit today challenging one of the last male preserves in this state -- the bar stool. Lynda McElroy of Tacoma, described in court papers as "of impeccable character," asked that the State Liquor Control Board be restrained from enforcing a state law prohibiting women from sitting at the bar in cocktail lounges.
The Theater Guild-American Theater Society, which has subscribers in 16 cities outside of New York, is streamlining its ticket distribution.
ALBANY, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice issued a temporary order today blocking the sale of Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory to a profit-making organization.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Pipers were downed by the Los Angles Stars, 123-116, tonight in an overtime A.B.A. game. With the score 116-all, Steve Chubin scored a basket and a free throw and the Stars won going away.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Supreme Court refused today to disturb a lower court ruling that New York's largest bus terminal could not bar the distribution of autiwar leaflets.

The riders and mounts of the United States Equestrian Team ended the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night with a flourish, gaining the first three places in the Grand Prix of New York City.
THE concept of earnings-per-share, the most closely watched barometer of corporate health, is undergoing surgery again.

Columbia College has given final notice to about 90 student still facing disciplinary action as a result of last spring's occupation of five campus buildings that if they do not appear before a dean their cases will be referred to the college disciplinary tribunal, which may impose punishments up to suspension.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 -- John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board is expected to resign Dec. 15 and to become president and chief executive officer of the Investors Mortgage Insurance Company of Boston, savings and loan sources said here today.

Portugal's new Premier, Marcelo Caetano, continues slowly to dismantle some of the harsh trappings he inherited from the 36-year iron rule of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar. Dr. Caetano has now made good his promise to permit the return in freedom of Mario Soares, the democratic opposition leader who had been deported to the island of Sao Tome last March as "dangerous to the public order."

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Mike Torrez, the first St. Louis pitcher to go nine innings in Japan, tossed an eight-hitter as the Cardinals won, 5-3, over a Yomiuri Giants-Hiroshima Carps combine.
AL MATAWIR, Yemen, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The elder Mr. Namer was reported by a cousin here today as once having been a member of the secret police in Aden.

THE last time Harvard posted an undefeated football record was in 1913. The last time a Crimson squad won its first seven games was in 1931. The Crimson has won its first seven games and stands on the threshold of an unbeaten season again, but there is the small matter of Brown this Saturday and the very large matter of Yale next Saturday.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Government lifted drastic price and wage freezes imposed last June to check inflation. A decree authorized raises beginning next month and also said merchants could increase prices to meet higher costs "if absolutely necessary."

The City Council noted unanimously yesterday to approve legislation requiring the Housing and Development Administration to hold a public hearing before seeking a rent increase in a middle-income housing project that is under the administration's supervision.
The American Friends of the Hebrew University will hold their 10th Scopus Award dinner on Nov. 25 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Billy Walker, a British heavyweight, scored an upset tonight by stopping Thad Spencer of Tacoma, Wash., in the sixth round of their scheduled ten-round bout at Wembley.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 12 -- South Korean security forces today killed five more members of a group of about 30 North Koreans, that landed on the east coast 10 days ago. The Counterespionage Operations Command said that 28 of the intruders had now been killed in the continuing sweep in a wide area of snow-covered mountains in southeastern Korea.

An art exhibition and sale will be held at Kenyon's Painting Pad in the Volney Hotel, 23 East 74th Street, Monday through Dec. 23. Twenty per cent of the proceeds from the sale will go to the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine at the New York University Medical Center. The exhibition will include works by Helene Fortescue Reynolds, who signs her paintings Kenyon; Charles Adams, Herbert Foust and Marie Hetherington.
TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Dr. Kentaro Hayashi, dean of the Faculty of Letters at Tokyo University, was released by striking students today after having been held captive just over seven days.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Students demonstrated at Allahabad, Amritsar, Banaras and Agra universities today, burning files, damaging property and clashing with policemen. Their demands include improved curriculums, a voice in college government and job training.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 -- The Professional Golfers' Association looked back tonight to past achievements and inducted Melvin (Chick) Harbert into the game's Hall of Fame.

Crocker Nevin, president and chief executive officer of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, has been elected to the additional post of chairman of the succeeds the late George C. board. In his new post, he Textor.

SAN JUAN, Nov. 12 -- Frank Robinson, $100,000-a-year baseball player, stood sweltering in the farthest reaches of center field at Bithorn Stadium and tried to impart to three young men, all white, the pseudo science of judging the hop of a Texas Leaguer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- This year's corn production is expected to total 4,439,759,000 bushels, exceeded only by the record 1967 crop, the Agriculture Department announced today.

THE bidding science of the experts is reasonably effective with normal hands and an undisturbed auction. But an expert with a freakish hand is liable to have to guess like anyone else when the opponents crowd the bidding.
An unidentified holdup man was shot and killed, reportedly with his own revolver, last night during a struggle with a Brooklyn grocer.

PARIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- About 40 students occupied administrative offices at the Sorbonne today, demanding changes in graduation requirements. The occupation was the first since the police cleared the university during the student revolt in May and June.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- House Speaker John W. McCormack interprets the 1968 Congressional election results as a mandate to continue the policies of Democratic Congresses.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Information Minister Ton That Thien said here today that South Vietnam would want to know what would be discussed as well as who would be present before attending the talks in Paris.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Japan will purchase $100-million worth of special certificates from the United States Export-Import Bank by the end of November to cooperate in the United States dollar-saving program, the Finance Ministry said today.

Although last night's performance of "The Golden Cockerel" at the New York State Theater was the New York City Opera's fourth and final one of the season, a few cast changes were made for it. Spiro Malas sang King Dodon for the first time, Patricia Wise was new in the title role, as was John Lankston as the Astrologer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a 1965 Interstate Commerce Commission finding that northern railroads were entitled to an increased share of north-south freight revenues.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today denied a hearing to Morton Sobell, who is seeking a reduction in his prison term for conspiracy to commit espionage.
The all-Mahler recital by Dietrich Fischer - Dieskau and Leonard Bernstein in Philharmonic Hall last Friday evening will be broadcast Saturday on WQXR from 8:07 to 10 P.M.

NEWARK, Nov. 12 -- Nine inmates escaped from the Essex County Jail here last night in what was described as the biggest jail break in the history of the 131-year-old structure. One of the fugitives was back in custody within a few hours, and three others, including one charged with murder, were captured during the day.

"All My Sons," Arthur Miller's drama of 1947, will be presented from Friday night until Nov. 24 at the Master Theater, Riverside Drive and 103rd Street. Arthur Lipton is directing the Equity Library Theater revival.
BLOOMINGBURG, N. Y., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A family of seven died early today when fire raced through a small summer bungalow at a resort camp northeast of this Sullivan County community.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 13 -- The United States Air Force announced this morning that it planned to return a detachment of F-111 swing-wing jets to Nevada after nearly nine months at a combat base in Thailand.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Three days late and with a new propeller, the S.S. President Wilson left with 425 passengers today for a 46-day cruise.

DORADO, Puerto Rico, Nov. 12 -- Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew enjoyed four and one-half hours of golf and hot sun today on the Dorado Beach Hotel's east course. He reported his cold improved, if not his score.
ROME, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A leading Cardinal at the Vatican declared today that Roman Catholics questioning the authority of the church hierarchy were playing with heresy.

HONOLULU, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The sponsors of the Hawaiian open golf tournament voted today to sign a two-year contract with the American Professional Golfers. Officials also voted to increase the purse of the tournament from $125,000 to $200,000 starting in 1970.
A surprise witness at a National Labor Relations Board hearing yesterday buttressed the case of a seaman who has filed an unfair labor practice complaint aginst the National Maritime Union.
The delinquency rate on real estate taxes here, despite the city's efforts to improve billing procedures, is still near record levels.
The leader of the nation's birth control movement called upon President-elect Richard M. Nixon yesterday to make more Federal money available for family planning for the poor.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A class suit has been filed charging that Attorney General Ramsey Clark and Detroit officials had political reasons for allegedly failing to prosecute policemen "guilty of racist, criminal behavior against black citizens."

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- The chairman of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade called today on President-elect Richard M. Nixon to pursue a liberal trade policy in the interest of the United States as well as the entire international trading community.
MELBOURNE, Wednesday, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Australia's second heart transplant patient died today, 14 hours after he had undergone surgery at Alfred Hospital.

TRENTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- New Jersey servicemen, even those from some areas that went Democratic, preferred Richard M. Nixon for President to Hubert H. Humphrey. Official returns from 13 of the state's 21 counties that broke down absentee ballots into military and civilian categories gave Mr. Nixon 7,769 military votes to 4,055 for Mr. Humphrey and 1,566 for George C. Wallace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Congress was told today that seven major manufacturers of computers had refused to give the Government information on the cost and pricing of computer systems as required by law.

The election of__Robert P. Beasley as executive vice president, finance, of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, was announced yesterday, Mr. Beasley, 54 years old, joined Firestone in 1937.

The Melting Pot, a new repertory company at 18 Bleecker Street, will revive William Saroyan's "The Cave Dwellers" on Friday and Saturday nights. Performances will be repeated on the same nights next week.
Mike Currier, who sparked Auburn in its 28-14 upset over fifth-ranked Tennessee last Saturday, was named The Associated Press's college back of the week yesterday.

The possibility that one or more of the four Yemeni Arabs involved in the alleged plot to assassinate President-elect Richard M. Nixon was working -- or had once worked -- for foreign intelligence organizations was being investigated yesterday by the Secret Service and other Government agencies.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II had an anxious moment today when a big dog attacked one of the horses pulling her carriage to a joint session of the Chilean Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today that "the near brush with catastrophe" in Tuesday's election points up a need to change the Presidential election system.

LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Clark Graebner, the American Davis Cup player, pulled a back muscle today during his match with Keith Wooldridge of England in the British covered-court (indoor) tennis championships. Wooldridge was leading, 6-1, 5-1, when the big-serving American retired.
ROME, Nov. 12 -- Thousands of students demonstrated throughout the nation today for a greater voice in their education, better school facilities and other reforms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) -- President Johnson had breakfast today with Vice President Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie and discussed the future of the Democratic party in light of the defeat by the Republicans.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- A sociologist charged today that a clash over power and money among the Watts community, the University of Southern California and the Office of Economic Opportunity "inhibited realization of goals" of what was to be one of the nation's model neighborhood health centers.

WPIX (Channel 11) will present a "High School of the Air, to prepare seniors for state Regents examinations. The program, which starts tomorrow, will be carried Monday through Friday from 10 A.M. to noon during the teachers' strike.
The National Orchestral Association opened its season at Carnegie Hall last night and it introduced a fine, young violinist to New York audiences, Endre Granat, a Hungarian.
Biafran refugees will be aided by two events at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

The summary rejection by Albert Shanker of Mayor Lindsay's latest proposal for ending the demoralizing school shutdown makes it plain that the United Federation of Teachers wants peace only on a basis that will wipe out the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district and destroy all prospects of orderly school decentralization.

Laxmi Pradas Sihare is an intense 34-year-old art scholar who has spent the greater part of the last eight years in the United States on fellowships, acquiring a Ph.D. degree in modern art at New York University and immersing himself in the contemporary Western scene.
The City Council's inquiry into New York's anti-poverty programs formally opened yesterday with a promise by the participating Councilmen that it would be kept "nonpolitical."
MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Tonight's harness racing at Blue Bonnet Raceway was called off because of the snowstorm.
VIENNA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Austria celebrated her 50th anniversary as a republic today.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon began yesterday to choose the small body of semi-anonymous men who will form the core of the White House staff in his Administration.
