WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Johnson are expected to forgo their traditional holiday at the LBJ Ranch so they can spend the last Christmas of Mr. Johnson's Presidency at the White House with their daughters and grandchildren.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Defense Secretary Clark M. Clifford warned South Vietnamese leaders today that unless they agreed soon to participate in the Paris talks, the United States might feel compelled to proceed without them.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, repeating his earlier statement that the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia had changed the balance of power in Central Europe, today called for more men and weapons in the Western alliance to counter an increasing Soviet militancy in and around the Continent.

Three groups within the Police Department began an investigation yesterday into an early morning explosion that shattered a dozen windows of the 25th Precinct station at 148 East 126th Street in East Harlem.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Information Minister Ton That Thien said today that the United States, North Vietnam and the Vietcong could go ahead at the Paris talks without South Vietnam, "but their conclusions certainly will be of no validity at all."

LESSING'S "Minna Von Barnhelm" has its place in theater history as the first German social comedy -- "a tribute to German womanhood and the Prussian army," one authority describes it with unconscious humor -- and performances of it in its native land are apparently no more rare than, say, revivals of "She Stoops to Conquer" are here.

THE Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden is an admirable auditorium in many ways. But it has about as much theatricality as a surprisingly well-swept subway station. It therefore did not provide the finest setting for the distinguished Piraikon Theotron company from Athens.
LAGOS, Nigeria -- Sixteen months of civil war in Nigeria, and fierce emotions about it, have not yet made deep dents in the lives of many people in Lagos, the capital.
Geoffrey M. Shurlock will retire on Jan. 2 as director of the Motion Picture Association of America's Production Code Administration. He will be succeeded by Eugene G. Dougherty, his assistant.

An exhibition of primitive African stone carvings will be held from next Monday through Nov. 23 in the Manhattan Hotel, Eighth Avenue and 45th Street. None of the artists represented has had any formal training. Their sculptures have been carved from a jade green semi-translucent soapstone found in the ancient city of Zimbabwe.
The Buffalo Bills, who had lost three quarterbacks through injury this season and had only one left, signed Benny Russell yesterday. He is an untried rookie with a 17-day leave from the Air Force.
SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 12 (AP) -- John Scopes hailed today the Supreme Court's striking down Arkansas's anti-evolution law.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Twenty-two persons, many of them children, died yesterday in the collision of their bus and a tanker truck, the police said today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A transportation expert at Northwestern University recommended today that Chicago's proposed third major airport be built about 45 miles south of the Loop near the Will-Kankakee County line.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Administration officials said today that no specific proposals or messages changed hands during the "general conversation" Mr. McNamara and Premier Kosygin had yesterday in Moscow.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Sonny Liston, bidding to regain the heavyweight crown he once wore, chased Roger Rischer of San Francisco fort wo rounds tonight before knocking him out at 2:23 of the third round.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The Union of Writers refused today to take part in organizing the funeral of a long-time member who renounced his membership in the Communist party last week to protest what he called its return to Stalinism.

San Diego State's stunning 68-7 victory over Southern Mississippi kept the Aztecs well atop the small-college ratings yesterday as they received 28 first-place votes and 330 points from the 35-member United Press International board of coaches.

NAIROBI, Kenya -- From tawny slopes and thickets of eucalyptus close to Nairobi the cry of the hound and the sound of the hunting horn can be heard most Sunday mornings, and voices raised in an old question that seems alien to the African landscape -- "D'ye ken John Peel?"

The Sprague Electric Company announced a major realignment of its senior management yesterday. Bruce R. Carlson, 47, was elected president, succeeding Ernest L. Ward, 61. Mr. Ward, president since 1960, had asked to be relieved of his operating responsibilities, the company said.

MARIKO SANJO, a leading Japanese modern-dance choreographer and dancer, offered an unusual program with her company last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall that oscillated between the height of Eastern mysticism and the depths of Western banality.
PARIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Three World War I veterans died yesterday as they participated in observances of the 50th anniversary of the Armistice.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Tom Van Arsdale and Oscar Robertson sparked the Eastern Division leading Cincinnati Royals to a 126-115 National Basketball Association victory tonight over the Baltimore Bullets.

SAN DIEGO, Nov. 12 -- The excommunication of a former priest who married a Roman Catholic widow here 15 months ago has been lifted by the Vatican Holy Office in a rare decision, the San Diego Catholic Diocese confirmed today.
One year ago yesterday, the New York Rangers beat a National Hockey League expansion team and gained a tie for first place in the East Division.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- New-car sales sagged from normal levels in early November, the automobile industry reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Prices continued to decline with a smaller number of offerings in the weekly auction of mortgages to the Federal National Mortgage Association, the agency announced today.

Mariquilla, a highly gifted flamenco dancer whose affinity with the late Carmen Amaya should be noted but not overdone, comes to the Chateau Madrid with a national reputation in Spain and a powerful technique.

McGeorge Bundy, the president of the Ford Foundation, said yesterday that "irresponsible charges" by Albert Shanker that the foundation had too much influence on the city school system could impair the work of all philanthropic foundations and frighten talented men away from public service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The United States is preparing a new report on combat incidents along the Cambodian frontier for Prince Norodom Sihanouk, hoping to win the release of the 11 servicemen held prisoner since July.

ROBERT CROMIE has been conducting his weekly television program entitled "Book Beat" for over three years and it is either a miracle or an oversight that he has not been drummed out of membership in the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

SAIGON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Speedy United States Navy patrol boats, with air support, struck at an enemy stronghold in extreme southern Vietnam yesterday in an operation that destroyed 141 sampans, the United States command said today.
The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to expedite construction of the projected $60.5-mililon passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River between 46th and 50th Streets.
FULTON, Mo., Nov. 12 -- Following are excerpts from the John Findley Green Lecture by C. P. Snow at Westminster College here today:
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued firm yesterday.

Two grants of $50,000 each from the Billy Rose Foundation and the National Endowment on the Arts, a federal agency, have been made toward the local and Los Angeles engagements of the Minnesota Theater Company.
Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., general building contractor and construction consultant, has announced the appointment of Sidney Berger as vice president in charge of finance, a new position.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 12 (Agence France-Presse) -- North Vietnam denied today that there was a tacit agreement allowing the United States to continue reconnaissance flights over the country.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A U.C.L.A. dropout, ordered to report today for induction, instead chained himself to the university's administration building to protest in behalf of those "chained to the draft."

Talks aimed at ending the city school strike were broken off suddenly last night when negotiators for the teachers and supervisors stormed out of a Gracie Mansion session and accused Mayor Lindsay of trying to "deliberately deceive and fool the people."
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A civilian team of five Californians and one New Mexican won the final event of the national rifle team championships yesterday.

Dereco, Inc., the holding company formed earlier this year by the Norfolk Western Railway to control several small railroads that are included in the N. W. system, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,108,000 for the six months to Sept. 30.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- A Soviet vice admiral said today that the Soviet build-up in the Mediterranean would guarantee peace and security in the area.

"Tradition Strikes Back" could have been the subtitle of the symposium held Monday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.C.A. to celebrate jointly the 20th anniversary of The Hudson Review and the 30th of the Poetry Center of the Y.

HOUSTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Sidney Lebowitz, a 50-year-old Assemblyman from New York City, who received a heart transplant on Election Day, last Tuesday, died in St. Luke's Hospital today of what physicians called an unusual type of rejection.
An engine-room fire caused the Home Lines liner Oceanic to turn back yesterday on the outbound leg of a seven-day cruise to Nassau.

On Tuesdays, the Jewish Theological Seminary's Institute for Religious and Social Studies gathers -- as it did yesterday -- the faithful and less than faithful to hear three speakers talk about everything from God to man, even businessman.
Bobby Unser, Cale Yarborough and Mark Donohue were named yesterday to receive the auto racing fraternity achievement awards at the group's annual award dinner here Jan. 26.

SWAN QUARTER, N. C., Nov. 12 -- As they marched through a sharp wind toward the Hyde County courthouse today, more than 60 Negro high school students borrowed a tune from the segregationist's songbook.

The naming of Thomas W, Moore as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Ticket Reservations Systems, Inc., was announced yesterday. He formerly was president of the television network of American Broadcasting Companies Inc.

SAIGON, Wednesday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Three allied military installations and a province capital were shelled overnight by enemy gunners, the United States command reported this morning. Initial accounts said casualties and damage were light.

ATHOL FUGARD has a small human drama to unfold in "Hello and Goodbye," which was given its second and last performance yesterday afternoon at the Theater de Lys. His good fortune and that of the playgoers was that he had Kim Hunter and Nicolas Coster to show what a skillful dramatist he is.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Chicago Bears announced today that Bob Jones, an end formerly with San Diego State, had been called up for six months of active Army duty and would report Monday.

Leaders of a Jewish organization met with a committee of Negro clergymen yesterday in a closed conference, in an effort to quell the racial and religious animosities that have grown out of the teachers' strike here.

The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that Dr. Donald F. Hornig will become scientific adviser to the president, Dr. Louis K. Eilers in January. In his new post Dr. Hornig will consult with and advise members of the various Kodak research laboratories on research and development programs in the United States and abroad.

About $170-million worth of rental properties here have been abandoned by frustrated owners, a Texas real estate man said yesterday. His estimate was seen as "realistically in the ballpark" by a spokesman for the city, which has never released a precise figure on the subject.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Lucien Fontaine, enjoying the greatest year of his career, had to make an important decision and he had to make it before last midnight. It behooved the French-Canadian to decide whether to ante $10,000 to make Hodgen Special eligible for the Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway Nov. 23.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Supreme Court concluded the nation's second "monkey trial" today by declaring unconstitutional an Arkansas law that made it a crime to teach Charles Darwin's theory of evolution in the public schools.
A foretaste of winter swept the East Coast and inland areas from Florida to Maine yesterday in the form of gale and hurricane winds, angry seas, deep snow and blinding rain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The more than 40 Washington priests disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle for their public dissent on the birth control issue turned down today a new appeal for mediation on the ground that the Cardinal had refused to show "good faith in mediation."
PARIS, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Hanoi rejected today a South Vietnamese demand for written assurances on an agenda and the representation as a condition for participating in the Paris talks.
QUITO, Ecuador, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Rumania's Foreign Minister, Cornelio Manescu, left here today after reaching agreement with the Ecuadorean Government on the resumption of full diplomatic relations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Equatorial Guinea, a former Spanish colony on the west coast of Africa, became the 126th member of the United Nations today.

There is irony in the confrontation this week between Walter W. Heller, the chief architect of the United States's current policies of "new economics," and Prof. Milton Friedman, the principal challenger.
OPA-LOCKA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Governor Agnew, accompanied by his wife, flew into the Opa-Locka Airport tonight. They left immediately by car for Key Biscayne.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Gov. Raymond P. Shafer announced today the 10 recipients of the third annual Awards for Excellence of the Governor's Committee of 100,000 Pennsylvanians.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 12 -- With the conclusion of the McLaren-Hulme benefit series, otherwise known as the Canadian-American Challenge Cup, the Sports Car Club of America and the organizers of component races have begun roughing out the 1969 program.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Bucks held off a rally by the weary Seattle Supersonics for a 127-114 N.B.A. victory tonight.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's largest lender to corporations, abandoned yesterday its lonely position as the only major bank with a 6 per cent minimum interest charge on business loans.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12 -- A military spokesman announced tonight that the United States had lost its first jet fighter-bomber since the bombing of North Vietnam was halted 12 days ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Federal Trade Commission began a far-ranging series of hearings on consumers' problems today with assurance that no "antibusiness show" was contemplated.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- More than 150 of the 44,000 French priests have signed a letter demanding a revolution in the structure of the Roman Catholic Church.

BUDAPEST -- Janos Kadar, Hungarian boss, whose troops participated in the Czechoslovak intervention, is convinced that cold war trends are reviving in the world. "These are plain," he says. "First the extension of the Vietnam war; then the Middle East crisis and conflict; finally, this year, the political discussion on Czechoslovakia."

The election of Stephen D. Bechtel Jr., president of the Bechtel Corporation, San Francisco, to the post of chairman of the National Industrial Conference Board was announced yesterday. Formerly co-chairman of the board, he will fill the unexpired term of the late Gerald L. Phillippe, former chairman of the General Electric Company.
Five race tracks were shut down and one that had been closed, Atlantic City, suffered $100,000 in damages yesterday during the snowstorm and high winds that struck the East Coast.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- A strike by members of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra ended today when the musicians voted to accept a contract offer in which most displayed little delight.
Penn State, unbeaten in seven games and ranked third in the nation, is still the leading contender for the Lambert Trophy, symbolic of football supremacy in the East.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 -- A 14-year-old high school student was seized by the police last night when he allegedly arrived to pick up the $800 ransom demanded of his widowed mother by kidnapers he said were holding him at gunpoint.

TORONTO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- George Chuvalo moved closer to another shot at the world heavyweight boxing crown tonight with a seventh-round technical knockout over Dante Cane of Italy at Maple Leaf Gardens.

STORRS, Conn., Nov. 12 -- A total of 150 students marched peacefully out of the University of Connecticut's administration building this morning, ending a 24-hour sit-in demonstration, after the state police commissioner had threatened to use force to evict them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A recommendation to release from prison a Marine corporal convicted of murdering a Vietnamese woman has been approved by Secretary of the Navy Paul R. Ignatius, Representative Philip J. Philbin, Democrat of Massachusetts, reported today.

BONN, Nov. 12 -- The West German Ministry of the Interior disclosed today that its investigation of the right-wing extremist National Democratic party had turned up enough evidence to justify a constitutional ban on the organization.

Theodore Harmon, who allegedly stabbed Billy Daniels, the nightclub entertainer, on stage at the Latin Quarter on Nov. 5, was ordered sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for psychiatric examination. Criminal Court Judge Maurice Grey held the 43-year-old defendant without bail.

Wometco Enterprises, Inc., and the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Puerto Rico, Inc., announced yesterday they had terminated their previously announced merger talks because of "inability to reach agreement on business terms."

Hard-pressed crews of the Sanitation Department, struggling to cope with a pile-up of garbage because of the Veterans Day holiday and the continuing strike of incinerator firemen, were hampered further by yesterday's storm.
Two major railroads announced yesterday they would sharply increase the use of computers in their operations.

The Jeunesses Musicales is, as its name suggests, an organization devoted to furthering the careers of promising young artists. Last night at Carnegie Recital Hall it began its 1968-69 series with a piano recital by the young Belgian pianist Jean-Claude Vanden Eynden.
Benton Bowles has added its 17th senior vice president with the appointment of Robert F. Lyman, treasurer and assistant secretary.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon's popular vote margin over Vice President Humphrey was reduced yesterday as additional results of the Tuesday election were tabulated.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 12 -- Premier Abdullah Yaffi submitted the resignation of his four-man Cabinet to President Charles Helou. The Cabinet was formed only 23 days ago.

Plans for a Christmas flight of Apollo 8 around the moon, coming so soon after the successful completion of new manned space flights by the United States and the Soviet Union, make it plain that both nations are well-advanced in their preparations for putting a man on the moon. When that feat has been accomplished and the first human visitors have returned safely, the race for national prestige in this field will have been decided.
PRAGUE, Nov. 12 -- Exactly 12 weeks after the invasion of Czechoslovakia, Soviet troops are deployed along a line running from northern Bohemia to Slovakia.

LISBON, Nov. 12 -- Lisbon's Criminal Court for Political Affairs convicted seven young Portuguese today of "subversive activities against the state," with prison sentences ranging from 14 months to four and a half years.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12 -- The French Finance Ministry announced today an increase in the country's key lending rate to 6 per cent from 5 per cent and other severe measures aimed at restricting the flow of credit.

More than 30 suits have been filed by parents seeking to force the opening of schools by individual actions against school district superintendents, principals or custodians, invoking the State Constitution or the state law on children's right to an education.

HARTFORD, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Teachers' union members here ratified a new contract with the city today, ending the threat of another strike. They acted after receiving a promise from the City Council that money would be forthcoming to pay for salary increases and other contract items.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford's news conference today at the Pentagon:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintain a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.
FULTON, Mo., Nov. 12 -- C. P. Snow took a cold, hard look at the world today and, despairingly, found the prognosis very dim indeed.
Ludwig A. Breitenfeld, a harbor pilot, is off on an unexpected Caribbean cruise because of yesterday's storm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- President Johnson has accepted the resignation of Raymond L. Thurston, who has been Ambassador to the Somali Republic for three years. The White House, announcing this today, said Mr. Thurston was retiring after more than 30 years in the State Department's Foreign Service.
A dismissed patrolman accused the Police Department yesterday of being a peeping Tom.
The chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank called yesterday for the substitution of "a value-added tax" for the present system of corporate taxation, which imposes a levy as a percentage of profits.

Unless the city finds the money to pay for dispatchers, the experiment in group taxi riding from the Eastern Airlines shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport into Manhattan will stop at the end of this month, the chairman of the Mayor's Taxi Study Panel said yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Appointment of Calvin Ripken as manager of the Rochester Red Wings of the International Baseball League was announced jointly today by the parent Baltimore Orioles and the Red Wings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Three astronauts are to fly around the moon late next month in the most ambitious and riskiest space flight in history.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- The International Labor Organization, rather than risk a venting of acrimony over the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, postponed indefinitely today a 30-nation conference it had scheduled for next month.

MONTREAL, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Canada's 11th heart transplant was performed at the Montreal Heart Institute last night. Physicians said today that the patient, a mill worker named Aldo Martine, 43 years old, was recovering well.

Strength in the London market Monday and yesterday influenced cocoa futures prices here. New life-of-contract highs were set in all contracts, and most contracts rose the penny-a-pound daily permissible limit.
A young Greek on trial for attempting to assassinate Premier Papadopoulos last August has refused dramatically to follow the courtroom script prepared by the ruling junta.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Three members of the Advisory Board on Kosher Law Enforcement have been reappointed by state Agriculture Commissioner Don J. Wickham. The members are Rabbi Jacob Leibowitz, 386 East 46th Street, Brooklyn; Rabbi Avigdor Cyperstein, 141-04 Jewel Avenue, Flushing, Queens, and Charles Altman, 69-49 Ingram Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

PREYTOUL, Cambodia, Nov. 12 -- The three members of the International Control Commission traveled to this tiny village about a mile from the South Vietnamese border today to investigate a spillover from the Vietnam war in which American helicopter gunships allegedly killed a Cambodian peasant and injured 23.

A 40-foot trailer truck loaded with Scotch whisky was hijacked early yesterday in downtown Manhattan, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported. The hijackers took over the truck and its cargo, valued at about $100,000 near Hudson Street and held the driver hostage until noon, when he was released.
LISBON, Nov. 11 -- When things get tough, Mario Soares likes to repeat an old Portuguese saying: "He who doesn't want to be a wolf doesn't wear a wolfskin."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- An official of the Shell Oil Company said today that the company was recalling all its service station sweepstakes games because dealers could determine the winners before distributing them to customers.

A phantom luncheon with no guests and no food has been arranged for Friday at noon to benefit the Manhattan chapter of Childville, a residential treatment center for 48 boys and girls with emotional problems.
The New York Giants next play the Philadelphia Eagles. The Eagles have not won a game and may not. The Giants just beat the Dallas Cowboys, one of the best teams in pro football.

The Bronx-Whitestone Bridge bounced up and down in winds up to 70 miles an hour during yesterday's storm, leading about 30 motorists to panic and abandon their cars and forcing the span to be closed between 7 A.M. and noon.
A leading European financial authority warned here yesterday that a weak dollar in the international money markets could rob the United States of its role as a leader in world politics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Senator Charles E. Goodell said to day that he expected President-elect Richard M. Nixon to appoint a Negro to the Cabinet.
The stock market continued to display its post-election mood of confidence yesterday as prices rose on a broad front in heavy trading.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 12 -- James Earl Ray won today a postponement until next March 3 of his trial for the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 12 -- More Americans at this time favor families of four or more children than do the people of nine other widely separated nations of the world, according to the Gallup Poll.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 12 -- Mrs. Jacqueline Natoli testified today that one reason she had told so many conflicting stories about the Kavanaugh and DeFranco murders was that her life and her child's life had been threatened.

The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York reported yesterday a record $118,143,295 in new business for the 10 months ended Oct. 31. This represented a 12 per cent increase over the $105,629,500 written during the period last year. Insurance in force climbed 12 per cent to $763,500,000, from $680,000,000 ayear ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Supreme Court granted a chance for freedom today to Edgar H. Smith Jr., who in 11 years on Death Row in New Jersey has become a legal buff, an author and a friend of William F. Buckley Jr.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Negro students at San Francisco State College refused today to submit their week-long strike to arbitration as sporadic arrests continued to be made on the campus.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 8 -- In the lovely old State House where General George Washington resigned his commission to the Continental Congress on Dec. 23, 1783, Spiro T. Agnew made ready today to surrender his commission as Governor to take on the duties of Vice President of the United States.
The American Stock Exchange made another strong advance yesterday as the list closed at or near its best level of the day in active trading.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Israel upset the United States basketball team, but the United States still managed to take a 29-25 lead in gold medals over Britain today in the wheelchair Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Justice Department's Antitrust Division is looking into the recent price increase for home heating fuel oil, Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The world flyweight boxing champion, Chartchai Chionoi of Thailand, rocked the boxing world today by announcing he has decided to retire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Officials of the seven leading national higher education organizations said today that they had agreed to press Congress and the new Administration for general aid to colleges and universities.
The American Stock Exchange, where volume records keep tumbling, has set its sights on a new boom -- the visitors' market.

SAMTHONG, Laos, Nov. 12 -- Anti-Communist guerrilla bands of mountain tribesmen are slowly moving back into the isolated outposts in northeastern Laos only a few miles from the North Vietnamese border from which they were driven last spring.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Former Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that he had not passed or received any messages during a two - hour meeting yesterday with Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Former Foreign Minister Nasser el-Hani of Iraq was assassinated in Baghdad last night, the Baghdad radio reported today. It gave no details.
A Federal Court ruled in a 2-to-1 decision yesterday that Charles Goodell could fill the Senate seat of the late Robert F. Kennedy until Dec. 1, 1970.

The city has established a new employment standard by which impoverished people applying to the Human Resources Administration for clerical jobs will be granted up to 12 extra points on civil service tests.
High winds and rain hampered firemen fighting a five-alarm blaze yesterday that burned 14 stores' and 13 offices in a Queens shopping center.

Ingrid Bergman has been signed to make her first American movie in 20 years. It is "A Walk in the Spring Rain," a romantic drama that Columbia Pictures will film in the Smoky Mountains of Tennessee in the spring.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The San Francisco Warriors held the Atlanta Hawks without a field goal for the last 5 minutes 18 seconds of the third period tonight en route to a 123-108 N.B.A. victory.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Europe is still struggling, fifty years after the end of the First World War, to learn the lessons of that tragic conflict. Essentially it was a civil war within the Western world, in which Russia lost 1,700,000 dead, France 1,357,800, the British 908,371, and Italy 650,000; but the spirit of nationalism, which produced this frightful disaster, is rising again five decades later.
Interest rates, especially on corporate bonds, climbed sharply higher yesterday amid growing pessimism over the outlook for fixed-income securities prices.
In the hearts of ad men everywhere there must be a warm feeling at the news that Hershey, the country's most famous holdout, is joining the advertiser fold. It's nice to be wanted.

The program notes for Respighi's "The Birds," performed last night at Philharmonic Hall by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Seiji Ozawa, quoted a remark by Verdi on the state of music in his day: "To return to the past would be progress."

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Bill Daly, manager of the former lightweight champion, Carlos Ortiz, said today his fighter planned to go after the title he lost to Teo Cruz in June. Daly said Ortiz recently returned from a trip to Vietnam. He added that Ortiz would take one or two preparatory fights prior to challenging Cruz.

ON her dressing room door is a framed picture of a broad sweep of beach with a couple embracing in the distance and one printed word, "Love." And somehow it sums up what Pearl Bailey is all about as well as one word can.

DENVER, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Denver Rockets took advantage of a cold third quarter by the Oakland Oaks and defeated the Western Division leaders, 134-127, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

A massive northeaster carrying winds of near-hurricane force sent heavy tides crashing inland yesterday, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of families from coastal areas in New Jersey. Long Island and Connecticut.

LISBON, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- A medical bulletin on former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar said today his condition remained stationary. The bulletin said his blood pressure and pulse were regular after a stroke.
PRAGUE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Vera Caslavska, Czechoslovakia's Olympic gymnastics queen, will visit Japan at the end of this year for a series of exhibition performances.

OTTAWA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Revenue Minister Jean-Pierre Cote underwent heart surgery today at the National Defense Medical Center. A medical bulletin later said he was in satisfactory condition. He is 42 years old.
The atomic-powered merchant ship Savannah sailed yesterday for Mediterranean ports on her first voyage with a new charge of nuclear fuel.

An augmented senior team at Interstate Department Stores, Inc., one of the country's largest discountstore chain, has some big plans this year, including a doubling of the store expansion rate and a heightened inclination toward moving into specialized discount stores.
There is nothing so melodic as the fortissimo sound of a New York success, Aleksandr Slobodyanik, 26-year-old Soviet pianist, acknowledged yesterday with a broad, boyish smile.
CHRYSLER attracted attention in Wall Street yesterday as a mammoth block of 531,000 shares crossed the tape at 65 1/2. It closed at 66 5/8, off 1 5/8.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Five days a week Yoko Tatsumi goes to the fifth grade at the Stephenson School here She likes it.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- South Vietnamese officials took the position today that the United States would be making a political mistake and taking a serious risk if it went ahead with Vietnam negotiations in the absence of Saigon.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union launched today Cosmos 253 in its series of unmanned satelites, the Tass press agency reported. Tass said the craft was placed in orbit with an initial period of 89.9 minutes. Its maximum distance from the earth is 220 miles and minimum, 127.9.
WALTHAM, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Brandeis University announced today a program of reciprocal study with foreign universities enabling students to receive joint degrees from the cooperating institutions.
Calvin Hill, Yale's all-Ivy halfback, was named Ivy League back of the week yesterday for his strong performance in the Bulldogs' 30-13 victory over Penn last Saturday.

"The Misanthrope" will be given 11 nonsubscription performances between Dec. 20 and Jan. 2 at the Lyceum Theater. APA-Phoenix has been presenting the Moliere play, as adapted by Richard Wilbur, in repertory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United States charged North Vietnam today with distorting and failing to live up to the terms of the agreement that led to the end of American bombing of North Vietnam 12 days ago.

CURACAO, Netherlands Antilles Nov. 14 -- The American Association of Port Authorities has decided to expand its guidance program for the training of professional port managers for Latin-American countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The four statements filed today brought the reported total of contributions to President - elect Richard M. Nixon's campaign to about $12-million.

Twenty parking lot employes at Kennedy International Airport were indicted yesterday in connection with a complicated parking check transfer scheme in which, according to the Queens District Attorney, as much as $750,000 may have been siphoned off.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Three blind dolphins flopped into a tank at Steinhart Aquarium today after a 12,000-mile flight from their Ganges River home in India. Dr. Earl S. Herald, aquarium director, accompanied them aboard a Pan American cargo jet from Karachi.
The Manhattan College cross-country team easily triumphed over Fordham University, 16-46, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
The Dial Press Inc., issued a statement calling unfounded charges by a British publisher that it infringed a copyright when it published Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsy's novel "The Cancer Ward" last month.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian university here was closed indefinitely today after demonstrations yesterday in which 19 students were injured and 26 arrested. The students are demanding the dissolution of the Moslem Brotherhood, a political group.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 13 (AP) -- A 24-year-old mother of three children, who was injured in an automobile crash, died today after her husband had refused on religious grounds to allow doctors to give her a blood transfusion.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 13 -- Traffic delays and other inconveniences to motorists using state highways on Long Island were expected as a result of an announcement today by the Long Island State Parkway police that they would provide "super" enforcement of traffic laws starting tomorrow.

KENT, Ohio, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Members of two groups marched around the Kent State University campus tonight after staging a demonstration to protest recruiting efforts by the Oakland, Calif., Police Department on campus. The groups were the Students for a Democratic Society and the Black United Students.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- A formal dinner in the Conrad Hilton Hotel honoring Edward H. Levi, who will be inaugurated tomorrow as president of the University of Chicago, was disrupted 25 times tonight by shouts of student demonstrators, who rose from places among the guests.
TORONTO, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- An unassisted goal by Derek Sanderson with 1 minute 4 seconds left gave the Boston Bruins a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight.

Brahms's "Magelone" song cycle is a problematic work, and this apparently accounts for the fact that it is seldom performed. Last night it was given one of its rare presentations here by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau in Carnegie Hall.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 13 (AP) -- John Nerud, the trainer and part owner of Dr. Fager, was named today 1968 recipient of the "Big Sport of Turfdom" award by the Turf Publicists of America, Inc. Nerud is the first trainer to win the award given annually by the organization of race track publicity and public relations personnel in the United States, Canada and Mexico. The presentation will be made in New York on Dec. 3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Robert G. Baker, the former Senate staff official who was convicted of tax evasion last year, has asked for a new trial on the grounds that evidence used against him has since been declared "tainted."

The Trust Company of Georgia, based in Atlanta, one of a small number of medium-sized banks that had been post ing a 6 per cent prime, or minimum interest rate on business loans, said yesterday that it was boosting its basic loan charge to 6 1/4 per cent.
SAIGON, South Vietnaw, Nov. 14 -- The United States command said this morning that it had evidence of five new incidents of enemy activity in the demilitarized zone.

MATSUYAMA, Japan, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals spotted the Yomiuri Giants four runs in the first inning today but pecked away to score a 7-5 victory. It was their 11th victory in 14 games in Japan.
ROME, Nov. 13 -- Thousands of high school students demonstrated in the streets of Rome today, causing traffic jams and disorder, to back their demands for school reform and meeting halls.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- An Air Force spokesman conceded today that the Pentagon might end up paying the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation double the original contract estimate for building 115 C-5A military cargo jets.
Seas flattened, winds abated, trains and ferries ran on schedule, even the sun came out for a few minutes yesterday as the metropolitan area returned to normal after Tuesday's severe northeaster.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Three Negroes were shot to death and two others were wounded today by five other Negroes who burst into a community civil rights headquarters in the Roxbury District.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bowie regained the coveted January horse racing days in Maryland today, but Pimlico complained of being left out in the cold with dates in the spring.

EAST MEADOW, L. I., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Dominick Sirico, 46 years old, of North Lindenhurst, was killed yesterday when the cement truck he was driving went out of control and struck a tree. He lived at 352 Forsythe Avenue.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Manford Byrd Jr. was named today as the first Negro deputy superintendent of the Chicago school system. A meeting of the Board of Education was told Mr. Byrd's appointment culminated a "nationwide and systemwide search" during the last 18 months.
LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Gerald Battrick of Britain romped to a 6-1, 6-4, 6-2 victory over Arthur Ashe in the British indoor tennis championship today.

The Allegro Ball, a benefit for the Queens Symphony Orchestra, will be held Saturday at the Sheraton Inn near La Guardia Airport in Queens. Mrs. Isaac Allen, a founder and past president of the orchestra's auxiliary, will be guest of honor.

Mrs. Benjamin Berkey received the Casita Maria Gold Medallion yesterday afternoon during a reception at the 322 East 57th Street home of Mrs. John T. Collins, president of the Casita Maria settlement.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- President de Gaulle placed his prestige behind France's crisis-ridden currency today and vowed that the franc would not be devalued. The President's state ment, made at his weekly Cabinet meeting, came as reports swept financial capitals that the franc faced devaluation -- if not immediately, then by early next year.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- Pope Paul VI today sharply reproved Roman Catholic priests and laymen who have tried to establish sacremental links with non-Roman Christians while huge gulfs of doctrinal difference remain.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Art Williams stole a pass and scored on a layup with 16 seconds to go and John Block cashed in on a technical foul as the San Diego Rockets rallied tonight to edge the Detroit Pistons, 122-120, in a National Basketball Association contest.
The women's division of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith will hold a luncheon and fashion show next Thursday at the New York Hilton.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Britain's troublesome trade deficit took a turn for the worse in October following two months of heartening improvement.

Pepsico International has made a grant of $25,000 to Experiments in Art and Technology, a non-profit organization, to explore educational techniques for communicating with young people. Experiments in Art and Technology was formed in 1966 "to involve the artist with the relevant forces shaping the technological environment."
NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 -- Zulfikar Ali Bhutto seemed to have sealed his own fate yesterday when he refused to appeal to students in West Pakistan to end their anti-Government protests.

Army Pvt. William S. Brakefield, a pacifist who was given sanctuary for six days by City College students in the Finley Student Center, was found guilty yesterday of criminal trespass in the third degree.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Pamela Ann Anicich, 18 years old, was selected as queen of the 1969 Tournament of Roses. Pamela, a freshman at Pasadena City College, was chosen from seven finalists. Among them was the first Negro ever named to the queen's court. She is Sylvia Mario Peebles, 17, Altadena, a senior in high school who is studying to be a philharmonic orchestra conductor.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- A charge of obtaining credit by fraud against Thad Spencer, an American heavyweight boxer, was dismissed today by a magistrate at Clerkenwell, London. Spencer had pleaded innocent to the charge of obtaining $176 by fraud from Charles Julian Wills in connection with the renting of an apartment.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Officials here confirmed that the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain were eager to see Dr. Jarring continue his mission past the Nov. 30 deadline.

The 1968 Industrial Award of Excellence of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing was presented yesterday to the Union Oil Company of California for outstanding contribution to motor sports and the motoring public.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Six Federal career officials were named as recipients today of the 1968 Rockefeller Public Service Awards. The awards, each carrying a cash stipend of $10,000, will be presented Dec. 4 in Washington.

SEATTLE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Joe Caldwell led a third-quarter spurt for the Atlanta Hawks tonight as the Hawks defeated the Seattle Supersonics, 142-113, in a National Basketball Association game. Caldwell got 11 of his 26 points in the period, hitting on five of six from the field.
DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- Nine police officers, including two sergeants and seven patrolmen, were suspended today after an investigation into the beating of Negro teen-agers.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The South Korean Government reported today that a second band of North Korean guerrillas landed on South Korea's east coast two weeks ago, bringing the total number of invaders in the area this month to 60, twice the number reported earlier.
A fourth-quarter goal by Demetri Ellis gave New York University's soccer team a 2-1 victory over City College of New York yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 12 -- King Faisal showed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran a special mark of respect today by flying from Riyadh, the capital on Saudi Arabia's continental plateau, to the Red Sea port of Jidda to attend a dinner given for the Shah by the Iranian Ambassador.

The man who was convicted in the slaying last year of Dr. Elena Gall, Hunter College professor and authority on the education of physically handicapped children, was sentenced yesterday to two terms of life imprisonment and one of 20 years to life.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Israel and Jordanian forces bombarded each other across the Jordan River for more than four hours today, using tanks, artillery, mortars and small arms in two battles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- The 18,700-student San Francisco State College was closed indefinitely tonight by its president, Dr. Robert R. Smith, after a week of violence that culminated in a faculty vote to suspend classes.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Danny O'Shea scored at 10:39 of the third period to give the Minnesota Stars a 4-3 National Hockey League victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.

GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- The failure of the United States to abolish its controversial American Selling Price system for assessing customs duties on benzoid chemicals was deplored today by Olivier Long, executive head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Long after most midtown offices had gone dark, the lights continued to blaze during recent nights on the 61st floor of the Chrysler Building, where a dozen editors, blacks and whites, worked frantically to put out a new weekly newspaper called Manhattan Tribune.

John R. Bunting, president of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, and Reavis Cox, professor of marketing at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, were named yesterday to the board of The Villager, Inc., a diversified apparel company.
Leaders of the State Legislature yesterday called an emergency meeting for today of a special committee to consider ways of ending the city's crippling teacher strike.
DR. ARIEL MENGARINI of New York, the pereptually optimistic tactician, outwitted a strong field in the recent Westchester Experts Open Tourney at the Roger Smith Hotel, White Plains.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 13 -- A new method of treating sewage with radiation that would lower the cost of disposal and reduce odor and air pollution is under study by the city of Chicago, it was reported here today.

A cooperative that includes more than 50 meat processing companies will be asked by its chairman at a special meeting today to dissolve itself and end plans to shift the city's meat distribution industry to Hunts Point in the Bronx.

Vince Costello's knee has been improving the last few weeks to the point where there was no excess fluid for the doctor to drain yesterday. But Henry Davis's work at linebacker has been improving also and that factor could keep Costello on the inactive list.

Three law school graduates yesterday challenged the constitutionality of questionnaires that the State Appellate Division's Committee on Character and Fitness requires them to fill out for admission to the state bar.

THERE was a time when all boys were taught to hunt by their fathers, but today, when more and more men and women whose parents never hunted are turning to the sport, there had to be a substitute for the father's example and his posthunt storytelling beside the fireplace.
Young Rubican has added Roby Harrington 3d to its roster of senior vice presidents.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 13 -- Former Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was arrested today in Lahore, capital of West Pakistan, on a charge of inciting the people, particularly students, to create disorder by resorting to violence.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Union urged the United Nations today to disregard what it called the transitory stage of Moscow's relations and admit Communist China to membership.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States established diplomatic relations today with Panama's month-old military junta but withheld resumption of its $14.2-million program of aid to the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Bobby Hull scored his 10th goal of the season, with 17 seconds remaining, tonight to end a four-game Chicago losing streak as the Black Hawks beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-5.
In an era of "black power" and "white power," the nation's real estate establishment was urged yesterday to use "real estate power" to help implement new laws and court decisions on open housing.
SANTIAGO, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth planted a tree in a public park today and inaugurated a British-financed annex to a vocational school as mementos of her visit.
ATHENS, Nov. 13 -- Greece's army-backed regime appears to have adopted a tougher line on internal security, as a deterrent to increased hostility by its domestic opponents.
Ned Irish, the president of Madison Square Garden, was happy. Walter Devereux, the president of the National Horse Show, was happy.

PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States plans to send two Mariner spacecraft into orbit around Mars in 1971 to seek close camera views of the red planet that will help find a site for a landing mission in 1973.
Richard M. Nixon intends at this time not to allow his personal White House staff to dominate the functions or control the direction of the major agencies and bureaus of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Commerce Department will approve a foreign trade zone for Bayonne, N. J., this month, an aide of Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, Democrat of New Jersey, said today.
The London Stock Exchange kept its bright tone yesterday despite some disappointment over Britain's trade figures for October.
A $650,000 Ford Foundation grant was announced yesterday to start expanding a New York City program for building Puerto Rican leadership into a national program.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 13 -- Winds with a velocity of up to 40 miles an hour at times did not blow chalk-players -- or horses -- too much good tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. In particular, they appeared to deter Carmine Abbatiello the most at the most inopportune moments.

EMERALDS or rubies by the pebble, opals or aquamarines by the chunk may now be bought, along with a lot of other stones-in-the-rough, at Bloomingdale's. The gems can then be taken to a jewelry designer to be cut and trimmed to fulfill a customer's dream.
A Federal jury of 10 men and two women yesterday convicted a 25-year-old divinity student of refusing to be inducted into the Armed Forces.

Hyman Bress, a Canadian violinist who has given several recitals here since his New York debut in 1957, appeared at Philharmonic Hall last night to perform a program made up of pieces he has played here previously. It consisted of Tartini's "Devil's Trill" Sonata, Bach's unaccompanied Chaconne in D minor, Bartok's Sonata No. 1, Brahms's Sonata in D minor and Ravel's "Tzigane."
DORADO, P. R., Nov. 13 -- Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew cheered at least some of the islanders here today by saying that he favored statehood for Puerto Rico.

DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- The highest ranking Negro physician in the American Public Health Association today said that the current emphasis on medical care and health services for the nation's poor and black populations was "developing into exploitation."

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- North Dakota State, the nation's No. 2 small-college football team, today was invited by the National Collegiate Athletic Association to play in its third Pecan Bowl on Dec. 14 at Arlington, Tex. The Bisons have completed a perfect 9-0 won-lost season.
A PLEA to protect the dog buyer was made yesterday at the monthly meeting of the Dog Fanciers Club at the Overseas Press Club.
Paperboard production rose 7.2 per cent to 503.8 tons last week from 469.8 tons in the corresponding 1967 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.
FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The police said today they had found folios of Leonardo da Vinci's 15th-century designs and inventions, which were stolen from a Milan museum in June.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Possible sabotage at a plant that manufactures helicopters used in Vietnam is under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Joe D. Jamieson, special agent, would not elaborate.

As is their custom, members of the United Nations devoted the opening weeks of this year's General Assembly debate to telling each other how highly they prize the world organization and how deeply devoted they are to its objective of promoting world peace. Now comes the moment of truth.

Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas says: "To be in the service of one's country is one of the most rewarding experiences a man can have. There are mo ments of great satisfaction. . . there are also moments of loneliness and frustration.
PNOMPENH, Cambodian, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Foreign journalists will be allowed to visit Cambodia only once very five years, the Government said today.
HOUSTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Walter Charles Carey, 43 years old, of Carmel, N. Y., who received a new lung in a multiple transplant less than one week ago, died tonight in St. Luke's Hospital.
In an evening of vapid vocalism and melancholy melodramatics by the New York City Opera at the State Theater, the debut of Timo Callio as Canio in "Pagliacci" stood out sharply.
The City Center of Music and Drama will present a two-hour program of short, animated films at the City Center Theater for five days starting Nov. 26.

ATLANTA Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia today shipped a basset hound with a "sad face and long ears" to a North Kingstown, R. I., man who had written the Governor that he wanted a dog to be his friend.

ANNA SOKOLOW is a prophet of doom. I can never see one of her performances without feeling guilty in the first place, distressed in the second, and wondering whether I remembered to latch the door of the apartment in the third.

TORONTO, Nov. 13 -- Ontario's Royal College of Dental Surgeons, reversing an earlier ruling, has decided to let refugee dentists from Czechoslovakia take examinations to determine whether they are qualified to practice in this province.

Wilkes, unbeaten in seven games this season, took the lead yesterday in the race for the Lambert Bowl, symbolic of supremacy among the East's small-college football teams. Wilkes took the lead after Kings Point had lost its first game of the season, 7-0, to Lafayette Saturday.

Eugene A. March has been elected vice president-group executive of Colt Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Mr. March will direct steel-making at the Midland and Syracuse divisions of Crucible Steel, which was acquired last month by Colt. Ralph Mitchell Jr., chairman and president of the Central Transformer Corporation, acquired Nov. 4, was elected a director of Colt.

Ben Shahn has given Channel 13 a limited edition of a lithograph for use in the TV station's fund-raising efforts, it was announced yesterday by John Kiermaeier, station president. The picture is in black and white, with a Hebrew letter in red.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Stories about the burning of Mrs. Judith Kavanaugh's automobile the day she was murdered and the collecting of a $2,000 payment a few days later were recited today at the DeFranco murder trial.

MALONE, N. Y., Nov. 13 (AP) -- "The Rattlesnake," a solen Frederic Remington bronze sculpture valued at more than $15,000, has been recovered. It was apparently taken from the Berkshire School in Sheffield, Mass., last summer.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- America's golfing "odd couple" -- tranquil 48-year-old Julius Boros and ebullient Lee Trevino, 20 years younger -- clinched their position as favorites to win the 16th annual World Cup tournament today.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Mothers protesting welfare allowances for winter clothing reached the State House today in their campaign for more liberal benefits.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange scored their third straight advance yesterday in moderately active trading.
MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 14 (Repters) -- The Russian spacecraft Zond 6 passed around the moon early this morning and is believed to be heading back to earth, the Jodrell Bank Observatory said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Transition is the rage in Washington now. It will be hard for President-elect Nixon and harder still for the new men accompanying him, but is hardest of all on the permanent residents who want to stay in touch with the magic and excitement of the city's political life.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Mayor Carl B. Stokes, evaluating his first year in office, said today that despite many problems he has Cleveland "on the move." Mr. Stokes became the first Negro mayor of a major American city in November, 1967.

The civilized way to provide arriving passengers with taxicabs at such points of great demand as air terminals and railroad stations is to have a dispatcher assign them in turn. This practice, common in many cities in this country and abroad, is the only system that is fair to all -- women with children, the elderly and infirm, the handicapped.
PRAGUE, Nov. 13 -- Amid growing tension in Prague tonight, Czechoslovakia's Communist leaders prepared to convene their party's Central Committee for a crucial session tomorrow morning.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- David P. O'Brien, 21 years old, of Cambridge, the first draft card burner to take his case to the Supreme Court, only to lose an appeal and begin a six-year Federal prison term, was set free today because of a "change of attitude."
BRUSSELS, Nov. 13 -- The United States has taken an intricate action designed to ease financial pressures in Belgium.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Trainer Melvin (Sunshine Calvert, acting as agent for an undisclosed party, paid $290,000 today for a 5-year-old mare in foal to Tom Rolfe at the Keeneland fall sale of thoroughbreds.

Big agencies in the future will be handling small advertisers who are in need of all the services big agencies provide. At the same time, big advertisers, who by then will have most of these services themselves, will be going to little outside creative cells for the advertising they need.

Samuel Schiffer, a 65-yearold consulting engineer, has been arrested on charges of demanding $600 from a construction company; allegedly to pay off inspectors at the Department of Buildings, Commissioner of Investigation Arnold G. Fraiman, disclosed yesterday.

EXCEPT for President John F. Kennedy, who seemed instantly to comprehend the magnitude of the problem, almost everyone in the room was dumbfounded. Teodoro Moscoso, then the new head of the fledgling Alliance for Progress, was exercising a rare chance to ask the President for help on all sorts of matters, and what was his first request?

LONDON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Sir Robert Menzies, former Prime Minister of Australia, said here today that he was learning to walk and talk again after a stroke early in September. Sir Robert and his wife, Pattie, were sailing from Tilbury near London for home aboard the liner Iberia.

A group of American television newsmen reported yesterday that they had followed a Vietcong bicycle convoy from a food-supply center and staging area in Cambodia to an enemy encampment in South Vietnam, less than 50 miles from Saigon.

"YELLOW SUBMARINE," which opened yesterday, at the Forum and Tower East, is the Beatles' first feature length cartoon, designed, for the most part beautifully, by Heinz Edelmann, in styles ranging through Steinberg, Arshile Gorky, Bob Godfrey (of the short film "The Do It Yourself Cartoon Kit"), the Sgt. Pepper album cover, and -- mainly, really -- the spirit and conventions of the Sunday comic strip.
BALTIMORE -- The Morris Whitehursts love to travel. They have an eclectic interest in wines and food. And for the last 16 years they've had a business that permits them to satisfy both.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 13 -- A Federal District Court judge returned a $1,021,500 judgment here today against the White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and three Natchez white men for the slaying of an aged Negro, Ben Chester White, in 1966.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Dr. Howard F. Miller, secretary of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, has been named director of Social Development Planning for New York State. The appointment was announced today by Social Services Commissioner George K. Wyman.
Joe Namath will return Sunday to Oakland where the Raider pass-pushers, he says, "all want to hurt a quarterback."

FREEHOLD, N. J. Nov. 13 (AP) -- Royal Smokey captured the feature trot today at Freehold Raceway. Driven by Bob Collins. Royal Smokey raced the mile in 2:11 4/5 and returned $5.60, $3.80 and $2.80 for $2 across the board. Speed-win was second and Big Question third.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Gary Jarrett slapped a 25-foot goal into the net with 48 seconds remaining to play tonight to lift the Oakland Seals over the Detroit Red Wings, 2-1, in the National Hockey League.
HOUSTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Apollo 10 spacecraft, which will be launched in the second quarter of 1969, will fly within nine miles of the moon and may make a lunar landing.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 13 -- The Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia and the May-June strikes in France appear to have strengthened the willingness of Western Europe's nations to work together.
An increase in airline delays was forecast yesterday by Michael Rock, board chairman of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 13 -- Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois, said today that President-elect Richard M. Nixon would give Atlantic unity priority over improved relations with the Soviet Union.
The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York held its annual campaign reception in the Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf - Astoria yesterday afternoon.

A stockholder request to pay off $146,000 in preferred dividend arrears in order to return control of the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation to owners of common shares was turned aside by management yesterday at the annual meeting.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Bullets lost a 13-point fourth-period lead and then bounced back in the closing minutes to salvage a 115-111 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Royals. The result snapped a six-game Cincinnati winning streak.
BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- A policeman and a Black Panther were wounded in a street gun battle today after a car carrying three men was pulled over for a traffic violation.
The election of Robert D. Stuart Jr., to the board of United Air Lines was announced yesterday by G. E. Keck, United's president. His election increases the board membership to 15.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will make her final trip around the nation as First Lady later this month "to get reacquainted with the America behind the headlines."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board announced approval today of the application of Central Bancorporation, Inc., Cincinnati, to become a bank holding company, by acquiring control of the Central Trust Company of Cincinnati and the Citizens National Bank of Marietta, Ohio.

Yorkshire Potash, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation, said yesterday it planned to spend $60-million to $72-million to develop a potash mine and refinery in England near Whitby, Yorkshire.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- The South Vietnamese Government clung to its formula for the Paris peace talks today amid some signs that President Nguyen Van Thieu might soon make another shift in policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Drew Pearson said today that President-elect Richard M. Nixon had consulted a "psychiatrist" when he was Vice President, and he quoted the doctor as having said that Mr. Nixon "did have a problem -- not standing up under great pressure."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- With less than one-half of 1 per cent error in predicting President-elect Richard M. Nixon's national vote total, the polls were more accurate this year than ever before, Dr. George Gallup told delegates to the annual Associated Press Managing Editors convention today.

Trying to snap a four-game losing streak and to begin pursuit of the teams they must catch to make the playoffs,the New York Knickerbockers face the Cincinnati Royals at Madison Square Garden tonight at 8:35 o'clock in the first of three straight National Basketball Association home games for the Knicks.

THE Los Angeles Dodgers announced yesterday what Walter O'Malley, their owner, had decided before the last baseball season ended: the dimensions of Dodger Stadium in Chavez Ravine would be altered to help the hitters.

Mayor Lindsay has begun a personal campaign to mobilize the public -- including union members -- to force the United Federation of Teachers to accept one of the many school strike settlement proposals that it has already rejected, according to sources close to the negotiations.
The election of Ralph F. Leach as a director of the Niagara Mohawk Corporation was announced yesterday by Earle J. Machold, chairman of the utility's board of directors.
BERLIN, Nov. 13 -- The East Germans have released six of seven youths sentenced last month for demonstrating against the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, it was learned today.

CAIRO, Nov. 13 -- Highly placed sources said today that the United States the Soviet Union, France and Britain had recently been urging Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations envoy, to take a more active role in his efforts to achieve a political settlement in the Middle East.
The selection of Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals as the most valuable player in the National League yesterday put an official stamp of the Year of the Pitcher on the 1968 baseball season.

Builders who have been buying up property in a down-town Manhattan urban renewal area lost their fight yesterday for a delay in city consideration of the renewal project which includes a seaport museum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- An antismoking organization asked the Federal Communications Commission today to hold up the license renewal of four California television and radio stations because of alleged violation of the commission's "fairness doctrine" by three other stations in Indiana.
