LISBON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The Portuguese Navy, with three escort ships recently commissioned, will take part in maneuvers with other countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for the first time in many years, it was announced today.

Herman Kahn, who has been on the staff of the National Archives in Washington for 19 years, has been appointed associate librarian for manuscripts and archives at the Yale University Library, it was announced yesterday by Prof. John M. Blum, the library's acting director.
The Semet-Solvay division of the Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it would increase its price for foundry coke by $1 a ton effective tomorrow.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 13 (AP) -- North Vietnamese troops have heavily reinforced the Ho Chi Minh Trail through Laos to South Vietnam, the Laotian Army's chief of staff said today.
Conjecture that widened Paris peace talks on Vietnam may begin shortly buoyed the stock market yesterday as prices advanced for the third consecutive session in fairly active trading.

The Meadow Stable's even-money Queen's Double, unable to win since her driving victory in last August's Spinaway at Saratoga, was under a stirring drive again yesterday in capturing the $28,800 Demoiselle at Aqueduct

SAN ANTONIA, Tex. Nov. 13 (AP) -- The spokesman for 68 Roman Catholic priests seeking their Archbishop's resignation said today that a local commission set up to study the troubled San Antonio Archdiocese was not what they wanted.

Roy Rubin, whose Long Island University team captured the small-college basketball championship last year and earned a National Invitation Tournament berth, was invited yesterday to coach Israel's team for the eighth World Maccabiah Games.
The appointment of Leonor F. Loree II as executive vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in charge of corporate activities, was announced yesterday. He formerly was a senior vice president.

Stuart G. Schwartz, chairmar of the Committee for Democratic Voters, called yesterday for all reform-minded Democrats to combine in one organization to support a single reform slate for Mayor and other major offices i nthe 1969 city election
NEWARK, Nov. 13 (AP) -The Legislature was urged tonight to repeal all criminal sanctions dealing with abortions.

Corn futures rose yesterday, after the Department of Agriculture estimated a slightly smaller corn crop than it had forecast a month earlier. The latest tally indicated 4.4 billion bushels as of Nov. 1, compared with a forecast of 4.7 billion as of Oct. 1.

OLATHE, Kan., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Grant Nash, 11 years old, who spent more than four months in a coma, has recovered consciousness, his mother said today. The boy revived suddenly Nov. 5, but Dr. Robert Nash, his physician father, kept it secret until he could determine whether the improvement was permanent and until his wife returned from vacation.

NEWELL, W. Va., Nov. 13 (AP) -- A barn fire at Waterford Park race track killed 20 horses early this morning and left two horses so badly burned they were put to death later. Three other horses also may have to be destroyed.
TEL AVIV, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The United States headed the unofficial medals table in the XVII paraplegic games, which ended here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church expressed "grave concern" today at the growing number of priests who were leaving the ministry to marry.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- James T. Harris Jr. of New Rochelle, N. Y., will become executive director of the National Catholic Conference for Interracial Justice on Jan. 1, with headquarters in Chicago, it was announced here today.

The election of Thomas M. Phillips as a director of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company was announced yesterday. He is senior partner in the Houston law firm of Baker, Botts, Shepherd Coates. He will replace Francis G. Coates on the Texas Gulf Sulphur board. Mr. Coates has resigned for health reasons.

The board of directors of the American National Theater and Academy approved the recommendation yesterday of its executive committee to seek an affiliation with the National Council on the Arts. Of the 60 members on the board, 56 members were in favor of the step; the remaining four did not vote.

The manuscript of Igor Stravinsky's first composition in the jazz idiom -- his "Ragtime" of 1918 -- was auctioned yesterday for $4,750 in a sale of musical, literary and historical manuscripts at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Richard M. Nixon's selection of Bryce N. Harlow as his first major appointee is believed here to reflect the President-elect's appreciation of his position as the first man in 120 years to begin his White House tenure with both Congressional houses controlled by the opposition party.

A report on alleged ties between Vincent F. Abano Jr., the Manhattan Republican chairman, and figures in the Marcus kickback conspiracy, and on charges that the county chairman mishandled party funds is expected to be submitted to Mayor Lindsay late next week.
FALLS CHURCH, Va., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall has bought a $52,000 home in the all-white community of Lake Barcroft near here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen says he expects Chief Justice Earl Warren to administer the Presidential oath to Richard M. Nixon on Jan. 20 despite the past political differences between the two.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- United Nations officials said today that additional emergency food would be provided for Nigerian war victims under a new agreement with the Lagos Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The latest tabulation by United Press International showed these figures today for the three major Presidential candidates in the Nov. 5 election.

For the first time in its 52 years as a national voluntary birth-control agency, Planned Parenthood-World Population yesterday approved unanimously a policy recognizing abortion and sterilization as proper medical procedures.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- High-ranking military officers said today that self-defense was the rule of thumb that American troops had been ordered to use in deciding whether to direct air and artillery attacks into North Vietnam and the demilitarized zone.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 13 -- Max Elbin, president of the Professional Golfers' Association, said today that golf would suffer if the dissident touring pros and the P.G.A. "don't get back together."
U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc. and the Johns-Manville Corporation are holding exploratory talks regarding a possible mer ger of the two companies, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The creation of a Federal agency to collect and disseminate information about fraudulent business activities was proposed today at a hearing of the Federal Trade Commission into the need for more consumer protection.

John Kennedy, a well-traveled infielder, has been sold to the Seattle Pilots by the New York Yankees, reducing the Yankee roster to 37 men plus four in military service. The price was undisclosed but probably in the waiver range of $20,000.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 13 -- Frank Wille, New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced plans today to require mutual savings banks to significantly expand the amount of information they make available to the public, including a full statement of income and expenses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Justice filed an antitrust suit today against a major manufacturer of men's clothing, seeking to force the sale of 33 companies operating 48 stores acquired by the company since 1964.
Dun Bradstreet, Inc., announced yesterday a computerized data service to provide market profiles on 3 million of the nation's leading businesses.

A grand jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court returned indictments yesterday against three Yemini Arabs being held in connection with an alleged plot to murder Richard M. Nixon, but the indictment failed to mention the President-elect.

The American Football League announced playoff plans yesterday in case of a two-way or three-way tie in the Western Division. Kansas City leads in the West by half a game over Oakland and San Diego. The Chiefs have an 8-2 won-lost record and the other teams 7-2.
BONN, Nov. 13 -- West Germany's Finance Minister, FranzJosef Strauss, today denied reports that the Government was secretly planning a revaluation of the mark.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for the September quarter and for the nine months ended Sept. 30.
REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., (AP) -- A grounded barge was the center of salvage claims today, as leakage from its cargo of oil stained the beaches of this Delaware Bay resort community.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- President Johnson approved a national contingency plan today, the purpose of which is to reduce damage from oil spills resulting from such things as the wrecking of the Torrey Canyon off the coast of England last year and the Ocean Eagle off Puerto Rico last March.
Now that almost all of the votes have been counted and the excitement and exhaustion of the campaign have passed, the main outlines of this extraordinary election are clear.

Ralph S. Saul, president of the American Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that existing regulations on corporate disclosure are inadequate and said his exchange may issue further guidelines on the subject.

In a surprising move that reflected the substantial rise in interest rates over the last weekend, the Tennessee Valley Authority yesterday decided to postpone its $80-million bond sale scheduled at 11 A.M.

About 50 angry Negro and Puerto Rican union leaders warned the president of the New York City Central Labor Council last night that they would lead a racial revolt within the labor movement unless they were consulted in advance of strikes affecting their communities.
The Ziegfeld Club will hold its 31st Charity Ball tomorrow at the Pierre. The club, organized by former members of the Ziegfeld Follies, aids needy theater women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Pentagon announced today that areas in Wyoming and Montana would be surveyed as potential antimissile sites for the nation's Sentinel defense system. The locations are near Cheyenne, Wyo., and Great Falls, Mont.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Fred Patek, a Pittsburgh Pirate infielder, underwent surgery today at Presbyterian-University Hospital for removal of a small bone from his left wrist. The bone was fractured when Patek was hit by a pitch from Don Drysdale, a Los Angeles hurler, last June 18.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintains a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- The police dislodged defiant students from two schools at the University of Barcelona today when they met to discuss measures by the authorities banning mass meetings.

WARSAW, Nov. 13 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev said today the invasion of Czechoslovakia had thwarted the plans of "imperialist wolves in sheep's clothing" who sought to overthrow Communism in East Germany and Poland as well as in Czechoslovakia.

Joseph Traficante, the mandolin-playing minstrel who was arrested in Washington Square Park last Sept. 1 in the middle of a ballad has been acquitted of a charge that he illegally played a musical instrument in thte park.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon took his family and some friends to see "George M" at the Palace Theater last night. He was given a standing ovation by the audience and, in turn, warmly applauded such George M. Cohan classics as "Give My Regards to Broadway," "Mary," "Over There" and "You're a Grand Old Flag."

MEXICO CITY -- The Periferico is the road that girdles Mexico City the way the Belt Parkway does Brooklyn. It has cloverleafs and underpasses, just like the Belt. But for about 11 miles of its length, along the road leading to the Olympic Village, it has one thing the Belt Parkway does not have -- sculpture.

Richard E. Elliffe and John J. White of the class of 1912 are among the past captains of New York University sports teams who will be honored this evening by N.Y.U.'s Varsity Club at its annual dinner.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The following men from the New York area were identified by the Defense Department today as having been killed in Vietnam:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Johnson Administration is worried, authoritative sources here say, that the "Paris understanding," under which the bombing of North Vietnam was stopped and broadened peace talks scheduled, seems to be in danger of falling apart.

Pan American World Airways announced plans yesterday for a $50-million four-tier expansion of its terminal at Kennedy International Airport. The combined facility will have six and a half times as much space as the "umbrella" terminal the airline now uses.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Robert S. McNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, arrived from Moscow today for a two-day discussion of projects the bank could finance.

A reorganization plan for the Republic Carloading and Distributing Company, Inc., was approved in Federal court here yesterday by Judge Harold R. Tyler Jr. It was recommended by F. Ralph Nogg, trustee in reorganization of Yale Express System, Inc., and its subsidiaries, including Republic Carloading.
COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 13 -- The New York Nets of the American Basketball Association placed Tony Koski on waivers today to make room for Bob Verga, obtained Monday from the Denver Rockets.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 13 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva of Chile is leading his nation in a warm and gallant reception of Queen Elizabeth II of Britain. But even as the President plays host to his royal guest, his governing Christian Democratic party has entered another period of difficulties that could cost it the next election.

Secretary Clifford's warning to Saigon should remove any hope that might remain there that the Nixon-Johnson understanding on the Vietnam peace talks was less than firm. Mr. Clifford attended the Nixon-Johnson meeting. He states unequivocally that the United States will go ahead with the peace talks alone -- and soon -- if a Saigon delegation does not come to Paris.

The jazz concerts that are given at the various branches of the Public Library usually involve contemporary musicians of some reputation who are not heard often in jazz clubs and young, emerging musicians who are not heard often anywhere.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels, sparked by Louie Dampier's 37 points, raced to a big first-quarter lead and defeated the Los Angeles Stars, 115-108, in their American Basketball Association game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Four Nixon-Agnew campaign committees filed financial reports today with the clerk of the House of Representatives, listing contributions totaling $772,915 from Aug. 8 to Oct. 21.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The proportion of Negroes in Washington, D. C., schools rose to 93.6 per cent last month from 92.3 per cent a year earlier, the school system reported today. The rate of change was about the same as it has been for several years, but the growth in total enrollment has stopped.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals assignment of patent cases for session commencing Monday, Dec. 2, 1968:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13 -- Premier Abdullah Yaffi announced today that he had withdrawn his resignation at the request of President Charles Helou and that of members of the Cabinet.

A PLAYER who is considering a slam has a valuable clue at his disposal when his partner has indicated a two-suited hand. He should inspect his holding in what will be his partner's side suit and exercise great caution if he has three small cards in that suit.

With the announcement yesterday that the American Broadcasting Company will bring in five new television programs to replace six old ones, the three major networks have almost completed their changes for the second half of the season.
LONDON, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Japan, the world's major shipbuilding nation, was reported today to be close to overtaking Norway and Britain as a shipowning country.

TORONTO, Nov. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Doctors at Toronto General Hospital successfully transplanted the heart today of a 22-year-old traffic victim to Alfred Gagnier, 54 years old, of Belle River, Ont.
Roy C. Schoenhaar has been elected to the board of trustees of the Hamburg Savings Bank, Brooklyn and Queens. He is president of Unexcelled, Inc., a conglomorate company.

The eighteenth annual China debate at the United Nations this week is essentially a formality. Few votes will be changed by it. Communist China's militancy and the chaos of its cultural revolution assure the United States a substantial majority in blocking its admission. The Sino-Soviet dispute deprives Peking of anything more than pro forma support from Russia and its Communist allies.
The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter had risen by 8 per cent to 52 cents a share from 48 cents a share in the like 1967 period.
Members of the Uniformed Firefighters Association have voted overwhelmingly in a mail referendum to accept a new two-year contract that will give them a pay increase totaling $1,367.

PARIS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Boy students fought with girls and battled each other with ax handles in Paris today during a brief flare-up of violence in connection with a leftist call for "action meetings" in the nation's high schools.
Negotiations between the striking American Federation of Musicians and the three major television networks will resume today at 11 A.M. at an undisclosed location.
UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 13 -- Eleven countries signed an agreement today to set in motion a $27-million project for power and irrigation development in the lower Mekong River basin in Cambodia.

The city was given state permission yesterday to accept all relief applicants' statements on their eligibility, instead of requiring detailed investigations in every case. The new program is to take effect in stages starting Jan. 1.

It started as one of the biggest corporate marriages of all time, but late yesterday the proposed merger of the Xerox Corporation and the C.I.T. Financial Corporation was simply a giant might-have-been.
HONG KONG, Nov. 13 -- The Chinese Communist regime in Peking has taken new steps to seal off the outside world from knowledge of what is happening in Communist China.
Thousands of investors are anxiously watching for the postman these days, looking for a package that never seems to arrive.

Off Broadway will get another playhouse when the Mercury Theater, 136 East 13th Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, opens Dec. 9 with two short plays by James Prideaux, "Lemonade" and "The Autograph Hound."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States, the following proceedings were hold today:

SWAN QUARTER, N. C., Nov. 13 -- Inside the white, stucco courthouse, a dozen highway patrolmen load their paper plates with boiled shrimp, ham and biscuit sandwiches, fried chicken and potato salad. A stainless steel percolator gurgles.
Eddie Bracken, Michaele Myers and Robert Elston will join "You Know I Can't Hear You When the Water's Running" when the comedy moves Dec. 2 from the Broadhurst Theater to the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The Defense Department announced today it was cutting back by more than twothirds its program of housing construction on military bases.

TOM TRIOLO has gained 474 yards running for the Lafayette football team this season and interrupted the studies of at least 474 students with his violin-playing at night. The junior fullback, who enjoys country music, said, "They can always study in the library."

CAMBRIDGE, England, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, ceased being a teen-ager today and took the day off from university lectures to celebrate. The 20-year-old Prince went off in his sport car, accompanied by a detective, to join friends at a hunting party in Suffolk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- West Germany has warned the United States, Great Britain and France that new restrictions on access to Berlin may be imposed by East Germany when its parliament meets tomorrow.
The Met had another go at Verdi's "Don Carlo" last night, its sixth this season.
The great shoot-out at the corral on Trinity Place ended in a draw yesterday afternoon.

Eleven guns have been stolen from an apartment in Lefrak City in Corona, Queens, the police reported yesterday. The tenant, Morton Wagner of 9707 Horace Harding Boulevard, who notified the police at 8 P.M. Wednesday of the theft, said he used the weapons for target practice and hunting.

DALLAS, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Oakland Oaks got a 19-point first-quarter scoring performance from Rick Barry tonight to take a 41-20 opening period lead and go on to beat the Dallas Chaparrals, 122-106, in an American Basketball Association game.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 14 -- A crackdown on motorists who violated the state's motor vehicle and traffic laws was started by the Long Island State Parkway police today in their efforts to obtain a pay raise.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 14 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia is a man passionately fond of surprises.

When trouble rains on the international monetary front, it falls by the bucket rather than the drop. Speculation on a revaluation of the Deutsche Mark and the concomitant weakening of the French franc were alone sufficient to send shock waves through the network of interrelated financial markets. But then the disturbance was compounded by sour October trade figures from the United Kingdom and renewed pressure on the pound sterling.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would build a "multimillion-dollar" steel fabricating shop at its Sparrows Point, Md., shipyard designed to modernize fabrication and assembly of ship components.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Harold Howe 2d, United States Commissioner of Education, who was accused of going too far in requiring desegregattion of schools, is leaving the Government with the view that "we haven't gone far enough."

A 26-year-old convict was indicted here yesterday as the ringleader of a gang that stole Cadillacs to order after stealing Cadillac registrations in Massachusetts that were used in later registering the cars in New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Government auditors said today hasty and inefficient planning by the Air Force had caused mililons of dollars of waste in Thailand construction projects.

It takes a university to put matters in historical perspective. "Make love, not war" is commonly thought of as a hippie contribution to contemporary mores, and the phrase is so catchy and up-to-date that it has even become high camp.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 -- A thousand North Vietnamese soldiers attacked an allied camp 60 miles north of Saigon but were beaten off in a battle that raged from midnight to nearly dawn today.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- An unheralded team of Taiwan Chinese, dropping long putts as if they were using billiard cues, took the first-round lead today in the 16th annual World Cup golf competition.

DAKAR, Senegal -- "Lots of white people think Africans do not feel pain the way other people do. Even the French people who were here believed that it was easier for African women to have their babies because they had so much less feeling."

MERIDIAN, Miss., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- A self-proclaimed anti-Semitic guerrilla and an admitted Ku Klux Klansman were indicted yesterday in connection with an abortive attempt to bomb a Jewish leader's home.

Sir Reginald Sholl, Australia's consul general here, will deliver an essay on American and Australian pioneers this evening in the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Ballroom. The occasion is the annual banquet of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York.

The election of Lawrence C. Marshall as chairman of the executive committee of the board of directors of the Grand Union Company, East Paterson, N. J., was announced yesterday by Charles G. Rodman, president of the food and general merchandising retailing chain. Mr. Marshall, who succeeds the late Louis A. Green, is vice chairman of the board of directors of the Chase Manhattan Bank. He has been a Grand Union director since 1965.
The monthly meeting of the Society of Marine Port Engineers of New York will take place next Wednesday evening at the Commuters Cafe and Restaurant, 32 Cortlandt Street.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 14 -- Only six 4-year-olds representing five betting interests, since Billy Haughton will have an entry in the race, were named today to go to the post in the seventh annual Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway on Nov. 23.
KUWAIT, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi of Iran arrived today for talks with Kuwaiti leaders. It was his first visit to this Country.

IN their moments of transcendent ardency, lovers of New York are wont to crow that their city can take anything -- massive power failure, blizzards, and, of course, the seemingly endless series of strikes that cripple the subways, litter the streets and shut down the schools.

DORADO BEACH, Puerto Rico, Nov. 14 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, the Vice President-elect, has invited Vice President Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie to join him in a round of golf tomorrow at the Fountain Valley Course on St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

Michael McDonagh Jr. was named yesterday as manager of brooadcast affairs for the New York Yankees. McDonagh will handle client services and assist D. Thomas Miller, vice president for broadcast affairs, in broadcast activity.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 14 -- The Nigerian Government announced today that its army had killed "more than 1,000" Biafran troops in a recent battle at Onitsha. A Government announcement also said that Nigerian soldiers had captured 808 submachine guns, 238 rifles and 8 machine guns during a Biafran attack on the city of the east bank of the Niger River.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14 -- The $150,000 Thunderbird Classic, a major event in the New York metropolitan area since 1962, was discontinued today, partly because of the conflict between the Professional Golfers' Association and the American Professional Golfers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Ireland today became the 61st country to adhere to an international agreement granting women equal rights with men to vote and hold office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The latest vote totals showed today that Richard M. Nixon's popular vote margin over Vice President Humphrey was 316,704. Mr. Humphrey's total of 30,815,056 included 51,342 votes cast for electors pledged to him in Alabama, where George C. Wallace was the regular Democratic candidate.

At a special meeting yesterday shareholders of the Central Aguirre Sugar Company voted to change the company name to Aguirre Company. They also approved a two-for-one stock split and increased the number of shares to 5 million from the current maximum of 753,374.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon indicated yesterday that President Johnson had agreed to reach no major foreign policy decisions without the concurrence of Mr. Nixon.
Two young brothers died last night in a smoky, two-alarm fire in a four story apartment house in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
HONG KONG, Nov. 14 -- Reports reaching here from Peking indicate that Communist China may have failed recently in an attempt to put a satellite in orbit around the earth.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The vaue of much of present graduate school education was questioned today by Edward H. Levi as he was inaugurated as president of the University of Chicago.

McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation, yesterday offered the foundation's aid to the National Association of Real Estate Boards in programs the association may undertake to help make the Federal open-housing law work.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Do poets have a right to pessimism? What if Shakespeare's first play had gone unperformed? And -- perhaps more to the point in Parliament's budget debate last night -- should France spend money on regional theater?

GUATEMALA, Nov. 14 -- Terrorists set off five bombs in various parts of Guatemala City last night, one of them in a window of the British consulate. There were no injuries reported. The bombings coincided with the anniversary of the founding of the Thirteenth of November, a guerrilla movement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- An early recruit of the Kennedy Administration was reminiscing the other day about his early weeks at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

When the list of persons who passed the New York State bar examination was published in The New York Times on Nov. 5, the name of Fred Weinstein, Ithaca, N. Y., was inadvertently omitted. Mr. Weinstein passed the bar examination.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov 14 (UPI) -- The high-scoring Detroit Red Wings exploded for three goals in the first period tonight to down the Los Angeles Kings, 5-2, in a National Hockey League encounter at the Forum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Johnson, once a heart attack patient himself, celebrated the 20th birthday of the National Heart Institute today with some of the nation's most prominent heart specialists.

ROME, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- The condition of Augustin Cardinal Bea, 87-year-old president of the Vatican Secretariat for Christian Unity, has worened, the Vatican said today. The German-born Cardinal is in a Rome clinic with influenza, believed to be complicated by heart trouble.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrived here today for an official visit at the invitation of Foreign Minister Janos Peter, The Hungarian press agency M.T.I. reported.

Brooklyn longshoremen, expecting a 63-cents-an-hour increase in their wages under a new labor contract, have agreed to have their union dues more than doubled, Anthony Scotto, president of Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 -- David Rockefeller was asked publicly today how he would feel about being Secretary of the Treasury in the Nixon Administration. He did not say no.

Albert Einstein College of Medicine announced yesterday that it would present an honorary degree to Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas on Nov. 24 "for his commitment to human rights and equal justice under the law."

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Top Knight is favored to win the 16th running of the rich Garden State Stakes Saturday, but past performances of this race indicate being the choice isn't exactly money in the bank.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 -- Three physicians received Bronfman Prizes tonight for their work in improving health and life expectancy of large numbers of people. The $5,000 prizes are awarded by the American Public Health Association.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- Thirty-one army officers from the Bernese section of the Jura, in the French-speaking northwestern corner of Switzerland, protested today to the authorities in Berne against the use of federal troops to protect federal property and military installations in their area against possible seizure by the separatist movement.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The United Nations Theater will offer "The Women" by Clare Boothe Luce as its annual play next week. It will be presented from Monday through Saturday nightly at 8 in the Dag Hammerskjold Auditorium here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to release from solitary confinement a Tennessee "jailhouse lawyer" who breaks prison regulations by giving free legal help to illiterate cellmates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The armed forces will discharge some servicemen early so that they can be home for Christmas, the Pentagon announced today.
DAX, France, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Two French Army helicopters collided during a training flight near here today and crashed, killing all five men aboard the two craft.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 -- Citing the need to face up to the crisis in health care," Walter P. Reuther tonight announced creation of an organization to lobby for enactment of a national health insurance system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A successful step toward an entirely new type of treatment for virus diseases was reported today by scientists here and in New York.

AUBURN, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Bruce Dancis, 20 years old, the first Cornell University student to mutilate his draft card to protest the Vietnam war was sentenced here today to an indefinite prison term as a youthful offender.
Large-scale profit taking caused prices to drop on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

ONLY a grouch could find fault with the titles of Erick Hawkins's dances. They bring to mind instant poetic images. "Tightrope," "Naked Leopard," "Geography of Noon," "Cantilever," supplemented by a revised version of one of the choreographer's earliest works, "John Brown," made up the program last night of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy's continuing Festival of Dance.
The directors of a cooperative of meat-processing companies voted yesterday to present to the members a plan to dissolve the co-op and to abandon plans to move to a proposed new complex in the Bronx.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- Policemen charged into the philosophy building of Barcelona University today after a group of students poured gasoline over a door and set it afire. The police scattered the students, who were protesting against a ban on mass meetings.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The flight from the franc gained momentum today and the French Government studied new measures to tighten credit.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Norm Ullman and Paul Henderson scored 10 seconds apart tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs registered a 5-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Philadelphia judge ruled for a second time that the Police Advisory Board, formed to hear civilian complaints against policemen, was illegal. Unless the city solicitor's office appeals the ruling by Common Pleas Court Judge Leon Weinrott, the board is out.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The institution of a Federal Court suit raised doubts today that Ford's Theater, where Abraham Lincoln was shot, would reopen soon as a living theater.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- A former major general of the Soviet Army stood over the open coffin of a comrade tonight and denounced the "totalitarianism that hides behind the mask of so-called Soviet democracy."

The leaders of two antitrust control groups here have asked President-elect Richard M. Nixon to start an "immediate investigation into the waste of Federal funds earmarked for housing redevelopment" in the city.

Several thousand parents demonstrated outside Governor Rockefeller's midtown office yesterday to demand that he call a special session of the Legislature, as efforts to resolve the city school crisis continued without signs of a break.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 -- The Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu closed down today a Saigon newspaper that printed details of criticism of the Thien regime voiced Tuesday by the United States Secretary of Defense, Clark M. Clifford.

A fire in three one-story brick stores in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday caused slight smoke inhalation and burn injuries to three of the 80 firemen. The 70-minute blaze started at 1:27 P.M. in the cellar of a clothing store at 2287 Nostrand Avenue and spread to the attached buildings at 2281 and 2283.

Bill Cosby will play a teacher in an integrated junior high school in the San Francisco Bay area when he returns to weekly television next season. The actor, who won three Emmy Awards for "best actor in a continuing role" as Alexander Scott in "I Spy," will appear in a half-hour comedy-drama series for the National Broadcasting Company.
PRAGUE, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- A leading Communist theoretician warned the party leadership today that if it compromised too far on reforms it would suffer isolation from the people.
A union of 20,000 workers at the Consolidated Edison Company threatened yesterday to strike Nov. 30 if agreement on a new labor contract was not reached by them.

HUNTER, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Accustomed to prewinter weather that has been mostly mild for the last two decades, residents of this northern Catskills village awakened early this week to find 30 inches of snow, on an average, in their backyards.

THE inner precincts of Christie's, the venerable London auction house that now occupies a resplendent eighteen - nineties landmark mansion at 867 Madison Avenue, were opened to the public for the first time yesterday with an exhibition entitled "Van Gogh, Gauguin and Their Circle."
Continued pressure on two leading automobile issues yesterday helped influence the irregular trend of the market.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 14 -- Bus service for the schools in Commack and Hauppaugue is expected to be restored tomorrow after striking drivers decided to return to work today while negotiations were in progress. The schools in the two communities with an enrollment of about 20,000 pupils, were left without service after 170 drivers called a wildcat strike early this morning.

PARIS, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- More than half the delegations attending the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization walked out today when the delegate of Portugal stepped up to the rostrum.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Probate Judge Chase M. Davies, approved today a $600,000 settlement between Trans World Airlines and the estate of Dr. Frederick Wolf of Cincinnati. Mr. Wolf was killed in the crash of a jetliner near the Greater Cincinnati Airport last Nov. 20.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- The leaders of the Legislature today set up a special fact-finding team and announced it would begin tomorrow to interview all the principal figures in the city's protracted teachers' strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Walt W. Rostow, President Johnson's Special Assistant for National Security Affairs, expressed confidence today that neither the Johnson nor Nixon administration would attempt to force Saigon to accept a coalition Government with the National Liberation Front, or Vietcong.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Pfc. Raymond Kroll, 18 years old, who spent a week in "sanctuary" at the Marsh Chapel at Boston University, is under sentence of three months at hard labor for being absent without leave. Kroll was convicted by a five-member court-martial yesterday.
DENVER, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Wayne Hightower scored 33 points, tonight in leading the Denver Rockets to a 105-89 victory over the Houston Mavericks. It was the fourth straight triumph.

A Federal judge yesterday adjourned temporarily a hearing on an application by Louis E. Wolfson, the financier, who is seeking to vacate his 1967 conviction and sentence for the sale of unregistered stock.
John Nerud tossed a bale of alfalfa into the van, gave the horse inside a final pat on the nose and said, "See you in Florida, old boy."

Marianne Moore, who is 81 today, has been awarded the 1968 National Medal for Literature, which is accompanied by a prize of $5,000. The poet's reaction to the award was: "I am mystified but delighted."

PRAGUE, Nov. 14 -- Alexander Dubcek, the first secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist party, outlined today a new political program designed to reconcile the liberalizing aspirations of his "humanistic socialism" with the situation that followed the Soviet-led invasion last August.

WATERFORD, Me., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The body of Henry Carter, a missing Portland hunter, was found today in woods near here. Mr. Carter, 38 years old, a retired Navy veteran, had apparently been shot in the chest.
PROGRESSIVE HISTORIANS: Turner, Beard, Parrington. By Richard Hofstadter. 498 pages. Knopf. $8.95.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $683-million, up 2 per cent from the year-earlier $671-million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $6,796,000,000, up 10 per cent from $6,171,000,000.

ALBANY,Nov. 14 (AP) -- Receipts from the sale of state lottery tickets climbed in October to $4,212,399, or 3 per cent above those in September. Drawings to determine winners will begin on Monday and will be completed Wednesday at Pennsylvania Station in New York City.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The San Juan Star, an English-language newspaper editorally criticized Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew today for alleged statements favoring statehood for Puerto Rico.

The Buttenheim Publishing Corporation has announced the election of Edgar M. Buttenheim as president, succeeding his brother, Donald V. Buttenheim, who becomes chairman while remaining chief executive officer.
An upturn in the fortunes of the American shipbuilding industry was forecast here yesterday by one of its leading officials.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintains a College Information Service Line to inform high school seniors about college admissions.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon proceeded yesterday at his customarily cautious pace to fashion the small group of men who will advise him in the White House.

SHREVEPORT, La., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal panel upheld today the "freedom of choice" type of school desegregation plan that the Supreme Court earlier this year ordered replaced in the South.
The city moved yesterday to correct a situation in which many itinerant peddlers find it helps to operate illegally rather than legally.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 14 -- Premier Abdullah Yafi tonight appealed to Lebanese -- Christian and Moslem alike -- to close their ranks and maintain national unity.

The premieres of two Off Broadway shows have been postponed. "Up Eden," which had been due next Wednesday night, will open Nov. 26 at the Jan Hus Playhouse. "Big Time Buck White" has been set back from Dec. 5 to Dec. 8 at the Village South Theater.
Two former world boxing champions, Ismael Laguna and Luis Rodriguez, appear on a program of three 10-rounders tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The day of the $100-or-less fare on trans-Atlantic flights may be realized once the new Boeing 747 superjetliners go into service, according to R. G. Ferguson, senior vice president-finance of Pan American World Airways, Inc.
About 1,000 pickets, members of the Social Service Employes Union, paraded for an hour outside Gracie Mansion in a protest against What they said was the city's violation of their contract.

The Society for the History of Czechoslovak Jews, Inc., 208 East 28th Street, will hold a historical and cultural program Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock, in Town Hall. Proceeds from the lecture and concert, called "1000 Years of Jewish Life in Czechoslovakia," will go toward the printing of a second volume of essays on the subject.

A letter from Senator Edward M. Kennedy was instrumental in gaining a conditional discharge yesterday for a 30-year-old Syracuse businessman convicted last month of illegal possession of a pistol at the funeral of Senator Robert F. Kennedy last June 8.
Serious doubt has been cast on the credibility of the informant who tipped off the police about an alleged plot to assassinate President-elect Richard M. Nixon.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- The International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, has refused to act on requests for technical assistance from the Greek Government because the regime is accused of flouting trade union rights.

KENT, Ohio, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Robert I. White, president of Kent State University, said today that students who participated in a demonstration yesterday against police force recruiters would be subject to disciplinary action.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- King Constantine and Queen Anne Marie of Greece arrived here today from Madrid for a hunting weekend as guests of King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of Belgium.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday it would charge higher prices for its rigid vinyl film and sheet products and for a line of plastic bottles beginning with shipments after Jan. 1.
ALUMNI of Harvard, Princeton and Yale have a somewhat negligible view of their own teams' efforts during the entire football season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (AP) -- George Randolph Hearst Jr., publisher of The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner, has been sued for divorce by his wife of 17 years on grounds of extreme cruelty.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Welfare recipients, saying they want to "provide a decent American Christmas for our children," staged demonstrations at Department of Welfare offices here and in Chester today.

EVERY quail hunter who uses a dog -- and hunting quail without a dog is, if an abominable pun can be tolerated, pointless -- has on occasion been troubled by birds that refuse to hold in front of the dog.

JERSUALEM, Nov. 14 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban was understood to have told his Cabinet colleagues today that Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring was likely to continue his work as the United Nations envoy on peace in the Middle East and to shift his headquarters, probably to Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren's intention to retire has not been affected by the election. His letter stating his intention will remain on the table, ready for action by Richard M. Nixon when he becomes President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Nov. 9 totaled an estimated 15.3 billion ton-miles, 4.7 per cent above the comparable week of last year. Carloadings in the same week totaled 577,180, an increase of 7,899 cars, or 1.4 per cent, above the 1967 level.

Leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., irritated by the bid of Walter P. Reuther and his automobile union for membership in the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, have decided to boycott a meeting of the confederation's executive board next week in Brussels.

The New Yorkk City Hall of Science has announced plans for a second special tutoring course in science and mathematics for high school seniors. The program is designed to help students pass the College Board Entrance Examinations and Regents' scholarship examinations.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 14 -- A vast natural gas deposit has reportedly been discovered off the southeast coast of this island by the Pan American Oil Company, wholly owned subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

Things went from bad to worse for the New York Knickerbockers last night as they suffered their fifth straight loss, bowing, 110-101, to the Cincinnati Royals before 9,214 fans at Madison Square Garden.

Spartans Industries, Inc., operator of the E. J. Korvette and Spartan-Atlantic discount store chains, announced yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to purchase 45 properties which it now leases from Arlen Properties and affiliated companies.

KARACHI, Nov. 14 -- Mr. Bhutto was a lawyer of some eminence when President Ayub selected him in October, 1958, for his Cabinet. Mr. Bhutto remained in the Cabinet, holding different portfolios, until September, 1966.
This country's population expansion is caused by "wanted" babies born in middle-class comfort, rather than by "unwanted" babies among poverty-striken women who are ignorant of contraception.

It is a cliche, but a painfully true one, in the overwhelming majority of instances: By the time a singer has matured enough to sing lieder with intelligence and emotional depth, the voice is in tatters. Now and then, at intervals too rare to be depended upon, there comes along a great artist whose voice lasts into late maturity or whose maturity comes early.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 14 -- New York State savings bankers said today they expected to push hard in the next session of the Legislature for authority to make personal loans, for wider branching privileges and for other powers.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday the establishment of a new agency to provide what it called "the first voluntarily supported, comprehensive and coordinated program for care and rehabilitation of the aged in New York City and neighboring suburbs."
The "Lubitsch touch" of Hollywood's golden days is lighting up West 53d Street.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Detroit Pistons, which saw a 16-point half-time lead dwindle to a tie in the opening minutes of the third quarter, managed to hold on tonight to defeat the Phoenix Suns, 111-109, in a National Basketball Association game.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 14 -- The United States announced a six-point program to the North Atlantic Alliance today to bolster American conventional military strength in Europe and to warn the Soviet Union against pressure on alliance members.
No progress was reported yesterday in the meeting between representatives of the striking American Federation of Musicians and the three major television networks.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 14 -- For the first time in its 265-year history Yale University will admit undergraduate women next fall to "enhance its contribution to the generations ahead."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Christmas cards this year will require a 6-cent stamp, the same as first-class mail, whether they are sealed or not.

The Seventeenth Amendment to the Constitution clearly proclaims that United States Senators shall be "elected by the people. . . ." In the light of this central purpose it is surprising that a Federal court has now ruled (in a split decision) that the unexpired term of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy can be held by an appointive successor until the election of 1970 -- nearly 29 months after Mr. Kennedy's death.
The Conservative party, top vote-getting minor party in state history, announced yesday that it would be running candidates in every city election in New York State in 1969.
TOKYO, Nov. 14 -- Emperor Hirohito's new $36.2-million Showa Palace was formally opened today in a solemn ceremony marking the completion of construction work that began four and a half years ago.

David McKay, Inc., which was started 66 years ago in Philadelphia as the publisher of Walt Whitman, has sold an interest to Maxwell M. Geffen, a publisher of medical and religious books, to finance its expansion.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 15 -- Authoritative sources said today that Premier Tran Van Huong had submitted his resignation to President Nguyen Van Thieu, partly as a result of differences arising from the stalemated Paris peace talks.

THE College Clubs Bridge League began its 1968-69 schedule here last month and broke a long masculine tradition. A team representing Wellesley - Barnard was accepted and is struggling against experienced teams representing Brown, Columbia, Harvard, N.Y.U., Penn-Cornell, Princeton and Yale.

The new owners of the Ocala Stud Farm -- Ed Abramson, Richard Hersch and Peter Jacobs of New York -- paid $235,000 for the 6-year-old brood mare, Treasure Chest. She was purchased from David Shaer, the Boston shoe manufacturer, in a private sale.

Fairfield Osborn, in his 82d year still one of the great names of the conservation movement, added another deserved award the other evening to the long list he has already received. This was the Audubon Medal, presented at the National Audubon Society's annual dinner at which this major conservation organization's new president, Dr. Elvis J. Stahr (former president of Indiana University), was inaugurated.

Forty witnesses, subpoenaed after six months of undercover investigation, went to the Bronx County Court House yesterday for the opening of a grand jury inquiry into a two-county gambling operation allegedly controlled by crime bosses.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Union announced that its unmanned spacecraft Zond 6 had flown around the moon today and was continuing its flight.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Law enforcement officers posing as news reporters policed a band of 80 to 100 antiwar demonstrators who massed at the Federal Office Building in Tampa today as part of "national draft card turn-in day."
Nearly 3,000 policemen remained on patrol duties during the past year instead of sitting in traffic court waiting to appear as witnesses, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Following are the texts of the new English canons approved by the Vatican and released today:

WARSAW, Nov. 14 -- Poland's Fifth party Congress today heard a Rumanian Communist leader in a speech that reflected the cautious policy of his independent-minded country despite continuing Soviet pressures.

Donald F. Turner, former Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division of the Justice Department, sharply criticized last night "inadequate" antitrust enforcement of business concentration.
The New York Philharmonic's program last night in Philharmonic Hall was studded with proper names beginning with the letter "B."

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has decided to discontinue the drilling of its exploratory well for natural gas and gas storge facilities in the Shawangunk Mountains near Ellenville, N. Y. The company said that the well has been capped and the 145-foot drilling rig would be removed as soon as weather permitted.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Martin Luther King School in the predominantly Negro Roxbury District, plagued by student disorders and disciplinary problems, is being closed indefinitely until order can be restored.
Sixteen-month old Siamese twin girls who were born with a common leg, were separated successfully 10 days ago, their surgeon announced yesterday.

Repeated attacks and muggings on and near the campus of Yeshiva University have led many undergraduates at the Washington Heights school to arm themselves with aerosol cans containing a chemical irritant.
Four organizations in the New York area will benefit from bazaars and boutiques in the next two weeks.

In fine physical condition, with morale high and hoping to take a giant step toward clinching their first American Football League Eastern Division championship, the New York Jets held a short workout at Hofstra University yesterday and then headed for Oakland, where they will face the Raiders on Sunday.
WITH U.S. FORCES IN BINHLONG PROVINCE, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 -- The colonel told his troops to avoid shooting up the French planter's rubber-tree grove, if possible.

BELGRADE, Yugaslavia, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- President Tito and Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, had a cordial talk here today, Yugoslav sources said. The Senate majority leader arrived Tuesday on a two-day informative visit.
HONOLULU, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent arrived here yesterday with her 16-month-old son to wait for reunion with her husband, who will be taking a leave from Vietnam war duty next week.
In the graceful, airy rooms of the 39th floor of the Pierre, furniture is being switched around as fast as stage props between the scenes of a play.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- In the long and melancholy history of U.S. negotiations over the Vietnam war, no American diplomats have had a more difficult task than Ambassadors Averell Harriman and Cyrus Vance here at the Paris peace talks.
The winds of November subsided at Aqueduct yesterday, but the long shots of November did not.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Representative Richard Bolling of Missouri, one of a group of House liberal Democrats who saw to it that two Democratic defectors in the election of 1964 were punished, said today he would propose that Representative L. Mendel Rivers of South Carolina be punished for opposing party principles.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- While San Francisco State College remained closed today because of student violence and a faculty refusal to teach classes, in Sacramento Gov. Ronald Reagan said it was "absolutely essential" that the campus be reopened.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Gary Dornhoefer found time between fights with Bobby Orr tonight to score two goals and lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 4-2 upset over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

The Fordham club football team, which has won six of seven games this season, was ranked No. 1 yesterday in the National Club Football Service rating of the nation's 20 top teams. Fordham's victory over Manhattan last Saturday lifted the Rams, who had been No. 2 for five weeks, over Loyola (Calif.), which lost to Southern Utah.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- With the resolve to make higher learning "relevant to the total black community," an all-Negro student conference held its first full day of meetings today after admonitions from advisers to "quit talking and start acting."

"My mother lived to be 106 years old," said an impoverished middle-aged woman from North Carolina. "People didn't live out of tin cans then. They had good pure water to drink then. It wasn't doped up like the water is now."
ATHENS, Nov. 14 -- Premier George Papadopoulos reminded all state employes today that bureaucratic sluggishness was punishable by law.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- Direct railroad service between the Italian automobile city of Turin and the Soviet city of Togliatti, where the Turin Fiat Company is building a factory, will be opened in May, 1969, it was announced today.
The State Public Employment Relations Board announced last night the designation of a three-man mediation panel in an effort to avert a strike of employes at state mental hospitals next week.
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino and representatives of the striking incinerator stokers last night announced an agreement ending a nine-day wildcat walkout.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 14 -- Louis DePascale, Mayor of Hoboken, was sworn in today as a member of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders, succeeding James F. Quinn. Mr. Quinn, also of Hoboken, was elected County Clerk on Nov. 5 and will take office tomorrow.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

The Lytton Financial Corporation, a troubled Los Angeles savings and loan holding company, lost $12.3-million in the nine months ended Sept. 30, when the results are included of two other savings and loan associations with which it expects to merge, the company disclosed yesterday.
The Federal Reserve's current tight-money policy continues to hold banks here and in other major money markets in tight rein.

Parents and friends of Bennington College students, graduates and trustees of the college will open their art collections Dec. 4 for a tour to raise funds for the Paul T. Feeley Visual Arts Center to be built on the college campus in Vermont.

A proposal for the establishment of a United States Development Corporation that was prepared by a panel of business and banking experts and government agencies will be ready for Congressional consideration early next year.

Marcor, Inc., the company formed Nov. 1 by the merger of Montgomery Ward Co. and the Container Corporation of America, reported from Chicago yesterday results for the quarter and nine months ended Oct. 30 on a consolidated basis for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- President Johnson gave a recess appointment today to former Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland as a member of the Indian Claims Commission.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- Workers in a nationwide, 24-hour strike for major reforms in the social security program were joined today by students seeking school reforms.
COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Los Angeles survived a late New York rally to post a 113-104 victory over the Nets in the American Basketball Association tonight.

After agonizing debate the American Roman Catholic bishops have taken modest steps to encourage responsible dissent, to seek better procedures for resolving ecclesiastical disputes and to ease the consciences of Catholics who find they cannot accept Pope Paul's ban on artificial contraception.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Johnson said today that the United States was doing "all we can" to get the expanded Paris talks started with South Vietnam present.
Profits of Walt Disney Productions rose to $1.34 a share in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Sept. 28, from $1.11 in the 1967 period, the company reported yesterday.
The use of human figures in stained glass windows, long a fixture in Christian churches, is becoming an increasingly important adjunct to Jewish worship in Reform and Conservative synagogues.
Jim Brown, the former Cleveland Browns fullback who is now in the movies, went to Harlem yesterday as a businessman.

THE venerable and usually sobersided Folksbiene Yiddish Theater opened its new season last night in a lighthearted vein, its first comedy in many years, "Bronx Express, 1968."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Montclair State College advanced to the final round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Eastern Regional College Division soccer tournament today, downing the University of Baltimore, 2-1.

One of the numerous unfortunate side effects of the war in Vietnam has been the breakdown in relations between the United States and Cambodia, that small but proud neighbor of South Vietnam whose effervescent ruler, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, oscillates between friendliness and hostility as the war waxes and wanes along his vulnerable border.
ATHENS, Nov. 15 -- The army-backed regime put into force today Greece's new Constitution, which provides for a "disciplined democracy."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Underwrater pictures of the submarine Scorpion, which was lost in the Atlantic last May, show that the hull is in several major pieces and completely flooded, the Navy said today.
CALU, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- A young United States marine on a night ambush patrol was dragged away screaming and killed by a tiger, a regimental commander said today.

LISBON, Nov. 15 -- The return of the banished opposition leader Mario Soares was explained by the press of the ruling National Union today as a sign of "new times for Portugal" under the regime of Premier Marcelo Caetano.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 15 -- The West Pakistan High Court at Lahore accepted today a petititon challenging the detention of former Foreign Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

Billy Schulman is 13 years old and mentally retarded. Doctors say he has the mental age of an 8-year-old. But Billy is the star of a major television drama that "The Hallmark Hall of Fame" will present Feb. 5 at 7:30 P.M. on the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- An accused New Orleans bank robber, described as heavily armed and extremely dangerous, was placed today on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of 10 most wanted criminals.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The police spread a dragnet today for two escaped convicts, armed and considered dangerous but who were described as polite and considerate to a family they held hostage through the night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- United States diplomatic sources said today that there was no pressure from the major Security Council powers on Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring to alter the scope or method of operation of his Middle East peace mission.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Mia Farrow shattered the quiet dignity of a London court today with a four-letter word.
LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Civic authorities tonight ordered 6,000 Londoners to evacuate 29 towering apartment houses while workmen strengthen them against collapse.

ROME, Saturday, Nov. 16 -- Augustin Cardinal Bea, the German Jesuit scholar who shaped the current effort by his church to find paths to eventual unity with other Christians, the triumph of religious liberty, and retraction of ancient slanders against the Jewish people, died early today.
PANAMA, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The Vatican has announced recognition of the military junta that overthrew President Arnulfo Arias last month.
The first in a monthly series of private dinners for the Foundation of the Peoples of South Pacific will be held this evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan McGregor of 63 East 90th Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Old Washington hands -- those used to seeing political celebrities come and go at the bidding of the electorate -- had the same politely amused reaction to the Hollywood celebrities who invaded their precincts last night for the official world premiere and benefit performance of "The Shoes of the Fisherman."

The Clarion Music Society will give a concert on Tuesday at Town Hall to which high school students in the city will be admitted for $1. The special price has been made possible by the Department of Parks. Tickets may be obtained by presenting a student identification card at the box office.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 15 -- A curfew that was imposed in Tripoli, 60 miles north of here where student clashes yesterday left one dead and two wounded, was temporarily lifted today.

Luciano Pavarotti, the Italian tenor who will make his Metropolitan Opera debut next Saturday afternoon in "La Boheme," is scheduled to appear as Elvino in "La Sonnambula" on Dec. 12, during the 13th week of the Met season.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- A rescue ship that plowed into a drilling platform leaking natural gas, capsized today in the North Sea. Two members of the eight-man crew of the supply ship Hector Gannet were dead and one man was missing as huge waves lashed the drilling rig.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP) -- A circuit judge ruled today Time Inc. did not libel the former wife of Russell A. Firestone Jr., the tire heir, when reporting her divorce because editors thought the item was correct.
The London Stock Exchange closed with widespread losses yesterday. Sentiment was depressed by currency uncertainties.
WINDSOR, Ontario, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Ford of Canada, Ltd., announced today a multimillion-dollar realignment of its Windsor manufacturing operations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pentagon identified today the following servicemen as having been killed in Vietnam:

LONDON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Bob Lutz, 21-year-old tennis star from Los Angeles, revived the sagging reputation of the United States Davis Cup team today by defeating Graham Stilwell of Britain, 6-1, 6-2, 6-4, to reach the final of the British indoor championships.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, ahead by only 3 points, reeled off 10 straight points at the outset of the fourth quarter tonight and went on to a 116-105 National Basketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Blue Cross members' benefits wil cover a 10 per cent increase in Medicare hospital charges, the state hospital plan announced today. The United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare recently announced a 10 per cent increase in hospital fees for Medicare patients beginning Jan. 1.

The Marine Midland Grace Trust Company has announced the promotion of three executives to senior vice presidents. They are Robert B. Decker, controller; David E. Gile, head of the New York City division, and Richard W. Sherman, in charge of operations.
