Then there is the uneasy relation of comic materials to the construction of pictorial form -- uneasy, because comedy has a way of acting as a criticism of pure form, of subverting its pretensions and exposing its solemnity.

GNEEAV, Nov. 15 -- Ernest Meyer, a French journalist, has been appointed director of the International Press Institute and will take up his duties in Zurich in January, it was announced today. Mr. Meyer, now director of the International Federation of the Periodical Press, in Paris, succeeds Per Monsen, who resigned last fall.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan was among thousands of nonstriking officials, teachers and other school employes who did not receive their salary checks yesterday.
WARSAW, Nov. 15 -- Premier Josef Cyrankiewicz of Poland charged today that West Germany was risking a nuclear war by pursuing what he described as its policy of undermining the status quo in Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15 -- Carmen Cozza, a modest man from Miami (Ohio), is in charge of what may be the best football team Yale has ever had. Cozza, however, was leery of such praise on the eve of the first of two games that could make the Yale season a delight or a disaster, those against Princeton and Harvard.

TRENTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Governor Richard J. Hughes refused today to order the extradition of a 58-year-old fugitive from an Alabama prison camp who had lived quietly for 25 years in Union and Middlesex Counties.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Walter R. Cunningham, the astronaut, said today that the first Apollo manned landing on the moon was to be a very short visit, much less leisurely and ambitious than had been planned.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Nov. 15 Mark Rudd, one of the leaders of last spring's student rebellion at Columbia University, asked his draft board today to grant him an occupational deferment as a "revolutionist."

ROME, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Vatican sources said tonight that the American Catholic bishops' statement on birth control appeared to be "less rigorous than might have been expected" after the encyclical of Pope Paul VI opposing contraception.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Jim Lovelace, a halfback, scored three touchdowns today to lead Army to a 41-7 victory over Cornell in an Eastern Lightweight League championship game. The cadets, who completed their season with a 6-0 won-lost record, captured their seventh title in the last 12 years.
Governor Rockefeller appealed yesterday to a union of state employes to forgo a threatened strike at mental hospitals and warned that a walkout would be met with firm action.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth and Marilyn Smith tied for first place today in the opening round of the $12,500, 54-hole Pensacola invitation golf tournament with two-under-par 71's over the 6,316-yard Scenic Hills Country Club course.

The Los Angeles branch of Arthur, which opened last December, has been stripped of name and any association with the parent club because of "failure to conduct operations in accordance with the general policies of the network," it was announced yesterday.
More than 30 striking teachers who were assigned to Public School 76, in Long Island City, Queens, have received letters containing death threats in the last two days.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Representatives of the Bethpage Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education here signed a contract tonight ending a nine-month dispute that led to a two-week strike by teachers last month.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Connie Hawkins scored 35 points tonight to lead the Minnesota Pipers to a 105-95 victory over the Indiana Pacers in an American Basketball Association game.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- United States District Judge Howard F. Corcoran held under advisement today a request to delay a Government regulation against sex discrimination in help wanted adds.

A nonstop shuttle bus from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, to the Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park, will operate during the Cloisters's special exhibition, "Medieval Art From Private Collections," beginning today at 10 A.M.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Levern Tart of the New York Nets will miss the next three to five games after suffering a fractured right cheekbone last night in an American Basketball Association game against Los Angeles.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Charles S. Rowe of the Fredericksburg (Va.) Free Lance-Star was elected president today of the Associated Press Managing Editors Association for 1969. Mr. Rowe, the current vice president, will succeed David N. Schutz of the Redwood City (Calif.) Tribune.

Draft cards -- or what were represented as being draft cards -- were dropped into boxes, burned, sent up in balloons, torn up or mailed back to some draft boards in observance of "National Turn in Your Draft Card Day," it became known yesterday.

Sixty Columbia College students facing disciplinary action as a result of last spring's demonstrations made a "collective defense" yesterday by appearing en masse before Dean Carl F. Hovde. They also announced plans to use the college's disciplinary hearings to "put the faculty and administration on trial."
PARIS, Nov. 15 -- W. Averell Harriman, the leader of the United States negotiating team at the Paris talks on Vietnam, worked as usual on his 77th birthday today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The final draft of a proposed Potomac River Basin Compact was unveiled today amid hopes that the four basin states, Congress and the District of Columbia would agree to it by 1970.
Ahmed Rageh Namer, one of the defendants in the alleged plot to assassinate President-elect Richard M. Nixon, was released yesterday on a $25,000 bail bond.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- In a country where politics is the concern of a secretive few and the voice of the great public is heard only as "(stormy applause)" in newspaper accounts of the speeches by the few, it is
The conviction of a 27-year-old Quaker for refusing to be inducted into the Armed Forces as a noncombatant was thrown out yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
Marsh McLennan, Inc., the world's largest insurance broker, announced plans yesterday to sell mutual funds and variable annuities in combination with insurance.

Admissions officers for 29 American colleges and five foreign universities began their semiannual two-day interview sessions yesterday for high school seniors, juniors and guidance counselors at the Roosevelt Hotel.
Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton says: "The United Service Organiza tions is one of the most worthwhile social agencies in New York City.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The outflow of francs, mainly toward West Germany, was reliably estimated to have caused a drop of well over $150-million in official French reserves during the week ended Wednesday. With this movement accelerating yesterday and today, the loss for this calendar week is thought to have approached $250-million.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 15 -- The West German mark and the French franc were buffeted by speculation today amid rumors of changes in their value this weekend. Western monetary authorities are to gather in Basel, Switzerland, on Sunday for a regularly scheduled meeting.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The Baltimore Bullets got exceptional shooting from Earl Monroe and Gus Johnson and strong rebounding from Wes Unseld tonight and went on to defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 129-102, in a National Basketball Association game.

ATLANTA, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Billy Cunningham sank two free throws with two seconds left tonight, giving the Philadelphia 76ers a 116-115 victory over the Atlanta Hawks in a National Basketball Association game.

PRAGUE, Nov. 15 -- The Czechoslovak Government and the Soviet occupation authorities took extraordinary precautions tonight to guarantee peace in Prague as the crucial debate on the nation's political future proceeded in the Communist party's Central Committee.

After many months of frustrating uncertainty there is at last something to cheer about in the long struggle to save the Staten Island greenbelt. The Tri-State Transportation Commission has abandoned its insistence that a new highway slash through the magnificent high ridge of woodland that is the greenbelt's most distinctive treasure.
Three major lumber associations reported an increase of 8.3 per cent in the production for the week ended Nov. 9, compared with the levels in corresponding 1967 week.

When New York City's patrolmen were conducting their short-lived slowdown for higher pay last month, they decided that one way to harass the community into capitulation was to stop issuing any tickets to violators of the traffic laws.

The three 10-round bouts at Madison Square Garden last night evidently weren't enough for some of the fans and there was more action outside of the ring than in it after Ismael Laguna was awarded a majority decision over Roman Blanco in the final 10-round bout.
A new route for part of Richmond Parkway will become known as "Lindsay's Folly," Robert T. Connor, Borough President of Staten Island, predicted yesterday.

Columbia Pictures will celebrate its 45th anniversary on Monday evening at the Museum of Modern Art with an invitational showing of a one-hour movie and a buffet supper for film industry leaders and performers.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Nov. 15 (AP) -- A decapitated body found on the beach in North Carolina was identified yesterday as that of a sailor, whose abandoned car was found here March 9 at Crotan Beach. He was identified as Vincent Frank Rapino, 21 years old, of Jersey City.

A 47-year-old Queens businessman who has been active in philanthropy and served as president of an Orthodox synagogue in Queens, was indicted yesterday on 18 counts of grand larceny totaling $292,642. At east three of the alleged victims were his neighbors.

Next April in Hong Kong, there will be an interesting switch when the Shui Hing Company, Ltd., one of Hong Kong's leading department stores, holds a two-week promotion of merchandise made in the United States.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged at 98.3 on Thursday from Wednesday.

The traditional dance of ancient Japan, with its modest reserve, is definitely not Western-oriented in pacing or temperament. But last night, at Lincoln Center's Library and Museum of the Performing Arts, Ayako Uchiyama presented a solo program that delicately conveyed the dramatic import of Japanese dances to a Western audience, without compromise.

The publicity director of the striking United Federation of Teachers testified yesterday that the union had spent "approximately $200,000" since Sept. 1 on newspaper advertisements setting forth its position on the school crises.
A gospel music pageant, "Soul Convention," was given at Carnegie Hall last night by the Utterbach Concert Ensemble.
CHERRY HILL N. J., Nov. 15 -- The Garden State Stakes, once the richest race in the world, will still offer a monumental sum of money when it is run for the 16th time tomorrow.

Tomorrow's performance by the City College Orchestra, scheduled for 8:30 P.M. at the Arenow Concert Hall on the campus has been canceled. On Dec. 15, the orchestra will be joined by the City College Chorus for an afternoon concert.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Eleven Republican fund-raising groups today listed with the clerk of the House contributions totaling $1.7-million and expenditures of $1.48-million between Oct. 22 and Oct. 31. The groups listed contributions of $3.1-million and expenditures of $2.4-million since Jan. 1.

PUCON, Chile, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip flew today from Valparaiso to this rustic retreat beside Lake Villarrica in Southern Chile for 36 hours of rest from their state visit.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 15 -- The president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said here today that the industry must take action to remove the conditions that have caused the $135-million Manchester Savings bank in his home state of New Hampshire to attempt to convert to a commercial bank.

VENICE, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- The state police are investigating three mysterious craters at Howard Lacey's farm here, all of them reportedly caused by explosions occurring about 12:30 A.M. on Nov. 12 of each of the past three years.

Tomorrow afternoon the Metropolitan Opera will play host to aspiring opera singers for the 31st time in 33 years. The day will also signal the second major change the Metropolitan Opera Auditions have undergone since they started Dec. 22, 1935.

BONN, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- West German officials said today that they had banned a concert tour by the Warsaw National Orchestra in reprisal for the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia, in which Poland participated.

VIENNA, Saturday, Nov. 16 -- The warning by Secretary Rusk that any assault on Austria would involve NATO's security interests was reported in banner headlines today by most early editions of Vienna's newspapers.

The Holland Society of New York will honor Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Army Chief of Staff, at its annual dinner Tuesday at the Biltmore. Among the speakers will be Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Bui Diem, Ambassador of South Vietnam to the United States.

The windstorm that battered the East Coast earlier this week will cost insurance companies $20-million in claims, according to a preliminary estimate on fixed property damage alone. The estimate by the American Insurance Association was based on a preliminary estimate of claims from 10 Eastern states.
The Arizona Biochemical Company filed a $45-million libel suit in Federal Court yesterday against Metromedia, Inc., which operates WNEW-TV, Channel 5 in New York.

A NEW exhibition at the Hirschl Adler Galleries, 21 East 67th Street, is called "The American Impressionists," and can be recommended as a bright, attractive show if you don't demand that the painters be represented by their accepted masterpieces.
BASEL, Switzerland, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Central bankers will meet here tomorrow against a background of currency speculation centered on the French franc and the West German mark.
ROME, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The Vatican has been studying new plans for closer contacts between Christians and Jews, it was announced today.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew was forced today to cancel a golfing trip to St. Croix in the Virgin Islands because of a driving rainstorm in the area. Plans to meet on the golf course with Vice President Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine were also canceled.

After five years as one of the most celebrated sidemen in Miles Davis's quintet, Herbie Hancock has left the jazz trumpeter to form his own group. Mr. Hancock's sextet made its debut this week at the Village Vanguard where it began a three-week engagement.

SOMEBODY -- the fans, the management, probably both -- owes Dick McGuire a public apology, and Red Holzman deserves to have his situation spelled out in detail. These two men, the last two New York Knickerbocker coaches, are different in personality but exactly alike in their first-rate basketball knowledge, dedication and loyalty to the organization, self-effacing seriousness of purpose and perpetual willingness to work.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- Julius Boros, with a magnificent gambling shot that gave him an eagle, lifted the United States into a first-place tie with Nationalist China today at the 36-hole halfway mark of the 16th World Cup team golf competition.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- The first direct rapid transit link between the downtown area of a major North American city and its airport was dedicated here today.

The international financial world, which has not played a dominant role in shaping the credit markets for months, thrust itself to the forefront yesterday. Two major forces -- speculation in West German marks and French francs on the one hand and a greatly improved United States balance-of-payments position on the other --- appeared to offset each other.
Business inventories rose by $460-million in September, the Department of Commerce reported in Washington yesterday. The rise was considerably under the revised $860-million figure for August.
A Federal Court judge in Brooklyn has begun a pioneering program of sending nonviolent minor criminals to jail on the "installment plan."

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 15 -- The Long Island State Park Commission offered today "to speed up action in Albany" to obtain pay increases for the Long Island State Parkway police if the police will halt their new campaign of rigidly enforcing vehicle and traffic laws.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Auto production this week is running 23.6 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year and is over 200,000 for the sixth straight week.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon sought yesterday to open lines of communication with groups that opposed his candidacy, including organized labor and the Negro community. He also sought to unsnarl his lines of communication with the White House.

GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- The United States called today for early removal of quantitative import restrictions that are resorted to by many countries in contravention of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15 -- Leo Fraser, president of the Professional Golfers' Association, said today he would "take every step to find an honorable peace" with the American Professional Golfers.
Mr. Right, who successfully challenged Damascus seven weeks ago, will be challenging weight, tradition and 10 other colts at Aqueduct today in the Queens County Handicap.
SAN FRANCISCO,, Nov. 15 -- The faculty of San Francisco State College was told today by the school's president, Robert R. Smith, that "we should aim for opening the campus Tuesday morning."
ATLANTA, Nov. 15 -- An underground newspaper has filed suit against five public officials here in an effort to prevent the prosecution of its staff members on obscenity charges.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 15 -- Civil rights groups appealed today for the State Attorney General to take over from the Passaic County prosecutor an investigation of alleged police brutality and misconduct during last July's racial disorders here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- American monetary officials have given no indication that they expect any major monetary moves this weekend, sources here said today.

SADDLE BROOK, N. J., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Mayor Benjamin Walenczyk and two township committeemen resigned today following a five-hour filibuster by a colleague during a tumultuous meeting over sewer assessments.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 -- Enemy troop and supply movements have quadrupled in North Vietnam since the halt of American bombing two weeks ago, according to reports by reconnaissance pilots.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Student delegates to the all-Negro conference on building black universities are discussing educational and life-style concepts that directly reflect the wide range of American Negro thought today.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The Cambodian Government modified today a ruling that would have barred all foreign correspondents for the next five years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- An avant-garde portrait of Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, intense and skeletal in what appears to be a black sweater, will soon join the conservatively tailored likenesses of other former Attorneys General in the corridors of the Justice Department.
LANGHORNE, Pa., Nov. 15 -- Dr. Roberto Rendon, an internationally known pediatric neurologist from Guatemala, has been appointed director of professional services of The Woods Schools here.
There is food for thought for well-fed Americans, and especially for the new Administration, in a report on world hunger just issued by the American Assembly.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The Mormon Church announced plans today to build a temple in a suburb of Washington, its first temple in the eastern United States.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- An 18-year-old Jordanian was arraigned in Federal Court in Detroit today and charged with threatening the life of President-elect Nixon.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- In a wide-ranging decision a Federal judge today called unconstitutional any zoning rules or housing regulations that would keep racial minorities or the poor from living in wealthier areas.
ROME, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Pope Paul VI today ordered a scientific investigation of an ancient wood and ivory throne in St. Peter's Basilica to establish whether it could be one used by St. Peter.

The works of 170 artists are being displayed in the rotunda of the Bronx County Building daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. until Nov. 23. The exhibition, called the Second Annual Bronx Showcase of the Visual Arts, is designed to present the Bronx's artists and to demonstrate the need for a community art gallery in the borough.

WOMEN have obviously won the right to look emancipated during the day and as fragile and helpless as they want at night. Designers aren't doing anything to discourage these chameleon tendencies in their spring collections. But they are managing to suggest, subtly or otherwise, that a woman can express the personality of her choice without wearing anything but pants.
The liner Oceanic, damaged by an engine-room fire at sea last Monday, docked at 9 A.M. yesterday with 1,025 passengers who had booked a seven-day cruise to Nassau, a port they never reached.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 16 -- A United States military spokesman said yesterday that aerial observers had round -- and artillery and bombers had destroyed -- three enemy-occupied bunker complexes and a five-truck convoy in the southern part of the demilitarized zone.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The winter's first snow fell over much of Yugoslavia today.
TRENTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The Assembly created a panel and appropriated $15,000 today to study obscenity in the media.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- J. Willard Marriott scotched today rumors that Richard M. Nixon would forgo the traditional inaugural parade and gala balls.

PERHAPS the most ignominious result that a player can achieve at the bridge table is to bid to five spades or five hearts in the course of a slam effort and go down one. He is jeopardizing a game without any prospect of gain, and therefore betting something to nothing.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers Union has pledged the union's "fullest cooperation" to President-elect Richard M. Nixon. Speaking out yesterday for the first time since Mr. Nixon's recent victory, Mr. Reuther said: "This is a time for people of goodwill of all political persuasions, races and creeds to get together to find a common answer to these challenging problems to face."

The disturbances on American campuses highlight the diverse roles of the president of a large university, and pose the question whether this is an office that he should hold until retirement age. Does he more closely resemble the professor-scholar who stays on till seventy, or the chief executive of a corporation who does not have tenure?
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Dr. Joseph L. Sutton, 44 years old, vice president and dean of faculties since 1966, was named today as the new president of Indiana University.
Penn's undefeated freshman football team scored its sixth victory of the year by trouncing Columbia, 48-7, in a game at Baker Field yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Nov. 15 -- Arthur J. Hanes, the dismissed attorney for James Earl Ray, contended today that it was "entirely possible" that he had been picked as Ray's attorney only to underscore the racial aspect of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and that he had never been expected to be the actual trial lawyer.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Nancy W. Wakeman convicted of firing a shot that left her husband, William, paralyzed, was placed on five years' probation today and ordered to abstain from liquor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A new method of printing, developed for the Radio Corporation of America, makes double use of the laser's intense beam of light.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall looked ahead today and confided that he was exploring the idea of creating a private international study group of experts to tackle the "worldwide crisis in urbanization."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following are excerpts from a pastoral letter of the American bishops of the Roman Catholic Church on birth control and conscientious objection to war:

About 80 Hunter College students detained a faculty committee for several hours in a room yesterday in an attempt to obtain classroom credit for teaching slum children during the city teachers' strike.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Officials said today, the United States has concluded "regretfully" that Communist China does not seem interested in continuing contacts in Warsaw during the remainder of the Johnson Administration.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Brazilians voted today in lackluster elections expected to leave the Government party, the National Renovating Alliance, still in firm control of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The Labor Department announced a job training program to aid servicemen who are about to enter civilian life qual ify for jobs ranging from a policeman to a television repairman. The project will include 350 servicemen in a project involving nearly 6,000 people in 27 states.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 15 -- The recent confrontation between King Hussein and Palestinian commandos operating out of Jordanian territory against Israel has led to the closing of Palestinian ranks and to more coordination among the commando organizations themselves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall indicated today that he might have time before he left office Jan. 20 to make a decision on the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's application to import oil into a proposed foreign-trade zone in Maine.
Seven City College alumni will be awarded the college's 35th annual Townsend Harris Medals for "distinguished post-graduate achievement."
The market for new issues, stock of companies only recently offered to the public, regained much of its upward momentum this week.
THIS is the season for antiques shows in the New York area.

British Petroleum announced yesterday a contingent agreement to purchase the marketing assets -- mainly gasoline stations -- of the Sinclair Oil Company in the Northeastern United States for $300-million.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The nation's Roman Catholic bishops declared today that artificial birth control was an "objective evil," but that Catholics who could not in conscience follow the church's teachings should not feel cut off from holy communion.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Max Conrad, 65-year-old "Flying Grandfather," landed his twin-engine plane at Nord, Greenland, owing to "extremely bad weather" and is awaiting a take-off for Tromso, Norway, it was learned here today.

DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Roy M. Innis, national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, urged public health officials today to support community control of health institutions as a "simple and old-fashioned solution" to the problem of health care in the cities.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Wes Ellis Jr., 36-year-old pro at the Westchester Country Club, Harrison. N. Y., smashed the Valle Arriba Club record with an eight-under-par 62 today and took the halfway lead at 130 in the Caracas open golf championship.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- North Vietnam charged the United States today with intensifying its "aggression" in South Vietnam and continuing reconnaissance flights as far north as Hanoi behind a "smokescreen" of false charges North Vietnam had violated the demilitarized zone.
WALL STREET'S rumor mill was buzzing yesterday with reports that a takeover bid for Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation was imminent.

The J. C. Penney Company, the country's second largest general merchandise and catalogue sales chain, plans to make its first major acquisition in six years by purchasing control of the Thrift Drug Company of Pennsylvania, for stock worth about $70-million.

Estelle Parsons, who won an Academy Award for her performance in "Bonnie and Clyde," will appear in the world premiere of "Honor and Offer," a comedy by Henry Livings, Nov. 21 at Cincinnati's Playhouse in the Park.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its fifth consecutive advance yesterday, completing its strongest weekly performance in months.
CINCINNATI -- You hear it again and again between Gotham and the Golden Gate that New Yorkers are, by and large, the most provincial citizens of America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 -- This summer, while the talks on Vietnam droned on in Paris, Vietcong political agents in South Vietnam were quietly holding elections in hundreds of villages, sources in the United States mission said today.
NATIONAL EDUCATIONAL TELEVISION presented "New Theater for Now," the first in its "Theater America" series devoted to the American regional theater movement, on Channel 13 last night.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 15 -- When the Oakland Raider quarterbacks assemble for their twice-weekly meetings, Eldridge Dickey is with them. And when he operates at quarterback in practice, his teammates shout, "way to go," and "nice pass," as if he were about to start Sunday against the New York Jets.

SIX months ago, a big gray stallion named Dancer's Image burst out of the ruck to win the Kentucky Derby. He held the victory for three days, until it was announced that traces of a nonnarcotic, anti-inflammatory painkiller called phenylbutazone were found in his urine. Dancer's Image was disqualified, the winner's share of $122,600 was earmarked for the runner-up. Forward Pass, and an afternoon newspaper ran the headline: "Derby Winner Doped."

Donald Driver has resigned as the director of the impending Broadway presentation of "Jimmy Shine," the Murray Schisgal play in which Dustin Hoffman is starred. Reports that Mr. Driver was planning to quit were denied recently by the management.

THE Giants are solid favorites to defeat pro football's only all-losing team, the Philadelphia Eagles, tomorrow at Yankee Stadium, but the Jets, despite their four-game winning streak, are underdogs against the Raiders in Oakland.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Alf M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee and former Kansas Governor, has been named Distinguished Professor of Political Science at Kansas State University. Dr. James McCain, president of the university, said that under the appointment, of indefinite duration, Mr. Landon, 81 years old, would make a series of appearances for informal discussions at the university each year.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 -- The cost of governing Westchester County, providing services for its affluent as well as its poor, will rise next year. County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian said today in a message presenting a proposed budget of $157.8-million for 1969.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Johnson made clear today that Richard M. Nixon would not have any decision-making role in foreign affairs before the Jan. 20 inauguration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Johnson's Thanksgiving Day proclamation, which was issued today by the White House.

The state's Young Repubicans, political advocates of pay-as-you-go, paid this week a $239 bill incurred last March at a three-day conference at the Travelers Hotel, at La Guardia Airport, but only after the hotel gave the bill to a collection agency.

Louis Abolafia, an abstract-expressionist artist who recently ran for President on the Love ticket, was arrested with three young women yesterday at Chase Manhattan Plaza in downtown Manhattan after one of the woman had partially disrobed.

PARIS, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, arrived in Paris this evening from Brussels where he had been attending a NATO parliamentary conference. Mr. Javits met with Herve Alphand, the Foreign Ministry's secretary general, who is a former French Ambassador to Washington.

If the Mozart marathons Lili Kraus has played here in recent seasons have led you to think she can do nothing else, think again. Or, better still, hear her play Schubert as she did last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
BONN, Nov. 15 -- The Christian Democratic party chose Defense Minister Gerhard Schroder today as its candidate in next year's presidential election.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 -- Arrest warrants were recommended today against two Detroit policemen accused of attacking Negro youngsters after a dance two weeks ago.
A proposal to start the 1969 World Series on a Saturday -- Oct. 11 -- will be voted on by the major league club owners at the winter meetings in San Francisco starting on Dec. 2.

Shirley Knight and William Devane will appear in "The Watering Place," a four-character drama by Lyle Kessler, scheduled to open on Broadway in February. Miss Knight is the wife of Gene Persson, who will be co-producer with James Walsh.

New York Airways, which operates a scheduled helicopter service, started flying STOL (short takeoff and landing) planes here yesterday. But its first such flight ran into a problem helicopters are not known for -- air traffic delay.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- The last of the 40,000 executives with more than a passing interest in plastics trooped their way through the International Amphitheater here today as the National Plastics Exposition came to a close.
The election of Philip Caldwell as a vice president of the Ford Motor Company was announced yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the board. Mr. Caldwell is general manager of truck operations.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Robert S. McNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, met Pakistani Government officials today to discuss the country's aid requirements, an official statement said.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- Seventy-two Atlantic City High School students, half of them white and half black, began a six-week, all-expenses-paid stay at the luxurious Traymore Hotel yesterday.
PALERMO, Sicily, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- An earthquake shook western Sicily today, but no damage was reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Leaders of Washington priests who have been disciplined by Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle in a dispute over birth control contended today that the country's Roman Catholic bishops had vindicated their position.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Transportation Department will investigate increasing costs of automobile repairs as part of its inquiry into the auto insurance industry, Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.
OTTAWA, NOV. 15 -- The Canadian Government announced today the sale of 58.5 million more bushels of wheat to Communist China.

The Appellate Division ruled in a 3-to-2 decision yesterday that the city Board of Education had acted illegally in appointing principals to schools in the controversial Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental school district in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United States balance of international payments showed a slight surplus in the third quarter for the first time in more than three years, the Department of Commerce reported today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 15 -- The Westchester Bulls, introducing a new starting quarterback in Jimmy Leclair, posted their fourth victory in the last five games tonight by defeating the Bridgeport Jets, 28-14.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Illinois served notice this week that it would seek substantial state aid to help meet the financial crisis in Catholic schools.
The Council of Supervisory Associations maintains a College Information Service Line inform high school seniors about college admissions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pentagon is considering reducing to 90 planes from 253, the planned production of the Air Force's newest bomber, the FB-111, it was reported today.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 15 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk declared today that Yugoslovia and Austria were clearly related to the security interests of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The comment was widely interpreted as a warning to the Soviet Union against further adventures in Central and Eastern Europe.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Miami Floridians beat the New Orleans Buccaneers 102-91, in an American Basketball Association game tonight with 6-foot-7-inch Les Hunter setting the victor' pace with 23 points. His teammate, Don Sidle, got 22.

PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The National Grange's 102d annual gathering heard its foreign affairs committee yesterday endorse trade of nonstrategic materials with Communist countries and recommended United States ratification of the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
Silver futures continued to move up yesterday, influenced by the crisis over the French franc and reports of troubles ahead for West Berlin from East Germany.

JONESBORO(Ark., Nov. 15 -- A lawyer for two Negro students, who were expelled from school for leaving a football pep rally where "Dixie" was played, filed a law suit here today in United States District Court.

The entire Brooklyn Public Library system closed down for one day yesterday so that all employes from maintenance workers to the library director could discuss how to improve their services to the community.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Londoners do not like their new tall buildings, and one is inclined to agree with them.

MIAMI, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Nine Cuban exiles, including Orlando Bosch, a former Havana pediatrician, weer found guilty in Federal court today of conspiring to damage ships of countries that trade with Cuba.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- A spokes man for Premier Tran Van Huong "strongly denied" today reports that the Premier had submitted his resignation to President Nguyen Van Thieu.

ATLANTA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Atlanta's leading pass catcher, Bob Long, who was injured seriously in an automobile accident Monday, will be lost to the Falcons for the remainder of the season. ATLANTA, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Richie Guerin, the Atlanta Hawks head coach who retired last year as one of the top stars in National Basketball Association history, was activated today to play for the Hawks.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Aristotle Onassis drove to London on business today and his wife, the former Mrs. John F. Kennedy, apparently spent the day at the home of her sister, Princess Stanislas Radziwill, at Henley-on-Thames 30 miles from here.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Jim Day and Jim Elder or Canada finished first and second, respectively, today in the International Welcome jumping stake at the opening of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

SAIGON, Saturday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- President Thieu said today that the United States and South Vietnamese Governments were working to resolve their differences over Saigon's participation in the Paris peace talks. Officials had said earlier that Mr. Thieu might end his boycott of the talks if he got certain assurances from Washington.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Dr. Roger Howell Jr., chairman of the department of history, was elected today as president of Bowdoin College at Brunswick, Me.

But instead of the widely-publicized crewelwork of the great seal of the United States that Richard M. Nixon received from his daughter, Julie, Mr. Humphrey's would have been a blue and gold needlepoint tapestry of a medieval king.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Dr. Otmar Emminger, central board member of the Deutsche Bundesbank, today described speculation about a revaluation of the mark this weekend as "nonsense."

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Walter C. Daniel, a 47 - year - old North Carolina educator, was named today to assume duties as president of Lincoln University next September. At that time, Dr. Earl E. Dawson, head of the school since 1956, will reach the mandatory retirement age of 65.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Leonard Marks, director of the United States Information Agency, expressed the hope today that the Soviet Union would stop its "senseless" jamming of Voice of America broadcasts. The jamming began again with the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
Archbishop Molloy High School turned the annual Marist Brothers cross-country meet into a virtual intrasquad workout yesterday, by sweeping its three races.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Cliffside Park rolled to its seventh victory in eight games when it crushed Rutherford, 32-0, today. Allie Albanese scored twice in the first half on runs of 2 and 16 yards, Gary Baraka went over twice in the fourth on a 46-yard run and a pass of 24 yards from Dennis DiBrango.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged today that President Johnson and President-elect Richard M. Nixon give high priority in their agenda for consultations to the prospect of mass starvation in Biafra.

THE Palacio de Bellas Artes dominat s one big square in Mexico City much as the Paris Opera dominates its locale. And, like the Paris Opera, the Palacio de Bellas Artes is a neoclassic building of imposing size. Architecturally, inside and out, the Palacio is of a piece, and is a good specimen of an official monument based on precepts of a previous century.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 16 -- Bruce Ball opened the second half with an 82-yard kickoff return to give Westbury the impetus it needed today to defeat Island Trees, 19-13. The victory enabled Westbury to clinch the North Shore Division championship.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Steve Worster opened the door by picking up 100 yards in the first half today as eighth-ranked Texas gained a 47-21 victory over Texas Christian to keep alive its Southwest Conference title and bowl hopes.

DALLAS, Nov. 16 -- Sales of new vehicles in Dallas County in October broke several records, and pushed total sales for the first 10 months to within 531 of the total for all of 1967.

HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Tom Miller's 22-yard field goal in the second period propelled Smithtown to its seventh straight victory today, a 3-0 decision over South Huntington.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Jim Carte raced three times across a muddy Indiana goal line in the third quarter today as Minnesota gained a 20-6 victory that spoiled Big Ten hopes for the Hoosiers.

FORT LEE, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Ralph Stanley threw two touchdown passes today as Tenafly defeated Fort Lee, 19-0. Stanley's first scoring pass went to Ed Harris for 35 yards. Early in the fourth period, he fired an 8-yard pass to Joe Nicolai in the end zone.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Czechoslovak Airlines said this week it would start using Soviet-built 1L-62 jet transports on twice-a-month flights between Prague and Havana starting Jan. 12. The airline now uses turboprop aircraft on weekly schedules. The new jets will carry 136 passengers. The Spanish airline, Iberia, uses United States-built jets on weekly flights between Madrid and Havana.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- About 100 students joined 54 others today in a fast to protest recruiting on the Oberlin College campus by the military services. The 54 students that began their hunger strike yesterday intend to subsist on vitamins and water. The other students just plan to take part in the fast for a day.

MADRID, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- Secretary Rusk arrived here tonight but canceled his scheduled talks with the Spanish Foreign Minister, Fernando Maria Castiella y Matz, after being taken ill with influenza.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- The newspaper of the Ministry of Culture sharply criticized Moscow authorities today for long delays, neglect and mismanagement in the construction of new homes for three prized institutions of culture.

SRINAGAR, India, Nov. 16 -- Chief Minister Ghulam Mohammed Sadiq of Jammir and Kashmir said here today that the police had unearthed a Pakistan - organized sabotage ring in Indian Kashmir. Mr. Sadiq said the ring was the largest to be uncovered in three years and had wide ramifications.

BELLMORE, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Victories don't come often to Mepham and if it weren't for Calhoun they might not come at all. Mepham beat Calhoun today, 19-7, to end a losing streak of 16 straight games that began the week after Mepham defeated Calhoun, 29-13 in 1966.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Central Florida, of which this city is the hub, is on the verge of a spectacular tourist boom. Largely responsible for the hum of activity is Walt Disney World, the mammoth entertainment park 17 miles south of Orlando, on which construction is just beginning.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The city fathers of Rotterdam, one of the world's largest ports, recently allocated funds to preserve 110 buildings in Delfshaven, the tiny, historic port of nearby Delft. Delfshaven was founded as Delft's seaport in the 14th century, and later became independent before being swallowed up by the Rotterdam municipality in 1886.

ON Jan. 20 next, Richard M. Nixon will become President of the United States. What sort of a President is he likely to be? Pre-inaugural forecasts are notoriously risky. No one can predict the impact of ultimate responsibility: the chemistry of the Presidency can turn a routine politician into a purposeful leader, as in the case of Polk, or a confident bureaucrat into a gloomy loser, as in the case of Hoover.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The Hambletonian trotting classic will be switched from Sunday back to Wednesday next year, the Hambletonian Maturity will be dropped and a filly race will be added in 1971, it was announced today. The changes, approved by Hambletonian Society directors, were announced by W. R. Hayes, president of the Du Quoin state fair, which sponsors the $100,000-plus betless harness race.

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- In these anxious days, when the pessimists are dominating the news, Berlin goes on proving that a determined people, backed by the steady power and policy of the United States, can prevail over all the gloomy prophecies of the day.

MEMPHIS -- James Earl Ray was arrested in London last June 8. MODERN latex (water-thinned) paints come remarkably close to being almost foolproof in application -- even when used by completely inexperienced amateurs. BIDDING can be a two-edged sword. The descriptive bidder will sometimes find that in the process of giving his partner perfectly legitimate information about his hand he has also clued in the opposition. WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A record avalanche of political mail was handled by postal workers this year, the Post Office Department said today. Mail volume runs at 82 billion pieces annually, the post office said, but the monthly average during the period from Sept. 21 to Oct. 18 was eight or nine billion pieces -- one billion above average and a record for the political season.

COLIMA, Mexico -- It could be said, as it is of Walla Walla, Wash., that they liked the name Colima so much that they used it twice. The first Colima is for the city: the second is for the state, which is on western Mexico's Pacific coast and is one of the smallest in the country.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Edgemont ended with a 4-4 won-lost record by defeating Briarcliff, 13-0, today. Rick Wolff's interception set up the first touchdown, getting the ball to the 10-yard line.

WASHINGTON -- For the first time since the famous electrical equipment industry cases of eight years ago, some executives of large, established corporations are going to jail for violations of the antitrust laws.

MADRID, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, arrived tonight for high-level military talks on the future of joint United States-Spanish military bases in Spain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The San Francisco 49ers activated Tommy Davis, a kicking specialist, today in time for tomorrow's game with the Los Angeles Rams. Davis has been on the injured list since hurting his right knee on Oct. 20 in a game against the New York Giants.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Leading all the way, the Philadelphia 76ers won their fourth straight by crushing the last-place Milwaukee Bucks, 136-92, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

AMONG the thousands of people who have been introduced to New York's jazz clubs by Pastor John Garcia Gensel during the nine years that he has been New York's "jazz pastor" was a group of European clerics who were curious to see how Gensel functioned in his unusual pastorate.

DES MOINES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Drake, with a fourth-quarter surge, defeated South Dakota State, 28-20, today. Bob Misner scored on a 1-yard plunge early in the fourth quarter to put the Bulldogs ahead, 21-20.

PARAMUS, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Paramus spotted Bergen Catholic of Oradell a touchdown lead, then rallied for a 14-6 victory today and lifted its won-lost record to 5-3. Dennis Bivona's 1-yard run, capping a 69-yard drive, and Joe Leicht's placement gave Paramus a 7-6 halftime lead.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 16 -- The women's auxiliary of St. Mary Hospital will hold its annual luncheon and fur fashion show next Saturday at the Stevens Institute of Technology on Castle Point.

NEW CONCORD, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Dave Heimerl scored the only touchdown on a 6-yard run today and Muskingum beat Hobart, 6-0.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Wesleyan University's sophomore quarterback, Peter Panciera, broke two New England small college passing records today in a game against Trinity, but it wasn't enough as the Bantams edged the Cardinals, 19-17.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Cuban armed forces radio said today that threats of sabotage against Cuba's sugar crop were increasing. It said anyone caught damaging the current sugar harvest would be executed.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 16 -- For the second straight week, an enemy conversion pass deflected by Hal Mayo gave Brien McMahon a victory. Staples of Westport was the 13-12 victim this time by the Senators who now have a 7-1 won-lost record.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Beau Brummel proved a dashing figure indeed in the $312,- 669 Garden State Stakes today. OYSTER BAY, L.I., Nov. 16 -- Tom Capozolli, coach of St. Dominic's, wanted to watch his son perform in the Eastern regional pass-punt contest at half time of the Giants-Eagles professional football game, so he talked St. Mary's into playing today rather than tomorrow. LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- British crude steel production last month reached the highest monthly level since late 1965. Weekly average output probably exceeded 590,000 tons last month, up from 542,000 tons in October, 1967.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 16 (UPI) -- An experimental re-entry vehicle launches today and sent down the Arce Western test range by an Atlas booster. The Atlas was launched by members of the 6595th Aerospace Test Wing.

NEWARK, Nov. 16 -- An important segment of Newark's Negro community, frustrated in its attempt to elect black members to the City Council in the Nov. 5 election, has organized again to try to elect a Negro Mayor in 1970.

CARACAS, Venezuala, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- Wes Ellis Jr., who set the Valle Arriba course record yesterday with an eight-under-par 62, staved off a late charge by Bert Weaver today to retain a one-stroke lead after three rounds in the 9th annual Caracas open golf tournament.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 16 -- The University of New Hampshire used a stout defense and a consistent offense to defeat the University of Massachusetts, 16-0, today before 8,000 fans in Alumni Stadium. PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 -- The New York Rangers moved into sole possession of second place in the National Hockey League's Eastern Division tonight with a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Expressway builders, who only recently have learned that they cannot blithely bulldoze people out of the way in laying concrete ribbons across the cities, now say they are having to learn an even harder lesson: How to make highways work for people, not against them.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 -- The partnership of Brian Dowling and Calvin Hill, majoring in touchdowns, was brilliant again today as Yale beat Princeton, 42-17, before 52,510 fans in the Yale Bowl for the Elis' 16th straight victory, eight having come in this season.
