Representative James H. Scheuer, an unavowed candidate for the Mayor whose aides are already trying to get him the Democratic nomination, said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay "has left a permanent mark on the office."

Grete Sultan, who has been giving piano recitals in New York for more than 20 years, last night played the first of three programs she will give this season at Town Hall. Miss Sultan does not bother with trifles. Last night's offering was nothing less than Bach's "Goldberg" Variations.

MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Western observers here likened the friction-landing technique used for Zond 6 to that of skipping a flat stone across water. The United States used a similar re-entry method with its unmanned Apollo 4 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Eight Republican fund-raising groups reported today receipt of $2.7-million in contributions and $2.4-million in expenditures during the 10-day period that ended Oct. 31.
The rain came down hard and steady as the short stocky woman looked somberly through the window of 249 Hopkinson Avenue yesterday and explained why she appeared said:

OCCIDENTAL Petroleum brought its own brand of razzle-dazzle to a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday, the first time the burgeoning oil and chemical company has touched base there since 1964.
ROME, Nov. 18 -- Italy faces a government crisis tomorrow at a time of widespread worker and student discontent and a 24-hour rail strike.
The election of A. Holly Patterson as vice chairman of the board of the Security National Bank, Huntington, L.I., was announced yesterday.

The Coast Guard said yesterday it was continuing an air-sea search in the North Atlantic in the hope that flares sighted Friday night could have come from missing crewmen of the Norwegian tanker Etnefjell.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers' Association reaffirmed today that members of the rival American Professional Golfers would be allowed to play in the 51st annual P.G.A. championship tournament here next Aug. 14 through Aug. 17.
NEWARK, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- An elderly bachelor died leaving $I00,000 in cash, securities and insurance in his house and listed no heirs, it has been disclosed.

The New York Committee of Girls Town of Italy will hold its 10th annual luncheon fashion show in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel on Thursday. The event will pay tribute to the memory of Mrs. George P. Skouras, who had been international chairman of the organization since its inception.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- A number of allied diplomats fear that the pace of the Vietnam talks will be slowed if the Nixon Administration replaces both of the American negotiators, W. Averell Harriman and Cyrus R. Vance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- For the fourth time in the last 50 years, the Supreme Court has ruled that a state can force railroads to use more men on train crews than the companies feel are necessary.

Ward attendants and food service employes at the Creedmoor State Mental Hospital in Queens went on strike yesterday in what Governor Rockefeller angrily denounced as a "union power play" that made sick people "the pawns."
MANILA, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The Eastern Moon, a 5,000-ton British steamer, rammed and sank a passenger-laden motor vessel at the entrance to Cebu harbor in the central Philippines today.
Subsidy payments to air carriers declined approximately $8.8-million in the last fiscal year, according to the Civil Aeronautics Board. Payments totaled $55.2-million.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that on Sunday evening "specific orders were issued to continue the New York Jets-Oakland Raiders football game to its conclusion, even though it ran past the beginning of 'Heidi,'" but that communications difficulties prevented those orders from being carried out.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 18 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko expressed the hope today that the "first violins of the NATO orchestra will realize that a relaxation of tensions also corresponds to their interests."

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Biafra was reported today to have expelled the hard core of its small mercenary task force, while continuing to mount major counteroffensives against federal Nigerian troops on nearly all fronts.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Nov. 18 The thing to do along Chestnut Ridge Road, when snow closed the schools and some of the roads in this still-rural suburban township, was to ski down the hill with the children and make cocoa over a fire in the snow.
A sports information center, which will provide facts and figures on records, results of games and details on coming events, opened yesterday in Pennsylvania Plaza.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the world's largest merchandising corporation, reported yesterday record earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31 and also announced a $1.5-billion expansion program.
HONG KONG, Nov. 18 -- An attempt over the weekend to win the release of a British newsman under house arrest in Peking has so far been unsuccessful.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court sustained today a $305,000 damage award for a railroad worker permanently disabled in a freight yard accident.

THE tall woman with the warm brown eyes and the cool pale gray hair shakes thousands of hands each year. Her clasp is firm and when she withdraws the pink-tipped fingers, it seems to be done with a sense of regret. But there is no assembly line bonhommie.

St. Cloud, Minn., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The president of St. Cloud State College, Robert Wick, promised Negro student leaders tonight that he would do all in his power to obtain a cultural center for minority students and to recruit more minority students for the school.

BASEBALL'S proudest boast has long been the trite but true statement: The game is never over until the final out. Presumably it represented a measure of superiority over such clock-confined sports as football where time limitations clamp down inexorably to snuff out rallies. The beauty of baseball, it is contended, is that it can continue endlessly. Much too often it just seems that way.
The man had been a patient at Creedmoor State Mental Hospital most of his adult life when, because of the threatened strike there, he was sent last week to his sister's home.
ATHENS, Nov. 18 -- Alexandros Panaghoulis, the 30-year-old army deserter who was sentenced to death by a special military court last night, is being held "incommunicado," his lawyer said tonight.

The city was assured yesterday by the Port of New York Authority that the new $60.5-million consolidated passenger ship terminal on the Hudson River would get under way in January if city approvals were given promptly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if convicts who gained retrials of old convictions can have their confessions ruled inadmissible under the Miranda vs. Arizona decision of 1966.

Your Oct. 16 editorial mentions the basic annual wage for New York City policemen as $10,325, to go up to $10,750 next year. By coincidence, today's mail also contains a recent survey of salaries' at our colleges and universities ("Notices of the American Mathematical Society," pp. 869-71).
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- A Soviet educator complained today that many young Russians were ignorant about sex and called for the introduction of sex education in schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The nation faces a "real prospect" for a recesion next year unless the incoming Nixon Administration drops the 10 per cent income tax surcharge according to a top Democratic economic policymaker in Congress.
LIBERTY, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Looming over Liberty, light from the massive bulk of Grossinger's resort hotel shone through the falling snow that soon became rain.

Through the fog and rain at Aqueduct yesterday came Rulero, carrying Ruth Cohen's colors to victory in the feature race of six furlongs. The 18,651 fans -- a large turn-out considering the inclemency -- were just able to follow the progress of the sprint, in which Rulero overtook the pace-setting Bolinasclip in the stretch to score by 1 1/4 lengths.
The 55th National Foreign Trade Convention got under way yesterday with an attack by a prominent business leader on the Government's mandatory curbs on foreign investment.
Peter Glenville has withdrawn as director of the incoming musical, "Dear World," starring Angela Lansbury. He is the second director to relinquish the staging of the $720,000 show.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Flames trapped workers behind barred windows in a Glasgow furniture factory today, killing at least 24 persons. Twenty bodies had been recovered by nightfall and four persons were missing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The A.F.L.-C.I.O. apparently is boycotting a meeting of the International Labor Organization in Geneva in protest against the organization's reaction to the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 18 -- A lawyer who drives to work on Long Island parkways obtained a court order today challenging the sharp increase in the number of traffic summonses being issued by parkway policemen in their campaign for a wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- In the view of one of the five Federal Trade Commissioners, the agency should require auto makers to provide lifetime warranties for their cars even when they have moved onto the used car market.

The city's 1.1 million public school pupils were scheduled to return to classes this morning after members of the United Federation of Teachers voted by a 6-to-1 margin yesterday to call off their citywide strike.

OTTAWA, Nov. 18 -- Fred Lebensold, the Montreal architect who designed the National Arts Center now rising in downtown Ottawa, pushed his steel helmet off his forehead and surveyed the facade of his latest creation.

DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- The American Motors Corporation today reported a loss for its fourth quarter, the period ended Sept. 30. However, the smallest American automobile maker was still in the black for all fiscal 1968, its first profitable year since 1965.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- A Federal grand jury indicted a Chicago patrolman, Joseph D. Fine, today on a charge of causing the death of a motorist last July 23 by beating him.

Added homework, delayed fall report cards and longer school days beginning Monday appear to be in the offing for city students as the public school system tries to recover the 36 days of instruction time lost during the teachers' strikes.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 --- Still full of legalistic run, Dancer's Image went to the post again here today in his continuing effort to retrieve the Kentucky Derby he supposedly won six months ago.

A watermark variation on Government documents used to convict Louis E. Wolfson, multi-millionaire Florida financier, of an alleged 1957 stock fraud might have resulted from chemicals used in papermaking, an expert witness admitted yesterday.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 18 -- The former commander in chief of the Pakistani Air Force, who announced yesterday that he was entering politics on the side of the opposition, plans to campaign for governmental reforms without joining any party.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- These are hard days for Richard Nixon in most of the European capitals, but in Moscow, where he has never been a hero, he is being treated with skeptical restraint.
PRAGUE, Nov. 18 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party published tonight excerpts from a policy resolution that appeared to presage far-ranging ideological controls in this occupied country.
Drug manufacturers will soon be ready to distribute a vaccine against Hong Kong flu.

The owner of an Orchard Street dress shop was fatally stabbed yesterday afternoon in a struggle with a teen-aged robber who escaped empty-handed when frightened off by the screams of a woman passer-by.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Sixty-eight Roman Catholic priests wrote a letter to Pope Paul VI today, denouncing a church commission set up to investigate their dispute with the Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, Archbishop of San Antonio.

A renewed effort to outlaw so-called Alimony Jail and to make women as well as men legally liable for the payment of alimony in New York State will be placed before the 1969 session of the Legislature.

Pandemonium broke loose in Madison Square Garden last night as Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, defeated The Sheik in the feature heavyweight wrestling event before more than 12,000 wildly screaming, foot-stomping fans. The Sheik was billed as the Syrian champion.

Decentralization must succeed. It must not be killed. However, it should not be accepted at all costs. Those who favor decentralization and the experiment in Ocean Hill-Brownsville must not let the word experiment become equated with expediency.
Among all the musical instruments available today, the guitar can still impress as the most subtle, most widely varied in tone, of them all. When it is played by a master, that is.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 18 -- Challenging his critics, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said in Parliament today that the economic integration of occupied areas into Israel was Government policy, not just his idea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Johnson gathered 130 top military officials and members of Congress today for an 85th birthday party for former Representative Carl Vinson of Georgia, whom the President called "my chairman, my tutor and my friend."

Dr. Herbert F. Johnson, the newly appointed trustee of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district in Brooklyn, said yesterday that he had esestablished headquarters at Intermediate School 55 at Hopkinson Avenue and Dean Street.
NAHA, Okinawa, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A B-52 bomber bound for Vietnam crashed and burned at Kadena air base early today, shaking the area with a thunderous roar, as its bombs and fuel tanks exploded.

The board of directors of Daytop Village, Inc., a narcotics addict rehabilitation center, voted unanimously last night to accept the resignation of the executive director and co-founder, David Deitch, as the element in a program aimed at resolving its dispute with a majority of its staff.

TRENTON, Nov. 18 -- The controversial Hackensack River Meadowland Development Plan, amended to exclude nearly one-third of its original area in the northern New Jersey tidal marshes, cleared the Assembly tonight, 57 to 6.
The stock market clung to an upward course yesterday despite growing concern about the monetary situation in Europe and continued uncertainty about the future of the peace talks with North Vietnam.
The 17th annual Angels Ball for the benefit of the community services of the National Council of Jewish Women's New York section, will be held at the Plaza tomorrow.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- A former Ku Klux Klan leader, Sam H. Bowers Jr., was arrested today on a murder charge in the slaying of Vernon H. Dahmer, a Negro, while preparing for his conspiracy trial in the same case.
Steel output advanced fractionally last week, marking the sixth increase in the last seven weeks, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HAMBURG, West Germany, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- A man charged with extortion and terrorizing of rail travelers by bomb threats over a period of eight years told a court here today that his misdeeds were a result of quarrels with his second wife.

Penn State, undefeated and ranked third nationally, and Kansas, a co-leader of the Big Eight Conference, accepted invitations yesterday to meet in the Orange Bowl football game the night of Jan. 1 in Miami. The Nittany Lions, with an 8-0 won-lost record, must beat Pittsburgh Saturday and Syracuse, Dec. 7, to post their first undefeated regular season since 1947 and the first 10-0 record in Penn State history.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Louis Aragon, the writer, charged the Goncourt Academy today with "cannibalism" and resigned from its jury as it was awarding its coveted annual literary award to a candidate Mr. Aragon did not support.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The top Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee says that the 10 per cent income surtax will have to be continued unless there is a quick reduction of the Vietnam war.
LONDON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Two rival tennis tournaments are competing for the crowds in London this week, and behind them lies a struggle for control of the world game.
City officials are trying to end the fragmentation of the city's job-training programs, double their output and save hundreds of millions of dollars in welfare payments in the next decade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked indirectly today to clear the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from conviction in a Birmingham civil rights march five years before his slaying.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Hand To Hand scored a seven-length victory in the $28,475 Walt Whitman Handicap at muddy Garden State Park today.
WASHINGTON -- I.F. Stone is a radical journalist who cannot bear the thought of not knowing the worst about any situation.

BROWN'S 1966 and 1967 soccer teams were strong, explosive and of championship caliber. But those teams were refused permission to compete in the National Collegiate championship tournament. Now Brown is eligible for the tournament, and the current squad, though not as powerful as the two previous units, will try to make up for what most Bruin fans consider to be an injustice.

" Inflation is likely to continue next year, and any slowdown will be moderate," Leif Olsen, senior vice president of the First National City Bank, said yesterday. At a "Think In" for women investors, he told 200 listeners that he expected the pace of inflation to run about 3 1/2 per cent next year compared with about 4 per cent this year.

A tank truck carrying 3,000 gallons of a chemical that emits deadly fumes when mixed with water skidded and overturned on rain-slicked Route 9W in Palisades, N. Y., early yesterday, forcing authorities to evacuate hundreds of persons as a precaution.

GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- The United States strongly supported today a New Zealand proposal calling for action against limitations placed on imports in contravention of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

President-elect Nixon has expressed his intention to establish a coalition government similar to the one that prevailed during World War II. In European parlance a coalition is often a euphemism for inaction and stalemate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

NEWARK, Nov. 18 -- The long-delayed trial of two former Woodbridge, N.J., officials, three industrial concerns and two executives on charges of bribery and conspiracy stalled today in a legal tangle over efforts by defense lawyers to have separate trials for the two groups of defendants.

At noon today the New York Jets will reassemble in Long Beach, Calif., where they will await Sunday's game against the Chargers at San Diego while attempting to forget their incredible 43-32 defeat in Oakland.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- One of the world's wealthiest men went before a committee of the United Nations today to appeal for more funds to help assist some of the world's poorest -the refugees.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Leaders of the Kurdish nationalist movement in Iraq have asked Secretary General Thant to send a mediator to help settle the conflict between Baghdad and insurgent Kurdish tribesmen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- It is time to do something about the traditional Inauguration Day parade which, alas, will be held next Jan. 20 as usual. The sensible thing, of course, would be to abolish it.
The New York City Opera will offer new productions of Borodin's "Prince Igor" and Verdi's "Rigoletto" in its spring season at the New York State Theater, which will run from Feb. 20 through April 20.

THOSE who expected Boom Boom Geoffrion to get vicious after his Rangers played a bad game, or overly ecstatic after a victory, have been disappointed. But yesterday, flushed with possession of first place in the National Hockey League's East Division following Sunday's 3-2 victory over the Canadiens, the Boomer showed his well-known Gallic pique.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Major economic statistics made public by Government agencies today showed some slowdown in business activity but not a consistent pattern.
L'AFRICANA, a boutique of African-inspired fashions for women and men, opened yesterday at Abraham Straus. While it may have a special appeal for Negroes, there is no color line in its fashions.

The overwhelming ratification of the school strike settlement by membership of the United Federation of Teachers yesterday is a welcome antidote to the vindictive spirit that animated the rebellious meeting of the union's delegate assembly the previous night.

TOKYO, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Shozo Saijo of Japan, the world featherweight champion, thrilled a packed house at the Korakuen Sports Arena tonight by rallying to score a dramatic eighth-round knockout over a Filipino, Flash Besande, in a scheduled 10-round nontitle bout.

An action at the United Nations General Assembly illustrates the hazard involved in the Senate's move to delay until next year the United States ratification of the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. Nine countries not possessing nuclear arms have now introduced a resolution likely, at minimum, to delay implementation of the nonproliferation treaty.

" MILTON WEBER and Louis Heilbroner must be shaking tonight," Henry C. Schwartz remarked with satisfaction. The president of Weber Heilbroner, who is 38 years old and a revolutionary, was watching the transformation of the 47th Street branch of the 3-store men's clothing chain into a discotheque.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The United States and Britain called on Israel today to make a magnanimous gesture and permit most of the half-million Arabs uprooted by the 1967 war to return before winter to their homes or to refugee camps on the Israeli-occupied west bank.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- With the Vietnam buildup nearly complete, the Army has approved plans to cut its basic combat training output by about 2,000 men every eight weeks.

John F. Hatchett, whose appointment and subsequent dismissal as director of a center for black students at New York University led to condemnations, demonstrations and a student strike, has decided he does not want the job.
The 43-year-old president of Wesleyan University said last night that it would be short-sighted for older Americans to become preoccupied with the excesses of youthful dissent.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 18 -- South Vietnamese officials said today that an important step had been taken toward ending their Government's boycott of the Paris talks, but they warned that "a lot of details" remained to be settled.

Representative Hugh L. Carey, Brooklyn Democrat, yesterday urged a national minimum standard to aid dependent children, the ill, handicapped and elderly, in an effort to end migration to New York by those seeking greater benefits.
Leaders of groups within the teachers' union that favor community control of schools were found yesterday to be critical of the agreement that ended the school strike.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- What is popularly called progress in American cities is about to be stopped dead in its tracks, or at least slowed to a stumbling halt in London. A strong Government brake is being put on the private development of large parts of this city's older, historic areas, the kind of places and names that form a litany of London history, character and beauty to both residents and visitors.

PHILADELPHIA -- Leary's Book Store, which began as a sidewalk stall in 1836 and became a seven-floor treasure house known as the largest second-hand book shop in the world, will go out of business tomorrow.

The weird world of the Galapagos Islands, the living laboratory of giant turtles, iguanas and dandelion trees that inspired Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, is reported by scientists to have survived a severe volcano eruption last summer with appreciable damage.
Your editorial entitled "Everyone Out of Step but the U.F.T." [Nov. 6] was either deliberately misleading or merely the expression or your extreme naivete.
When it comes to littering, young men are the worst offenders, according to George H. Gallup Jr., president of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

I read with interest the article by A.H. Raskin entitled "The Trouble With the Taylor Law." [Week in Review Nov 3.] Not everyone would agree that the Taylor Law is "the most comprehensive code of union rights for public employes in any state.

New York basketball fans will get a long-anticipated first look at Elvin (Big E) Hayes as a professional tonight in the second game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.
Professional sports turned toward another lucrative market yesterday with the disclosure of a track and field league that will offer annual prize money approaching $4-million.
CHICAGO Nov. 18 -- A 24-year-old seminarian who was clubbed during the Democratic National Convention sued the City of Chicago, Mayor Richard J. Daley and Chicago policemen today for $1.25-million.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 18 -- Marion Tolson, one of the few Negro drivers in harness racing, doesn't really have aspirations to be a reinsman. The 50-year-old Brooklynite, whose future is directed toward training standardbreds, drove Wilder in tonight's first race at Roosevelt Raceway only for a special reason.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Members of the United States delegation at the peace talks here continued today to voice confidence that the Saigon regime was inching toward participation in the negotiations. However, these sources would not venture to predict when the impasse would be resolved.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- In another day of uneasiness in the financial markets of Europe, speculation continued today that the French franc would see its international value reduced and the German mark its international value increased.

John (Peanuts) Manfredonia, a reputed Mafia figure and one of Westchester County's biggest bookmakers, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to 18 months in prison and fined $4,000 for perjuring himself during an earlier trial on gambling charges.
On a rain-swept course, ankle-deep in mud in places, Steve Stageberg of Georgetown captured the I.C. 4-A university-division cross-country crown with ease yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Premier Maurice Couve de Murville declared tonight that France's monetary allies had assured her of "all the help she might need or will need in the future, without any reservation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- President Johnson will award Medals of Honor tomorrow to five Army men, including the first chaplain to receive one for extraordinary heroism in Vietnam.

The Nov. 7article of Anthony Lewis in The Times concerning election reform, prompts this suggestion -- that Presidential elections should be abandoned. That instead the nation should elect only a Vice President who in four years would automatically assume the office of President for the following four years.

All bridge experts are scared of ghosts, in a strictly technical sense. They fear the "phantom," a sacrifice bid that turns out to be futile because it develops that the opponents' contract would have failed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Supporters of Senator Roman L. Hruska of Nebraska said today that he had more than enough commitments for election as the assistant Republican leader, or party whip, in the new Senate.

A husband who committed bigamy and averted prison through the "grace" of his legal wife, was held here yesterday to have the right to sue her for divorce on the ground that they had not lived together for two years.

A YOUNG Austrian architect stepped out of a converted garage in Wooster Street in Greenwich Village over the weekend, with his eyes bright with excitement. "There is nothing like that anywhere in Europe, no?"

MEXICO CITY -- As a prod for a city just emerging from provincialism, the Cultural Olympics is admitted to be the greatest thing that ever happened. Running in connection with the Olympic games, it started last January and still has over a month to go.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The three-month Treasury bill rate was unchanged at today's auction from the preceding one held Nov. 8, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The rate on the six-month bills rose.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- A liberal Democrat said today that the Speaker of the House did not have to be a member of Congress and urged Vice President Humphrey to seek the post. Mr. Humphrey, however, promptly rejected the idea.
The London Stock Exchange closed on a firmer note yesterday after initial dullness.

The strike that has disrupted operations at Creedmoor State Mental Hospital in Queens Village is the ultimate expression of everything that is wrong with labor-management relations in the civil service.

In moderately heavy trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday for the sixth straight session. The exchange index closed at $31.39, up 11 cents, another record, for the third day in a row.
Will securities markets continue their restricted four-day trading week into December?
ZURICH, Nov. 19 -- Swiss bankers, ever ready with advice on other people's currency problems, are divided on the best resolution of the crisis over the French franc and the German mark.

DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Nov. 19 -- Max Reimann, the 70-year-old West German Communist leader who returned last week after 14 years of exile in East Germany, announced today that he was seeking negotiations with the Bonn Governmemt to lift the ban on his Communist party of Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Manuel F. Cohen, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, warned the insurance industry today it would not automatically be exempted from regulation under the securities laws as it moves more and more into the selling of securities.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 19 -A 19-year-old youth who went back to a dairy store to return $120 that he and an accomplice had stolen at knife-point was given special consideration in court here today and released in his father's custody.

"My PORES are 'almost invisible.' Isn't that exciting?" Hope Skillman squealed like a teen-ager. The textile executive, who retired a few years ago, was having her skin programmed on an itty bitty pastel-colored computer.

A three-man committee empowered to investigate charges of violations of the rights of teachers and supervisors held its first meeting yesterday and announced that it would try to give "instant hearings" to complaints.

MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- The Supreme Court of the Russian Republic turned down today an appeal by five persons sentenced last month for blocking pedestrian traffic on Red Square by staging a demonstration against the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Johnson urged the nation and its fighting men today to stand fast in Vietnam.

THE Piri Thomas scream of anguish and cry for dignity, incorporated in his autobiography entitled "Down These Mean Streets," was transformed last night into a television documentary of uncommon artistry and force.

DENVER, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- A "concussion" causing "acrid brown smoke and changes in cabin pressure" rocked a jetliner today high over the Rocky Mountains. The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had arrested one man in the incident.

Newell Jenkins may qualify for some kind of prize when it comes to packing a concert program with novelties of one sort or another. The Clarion Concerts program he conducted at Town Hall last night is a typical example of what he can do.
The city took the first legal step yesterday toward foreclosing the mortgages of 14 cooperative apartment projects housing 9,269 families, some of whom have refused to pay increased carrying charges.

A pulsing source of celestial radio emissions, or "pulsar," has been discovered almost exactly where astronomers had predicted the existence of a super-dense "cinder" left by a steMar explosion observed in A.D. 1054.

LIVINGSTON, N. J., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate minority leader, rested comfortably today after undergoing a series of undisclosed tests at St. Barnabas Medical Center.

ATLANTA, Nov. 19 (AP) -Fonty Flock, former national stock car racing champion, has filed a $4-million suit accusing the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing and its president of "monopolistic control over stock car racing in the South."
The stock market's post election rally continued unabated yesterday as winners topped losers for the ninth consecutive session.
Doyle Dane Bernbach has been assigned about $6-million in advertising by the Quaker Oats people.

GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Union is experimenting with mild electrical shocks to improve the circulation of future astronauts. This way they hope to help keep them fit for space flights of a year or more to Mars and Venus, it was disclosed today.

BONN, Nov. 19 -- Official sources said today that West Germany intends to resist what they described as United States pressure to abandon a German plan for bringing Britain and the Scandinavian countries closer to the European Common Market.

The city's public school teachers and pupils returned to their classrooms generally without incident yesterday morning after a five-week teachers' strike, but new troubles erupted last night in the controversial Ocean Hill-Brownsville district in Brooklyn.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics today placed New Mexico Highlands University on probation for the remainder of the school year, knocking the school's No. 1 ranked football team out of the N.A.I.A. post-season playoffs.

A 46-year-old psychologist was critically wounded yesterday by a man described as a former patient who burst into his East Side office, fired two shots with a .22-caliber pistol and fled into the street with the wounded man in pursuit.

Three-quarters of a million people may die of starvation in Biafra during December unless Nigeria's civil war can be ended promptly. This grim projection by responsible international relief agency officials is based on evidence that Biafra's remaining supply of starch foods will be exhausted by the end of the year.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 -- The Department of Justice sought today to intervene in a suit against the Pasadena school system. It accused the system of espousing racially discriminatory policies in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

The 1969 Opel, the General Motors West German-built car which is second in sales here to Volkswagen, will go on display tomorrow in dealer showrooms. For the first time the four-cylinder cars will be available with a fully automatic three-speed transmission, an unusual feature for a small economy import.
It would prove a tremendous advance in human enlightenment if it were equally as prestigious for public servants to visit a psychiatrist as it is to visit a dentist.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Supporters of the seating of Communist China in the United Nations lost ground again today in the annual vote in the General Assembly on the issue of Chinese representation.

THE "Hippolytus" presented at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden last night by the Piraikon Theatron of Greece represents an approach to Greek tragedy that seems to this reviewer fatally misguided and, worse than that, fatally boring.

OF all the chess-playing brothers, the strongest pair in the world is Grandmaster Robert Byrne of Indianapolis and International Master Donald Byrne of State College, Pa. Tough opposition in any company -- and moving at the top of their form -- they bowled over two of Australia's top players in the recent 53-nation team matches at Lugano, Switzerland.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 20 -- The popularity of the New York Jets, compared to that of the Giants, will be tested Sunday in a television confrontation.
ATHENS, Nov. 20 -- The maximum three-day period between death sentence and execution expired tonight for Alexandros Panaghoulis, the man who tried to kill Premier George Papadopoulos on Aug. 13.
Federal mediators intervened yesterday in the three-week strike by network musicians, summoning both sides in the contract dispute to a meeting Saturday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -- This is where America stops. Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm at the close yesterday following earlier irregularity over the meeting of Western finance ministers in Bonn.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- France is believed here tonight to be standing firm at the emergency monetary conference in Bonn against any unilateral devaluation of the franc.

NAPLES, Italy, Nov. 20 -- Despite President de Gaulle's official policy of military disengagement from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, France appears to be moving back toward effective military cooperation with her Western allies in several important spheres.

The $24-million luxury liner Hamburg of the German Atlantic Line, scheduled to undergo sea trials next week, has what engineers believe to be the most efficient funnel of any passenger ship in the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- Policemen were called to the San Francisco State College campus today when renewed violence broke out.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Frederick B. Thompson was found guilty of murder in the first degree tonight and will be executed for slaying his former employer, Mrs. Dorothy Beck Palmer, more than two years ago.

FARMINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 21 -- Mining company and union officials refused to abandon hope tonight for 78 men trapped here since yesterday in the nearly volcanic inferno of an exploding, burning, gas-filled coal mine.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21 -- Racing's shapeliest jockey insists she is not a publicity hound, a crusader for women's rights or a demented daredevil.

VOYEURS of the world unite -- you have nothing to break but your binoculars! Terrence McNally's double bill, opening last night at the Gramercy Arts Theater, has, in the end a little more to offer than voyeurism, pure and not so simple.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Arthur Grafton, attorney for Peter Fuller, owner of the disqualified Kentucky Derby winner, Dancer's Image, challenged today the validity of a Kentucky racing rule that bars a horse from participating in a purse if evidence of phenylbutazone, or a derivative, is found during urinalysis.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Freedom of the press is in grave danger from constant erosion and qualification, Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, said today.

"ALL HE DID was paper the walls here and there, stretch some fabric across the ceiling and then spray the whole area with plastic foam," Paul J. Smith said, banging his fist against the rock-hard surface framing the entryway of the Museum of Contemporary Crafts, 29 West 53rd Street.

MANILA, Nov. 21 -- President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines said today that his Government was assessing a new foreign policy to prepare for a possible withdrawal of United States power from East Asia.

The strike of ward attendants and other nonprofessional employes at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens was extended yesterday to the Bronx State and Manhattan State Hospitals. Dr. Alan D. Miller, Commissioner of the state's Mental Hygiene Department, reported that the patient load had been eased at both the Bronx and Manhattan hospitals by sending many patients home and by transferring others.

Your editorial "The U.N. China Problem" (Nov. 14) argues that "the really important question, however, is not answered by these votes" on the Chinese representation question. You emphasize that "it is how to bring China back into the community of nations."

Two of the nation's largest retail chains, the W. T. Grant Company and the S. S. Kresge Company, announced yesterday higher earnings for the fiscal quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31, while a third retailer, Gimbel Brothers reported lower profit figures for the periods.

Port Jersey, a $150-million industrial center with a 17-berth terminal for containerships, will be built on the New Jersey side of Upper New York Bay adjoining the United States Military Ocean Terminal in Bayonne.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Even before Richard M. Nixon gives the first post-election signal on how he will move in the critical area of cities and race relations, citizens' groups are organizing for a fight to expand the role of the Federal Government in this area.

A dynamite explosion at an excavation site in mid-Manhattan startled many persons in the area yesterday, damaged cars in a parking lot with a shower of stones and broke many windows in surrounding buildings.
The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in net income for the 12 months ended Oct. 31.

The N.A.A.C.P. has urged Negroes to speak out "loud and clear" against what it called "extremists who are shrilly and insistently espousing apartheid; racism, including anti-Semitism; intimidation and violence."

A plan to create a separate Harlem school district, independent of the districts in the rest of the city, was outlined to Board of Education members yesterday by Roy Innis, the national director of the Congress of Racial Equality.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Nov. 21 -- The countryside surrounding this Seaport city and stretching southward has seen a major increase in enemy activity in the last five days.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 21 -- Russell Rash, Joe Bonacorsa and Maurice Pusey, three drivers involved in a pile-up in the second race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, were fortunate to escape serious injury. The drivers suffered only bruises and abrasions in the accident during the Class C-3 one-mile pace, won in 2:10 4-5 by the favored Tag A Star, who paid $5 straight.

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Joseph Francis Cowan, 29 years old, one of four fugitives sought as suspects in a possible nationwide bombing conspiracy, was arrested today in a farm labor camp in this coastal resort community just south of San Francisco.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -Yoko Ono suffered a miscarriage today. Nurses at Queen Charlotte's maternity hospital said the Japanese girlfriend of the Beatles' John Lennon was in satisfactory condition.

Bundled against the blustery morning cold, shuffling uncertainly under the soothing direction of doctors and uniformed attendants, 650 patients began an exodus yesterday from Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island.

MADRID, Nov. 21 -- The revelation by Foreign Minister Castiella of his suggestion to Secretary of State Rusk for the withdrawal of both Soviet and American forces from the Mediterranean has caused considerable perplexity in diplomatic circles here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Lee C. White, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission, cautioned today against the widespread belief that President-elect Richard M. Nixon would make large and immediate changes in the policies of the Government agencies that directly regulate business.
About 150 mothers who receive welfare assistance staged a demonstration at E. J. Korvette's downtown Brooklyn store yesterday demanding credit to permit winter clothing purchases.
THE game began in Wall Street even before the final tally. The question raised was what Presidentelect Nixon would do about Government controls over business.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- William H. Rentschler, who as Richard M. Nixon's Illinois campaign manager helped engineer the Republican victory, said today he was looking for a job.
City College officials told hundreds of shouting, shivering engineering students yesterday that industrial interviewers would return today to continue talking to seniors.
DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Production of automobiles continues to surpass previous records with a large boost from increased Saturday operations, Automobile News reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -The Washington Post said today that the principal national Republican campaign committee in Massachusetts received $30,000 from the First National Bank of Boston.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Stan Smith, United States Davis Cup player from Los Angeles, went into the semi-finals of an international indoor tennis tournament today with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Gerald Battrick of Britain.

It was another busy day yesterday for the merger makers, with at least 49 transactions in various stages of resolution, but the biggest and most noteworthy involved two giants in the entertainment world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Justice Department is beginning an inquiry that appears likely to dump into Richard M. Nixon's lap the question of whether to prosecute Republican fund-raisers who filed their reports too late.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh and two others were honored by the National Institute of Social Sciences here last night. The others honored were Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the church leader, and Eugene R. Black, a former head of the World Bank.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Two seemingly unreleated recent events in Okinawa -- a local election and a plane crash -- may force President-elect Richard M. Nixon to grapple with a new military strategy for the Far East sooner than he might have wished.
The financial convulsions in Europe this week produced massive flows of funds in the New York money market, banking figures released yesterday showed.
The Board of Estimate early last evening cleared the way for construction of a $60.5-million terminal from West 45th Street to 50th Street to serve all passenger liners that call here.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- The State Court of Appeals today upheld the constitutionality of the provision in the Taylor Law that bars strikes by public employes.

ALTHOUGH many golfers who play the 19th hole agree this is the time for all good golfers to come to the aid of their game, impending legal action continues to blur the professional tournament horizon.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (UPI) -Mass production of powerful intercontinental rockets to meet growing space exploration needs has started at the Soviet Union's "Rocket City," the Trade Union newspaper, Trud, reported today.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The British consumer braced himself today for a new squeeze on his buying power.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 -- A Senate investigation of the Black Panthers, the Negro militant group, is in the formative stage, Washington sources confirmed today.
BUDAPEST, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union overrode the objections of rebels among the Western Communist parties and won agreement today for a meeting of world Communist leaders in Moscow next May.
BONN, Nov. 31 -- West Germany's stance in the international monetary crisis tonight signaled its sudden growth after a long period as a political featherweight in the world arena.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 21 -- Physicians were warned today that heart disease might stem unexpectedly from the use of an experimental vaccine against streptococcal infections, and some drugs used to treat mental illness.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mob violence accompanying the visit to Calcutta of Robert S. McNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, continued into its second day today as the police and students again clashed, in front of the United States Information Services building.

A boy will be born and a man will die on television on Dec. 1 as the Public Broadcasting Laboratory opens its season with an apparent effort to change the image from its frequently troubled initial year.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored a goal in each period tonight to defeat the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-0, and take first place in the National Hockey League's East Division.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 -- Pinhas Sapir, one of Israel's most influential leaders, said today that the question of integrating the occupied territories into Israel had never reached the Cabinet.
Opponents of a proposed $46.5-million high-speed rail link from Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport succeeded last night in winning an indefinite delay in the city's approval.

TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes conditionally vetoed the controversial Hackensack River Meadowland Development Plan tonight, calling on the Republican legislative majorities to restore nearly one-third of the original development tract they had taken out Monday.

Electronic box offices for the sale of reserved seats have been installed this season for the first time in eight legitimate showcases here, four on Broadway and four off. The automated vending machines are also connected to a network of remote sales outlets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The United States Senate barred the press and the public on Oct. 2, swore its employes to secrecy, locked its doors and discussed the America that would remain following a "nuclear exchange" with the Soviet Union.

Columbia University reported yesterday it had started new programs in the fields of urban and minority affairs. To do this and at the same time to re-examine its courses, it has drawn $4.2-million from a $10-million credit opened for it by the Ford Foundation two years ago.

An air of optimism pervaded the 53d annual meeting of the Rubber Manufacturers Association yesterday in the Essex Hotel here despite a warning by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, the luncheon speaker, that there was some danger of inflation.
The London Stock Exchange closed marginally easier yesterday. However, there was further improvement in gold shares on hedge buying.

PARIS -- The immediate result of the Czechoslovakian crisis has been a tightening up of the two alliances that divide Europe into Western and Eastern blocs. Furthermore, in each instance -- that of NATO and that of the Warsaw Pact -- ties between the superpowers and their smaller allies have been strengthened.
The top of the marketing team of American Motors was in town yesterday to explain its contribution to the company's first profitable fiscal year since 1965.

The Southern Pacific Company, the nation's second largest railroad (Penn Central is No. 1), and one of the most diversified trnsportation systems in the country, took steps yesterday that would help it pursue further acquisitions.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- American officials here are taking a fairly optimistic line about President-elect Nixon's chances of reaching an accommodation with the Soviets on both military arms reduction and the Middle East during the first year of the new American Administration.

VIENNA, Nov. 21 -- Britain annoyed her partners in the European Free Trade Association today with her coolness toward recent French-West German ideas for bridging the division of Europe through tariff reductions, without necessarily enlarging the six-nation European Economic Community.
The Transamerica Corporation yesterday got a 39-year-old president who will be its chief operating officer.
The president and two employes of a defunct Florida land company were convicted here yesterday by a jury in Federal Court of a scheme to sell undeveloped Florida land -- mostly underwater.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 -- The army-backed Greek regime decided tonight to spare the life of Alexandros Panaghoulis, the 30-year-old army deserter who tried to kill Premier George Papadopolous on Aug. 13, a Government official said.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- A well-informed South Vietnamese said today that Vietcong representatives here had made overtures for confidential contacts with Saigon's observers at the Paris talks, but had been rebuffed.

VICTORIA DE LOS ANGELES has reached the stage in her career where, so far as her audience is concerned, she can do no wrong. (Why is it, one idly wonders, that singers call forth an intensity of idolatry that is rarely matched elsewhere in public life?) And, in her Carnegie Hall recital last night, the Spanish soprano proved entirely worth the adoration bestowed upon her by a large and loudly vocal public.

Cherubini's Requiem in C is not usually ranked with the big four of Requiems -- the Mozarts, the Brahms, the Verdi and the Berlioz. However, as sung last night by the Dessoff Choirs at Philharmonic Hall, the Cherubini could hold its own anywhere.

When the tumult and the shouting have died down regarding the present school crisis, the least discussed but most vital questions will still remain: What about the educational future of this city? In all sincerity and candor, I cannot see a fruitful conclusion.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Nov. 16 -- This tiny island crowded with people and sugar cane is about to celebrate its second birthday as an independent nation. Prime Minister Errol W. Barrow and 250,000 other "Bajans" think that they are making a go of it.

The National Institutes of Health announced yesterday that it would sponsor a threeyear clinical study of a promising new treatment for Parkinson's disease, a chronic and difficult-to-treat disorder of the central nervous system that incapacitates more than 1.5 million Americans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -A Spanish suggestion for a mutual withdrawal of both the United States and Soviet fleets from the Mediterranean has met a distinctly cool response here.

NEW HAMPSHIRE Fish and Game Department biologists continue to dramatize the Connecticut River's potential for supporting anadromous fish, the salt-water species that run up rivers and streams to spawn.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Pope Paul VI said today that he would "very willingly" have gone to Hanoi this month to attend celebrations of the 100th anniversary of the consecration of the Hanoi diocese if circumstances had been more favorable.

Prices rose in the money and capital markets yesterday for the second consecutive day, partly because Wall Street expected the international currency crisis to be resolved soon and partly because interest rates had climbed so high investors at last stepped up their purchases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Arms manufacturers complained today that the Government's proposed rules to enforce the new gun control law overrode the intent of Congress and were likely to drive small dealers out of business.

SAIGON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- United States military command reported today an increase in the number of enemy troops killed in the week ended Saturday and attributed it to the pressure being maintained by allied forces.
The state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, yesterday ruled, in effect, that Richard Rodgers and the estate of Oscar Hammerstein 2d must pay Leland Hayward and Richard Halliday $1,119,145.

IF FROGS fascinate you, hop on over to Cartier's new "gift salon" on the second floor at Fifth Avenue and 52d Street and prepare to be fascinated by frogs that do everything but keep you up nights with their croaking.

The recent news of the petition of the City of New York for leave to intervene in opposition to the proposed Consolidated Edison Company power plant at Storm King Mountain poses a number of questions other than the precise legal points to be decided by the Federal Power Commission.
Larousse, the French publisher of encyclopedias, dictionaries and manuals of art, medicine, gastronomy and natural science, is planning to establish a Fifth Avenue beach-head early next year.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 (AP) -The head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference said today that the conference had no intention of paying a $71,795 bill to the Federal Government.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange declined to 20,644,130 shares on Nov. 15 from the month-earlier total of 21,490,611 shares, the Big Board announced yesterday. he decline was 846,481 shares.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will continue to operate on a four-day week in December in preparation for five-day weeks with shortened trading hours starting in January.

Sharp increases in draft quotas and in the percentage of college graduates among those eligible for induction spell trouble for the new Administration and Congress unless both act quickly to achieve overdue reforms in the Selective Service System.
Long Island Rail Road commuters, starting Monday, will have to adjust to their first major timetable change in 20 years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Federal Aviation Administration has recommended the building of nine STOLports in New York City, including four in Manhattan.
WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 21 -- Waterbury's 900 public school teachers and principals went on strike today, forcing the cancellation of classes for the city's 18,000 pupils.

A 3-year-old filly, who had been on the sidelines since September, Sweet Tooth of the Calumet Farm, demonstrated at Aqueduct yesterday that the rest had done her good. Competing in the feature, a six-furlong sprint, Sweet Tooth, won by five lengths, under the steering of Angel Cordero.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Sir Elwyn Jones, Britain's Attorney General, said today that he was considering "all aspects" of the speech made here over the weekend by Enoch Powell, who denounced colored immigration in terms generally viewed as racist.
The ANTA Theater, a Broadway house, has been given to the United States Government, which will develop it as a performing arts center.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 -- The Israeli Supreme Court declined today to decide "who is a Jew" and recommended instead that the Government nullify the law pertaining to the question.

The dismissal from the police force of a patrolman who had been under suspension for the past five years for alleged involvement in a Mafia plot to kill informers was announced yesterday at police headquarters.
A three-car train was auctioned for $75,000 yesterday. Only three bidders tried for the train, known as the Permacel Express.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today a Federal Communications Commission ruling that radio and television stations that carry cigarette advertising must devote a significant amount of broadcast time to presenting the case against smoking.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 18 -- It was in the midst of a reception he was giving for visiting Western newsmen early this month that Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced his new policy on the admission of foreign journalists.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 21 -- Nigeria and the Soviet Union signed their first economic and technical-assistance agreement here today, a $140-million package of long-term credits formalizing the close relationship the Russians have been building with the war-torn nation.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The public opening of the rapid transit extension to Cleveland's Hopkins Airport was marred today by an accident in which 35 passengers on new "airporter" cars were reportedly shaken up.

BARROW, Alaska, Nov. 21 (AP -- Seven persons were killed and one critically injured in the crash of a twin-engine Aero Commander near here today. Five of the dead were members of the Alaska Governor's Em ployment Advisory Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A panel of scientists recommended today that the American people be allowed to judge sonic booms for themselves before they are subjected to this noise by regular supersonic transport flights.
BONN, Nov. 21 -- West Germany's Defense Ministry reported today that "sabotage and obstructionism" in the armed forces had risen sharply this year along with conscientious objection to the draft.

The Federal Power Commission has acted wisely in ordering a reopening of the hearings on Consolidated Edison's plan for building a hydroelectric plant on Storm King Mountain. It could hardly have done otherwise in view of the city's contention, belated though it was, that blasting for the project might endanger the watersupply for nearly eight million people.

A tense confrontation outside Junior High School 271 yesterday brought angry threats from the teachers' union of another strike, but state officials resolved the dispute after three and a half hours and peace returned -- for the moment at least -- to the troubled city school system.
Stock prices closed slightly lower yesterday after working their way out of an early sinking spell. Trading activity was the highest in almost a month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- A Federal judge denied today a request to block Federal guidelines requiring newspapers to abolish the practice of listing classified job advertisements separately for men and women.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 22 -- American artillery fired into the northern half of the demilitarized zone yesterday for the first time since President Johnson stopped the bombardment of North Vietnam three weeks ago.
The French franc and the British pound remained under severe pressure in the foreign-exchange market here yesterday, a session characterized by even less activity than on Wednesday.

The Board of Estimate last night approved a rezoning designed to prevent the construction of office buildings in place of any of a cluster of luxury hotels in the Fifth Avenue Grand Army Plaza area of Manhattan from 58th to 61st Street.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Russian poet, has come under bitter criticism in Britain as a pretended rebel who really is a propagandist for the Soviet regime.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 19 -- Robert S. McNamara was told by Indian leaders, in the three days of talks he held with them here, that they were making reduction of their heavy dependence on foreign aid one of the main aims of their economic planning.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 21 -- As a precaution against another breakdown in Sam Walton's pass-blocking, two guards, Dave Herman and Randy Rasmussen, practiced today at offensive right tackle as the New York Jets prepared for Sunday's game against the Chargers in San Diego.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The clue that finally led to the finding of the nuclear submarine Scorpion two miles deep in the Atlantic Ocean was a small piece of metal that may not have been from the ill-fated vessel.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Sheriff's deputies and policemen today arrested about 100 students, most of them Negroes, who went on a rampage through the administration building of Wisconsin State University's Oshkosh branch and occupied the president's office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The West Virginia coal mine where 78 miners were trapped yesterday has a long record of safety violations, but it is not far different from the vast majority of American coal mines.
Eleven of the nation's college football players were named yesterday as the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame scholar-athletes for 1968. Ten of the 11 were linemen.
The city's Health Department announced yesterday a drop of almost 50 per cent in the number of rat bites reported in the city over the last five years.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 21 -- The Los Angeles Rams are feeling the grinding pressure of the National Football League race, meaning the necessity of having to win every Sunday to stay within reach of the Baltimore Colts.

The role of Juliet in Shakespeare's play seems to loom eternally as a lure and challenge to actresses in the spoken theater, but it is unlikely that many sopranos regard the part in Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" as a prize.
Robert K. Ruskin, a former assistant United States attorney and former first deputy commissioner of investigation, was named Commissioner of Investigation yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

Governor Rockefeller, who has sat on the comfortable sidelines watching Mayor Lindsay hop from one labor crisis to another, is facing now in the mental hospital strike what some labor specialists see as only the beginning of his own labor headaches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Justice Department filed today the Government's first desegregation suit against a public housing agency, accusing the Little Rock (Ark.) Housing Authority of racially segregating its facilities.

Two members of the Board of Education have called for an investigation into the awarding of recent school construction contracts to a corporation that was barred from building schools seven years ago.
In one of the heaviest trading days since July 11, prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the seventh session in a row. The exchange index closed at $31.60, up 9 cents.

THE 1969 North American world championship team will be the first for seven years to lack a New York partnership, although it will include George Rapee, playing with Sidney Lazard of New Orleans, and Bill Eisenberg, a former New Yorker now living in Dallas.
A tentative contract agreement was reached yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company and Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union moments before the expiration of a noon deadline set by the union.

The planning of housing for the Milbank-Frawley Circle area of Harlem, drawn out for three years by bitter wrangling, took a step forward last night when the Board of Estimate unanimously approved a proposal to create apartments for families with a moderate income.
BONN, Friday, Nov. 22 -- An international monetary conference was deadlocked this morning over the issue of revaluation of the West German mark and devaluation of the French franc.

Walt Bellamy, one of the most expensive New York Knickerbockers, drew his second fine of the season yesterday but this time it was his own doing. Red Holzman, the Knick coach, slapped his 6-foot-11-inch center with a $50 fine for missing the plane from Atlanta to Boston.

The crisis of the French franc -- over which the Finance Ministers of ten nations were still deadlocked last night -- is a symptom of a deeper disorder that is political and psychological in its origins as well as economic and financial.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Fear of an imminent devaluation subsided here today, but Frenchmen in many walks of life confessed that their confidence in the long-term stability of their money had been deeply shaken. Critics of the regime and some supporters cast about for where to put the blame.
PRAGUE, Nov. 21 -- The 76-hour sit-in strike by tens of thousands of Czechoslovak students in defense of this occupied nation's liberties ended at noon today in perfect order and discipline.
BAMAKO, Mali, Nov. 21 (Agence France-Presse) -- Portraits and statues of President Modibo Keita are being torn down throughout Mali two days after his ouster by army leaders.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 21 -- A boycott by jockeys at Churchill Downs prevented Penny Ann Early from doing today what the Kentucky Racing Commission had licensed her to do: ride in thoroughbred horse races.

Yesterday's brief flare-up of hostilities in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district makes plain the necessity for responsible adherence by all parties to the ground rules on which the present truce must rest.

FIVE years ago today President John Fitzgerald Kennedy was shot and killed in Dallas. Last June 5, his brother and Presidential aspirant, Senator Robert Francis Kennedy, was shot in Los Angeles. He died the following day. It is no wonder at all that we are confronted at this time with an outpouring of books on these two men and the national anguish of their deaths.
Prices of silver futures dropped sharply yesterday as reassuring statements emanated from Europe that the beleaguered French franc would receive support from other leading nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, swamped in a backlog of unprocessed registration statements for stock issues, announced today the temporary adoption of procedures designed to eliminate the backlog.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- After 10 years as a minority leader, Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen is emerging as the de facto leader of the Senate, commanding a middle-of-the-road coalition inclined to work in harmony with the Nixon Administration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- A $35-million contract award was announced today for start of construction of a new, "quiet" American submarine.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21 -- A Jesuit priest told 300 Protestant mission leaders today that "saving souls" from eternal damnation was no longer a valid theology for the worldwide Christian missionary effort.

Clark M. Clifford, Secretary of Defense, says: "Two senior staff members of the Depart ment of Defense recently visited various centers of the United Service Organi zations in Guam, South Vietnam, Thailand, Okinawa, and Korea.

A $3.5-million grant for charitable and educational programs in the New York area has been presented to the Cardinal Spellman Memorial Foundation by the Dorothy H. and Lewis Rosenstiel Foundation, Archbishop Terence J. Cooke, announced yesterday.
Following are the basic facts and issues in the strike by District 50 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes against three of the state's 24 mental hospitals:

After 35 years the forest in Spruce Notch is tall and sturdy. It began during the Depression when work gangs planted thousands of tiny seedlings in abandoned pastures on Richmond Peak in the northern Catskills.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission heard pleas today for direct Federal financial support for agencies of states, cities and counties that are trying to protect consumers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -In a sparkling sunrise and again in the radiance of a splendid autumn afternoon, the last of the Kennedy brothers went to two graves today on the saddest and most celebrated hill in Arlington National Cemetery.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 22 -- The town dock here finally drew recognition today as the starting point for the first trans-Atlantic commercial flight on July 9, 1937.

Volunteer fire companies survive in scores of suburban communities today, partly because they provide economical and reasonably effective fire protection where most of the structures are private homes and partly because they offer an opportunity for men to find excitement outside their daily routine.

A strong field in which nine of the 11 contestants have won in stakes competition will run in the Gallant Fox Handicap at Aqueduct today. If all go, the 30th running of the event will have a gross value of $59,000, with the winner getting $38,350.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson began her final trip around the country as First Lady today after telling a group of newly naturalized citizens that the idea of America was to "give the individual a place to stand tall and breathe free -- regardless of who he is or where he comes from."

DETROIT, Nov. 22 -- New car sales bounced up sharply in the middle third of November with the auto companies today reporting 289,210 retail deliveries, up from 196,012 sales from Nov. 11 to 20 a year ago.

A wide-ranging stock promotion that attracted investors from coast to coast was enjoined here yesterday by a Federal Court judge who forbade the sale of the unregistered stock of the Dyna Ray Corporation.
WHILE most of Wall Street is figuring out deft year-end tax maneuvers, Edward G. Shufro of Shufro, Rose Meyer, the small Big Board member firm, is telling customers to stand pat.
A hearing will be held at City Hall Dec. 3 on the renewal permit for a heliport on top of the 59-story Pan Am Building, even though helicopter service there ended last February.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- President de Gaulle was 78 years old today. But instead of congratulations and good wishes, a flood of bitterness and recrimination from his countrymen started to pour in over the head of the national hero who has led France for the last 10 years.
It was midnight Friday, and James Brown, the soul singer, dancer, black leader and businessman, was still holding sway in front of 17,000 involved listeners at Madison Square Garden.

FOR the first time this season, the Giants and the Jets are simultaneous underdogs. The Rams are 10-point favorites over the Giants tomorrow in Los Angeles, while the Chargers are 6-point choices over the Jets in San Diego.

The Dayton Chamber of Commerce canceled last night its contract to hold the 1969 Professional Golfers' Association championship, recognized as one of the four major events in the sport. The tournament, with a purse of $175,000, was scheduled for the Ohio city at the National Cash Register course Aug. 14 through 17.
The nation's railroads after the end of the year are going to take over the operation of the sleeping cars now handled for them by the Pullman Company.

The Metropolitan Opera season's 14th week, which begins Dec. 16, will include revivals of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" and Mozart's "Don Giovanni." Teresa Zylis-Gara will make her debut as Donna Elvira in "Don Giovanni."

BONN, Nov. 22 -- The West German Government declared today that the three Western allies responsible for West Berlin had upheld the right of the Federal Republic to elect a new President in the isolated city next year.

NAIROBI, Kenya -- There is no place like Kenya to make a man worry about how he looks. Thousands of American male tourists start twitching about it almost as soon as they check into a hotel in Nairobi.

New explosions and raging flames in the gassy tunnels of a West Virginia coal mine have left virtually no hope for rescue of the 78 men trapped there since Wednesday. The usual fatalistic expressions of compassion are coming from company, union and Federal Bureau of Mines officials -- all seeking to convey the impression that every reasonable safeguard was taken against the hazards that make death the miner's constant companion.

Johnny Bench, 20-year-old catcher of the Cincinnati Reds, won the National League rookie-of-the-year award yesterday by the narrowest margin on record, but there were plenty of distinctions left the runner-up -- Jerry Koosman, 22-year-old left-handed pitcher of the New York Mets.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 23 -- United States artillery fired into the northern half of the demilitarized zone yesterday for the second day in a row and for the second time since President Johnson halted the bombing of North Vietnam Nov. 1.
COLLECTORS are searching the markets for Britannia, the metal that represented pewter's last stand against the dominance of ceramic ware.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 -- A Japan Air Lines DC-8 jet came down in San Francisco Bay this morning about three miles short of the runway at International Airport.
Prices slipped on the London stock market yesterday as most traders awaited definitive news from the Bonn monetary meeting.

This is the last full Saturday of the 1968 college football season, and two major championships will be decided head-tohead. Yale and Harvard, both going into The Game undefeated for the first time in 59 years, clash for the Ivy title at Cambridge; Michigan and Ohio State, the latter undefeated and ranked No. 2 nationally, meet at Columbus for the Big Ten crown and a trip to the Rose Bowl.
Modern science has split the atom and is exploring outer space, but mankind is only now beginning to learn the truth about mental retardation.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 22 -The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine claimed credit tonight for the explosion today in Jerusalem.

TARAWA, Gilbert Islands, Nov. 19 -- Still littered with the debris of war, the golden beaches and serene coconut groves of Betio Island, part of the Tarawa Atoll bear witness today to the fury of the historic battle fought here 25 years ago.

A FEW days after a battered actress was found on the courtyard beneath Jim Brown's Hollywood apartment, editors and authors began conducting whispery luncheon meetings. In at least one such conversation, an editor, with great excitement, outlined his idea for a book that would outsell such supposedly camouflaged biographies as "The Carpetbaggers" and "The King."

The head of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association said yesterday that it would appeal to the United States Supreme Court the decision of the State Court of Appeals upholding the Taylor Law's ban on strikes by public employes.

Trading volume continued heavy on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with 7,743,665 shares changing hands. A total of 502 issues showed rises; 368 were down and 156 remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Federal Trade Commission, in an effort to discourage the merger trend in the textile industry, announced today the guidelines under which it will consider taking legal action to block some such mergers.

Although Robert Goldsand has been a part of the American musical scene for so long and has played in New York so often, his appearance as piano soloist with the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall, yesterday afternoon was his first with that orchestra.

A 39-year-old woman school-bus driver was killed yesterday morning when her empty yellow school carrier was in collision with a car that had straddled the concrete divider on Grand Central Parkway at the Union Turnpike overpass in Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens.

The $2-billion financing package put together by several major central banks and the Bank for International Settlements is the latest in a series of cooperative monetary measures taken since currencies became generally convertible in December, 1958.
Mayor Lindsay visited a fire ravaged yeshiva in Brooklyn yesterday and presented the Rabbi Saul Wolf, the school's principal administrator, checks totalling $1,000 to help construct a new school.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22 (AP) -- James Chinn, the laboratory technician who detected a suspicious urinalysis after the Kentucky Derby last May 4, testified today he had no doubt it contained the forbidden medication, phenylbutazone.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last month's levels, the Treasury disclosed today.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- Italian financial circles see comfortable international monetary adjustment to a French franc devaluation of up to 10 per cent, but fear a serious "money-quake" in any reduction of franc value over 15 per cent.
DAKAR, Senegal, Nov. 22 -Mali's new young military leaders appealed today for outside aid to help them restore the stagnant economy of the nation, whose left-wing regime they overthrew Tuesday.
Increases in the prices of some polyethylene films were announced yesterday by the Dow Chemical Company and the United States Industrial Chemicals Company.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon disclosed yesterday some details of what he termed "an unprecedented search" for potential officeholders that would emphasize youth and would consider talent and imagination "regardless of party, race or section."

It was gala week in New York with big galas and little galas, and as Mrs. Charlotte Ford Niarchos said toward the end, "You'd be dead if you'd gone to everything. I didn't."

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 22 -The New York harness racing season's final stakes race, this one a $98,132.42 item plus fringe benefits -- a $50,000 bonus -- will be presented tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- President Johnson has appointed Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina as a member of the Civil Defense Advisory Council, the White House announced today.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- New York City students will not have to take Regents examinations this January, but they will be given a city examination.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- A Swedish plan for an international check on underground nuclear arms tests through seismic detectors won support today in a resolution and statements before the Political Committee of the General Assembly.

If technique to burn would set a theater afire, Robert Guralnik would be an arsonist of dangerous proportions.
