CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- Unbeaten Yale remained a reluctant 7-point favorite over unbeaten Harvard today for their showdown in THE GAME tomorrow.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy will make a literary appearance at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association on Monday, Dec. 2, at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Assuming that changes in currency parities as a result of the monetary crisis can be limited to the French franc, and possibly a few franc-area countries in Africa, this capital is confident that no imminent problems are likely for the dollar.

Adam Clayton Powell's parole on a pending maximum jail sentence of 90 days for criminal contempt of court was extended yesterday until Dec. 2.

The police seized $2.5-million worth of narcotics here yesterday and arrested three men and a 21-year-old woman in what Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell called "the largest narcotic conspiracy in the history of Queens County."

Debits, or charges to checking accounts, at banks in the New York Metropolitan area rose during October, but remained below the all-time peak posted in August, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

By all the conventional criteria, Wladyslaw Gomulka emerged as the main victor of the recently concluded Polish Communist Party Congress. IT isn't often that you hear moans in the executive suite when a company's stock goes up. But there are sounds remarkably like whimpers filtering out of the offices of Abacus Fund these days.
The Civil Service Employes Association, which has regularly and quietly added state employes to its membership ranks since 1910, is facing in the mental hospital strike its most serious challenge.

The New York Mets, themselves born out of baseball expansion, will open their eighth season on April 8 at Shea Stadium against the Montreal Expos, one of 1969's two National League expansion clubs. It will be the first of 81 home games on 74 playing dates.

President de Gaulle "shook up everybody" when he decided not to devalue the franc over the weekend, one broker commented yesterday. But the unexpected refusal had little impact on price changes in commodity futures in this country.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- The Legislature broke more than a century of deadlock tonight when it overwhelmingly approved a controversial plan to develop the largely uninhabited Hackensack River meadowland into a modern urban complex.

Temple Emanu-El, the largest Reform Jewish congregation in the country, has rejoined the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which it quit last year after a clash over the role of the union's president in speaking out on political and social issues.
Roy M. Cohn accused United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau yesterday of "misuse of office" by harassing him for six years in an effort to "send me to jail."
HUNTING for waterfowl and rabbits is now allowed on certain portions of Fire Island National Seashore, according to the assistant superintendent, Thomas F. Norris Jr.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Shivering but smiling bravely, pupils from the United Nations International School helped New York officials launch the city's holiday safety campaign yesterday by posting the first of 50,000 new multilingual traffic posters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide how long states may fill vacancies for the United States Senate by appointment rather than election.
Curtain calls for actors at the end of a performance, a tradition in the theater, have been eliminated at "We Bombed in New Haven." Joseph Heller, author of the play, confirmed the step yesterday.

DOUALA, Cameroon -- West Africa is not the ideal place for Christmas shopping unless someone on your list has always longed for a small gray mouse impaled on a stick. The mouse, quite dead, is sold for a few Nigerian shillings -- or less than 60 cents -- in the juju maket of Lagos.

CAIRO, Nov. 25 -- Student rioting spread to Cairo yesterday and continued today in Alexandria, with youths shouting demands for educational reforms, freedom of the press and punishment of heavy-handed security officials.

HONG KONG, Nov. 25 -- The Peking leadership appears to be embarked on a new effort to set guidelines for stability and more moderate domestic policies in Communist China, specialists in Chinese affairs here believe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -Some officials of the Johnson Administration believe that the key to obtaining freedom for the 82 Pueblo crewmen may be two costly fish-processing ships being built for North Korea in the Netherlands.
Corporate mergers and acquisitions continued at a busy pace yesterday.
BONN, Nov. 25 -- West Germany appeared to calm down a bit today after the shock provided by President de Gaulle's refusal to devalue the ranc.

City officials and the chairman of a meat-processing cooperative agreed tentatively yesterday to a solution of a dispute that threatened to keep the meat industry from the city's Hunt's Point Market in the Bronx.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Jean-Marcel Jeanneney, a quick-tempered economics professor turned Cabinet minister, emerged today as the man on whose judgment President de Gaulle primarily relied Saturday in making his decision not to devalue the franc.
Prices declined slightly yesterday in the money and capital markets in the wake of France's decision not to devalue the franc.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 25 -- The Federal District Court was asked today to grant H. Rap Brown the right to be tried in Dorchester County, where he is accused of riot, arson and inciting to riot.
ATHENS, Nov. 25 -- Two members of Greece's ruling revolutionary council resigned today in a disagreement with Premier George Papadopoulos over an exchange of their posts.

TOM WRIGHT is New Jersey's leading scholastic individual football scorer with 168 points and perhaps it is no accident that he has scored 28 touchdowns this season, including six against New Milford. Tom, a senior at Sparta (N. J.) High, has lived in a football atmosphere and has mingled with collegiate and professional players most of his young life.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
BALD HILL, Calif., Nov. 25 -Standing at the base of a 657year-old redwood tree, Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson dedicated today the country's newest national park, which is still deep in controversy.
Theodore C. Sorensen, former White House aide to President Johnson and President John F. Kennedy, said last night that he was interested in running for United States Senator in New York.

IT'S a little spooky that the name of Pablo Picasso should turn up (next to that of Bob Dylan) in the program notes for "Chad Mitchell's Counterpoint." For by the end of the evening, it's precisely Picasso you are thinking about -- specifically his famous grumble: "You do it first, then someone else does it pretty."
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Roy Jenkins, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated today that it was time to begin considering fundamental reforms of the monetary system.

Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber brought his campaign for the modernization of Europe's economy to New York yesterday with a warning that, if the United States wants to stimulate the growth of more responsible leadership in Western Europe, "you must cease treating our countries like children."

Richard M. Nixon is said to have begun active negotiations with one and possibly more prominent Democrats for Cabinet-level posts in his Administration. He is also said to believe that he should select the Democratic members of his Cabinet before proceeding with other high-level appointments.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Peter Fuller, the owner of Dancer's Image, made an unsuccessful attempt today to obtain immediate dismissal of the ruling which deprived his colt of his winnings in the Kentucky Derby.

FORT McMURRAY, Alberta -- In November, frost glistens on the grass until late morning and ice creeps from the edges toward the center of the countless small ponds in the unbroken jack-pine, spruce and birch country of northern Alberta.
FRANK SINATRA's fourth special for television, seen last night over the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System, was not in the same class as his earlier ventures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A California coin collector who was convicted of stealing coins from fellow numismatists has confronted the Supreme Court with a crucial test of a policeman's power to search the premises of arrested suspects.

Steel production in the week ended Saturday advanced 2.3 per cent beyond the level of the previous week, the seventh increase in the last eight weeks, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 President-elect Richard M. Nixon intends to provide new leadership for the Republican party next year.

Stockholders of the Columbia Pictures Corporation and Screen Gems, Inc., will vote on their merger at a special meeting to be held Dec. 16. If the merger is consummated the corporation will change its name to Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc.

A well-conceived plan by Coach Arne Arnesen to make his star harrier the National Collegiate champion met with success yesterday when Mike Ryan of the Air Force Academy captured the top honors at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- When President de Gaulle declared last night that he would see to it that "all existing taxes be effectively collected," he engaged in a battle that he may not be able to win.

Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, issued a stern warning to member firms against violating the forthcoming ban on customer directed "give - ups" by possible new trading patterns involving regional stock exchanges.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- A qualified West European source said today that North Vietnam and the Vietcong were increasingly impatient to engage in talks with the United States.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., a major unsubsidized American cargo ship operator, has announced a two-year $100 million expansion program.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Wartime colleagues of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill turned out for a ceremony in a chilly West London railroad depot today at which historic rail cars they had used were given to the United States.
TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that sanctions by teacher organizations against school systems were just as illegal as strikes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a legal move by three Chicagoans aimed at abolishing as unconstitutional the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren suggested today that the Supreme Court had ignored its own guidelines in permitting the Government to link gambling offenses with registration and tax violations.

Increasing tensions yesterday in the embattled Ocean Hill-Brownsville district have once again imperiled last week's precarious settlement of the school strike. The delicate balance reached in the agreements that ended the strike depends for its equilibrium on two vital conditions: strict adherence to the terms of those agreements and execution in good faith of the rulings of the temporary state trustee, Dr. Herbert Johnson.

The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that its directors had approved terms of a previously announced merger agreement with the Sinclair Oil Corporation. Atlantic Richfield shareholders will be asked to vote on the merger at a special meeting to be held at 10 A.M., Tuesday, Dec. 31, in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -Prepayment in one year of the interest due on a loan over a period of several years will henceforth be more carefully scrutinized by the Internal Revenue Service before it is allowed as a tax deduction.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 -Eldridge Cleaver was asked officially today to surrender himself as a parole violator.

A 36-year-old clerk was arrested yesterday as the "key figure" in a $10-million-a-year car-theft ring that allegedly took advantage of a loophole in shipping regulations to send stolen autos to Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.
WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 25 -Lucien Fontaine tries to make history at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night by becoming the youngest driver to earn $1million in purses in a single season.

The holders of 41 per cent of the 4 3/4 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Beck Industries, Inc., have filed suit against the company, some of its officers and others, charging that they conspired to obtain long-term debt in violation of the certificate of incorporation.

WHEN Fran Tarkenton threw his second touchdown pass on Sunday, giving the Giants a 14-0 lead over Los Angeles, a loud cheer went up in a locker room 3,000 miles away. In a leasing transaction carrying aggregate rent of more than $5-million, the New York Telephone Company has taken four floors in the 40-story office building nearing completion at 1250 Broadway.

Television musical programs have been using a variety of techniques to circumvent the absence of live music since Oct. 30, when staff musicians on the three networks went on strike.

THE death of Maurice Harrison -Gray in London Sunday at the age of 69 deprived the world of bridge of one of its greatest players and writers. The nation's railroads were given authority yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase their freight rates by 3 to 10 per cent on an interim basis.

PEKING, Nov. 26 (Agence France-Presse) -- Anthony Grey, the Reuters correspondent who has been under house arrest here for 16 months, is said to he in reasonable physical health but in a state of considerable nervous tension.

The Long Island Rail Road announced last night that an agreement had been reached to end a labor dispute that had shut down the line for two days, but early today it said that a second dispute was disrupting efforts to restore service.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 27 -- Premier Eisaku Sato turned back a challenge by two former Cabinet ministers today to win re-election as president of Japan's Liberal-Democratic party.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Robert R. Smith, president of San Francisco State Collage, submitted his resignation today and requested reassignment from his present post to "job duties other than college administration."

In the view of Milovan Djilas, the former Yugoslav Communist leader, the nature of the Soviet Union's challenge to the West has been significantly altered by a reemergence of Czarist imperialist ambitions and a decline of Communist revolutionary ideology.
Silver futures dropped sharply yesterday in heavy volume.
THE luncheon at Mrs. Elmer H. Bobst's handsome East Side apartment was a lot more than a chance for Julie Nixon's bridesmaids to get acquainted. It was her first bridal shower and she loved it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The South Vietnamese Government announced tonight that it was "prepared to participate" in expanded Vietnam peace talks. But no date was set for the start of the new negotiations.

ARTURO BENEDETTI MICHELANGELI is a legend in Europe, and last night in Carnegie Hall the Italian pianist showed why. In his recent New York recitals his interpretations have left some questions, though there never has been any doubt about his extraordinary technical finish.

The Sharon Steel Corporation, which recently broke off merger talks with Alloys Unlimited and remains the object of a takeover offer from the NVF Company, appeared to give its blessings yesterday to a third proposal from the Cyclops Corporation.
Governor Rockefeller has decided that he is not interested in taking a position in the Administration of Richard M. Nixon, authoritative sources disclosed yesterday.
The Lorillard Corporation, the 208-year-old tobacco company, held its last stockholder meeting yesterday, as its owners approved a management proposal to merge it into Loew's Theatres, Inc.

United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday that his "present intention" is to remain in his post, despite the advent of the Nixon Administration, possibly until his four-year term expires in June, 1971.

Daniel Charles, still high on about $-1-million in business from Schenley Industries, has just been named for three brands out of LanvinCharles of the Ritz with the same kind of billings tag. How sweet it is!
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A 54-year-old Australian businessman who was captured by the Vietcong in Saigon last February arrived in Bangkok today after nine months in captivity.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -Communist China proposed today a meeting Feb. 20 in Warsaw with Nixon Administration representatives, and for the first time publicly called on the United States to join "an agreement on the five principles of peaceful coexistence."

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- LeRoi Jones, the militan Negro poet and playwright, was found guilty today of having used loud and abusive language and resisting arrest during an encounter with two Newark policemen in a bank here last October.

MANNINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The big coal mine where 78 men have been missing for nearly a week throbbed with another explosion today soon after a mine official said the search would continue no matter how remote the possibility of rescue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -The Securities and Exchange Commission penalized Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. and a group of its employes today for allegedly giving inside information to 14 favored investment company clients that enabled them to avoid losses or make profits totaling $4.5-million in the stock of the Douglas Aircraft Company.

Not many authors can point to an article or a book and say that that single literary effort moved a nation to enact a major law. Upton Sinclair could. His novel "The Jungle," which vividly described the unspeakable conditions in Chicago's meat packinghouses, directly resulted in the first Federal pure-food legislation in history.

Shareholders of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., were told yesterday that the big, New Yorkbased department-store chain increased its net income by 7.6 per cent in the first quarter, ended Nov. 2. Sales rose 7.8 per cent in the period.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- A calm that some Zurich bankers described as deceptive returned to European financial markets today as the French Government announced another series of austerity measures aimed at defending the 10-year-old rate of the franc.
The dispute between the factions trying to operate the Daytop Village narcotics addict rehabilitation program continued to boil yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 26 -Forty-three per cent of adult Americans say they approve of the way President Johnson is handling his job, the Gallup Poll reported today.

Plans for proposed meat facilities at the city's Hunt's Point Market in the Bronx foundered again yesterday amid charges that city officials had refused to sign an agreement providing for the move.
A prominent French industrialist said here yesterday that devaluation of the French franc last week would have been illtimed.

The stock market steamed along in high gear yesterday with prices climbing on a broad front in active trading.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27 -- Some surprises that Navy has been developing for a year will be used against Army in their 69th football clash Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Methodist bishop gave his full backing today to birth control -- a subject of controversy within the Roman Catholic Church.

The annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade will begin at 9 A.M. It will proceed from 77th Street and Central Park West, south on Central Park West to Columbus Circle, and down Broadway to Herald Square.
Profit taking cut early advances in wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but the grain still managed to register a gain of 1/8 to 1 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Prof. Donald E. Farrar has been named director of the Special Study of Institutional Investors authorized by Congress last summer, Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today.

Dennis C. Stanfill has been elected vice president, finance and treasurer of The Los Angeles Times Miror, it was announced yesterday. Milton H. Day has been named vice president and controller. Mr. Stanfill, chief financial officer of the company, has been a Times Mirror vice president for finance since 1965.

The Junior League of New York honored 25 of its provisional members last night at Its Debutanto Ball at tlle Plaza, a drop of 19 over last year and of 36 over 1960. Also dropped was the midnight curtsy, a tradition since the founding of the ball 20 years ago, in favor of a short, simple ceremony.
With trading volume holding steady, most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Lloyd's of London, the famous society of private insurance underwriters, shattered tradition today and elected two Americans as members. It was the first admission of non-British subjects to the exclusive club.

Holiday theatergoers will have a choice of 28 matinees today. Only two Broadway presentations, "Man of La Mancha'" and "Hair," will omit them.

SNIFFEN COURT is an optical illusion in a city of steel and stone. One of New York's minor miracles, it is a narrow mews of brick, wrought iron, climbing vines and polished brass. The picturesque dwellings that border it were converted around the turn of the century from stables originally belonging to well-to-do New Yorkers living in the Murray Hill district.

Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, conductor of the Minnesota Orchestra -- known until recently as the Minneapolis Symphony -- began a two-week guest-conducting engagement with the New York Philharmonic at Philharmonic Hall last night.

A Dutch freighter, the Falkenburg, was adrift in the North Atlantic off Newfoundland last night with a disabled rudder. A spokesman for the Coast Guard said the cutter McCulloch was standing by the ship until a tug arrived.
