Slim Harpo, who will appear through Sunday at the Scene, helps prove the extent to which the blues has taken hold of today's pop music.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Eighth-ranked Arkansas will meet unbeaten and fourthranked Georgia in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Day, Dr. Fred Wolfe Jr., president of the Sugar Bowl, said today. The announcement was made shortly after Texas defeated Texas A. and M., 35-14, to gain the host berth in the Cotton Bowl.
The effects of automation on the printing shop of the Swedish American Line passenger ship Gripsholm has been counterbalanced by making the shop "coeducational."

WITH puritanical self-righteousness the baseball people have looked down on the gambling sport of horse racing. For several decades it was considered forbidden territory for the diamond fraternity. Although once rigid restrictions have since been eased, no welcome mat has been smoothed out for any baseball infidels who ally themselves with the turf.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's recent warning to the Soviet Union appears, in the light of the most reliable assessments of alliance forces, to be little more than a gamble to discourage Soviet action until the West's military position improves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Robert D. Murphy, dean of retired American diplomats, likes to describe himself as an "old gentleman who isn't looking for any job."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Luke Jackson shot seven for eight from the field and handed out a pair of assists in a thirdperiod rally that triggered a 122-107 National Basketball Association victory tonight for the Philadelphia 76ers over the Los Angeles Lakers.

The 19th annual Gotham Ball was held last night in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, where 28 young women in long white gowns and elbow length gloves, holding bouquets of pink and red geraniums, ivy and magnolia leaves, were presented to Archbishop Terence J. Cooke.

Arthur Cantor and Joel Schenker have bought themselves a church, less as an act of piety than wit. They plan to make it over into a couple of theaters -- one for stage productions, one for films -- when the congregation leaves.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., (UPI) -A minister in Plymouth, where the first Thanksgiving was held in 1621, criticized today an "ungrateful" white America for turning its back on the Indians who made the celebration possible.
KANSAS CITY, Mo. (UPI) -The Armco Steel Company plant here has ordered a new electric furnace from the Lectromelt Corporation to produce 170 tons of steel in each batch.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A melee among 200 youths, following a high school football game last night was finally quelled early today, but not before four policemen were injured and 10 persons arrested.

William L. Laurence, science editor emeritus of The New York Times, has been ejected to the board of the Thomas J. Deegan Company, a management -counsel concern, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Laurence, winner of two Pulitzer Prizes, was with The Times from 1930 until he retired in 1964.
DETROIT, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Gordon (Red) Berensen made two goals offsetting Gordie Howe's 699th regular-season goals and led the St. Louis Blues to a 3-1 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Silver Goblet scored an upset three-length victory in the $15,000 added Thanksgiving Day Handicap at Bay Meadows today.
Who else but Richard (Pancho) Gonzalez could have turned a ponderous opening program into another memorable tennis moment?
RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The body of the Burmese Communist party's chairman, Thakin Than Tun, was found last Saturday after an intensive search, Government officials announced today.

HONG KONG, Nov. 28 -- The manner and the timing of Communist China's proposal on Tuesday to resume ambassadorial talks with the United States in Warsaw are regarded by observers here as more significant than the substance of Peking's note to Washington suggesting a meeting Feb. 20.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The 30nation Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration elected John F. Thomas of the United States today to an indefinite term as director. Mr. Thomas, now chief of the United States aid program's refugee division in Vietnam will succeed Bastiaan W. Haveman of the Netherlands, who is retiring in February after seven years in the post.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Len Dawson got Kansas City's slow-starting offense clicking late in the first half today and then picked Houston's defense apart with his pinpoint passing to pace the Chiefs to a 24-10 American Football League victory over the Oilers.

ADOLFO SARDINA has every right to be the happy man he is. He has his own special place in couture and his customers are nothing but the very best people. The slim, blond, Cuban-born designer is one of the foremost exponents of the art of making anti-establishment clothes for the establishment.
BOHEMIA, L. I., Nov. 28 -Gary Milleisen scored two touchdowns to lead Hauppauge to a 28-0 victory over Connetquot today.
LONDON, Nov. 28 (AP) -Johnny Pritchett, the British middleweight champion, won a decision from Doug Huntley of Los Angeles in a 10-round bout tonight.
JAIPUR, India (AP) -- A former anti-British terrorist has become chairman of the Rajastham State Roadways Corporation.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 28 -Andy Bryant powered for 150 yards and three touchdowns today in leading South Side to a 26-6 upset victory over City League champion Weequahic. South Side (6-1-1) turned two interceptions into a 12-6 halftime lead with Bryant scoring on runs of 1 and 46 yards. Weequahic's final record is 6-3.
A Long Island Rail Road official said yesterday he expected "full service" today, when the line gets the first real test of its new timetables.

The Consolidated Edison Company, virtually certain of a strike by 20,000 workers at midnight tomorrow, said yesterday that it was organizing its supervisory staff to provide "essential" electric and gas services for an indefinite period.

Pravda had every reason recently to give front-page prominence to the communique of the Budapest meeting of 67 Communist parties. That document was essentially a report of a major political victory by the Soviet Union. What happened in Budapest was a mass surrender by most of the European Communist parties that had earlier condemned the invasion of Czechoslovakia and forced the indefinite postponement of the world Communist meeting scheduled for this month.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -The search for Eldridge Cleaver continued today amid growing speculation that the Black Panther leader might have left the country.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 28 -A strike of Government employes for pay increases began today, paralyzing Ceylon's postal and telecommunications services. All entrances to Colombo were heaviy guarded by the army, navy and police.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Bob Olender, a quarterback, threw four touchdown passes, three in the last quarter today to help Hackensack come from behhind and defeat Teaneck, 26-20, in a Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League game.

FLORENCE, Ky., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- High winds knocked down power lines today in scattered sections of northern Kentucky, and power was out in areas of Florence and adjacent Erlanger for nearly two hours.
BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Patrick McMahon of Oklahoma Baptist University won the 59th annual 9.3-mile Berwick marathon today in the record time of 45 minutes 19.6 seconds.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- A man firing a submachine gun from an automobile killed one person and wounded four others today. The shots sprayed downtown O'Leary Plaza, where supporters of the Popular Electoral Movement were hanging posters.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 28 -A wave of popular disillusion is washing over the government of President Arthur da Costa e Silva as the former general struggles through his second year in power in Brazil.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Religious leaders of six Christian communities in Jordan today called off all social festivities for Christmas and the New Year because of the Israeli occupation in Jordanian areas. Observance would be limited to church services only.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 28 -- A series of 22 Montclair victories that began in 1946 came to an end today when Bloomfield held the Mounties to a 7-7 tie in their traditional meeting at Woodman Field. It was the first tie in the series, and it gave the Mounties a final season won-lost-tied mark of 5-3-1, the worst for Clary Anderson since he became coach in 1940.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Kim Becker threw for two touchdowns in the first half today and led East Rutherford to a 14-6 victory over Lyndhurst. Becker, who completed 10 of 12 passes for 87 yards, completed a 33-yarder to Dave Doyle in the first period and a 12-yarder to Rich Robertson in the second.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 28 (AP) -Four members of a family were shot today, one critically, in a home at 21 Cuba Place near downtown Rochester, the police said. A man who fled in an automobile was being sought, they said.

SYOSSET, L. I., Nov. 28 -Gary Rossetti threw two touchdown passes late in the fourth quarter as Syosset came from behind to down Clarke, 23-12, and tie Hicksville for the North Shore Division I championship. The Braves finished with a 5-1 won-lost mark in the league and 7-1 overall.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 28 -St. Mary's of Greenwich fashioned the best record in its school history, a 7-3 won-lost record, by defeating Norwalk Central Catholic, 35-8. Ed Tammany returned the opening kickoff 80 yards to a touchdown at St. Mary's started off with a 29-0 half-time lead.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- The Kenya Government has warned that steps would be taken against public offices not displaying a portrait of President Jomo Kenyatta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Office of Saline Water announced today the award of a $1.174-million contract for the construction of a brackish water test facility at Roswell, N. M. The contract was won by the Penner Construction Company of Denv

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -The Federal Maritime Commission announced today compliance by a ship rate-making group with an order to eliminate certain rate disparities in the trade between the United States and Britain.

LIVINGSTON, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Jan Breski scored three touchdowns to power Livingston to a 32-6 victory over Essex today in a Jersey Hills Conference game. The Victory gave Livingston a final won-lost-tied record of 5-3-1, while West Essex dropped to 4-5.

Cardinal Hayes gained a share of the Catholic School Football League championship yesterday by defeating Mount St. Michael, 24-8, at Baker Field. The victory put Hayes, with a 5-1 won-lost record in the league, in a three-way tie for first place with St. Francis Prep and Chaminade.
Laurence Dunst will tell you he was a "lousy student" but is a great copywriter. And, since agencies are really only in the market for the latter, he's doing all right. All right? He's doing great.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Lou Angotti's goal midway in the second period tonight broke a 2-2 tie and gave the Pittsburgh Penguins a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- The Chilean Government expects to lose $8-million to $10-million in foreign exchange this year from copper because of labor disputes and a severe 10-month drought in 12 central and northern provinces.
The nation's electric power production rose 13.8 per cent last week from the level in the corresponding 1967 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.
PRAGUE, Nov. 28 (AP) -- National Assembly deputies demanded tonight an end to distribution of Soviet propaganda in Czechoslovakia.
NEWARK, Nov. 28 (AP) -Priests will receive benefits of $300 to $600 a month under a new retirement plan announced by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark.

On Saturday, Oct. 26, Robert Walters went into the vestibule of an apartment building on West 75th Street, leaned over the buzzer board and began searching for the name of a friend. Suddenly, two men appeared, placed a knife at his throat and demanded his money.
A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was fatally stabbed in the chest with a nail file Wednesday night in a fight with an older youth in the Williamsburg section.

OTTAWA, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Bonk of Canada said today that $73-million was added to the Treasury through Canada Savings Bond sales this week, swelling Government bank balances to $1,085,000,000.

GLASSBORO, N. J., Nov. 28 -- The undefeated team from the Netherlands scored a 2-0 victory over Mideast in the opening of the United States women's field hockey tournament in a pouring rain today at Glassboro State College.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The top American commander in Vietnam made the decision to send a small American raiding party into the demilitarized zone for the first time since the bombing halt, and cleared the decision in advance in Washington, it was learned today.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 28 -- East Orange, rated No. 1 in New Jersey, increased its unbeaten string to 22 today with a 14-0 victory over Barringer.

Geneva, Nov. 28 -- Two executives of Oerlikon-Buehrle, the Zurich arms company, have admitted to illegally exporting about $2.3-million worth of arms that eventually reached the United Arab Republic, Saudi Arabia, Lebanon, Israel and South Africa, it was announced in Berne tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A general alarm fire, which officials said was started by an arsonist, ripped through two abandoned buildings in this city's urban renewal project early today, slightly injuring one fireman.
The London Stock Exchange closed firmer yesterday, but most leaders had dropped slightly below their best quotations by the close.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- International legislation to give any nation the right to sink on the high seas any ship endangering its coast through oil pollution will be considered at a conference of world shipping experts next year, shipping men said today.
SCOTTSBORO, Ala., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Five members of an Alabama family were killed today in a two-car collision, which virtually sliced their vehicle in half, the police said.

UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N. J., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Two 18-year-old boys were killed early today when their auto struck a tree and split in half in what the police called the worst accident ever seen in this borough. The youths were identified as Thomas Winkler of Fairlawn and Guy Van Maanen of Glen Rock.
PARIS, Nov. 28--France's austerity program was adopted tonight by the Senate by a vote of 157 to 87. The National Assembly voted approval, 391 to 91, late last night.

OTTAWA, Nov. 27 -- As he rounds out his first half-year in office, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau views his program for Canada, the Just Society, as a plan to excite ideas, challenge past assumptions and involve the people in running their country.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 28 -- Patchogue scored three last quarter touchdowns on two explosive runs by Dave Antonio and another by Gary Rooney to upset favored Central Islip, 18-6, today.

Tim Moffitt threw three touchdown passes, two to Roger McTiernan, yesterday as Xavier overwhelmed Fordham Prep, 32-0, in the 40th meeting between the schools at Randalls Island. The triumph was Xavier's 22d in the series. Fordham Prep has won 16 and two games have ended in ties.

PRAGUE, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The United States Embassy invited all the 105 American residents of Prague to a do-it-yourself turkey dinner today at the home of Ambassador Jacob Beam. The journalists, diplomats, embassy employes and businessmen all brought part of the feast.
Motorists were advised yesterday to avoid the downtown section of Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn because of a water-main break at the intersection with Willoughby Street.

In a placid yet appropriately symbolic break from the rigors of the transition period yesterday, Richard M. Nixon paid a call on former President Dwight D. Eisenhower at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington.

FLORENCE, Ky., Nov. 28 (UPI) -- High winds knocked down power lines throughout scattered sections of northern Kentucky today and caused cancellation of races at Latonia race course after the fifth race.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Brian Murray's passing sparked White Plains to a 28-0 victory over Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn today. The Tigers, in thier first year under Coach Brant Wintersteen, completed an all-winning season of seven games.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- At the rate Memphis is pumping water out of the ground beneath it, the city may soon start sinking, the United States Geological Survey said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon has created an "information czar" through the appointment of Herbert G. Klein as a Governmentwide communications director, Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, said today.

CLYDEBANK, Scotland (UPI) -- Signals from space will help the new cruise ship, Queen Elizabeth 2, navigate. Electronic messages from a satellite will be fed into the vessel's computer, to give the ship's position within 200 yards.
The Heisman trophy winner, O. J. Simpson of Southern California, was named yesterday for the second straight year, the United Press International back of the year.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The United States delegation to the Vietnam talks announced today that its chief, W. Averell Harrima would leave Paris Sunday for a short visit home.

Nevele Pride, the record-breaking 3-year-old trotter, raced the entire season with a broken bone in his left front ankle, a veterinarian disclosed yesterday. He was declared sound now and ready to resume racing.
Group taxi riding from the Eastern Airlines shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport into Manhattan will be extended through Dec. 31.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Borrowing a leaf from their opponents' book, the Los Angeles Lakers used a fast-breaking attack on their way to a 93-92 triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight.

JAJCE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29 -- President Tito indirectly criticized today the Soviet Union's domestic and foreign policies by saying, "Those who do not respect their own country and their own people cannot respect other countries or other peoples."

"Lemonade" and "The Autograph Hound," short plays by James Prideaux, will open Dec. 9 at the Jan Hus Playhouse instead of at the new Mercury Theater because renovations at the Mercury could not be completed in time.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Nov. 29 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old youth allegedly involved in the slaying of Ramon Novarro, the actor, will be charged with murder and robbery and will stand trial as an adult, the authorities said today. Julius Libow, a juvenile court referee, has ordered that Thomas Scott Ferguson stand trial as an adult.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, has asked the Federal Trade Commission to establish a "truth rating" for gasoline octane.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 29 (AP) -- President Carlos Lleras Restrepo forced the resignation of his coalition Cabinet at dawn today after an all-night session in which he had accused the opposition Conservatives of sabotaging social and economic reforms.
Many investors and traders took an extra holiday yesterday, but the stock market didn't, and the key averages moved into higher ground.

A marked increase in contracts for large-scale building projects in October propelled the Dodge index of construction contract activity to a record 200 -- double the seasonally adjusted average for the years 1957-59.

THE Giants need a victory in Cleveland tomorrow in order to remain in the Capitol Division race, but they are a 12-point underdog to the Browns. The Jets normally would be a solid favorite over the Miami Dolphins at Shea Stadium, but now that they have been assured of the Eastern Division title, there is no betting line on that game.
MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The national ministry in charge of the police was renamed the Ministry of the Interior today, restoring to the police the Russian initials M. V. D. from Stalin's time.

For years, television has been saying that it wants to bring fresh writing talent into the medium but that playwrights are in short supply. Writers and critics, on the other hand, have maintained that television just hasn't looked hard enough or in the right places.
The United States Lines Company moved closer yester day to becoming a subsidiary of Walter Kidde Co., Inc.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Florida State's passing combination of Bill Cappleman-Ron Sellers gave the nation's No. 1 offensive team a lesson tonight as the Seminoles upset 10th-ranked Houston, 40-20, in their regular season football finale.

Ruby Goldstein, the referee who had been a top contender in professional boxing's lightweight and junior welterweight divisions in the late twenties and early thirties, yesterday was named a boxing judge by Edwin B. Dooley, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended Nov. 23 came to an estimated $805-million, an increase of 15 per cent above the $701-million sales for the corresponding week of last year.

MONTREAL, Nov. 29 -- About 1,300 delegates attending the Hemispheric Conference to End the Vietnam War heard charges today that the United States was using the halt in bombing of North Vietnam to build up its military strength.

The Consolidated Edison Company began deploying its 4,000 supervisors yesterday so they could take over the operation and maintenance of a vast electrical and gas network at midnight tonight, when 20,000 workers are scheduled to strike.

ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Alvin P. Lierheimer of nearby Delmar was appointed today as assistant commissioner of higher education in the State's Education Department. Education Commissioner James E. Allen named him to the $25,000-a-year post vacated two months ago by Allan A. Kuusisto.

Herman Shumlin has resigned as producer and director of Leonard Spigelgass's new comedy-drama, "The Wrong Way Light Bulb," due here in February. Elliot Martin will replace him as producer and Stephen Porter as director.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- The State Department said today that negotiations were continuing with Israel for the sale of 50 F-4 Phantom jets. A department spokesman, Robert J. McCloskey, made the statement in answer to questions about a report in The Baltimore Sun that the sale of the aircraft had been approved in principle after conferences between Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel.

The Court of Appeals has reversed the first-degree murder convictions of six men, known as the Harlem Six, who were sentenced to life imprisonment three years ago in the knife-slaying of a Hungarian woman in her Harlem clothing store.
The New York Jets announced yesterday their ticket plans for the American Football League championship game on Dec. 29 at Shea Stadium.

BONN, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- The West German Bundesrat, or upper house of Parliament, unanimously approved today emergency measures to cut the country's trade surplus in the interests of international financial stability.

Buffy Sainte-Marie attracted 2,400 people to Carnegie Hall last night with a maddening mix of magic and musical mayhem. The actress, songwriter, singer and social activist was enthusiastically received by most of her listeners.

WAVERLY, Minn., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey has received several teaching offers from universities and colleges in Minnesota and elsewhere, and will announce his plans by the first of the year, an aide said today.

GLASSBORO, N. J., Nov. 29 -- The touring team of the Netherlands continued undefeated in this country by scoring a 6-0 victory over Philadelphia First in the second round of the United States women's field hockey tournament today at Glassboro State College.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 29 -- The Vietcong's command issued orders today for a new offensive to "utterly destroy" United States and South Vietnamese combat units and pacification teams.
WEST HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith turned in a five-under-par 67 on sharp short iron shots today to take the first-round in the Hollywood Lakes open by a stroke.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Officials here said today that the United States had decided to accept Communist China's proposal to resume ambassadorial talks in Warsaw Feb. 20.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today the appointment of Eddie W. Schedt as United States representative on the advisory committee to the High Commission of the Ryukyu Islands. Mr. Schedt, 53 years old, is a career Foreign Service officer.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Oscar Robertson netted a season high of 40 points tonight, 14 of them in the final period, in leading the Cincinnati Royals to a 122-112 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

With seven of the 11 entrants having stakes triumphs to their credit, the Stuyvesant Handicap at Aqueduct today has all the aspects of the proverbial "wide open race." And, oddly enough, the favorite in the one-mile test is a 3-year-old who has yet to win in stakes competition.

BONN, Nov. 29 -- An assizes court in Darmstadt, in the state of Hesse, convicted seven former SS (Nazi elite guard) members today of participation in mass executions of 80,000 people in the Ukraine during World War II and sentenced them to a total of 61 years in prison.
ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Two little girls were found beaten to death today in a wooded area not far from their homes in this small community near Dover in central Morris County.

Since the 1962 United States embargo on Cuban tobacco, which affected the supply of the American cigar aficionado, new sources of supply have been successfully developed in the Canary Islands and Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- The Post office promised today to try its best to deliver Christmas mail on time. It hopes to do the job faster and more cheaply than ever by using a fewer people and more coordination.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Three workmen were killed today when a huge water tank collapsed at a 10-story building under construction in downtown Buenos Aires. The 40,000-gallon tank, which was being installed, tore lose huge chunks of the building as it fell to the street.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- Warsaw Pact army commanders ended today a four-day meeting in Bucharest on strengthening the defense potential of member countries, Tass, the Soviet press agency reported.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Seven of 10 losing favorites helped chill the chalk-players among the 8,510 fans who turned out in unseasonable 60-degree weather today for the close of New Jersey's longest harness racing season at Freehold Raceway.
French and British plans for the building of the supersonic Concorde emerged from the major surgery ordered for the French economy this week with an incision that hardly called for a bandage.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare proposed today a rule that would require continued welfare payments to a recipient while he is appealing cancellation or reduction of his benefits.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- five-year program aimed at helping low-income families plan more nutritious meals with the food they have available is being started by the Agriculture Department.
Philanthropic giving in New York City appears to be continuing to increase despite a slight decline in gifts under $25.
PARIS Nov. 29 (AP) -- The French Government decreed today new price controls, including some freezes, aimed at relieving the pressure on the franc.

The traffic death toll for the Thanksgiving holiday weekend climbed yesterday at a rate about the same as that for a nonholiday period at this season of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 (UPI) -- Favored Roberto de Vicenzo shot par 70 and a countryman, Florentino Molina, had a 69 today as the two Argentine golfers tied for the second round lead of the Argentina masters tournament with 36-hole totals of 138.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 29 -- Thieves made off with about $2,500 worth of equipment -- including, of all things, a 90-pound skate sharpening machine -- from the New York Rangers' practice rink here last night.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 29 -- Best Of All, who won the $98,132 Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway last Saturday night, is the even-money favorite to take the $50,000 National Pacing Derby at the track tomorrow night.

Alwin Nikolais once suggested that the 11 dances in his work "Imago" represented impressions of a small imaginary village as seen through the eyes of a child. These impressions, he added, "were very free in their abstract evolvement."

The State Department of Mental Hygiene reported yesterday that 14 employes at the Bronx State Hospital and three at the Manhattan State Hospital had been suspended on charges of misconduct during the recent strike of nonprofessional employes.
SAN ANTONIO, Nov. 29 -- The Federal Bureau of the Budget reported today that a cutback in Federal employment during the last three months saved $60-million.

World Airways, Inc., reported third-quarter earnings, including those of its subsidiary, the First Western Bank, rose to $4,738,000, or 17 cents a share, compared with $3,640,000, or 36 cents a share for the corresponding period last year before the acquisition of First Western.
LAKELAND, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Six convicts who overpowered two guards and escaped early today from the Camden County Prison Annex were recaptured within hours.

SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 29 -- South Korean militiamen killed four more North Korean guerrillas in the mountainous East Coast area today, a spokesman reported, bringing to 58 the total slain in the last month.

PHOENIX, N. Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A woman in her 70's was injured fatally today when struck by an automobile at an intersection in this village north of Syracuse. She was identified as Anna Limbeck of Phoenix. Her address was 602 Volney Street.

MADRID, Nov. 29 -- The apostolic administrator recently named by Pope Paul VI to take over the turbulent Basque Diocese of Bilbao has announced a series of liberal measures to meet the near-mutiny that has developed among the clergy there.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The experts say Army, but the bunting-draped signs around town distinctly say Army vs. Navy.
DETROIT, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Denny McLain, the Detroit Tigers' 31-game winner, underwent an appendectomy, at Ford Hospital this afternoon.
Last spring, a little more than a year after the death of Henry R. Luce, Time magazine began writing about the world in a new way.

LISBON, Nov. 29 -- Lisbon's Cardinal Patriarch celebrated his 80th birthday today with the realization of one of his lifelong aims, the opening of a Roman Catholic university in Portugal. This had been the only country in Europe with a large Roman Catholic population but no Catholic university.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The nation's foreign trade, heavily influenced by the threat of a dock strike, slipped back into deficit in October, the United States Commerce Department reported today.
THE record price of $134,400 paid for a pair of 1686 English silver tankards at Christie's, the London auction house, on Nov. 20 shows how rarity can account for price in the antiques market.
The crisis in the foreign-exchange markets last week produced massive flows of funds into the New York money market during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday indicated.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Britain will expand research on a 150-mile-an-hour passenger train, the Ministry of Transport announced today. The research will cost $24-million during the next five years. The aim is to get the new train into service by 1974.

Minor changes in suburban services on the Hudson and Harlem divisions of the Penn Central will go into effect starting tomorrow. The railroad this week cautioned commuters to check the new timetables now available at Grand Central Terminal and other stations on the two divisions.

PARIS, Saturday, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- The Europa One F-7 rocket was successfully launched from Australia's Woomera Range tonight, a spokesman for the European Launcher Development Organization announced today.

The Grand Ballroom at the Plaza, mecca for debutantes during the Thanksgiving season, was the scene last night of the first of the Junior Assemblies. Wednesday's Junior League Ball and Thursday's Gotham Ball were also held at the Plaza as will be tommorrow night's Grosvenor Ball.

The appointment of a former Premier of Belgium, Jean Van Houtte, as chairman of Sabena, the Belgian airline, was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Gilbert Perier, who headed the airline's board of directors for 20 years.

Arthur Daley (Nov. 15 column) is right about the baseball writers who vote for the most valuable player. Crosley of East Liverpool and Conneaut Lake, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Connie Lou Crossley, to David Milton Runyon of Port Washington, L. I. A WEEK before the season began, the athletic director, E. L. (Pete) Knerke; the football coach, Burt Grustle, and the sports information director, Barrington Miles, huddled in the crypt of the University Chapel. Knerke was bent double beneath his Favors File. Miles was carrying his Address-o-graph plates, and Grustle wore his varsity roster taped to his wrist. The coach studied the roster, and said: "How about my cornerback, Bobby Billy Davenport?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Johnson Administration is awaiting the concurrence of President-elect Richard M. Nixon before agreeing to open long delayed talks with the Soviet Union on limiting missiles, Administration sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Productivity of labor, or output per man hour, rose further in the third quarter, and for the year to date has done much better than last year's weak performance, the Labor Department reported today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- Viktor P. Nekrasov, a leading Soviet writer, has joined 94 other Soviet intellectuals in a protest against the trial of Pavel M. Litvinov and Mrs. Larisa Bogoraz - Daniel for having staged a demonstration on Red Square against the invasion of Czechoslovakia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The lively debate here among 100 foreign and American intellectuals about the alienation of modern man and the future of democracy has stirred sharp memories in a tall, bald man whose thick-rimmed glasses give him a scholarly look.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 -- The second Mrs. Samuel H. Sheppard sued for divorce today in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court.

It appears that more and more companies are slipping social messages into their product advertising. At least that's the way it appears to Horace J. De Podwin, dean of the Rutgers Graduate School of Business Administration, who said just that. "More and more companies and agencies," he emphasized, "are trying to create campaigns that sell products and carry social messages."
CONAKRY, Guinea, Dec. 3 -- Relations between the United States and Guinea, which in the past were often tempestuous, are now surprisingly warm.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- The baseball rules committee made three decisions tonight in the hope of producing more hits and more runs next season. The committee, which has the authority to make changes without further consultations with owners or general managers, voted to lower the pitching mound, to shrink the strike zone and to enforce the current rule about illegal pitches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Washington Senators club was sold today to Robert E. Short, the Democratic Party national treasurer.

The Corinthian Broadcasting Corporation, which owns several television stations and publishing enterprises, has leased the entire 38th floor, 16,500 square feet, in the 42-story addition to the Bankers Trust Building at 280 Park Avenue.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 3 -- A National Airlines jet refueled under a hijacker's waving gun late today and then flew to Havana with its 28 passengers and a crew of seven.

One of the lesser ironies of the raging debate between the Keynesians and the monetary economists is its effect on the continuing rivalry between New York's two largest banks. The Rockefellers have long been identified with the University of Chicago, where the monetary economists' challenge to Keynesianism springs from roots reaching back over a number of decades.
Elvis Presley, with one eye to the increasing interest in old-style rock and the other to his decreasing income from movie roles, is making plans for nationwide personal appearances again.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A California law student who conducted interviews for the Walker study team of the commission on violence said today that he had placed an advertisement in The Daily Californian, a student newspaper, seeking witnesses to violence in Chicago during the Democratic convention.
WASHINGTON, Dec 3 (UPI) -- President-elect Richard M Nixon has invited to his inauguration Vicki Lynne Cole, the 13-year-old girl who provided a theme for his Administration.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Albert H. DeSalvo, the former handyman who once proclaimed himself to be the "Boston Strangler," filed a $2-million damage suit in Federal district court today against 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, maker of the movie "The Boston Strangler."

SYRACUSE, Dec. 3 -- David Kidd, principal of Central Technical High School, a pre-dominantly Negro school, said today that the halls of the building would be constantly patrolled by Students and faculty.
Representative James H. Scheuer opened his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Mayor yesterday with a caustic attack on the Lindsay administration.

Msgr. Edward M. Connors, who has been associate superintendent of schools for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for the last nine year, has been named superintendent to succeed Msgr. Raymond P. Rigney.

LAST night's presentation titled "Margaret Mead's New Guinea Journal" was an uncommon offering in its distinctive blend of the sociological change in the tiny village of Peri, New Guinea, and a warm portrait of the distinguished anthropologist who brought the people of the remote hamlet to the attention of the world.
About 1,100 people attended the 18th annual fundraising luncheon yesterday of the Friends of the Philharmonic in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The new state trustee for the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn said yesterday that he hoped to reopen Junior High School 271 on Monday.

Dave Newmark, the 7-foot center who unexpectedly left Columbia to sign with the Chicago Bulls, may be only a memory now on Morningside Heights but optimism about this season's basketball campaign remains high on the Lions' campus.

One of Wall Street's most lucrative practices -- the customer-directed "give-up" -- came to an end yesterday as the securities industry prepared to adopt a new commission schedule.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, who as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee will play a key role in determining the tax and spending policies of the Nixon Administration, predicted here yesterday that Federal spending would rise to between $192-billion and $195-billion in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

BLUFFTON, Ind., Dec. 1 -- The sycamore and red oak trees are bare now. At dusk a cold rain sweeps over the plowed black soil, spattering the shingled roofs of farm houses where men in knee-length rubber boots pour oil over rusty tractors and plows and cornpickers.
The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the third largest bank in New York and fourth largest in the nation, announced yesterday its intention to join the trend toward one-bank holding companies.
CARACAS, Dec. 3 -- Venezuela was still without a President-elect today 48 hours after Sunday's extremely close general election.
LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- The British newspaper industry needs to modernize and readjust itself and several newspapers may have to close, Lord Thomson of Fleet said here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey said today he had been offered a post in the administration of Richard M. Nixon, "but I turned it down."

CAIRO, Dec. 3 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser said today that his Government had broken up an Israeli spy ring that included several Egyptians "who were caught red-handed" while operating in the United Arab Republic.

Salvatore V. (Bill) Bonanno, the 36-year-old son of Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno, was charged in a Federal indictment here yesterday with having used a stolen credit card to finance a coast-to-coast tour with an entourage that included alleged Mafia associates, a nightclub hostess and a chauffeur-bodyguard.

In a letter to The Times on Sunday, Nov. 17, it was said that Peru's economic "independence" had been jeopardized by the expropriation of the Standard Oil properties in Peru by the military junta there. On the contrary, the independence of Peru would seem to be advanced by such an action.

The Nine O'Clocks are barely 5 years old, which isn't exactly venerable by New York standards, and yet there's already something traditional and slightly recherche about their private dinner dances. Maybe it's because the 150 club members have convinced themselves that their parties aren't a bit like charity balls.

IN the matter of O. J. Simpson, the Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Southern California, the first of two crucial weekends are coming up for pro football. The leading candidates for the season's poorest won-lost record, which brings with it the first draft choice for the coveted Simpson are Philadelphia (1-11), Buffalo (1-11-1) and Atlanta (2-10). The Bills conclude their season on Saturday against Houston and they have a chance to win.

MOSCOW -- More than anything the Soviet Union would like to de-emphasize foreign policy and turn to internal problems -- for reasons to be discussed in a subsequent column. Dr. William D. Firman, the new state trustee for the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district, has given unmistakable notice that he will not be bullied by extremist pressure and that he is intent on the swift reopening of Junior High School 271. The two priorities are inseparably linked. Instruction cannot be carried on in an atmosphere of confrontation; and the closing of a school resolves no educational issue.
Moscow, Dec. 3 -- The Soviet Union declared today that it would not "permit" a resumption of Arab-Israeli fighting and would do all it could to facilitate a political settlement.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 3 -- Judge George W. Phillips Jr. of the Alameda County Superior Court ordered restrictions here yesterday on comment in the conspiracy trial of seven men arrested in anti-draft demonstrations here in October, 1967.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The Soviet Government made public today a harsh protest against British policy since the invasion of Czechoslovakia.

Determined defiance of television toothpaste ads that say you have to have glistening white teeth is one reason why hippies and Yippies have mouths full or cavities and chronic gum disease, a dentist told his colleagues at a meeting here yesterday.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec 3 -- The Rhodesian Government has moved the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, leader of the banned Zimbabwe African National Union, from Salisbury jail to a secret place of detention.

CHICAGO Dec. 3 -- James B. Conlisk, Chicago's Police Superintendent, disagreed sharply today with the conclusions in the report made public Sunday by the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence.

Kim Stanley, whose last Broadway appearance was in "The Three Sisters" (1964), will return in "Company," coming March 20 to a theater to be announced later. George Furth, an actor, is the author of the three-character comedy, which is divided into seven short plays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- President Johnson arrived more than an hour late tonight for a Democratic reception in his honor and left 15 minutes later after being nearly mobbed by enthusiastic supporters.

A signal switch malfunction at Pennsylvania Station and engine trouble on an Oyster Bay train yesterday morning plagued Long Island Rail Road commuters.

Senator William Proxmire urged yesterday an end to Federal spending on a supersonic transport plane. He said that its development should be determined in the commercial market place.

The Bach Aria Group gave its first concert of the season last night at Town Hall. In view of the current flu epidemic, the reduced forces permitted by the Group's choice of repertory may have been a wise medical -- if not necessarily theatrical -- choice.

QUANLOI, South Vietnam Dec. 4 -- For the last six weeks, the helicopter troopers of the First Cavalry Division (Air-mobile) have been ranging at will over this area northwest of Saigon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, proposed today that the position of Senate Republican whip be increased in importance and given to a junior Senator to help attract more young people to the party.
Silver futures inched ahead yesterday in quite active commodities trading but another precious metal, platinum, rose even more.
ROME, Dec. 4 -- Pope Paul VI, in a voice breaking with emotion, spoke out today against dissenters in the Roman Catholic Church and demanded obedience to its teachings.
The Brooklyn district attorney's office is continuing its investigation in the case of three Yemeni Arabs who were indicted last month for allegedly plotting to kill President-elect Richard M. Nixon.

OSAKA, Japan -- One of the most fascinating cooking enterprises near Japan's inland sea is a school where the students learn not only the fine points of tempura, sashimi and sukiyaki but also the luxury of French cuisine.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- With 700 policemen on the campus, there was no disorder today at the San Francisco State College, where a confrontation yesterday was the most riotous in the school's history.
A leading Negro educator said yesterday that the majority of American Negroes shun "separatism" from whites, but are determined to exercise control in their own communities.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- The nation's urban problems are too great to yield to "haphazard and limited solutions"; they require a "frontal assault that will not work without business participation." Andrew Heiskell, chairman of Time Inc. said in a speech tonight.
In a program that ranged from pseudo-Bach to somewhat-rock at Fillmore East last night, Duke Ellington and his orchestra filled in the broad middle area of the musical spectrum.

Interest rates halted their sharp advance yesterday, but the levels to which they had already risen forced the postponement or reduction of several large bond-market offerings scheduled for this week and next.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- As in South Vietnam, a battle between the Saigon regime and the Vietcong over the minds and hearts of people is taking place in France.

Four separate power failures, including one that the Consolidated Edison Company said was caused by sabotage, left about 5,000 people in this area without electricity for up to two hours yesterday morning.
The election of Magnus R. Bohm as executive vice president for operations of the General Foods Corporation was announced yesterday by the company's board of directors at a meeting in Houston, Tex.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 4 -- Carmine Abbatiello, a 32-year-old New Jersey reinsman, finally scored his 1,000th victory as a driver tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. He did it with a flourish, completing a triple before 10,243 rain-dampened fans.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Stanley Eveling, the latest Northern playwright to descend on London, is signaling his arrival with three plays whose themes range from abortion to the guilt of Germany. He is nonetheless a comic writer as is very clear in "The Lunatic, the Secret Sportsman and the Woman Next Door" which is at the Open Space Theater.
A spokesman for the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that the unfamiliarity of the line's employes with its new timetable was causing some delays.

Cornell University last night honored Arthur H. Dean and Walker L. Cisler, two of its most distinguished alumni, and announced five gifts totaling $6.5-million at a testimonial dinner at the New York Hilton.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 4 -- I don't agree in any way," a Colorado veterinarian said today at Freedom Hall, "with this extrapolation."

ONE of the most valuable aspects of the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater is its delightful home in the basement, the Forum Theater. This is a small but beautifully equipped theater-in-the-round in which the intention is to offer experimental plays -- this season, for the first time, on a subscription basis.

In his notable television interview with Eric Severeid and Martin Agronsky, Justice Hugo Black raised once again one of the most troublesome questions produced by the public demonstrations of dissent that have become common in the last decade: How far are demonstrators protected in their conduct by the constitutional rights of freedom of speech and assembly?

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Because of ailments Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner are doubtful starters for the Davis Cup tennis team in the challenge round against Australia. Donald Dell, the captain, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec.4 -- The United States warned Israel and Jordan today against continuing violations of the cease-fire line that serve to heighten tensions and endanger diplomatic efforts toward a peace settlement in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Nixon Administration must work to create a "new spirit of collaboration" to deal effectively with today's domestic problems, John D. Rockefeller 3d, said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The United States has rejected Czechoslovakia's request for the extradition of Maj. Gen. Jan Sejna, the State Department announced today.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 -- Israeli fighter-bombers attacked Iraqi positions in northern Jordan today, penetrating 40 miles in an hour-long assault, it was announced here.
The Dyna Ray Corporation said yesterday that it had consented to the issuance of a permanent court injunction against acts and practices that might violate Federal securities laws.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills told a group of business leaders yesterday that he and President-elect Richard M. Nixon had agreed that tax credits should be used only in cases where they are more effective than direct Federal spending or Federal subsidies.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, would head a special study group to outline the nation's educational priorities.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- British expectation of an early, total military victory for federal forces in Nigeria -- a belief that has persisted for many months -- shows signs of changing.

Flashing his characteristic smile, Angel Cordero was a happy jockey after he won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The reason was two fold, one being the normal feeling of euphoria for victory itself, and the other, that he resumed the lead in his duel with Alvaro Pineda for the riding championship of the country.

Hyman Shailes slumped in the corner of a high-backed wooden pew, fast asleep despite the steady drone of conversation among the clerks at the door and the new arrivals. Virginia Davis concentrated on her knitting. Peter Norman studied his newspaper, and glared when someone came up to him to ask a question.

The 25th Amendment to the Constitution provides procedures to be followed in the event that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office due to physical or mental disability. However, it provides no procedures to be followed in the event that the Vice President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office due to physical or mental disability.
A grimy foundry in Harlem changed ownership recently, and with the transaction, all the talk about giving Negroes a "piece of the action" took a small but profound step toward reality.

The Eltra Corporation, in its report yesterday for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, showed net income of $22,146,000, equal to $2.80 a common share, up from $21,345,000, or $2.70 a share, earned in the preceding fiscal year.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 -- The National Farmers Organization has made significant gains this year in promoting collective bargaining for farmers, Oren Lee Staley, the group's president, said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Chief Judge William J. Campbell of United States District Court here questioned today the release of a government commission report dealing with violence during the Democratic National Convention before a Federal grand jury had completed its investigation of the disorders.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- An official of the National Newspaper Association urged the Federal Trade Commission today not to make truthful advertising illegal.

The American International Group, Inc., has announced plans to offer to exchange its securities of the outstanding capital stocks of the American Home Assurance Company, the National Union Fire Insurance Company of Pittsburgh and the New Hampshire Insurance Company.

The sensible and dignified arrangement worked out between President-elect Nixon and Chief Justice Warren ends the confusion about whether the Chief Justice is staying or leaving. He is doing both.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4 -- The two leading candidates for President of Venezuela were separated by 30,000 votes today after more than 2.5 million votes from Sunday's general elections had been counted.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 14 -- Investment bankers meeting here were cautioned today that steps must be taken to blunt the inflationary expectations that had become so pronounced this year.

Jose Echaniz started but did not finish his piano recital last night in Philharmonic Hall. He had the Hong Kong flu.

President-elect Nixon has made another fine choice in naming Paul W. McCracken as chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers. The United States Freight Company, one of the nation's largest forwarders, will venture into passenger service this Saturday when its $9-million ship Freeport is to begin a daily service between Miami and Freeport in the Bahamas, 70 miles east of Palm Beach.

No one likes the hourly quotas fixed by the Federal Aviation Administration for airports in New York, Chicago and Washington. General aviation considers them discriminatory and the airlines are almost equally uphappy with them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it was conducting an investigation to determine if the National Rifle Association had engaged in lobbying without registering as a lobbyist.

GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- Television executives from the United States and a number of European countries insisted today that television coverage of parliamentary debates was essential for the public to understand how national policies were determined.

IN a big old farmhouse whose post office is Perkasie in Bucks County, Pa., there is fairly often these days -- in fact, for some of the occupants, it is far too often -- the enveloping aroma of kimchee. This is a Far Eastern dish of pickled vegetables that would be almost unbearably pungent even without garlic.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- Italy returned today to "normality" -- agitation by tens of thousands of students throughout the country -- after a 24-hour general strike that virtually paralyzed the Rome region yesterday.
HOW far along the road is the Fidelity Corporation in its quest for shares of the Monumental Life Insurance Company? There seems to be at least three schools of thought.
The proposed merger of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago and the Central Illinois Light Company was called off yesterday.

BAMAKO, Mali, Dec. 6 (Agence France-Presse) -- Lieut. Moussa Traore, chairman of Mali's Military Committee of National Liberation, has taken over as the country's President, it was announced in a decree here today.

ASPEN, Colo., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Fine giant slalom skiing by its men's team today propelled the United States into a 6-4 lead in the opening day of match-race competition for the French-American Challenge Cup.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art must close some of its exhibits on weekends because of insufficient guards, Thomas P. F. Hoving told the city yesterday.

Seven union teachers suspended by a local governing board in East Harlem entered Public School 39 with a heavy police escort yesterday only to find the school abandoned on orders of the local governing board.
A top Treasury Department official proposed yesterday a new system of variable border taxes and export rebates to adjust trade balances without affecting the domestic tax system.

IN this season, when well-wishers are easily parted from their money, the sales desks of museums are a good source for gifts that are comparatively inexpensive and often unusual. The Gallery Shop at the Brooklyn Museum is specializing in folk art objects and other amusements from around the world, with a number of items under $10.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- After the historic meeting today at which Baseball Commissioner William D. Eckert announced his "retirement," the various executives broke out of the Comstock Room as quickly as they could.
BALBOA, Panama, Dec. 6 -- A ship, officially reported to be the first Soviet-flag passenger liner to use the Panama Canal, moved northbound through the waterway today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence went into seclusion today to shape a report to the White House far from the furor caused by its disputed study of the antiwar clashes in Chicago.

The unexpected dismissal of William D. Eckert as commissioner of baseball confirms a fact that no one in the business has been willing to admit publicly: In the present structure of Organized Baseball there is no need, no desire and really no room for a commissioner.
The president of Fordham University praised a student-faculty coalition calling for a wide variety of reforms yesterday but indicated that major changes had to come from "the entire university body."

George Farkas, the dynamic, 67-year-old merchant who in four decades made Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., into a potent factor in metropolitan New York retailing, has retired from active participation in the company.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, the Kentucky Republican and a member of the United States delegation, made a plea today for continued aid to Arab refugees in the Middle East as he announced a United States pledge of $22,200,000 to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine refugees.
CAIRO, Saturday, Dec. 7 -- William W. Scranton, who is President-elect Richard M. Nixon's representative in the Middle East, conferred for two hours with President Gama Abdel Nasser here last night.

A victory aboard the Calumet Farm's filly Sweet Tooth was the only one registered by Angel Cordero Jr. at Aqueduct yesterday. The success came in the feature race of six furlongs, and it was appreciated by those in the crowd of 21,969 who bet her into $4.60 for $2 favoritism.
Equipment breakdowns plagued the Long Island Rail Road yesterday, causing more delays and unhappiness among thousands of the line's commuters.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The United States and North Vietnam have resolved a number of the procedural issues for the expanded talks here on Vietnam. They include such matters as the number of speakers at the first session, the number of participants on each side, the site of meetings and the use of English and Vietnamese as the official languages.
The indication that the debarment of the nine union teachers from Public School 39 in Harlem is being escalated from an unfortunate incident into a major new conflict flies in the face of all reason.

THE patterns in Joyce Carol Oates's new novel are going to be familiar: the ruin of a marriage seen through the eyes of a child, the essential hollowness of the American Dream (Edward Albee's and others). Life, if you have the money, becomes a push button exercise. Need a maid? Call a number.

Actors Equity Association yesterday rejected the claim by Carla Pinza, a Puerto Rican actress, that she had been discriminated against when she was dismissed from the company of "Jimmy Shine." The show opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Thursday night.

" Nobody writes letters any more, the art of letter-writing is dead." How often one hears this double - barreled lament from pundits who regard with nostalgia the great letter-writers of previous centuries. They then analyze the cause: in our time the telephone has made the letter obsolete, killed it as an art form.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Neutral military observers of the Nigerian civil war said here today they had concluded that Biafra's charges that Nigerian troops were engaged in genocide were unwarranted.
Leaders of the Negro and Jewish communities took a major step this week to bridge what they all described as a communication gap between the two groups.
The city's infant mortality rate here for the first 10 months of 1968 has fallen to a record low because of a decline in the mortality rate of nonwhites.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6 -- Aides to Richard M. Nixon are planning to try out electronic listening posts in Westchester County and Alabama later this month as a means to let the President-elect hear from "the forgotten American."
" There isn't much more they can give me," said Commodore George R. Hickey yesterday as he announced his retirement as senior master of ships for Farrell Lines, Inc.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Mohammad Azam Khan, who was once a minister in President Mohammad Ayub Khan's Cabinet and a Governor of East Pakistan, announced today that he would soon begin a tour of East and West Pakistan "to gather mass support to change the Government."
A new split in prices of hot-rolled steel sheet developed yesterday.

" A TREASURY OF DESIGN," the current exhibition of recent accessions at Cooper-Hewitt -- that's the new name of the venerable Cooper Union -- Museum, demonstrates the scope of the decorative arts in the 200 objects on display.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Currency speculation flared again in European financial centers today, only two weeks after the latest monetary crisis that led to austerity measures in France and Britain and efforts by West Germany to reduce its huge trade surplus.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- President Johnson said today that he hoped to encourage future Presidents to continue the "very long march" for civil rights.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- William D. Eckert was dismissed as the commissioner of baseball today, three years after he had been hired for a seven-year term.
NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- The United States Sixth Fleet announced today that two destroyers would enter the Black Sea in the next few days for routine operations in international waters.
Mayor Lindsay will return to the city today or tomorrow after a week-long Caribbean vacation, Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet said yesterday.

UNIVERSITY PARK, PA., Dec. 6 -- Penn State, ranked third in the nation, may be headed for the warmth of Miami and its Orange Bowl football date with Kansas the night of Jan. 1, but tomorrow, in order to accommodate television and make $180,000 each for Penn State and Syracuse, the Nittany Lions will put their undefeated record on the line against the Orange in freezing weather and possibly in a snowstorm.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 6 -- The possibility of death in the electric chair for 25-year-old Duane Earl Pope of Roxbury, Kan., was renewed here this afternoon as the Nebraska began steps toward a first-degree murder trial.

Ondine, the new 73-foot super-yacht that was dismasted in the Indian Ocean last month, while en route from Germany to Australia for the Sydney-Hobart race, presumably was proceeding to her destination under jury rig.

One of the world's leading central bankers said here yesterday that there was "no reason why" measures taken by France and Germany should not be successful in reestablishing monetary stability in Europe.

The 14th Imperial Ball, held in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza last night, was attended by some 400 of the socially prominent. Pink and red carnations and tall silver candelabra with red candles provided a romantic setting for the event, an annual benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.
About half the 11,700-member instructional staff of the City University has chosen the United Federation of College Teachers as its official bargaining agent.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- At a time when West End shows are closing right and left (six in a month), the likeliest explanation for the arrival of Ronald Millar's "They Don't Grow on Trees" is that it offers nine parts for a star.

The International Business Machines Corporation, in a surprise announcement that is expected to have an important impact on the data processing industry, said yesterday that it anticipated making changes in the way it supports its equipment and charges for it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Johnson is reported to have told his Cabinet in a light moment this week, "We've just got one more month to go. Let's not blow it."
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 6 -- It may have been an omen.
TOKYO -- We went to the Shogetsu, which means pine moon, restaurant with one of Japan's most famous surgeons, a gentlemen named Tokuji Ichikawa.

Twenty-two parking meter collectors and drivers -- more than half of the city's collection force -- were arrested yesterday in an investigation of the systematic theft of about $5-million from meters over the last four years.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- About 200 students stormed into a meeting of the University of Wisconsin Board of Regents in the state Capitol today and demanded reinstatement of suspended Negro students who went on a rampage at Oshkosh State University.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 6 (AP) -- William Manchester said today that two sentences the Krupp family "is said to have found objectionable" do not appear in his book, "The Arms of Krupp."
DALLAS, Dec. 6 -- Braniff International will open tomorrow its new $9-million passenger terminal at Love Field here.

THE exhibition called "Primitive to Picasso" at M. Knoedler Co., 14 East 57th Street, doesn't include everything that stretched in between, and observes no rule of proportion in representing historical periods according to their relative importance.
The pious denial of any Venezuelan expansion into Guyana's territory, made by Venezuela's Charge d'Affaires in an Oct. 18 letter, prompts me now to correct some of its erroneous impressions.
Spurred by a forecast of a sharp increase in capital investment early next year, the stock market posted its only gain of the week in active trading yesterday.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Richard M. Nixon flew to this picturesque desert resort today for some political shop talk with the Republican Governors -- and he lived up to his promise not to announce the names of his Cabinet appointees until next week.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 6 -- The Republican Governors Association balked today over the efforts of Ray C. Bliss to retain his post as Republican National Chairman.
In the London market yesterday traders rushed to buy cocoa for immediate and future delivery, causing a record turnover of 13,816 lots, or contracts. Prices rose sharply.

The development of a choice piece of New York land has unfortunately been used to tarnish the name of the Rev. Donald S. Harrington, senior minister of the Community Church on 35th Street. Suddenly he finds himself attacked by innuendo for racist behavior, a ridiculous and false accusation.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 6 -With a final flurry of assumptions, extrapolations and yawns, testimony in the Kentucky Derby appeal hearing droned to a close today.

The Rev. Donald S. Harrington, state chairman of the Liberal party, who has been accused of blocking the relocation of Central Commercial High School near his church, said yesterday that he might favor the move if there were open space around the school.

DALLAS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The national director of Upward Bound of the Office of Economic Opportunity charged today that enemies of the antipoverty drive had conducted a massive attack on his agency in Washington.
Two of six persons charged with conspiracy to hijack a Pan American World Airways plane to Cuba on Nov. 24 were arraigned in Federal court and held in bail yesterday.

Louis E. Wolfson, chairman of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, was sentenced in Federal Court here yesterday to 18 months in prison and fined $32,000 for conspiring in the illegal sale of stock.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 6 -- Surgeons at Beilinson Hospital in Petah Tikvah, near here, announced today that they had successfully carried out Israel's first heart transplant.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Three economists predicted today that business would continue to expand in the first year of the administration of President-elect Nixon.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew likened some newspapers to day to executioners and bird cage lining in some jesting off-the-cuff remarks at the Republican Governors Conference.

Joseph Papp of the New York Shakespeare Festival is facing a crisis. Typically, he is facing it like a tiger at bay, for even at a disadvantage Mr. Papp can contrive to appear ferociously in command of the situation.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- The clock thwarted a move in Parliament today to make the breakdown of a marriage the sole ground for divorce in Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Twister, which was patented this week for the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, wriggles its way across country, keeping all eight wheels on the ground despite bumps and hollows.
Wayne Zahn, a 27-year-old Georgian from Atlanta, is $10,000 richer than he was six days ago.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Dr. S. I. Hayakawa tried to meet some Black Student Union demands today at San Francisco State College, but his concessions were rejected, as not enough, and a crowd marched from the campus to demonstrate at San Francisco City Hall.

Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow at the box office for the Metropolitan Opera's 16th week, during which Gounod's "Faust" will be heard for the first time this season. Singing their roles for the first time at the Metropolitan will be Pilar Lorengar as Marguerite and Ron Bottcher as Valentin.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 6 -- Brown University proposed today a five-year timetable for accepting more Negroes in an attempt to end the walkout of about 65 of its 85 Negro undergraduates.

Eight Reform Democrats have entered a contest for the City Council seat of Edward I. Koch, who was elected to the House of Representatives last month, but there was some doubt yesterday that the winner would get the seat.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Special restrictions were ordered today on air traffic over the liner Queen Elizabeth as the vessel neared her scheduled arrival this weekend at Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Dec. 6 -- The owner of a cocktail lounge and a patron he had accused of passing a bad check stood uneasily before the justice of the peace in a small courtroom on the second floor of the Hampton Bays Fire Department building. It was the first experience in court for both men.

BUFFALO, Dec. 6 (UPI) -The president of a Buffalo concern has been released on $10,000 bail after his arrest in a crackdown on an alleged stolen television ring that authorities called a major breakthrough in linking Mafia families in New York and Pennsylvania.

Clarence C. Pell, a New York aviation insurance executive, has been appointed director general of an insurance corporation that major world airlines are planning to provide for their own coverage. WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Atlantic alliance, reacting to the growing strength of the Soviet Navy in recent years, is considering updating its battle plans to develop a fast-reaction fleet of up to 50 warships able to rush to any crisis spot in the North Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Jewish member of the University of Pennsylvania marching band's drill team was reinstated yesterday after having been dismissed for refusing to strut to the tune of Christmas carols on Thanksgiving Day.
The bond market shrugged off yesterday the Government's report that businesses plan substantial increases in capital spending over the next several months and ended the week with a small advance.

ST. THOMAS, V. I., Dec. 6 -- Six persons were killed and 10 others injured tonight when a light passenger plane crashed into a house near the Harry S. Truman Airport here.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Dr. Rafael Caldera a Christian Democrat, today was virtually assured of the Venezuelan presidency for the next four years, but reports of irregularities in vote counting from the interior delayed a final result.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The United States will fly 15,500 men and four F-4 Phantom fighter-bomber squadron to West Germany to take part in maneuvers near the Czechoslovak border in January, the Defense Department announced today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 6 -Overall, one of the foremost pacers in the United States, is the 3-5 favorite in the overnight line to take the $50,000 Nassau Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow. The 17th performance of the 1 1/2-mile marathon has attracted eight starters, with six wagering interests.

WOLVERHAMPTON, England, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Enoch Powell, whose position as an opponent of colored immigration has caused embarrassment to the Conservative party, moved even further away from the party leadership tonight by suggesting that Britain accept breakaway Rhodesia as an independent nation.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- A 40-year-old mailman here has been notified that he is to be discharged a week before Christmas because he has refused to deliver bulk mail on the ground that it is unfair to the taxpayer.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Jittery selling pushed the pound to its floor level today in pre-weekend trading in foreign-exchange markets. Government securities, stocks and commodities were all disturbed by the revival of European currency fears.

BONN, Dec. 6 -- East Germany and West Germany have agreed on a new formula to allow more than a doubling of trade in key items by 1975, Dr. Karl Schiller, the West German Minister of Economics, announced here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Secretary General Thant said today that the size of the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus was determined solely by the internal situation on that island.

The New York Stock Exchange shattered precedent the other day when it reduced brokerage commissions on large transactions. Under the new "interim" schedule, the result of prodding by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it will cost $2,460 in commissions to buy or sell 10,000 shares of a $40 stock as against $3,900 under the old schedule. The investing public -- especiailly holders of mutual funds and participants in pension programs -- should benefit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Officials of the Chicago Transit Authority and two unions agreed today on substantial pay increases for 11,000 employes.

College students looking to the future got a chance yesterday to discuss career opportunities with some of the country's top employers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 -- Oscar Bonavena will prance into the Spectrum ring Tuesday night on his flat feet, thrust his square torso defiantly, toss his leonine locks majestically and scowl fiercely at Joe Frazier, recognized as the world heavyweight champion in five states, including New York and Pennsylvania.

HAYWARD, Calif., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- The Far Western Conference ended its annual meeting today by voting to establish a part-time commissioner's post to be filled by next July. The conference, represented by San Francisco State, Hayward State, Humboldt State, Chico State, Sacramento State, the Cal Aggies, Sonoma State and Nevada, has not had a commissioner in more than 30 years.

HONG KONG, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Tse Kwong, secretary of a Communist labor union, was freed from jail today. He was among 54 Communists arrested at the height of anti-British riots last year. Six were released earlier this week.

The iron rule that the slightest infraction of the yacht racing code must in most cases lead to unconditional disqualification has been breached by the International Yacht Racing Union. At its annual meeting in London, the world governing body for the sport made a start toward fitting the penalty to the offense by voting that hitting a mark no longer would mean total disqualification.

Total transportation expenditures in the United States during 1967 were estimated at $155.9-billion, an increase of 4.8 per cent over the 1966 total of $148.8-billion, according to a statistical analysis released by the Transportation Association of America.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Two separate explosions injured eight marines yesterday at this training base Southern California. Five men were hurt in an explosion that occurred during a training exercise near Las Pulgas Lake.

Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the first surgeon to perform a successful heart transplant, said last night the only moral question regarding the operation was whether it was right to bury an organ that could save another person's life.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 7 -- The engagement of Miss Wendy Carol Fosner to Richard Greenberg has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Harvey Fosner. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Greenberg of Oceanside. The couple plan to be married in June.

Penn State will go to the Orange Bowl on Jan. 1 with its first undefeated and untied record in 21 years following its easy 30-12 victory yesterday over Syracuse. The Nittany Lions, playing before a home crowd of 38,000, won their 10th game and became the first Penn State eleven to win that many games in a season.

WHEN "Carnival" is revived on Thursday at the City Center, the 1961 musical will become, for the first time, an interracial love story. No one is making a fuss, none of the show's words are being changed to point it up. It is just happening that way because the versatile Negro folksinger Leon Bibb is playing the puppeteer Paul, who gets the girl Lili, played by pretty Victoria Mallory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- A "truly frightening" shortage of radiologists within a few years was predicted here this week by Dr. Stanley M. Wyman, of Belmont, Mass., outgoing president of the Radiological Society of North America.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. Dec. 7 (AP) -- Howell Fraser, a young New Jersey pro, shot a 65 today and jumped into the lead in the Professional Golfers' Association $50,000 Club Pro Tournament. His 7-under par card gave him a total of 203 for 54 holes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- E. Patrick Healy has been appointed by the Peace Corps director, Jack Hood Vaughn, to direct the corps' new program in the Republic of the Congo. Mr. Healy is Deputy Peace Corps Director for Brazil.
