RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 8 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and King Faisal, of Saudi Arabia, put before Mr. Scranton in the last two days explicit statements of the Arab claim to Jerusalem.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Policemen used clubs and fired water cannon today to disperse crowds who lined the streets in defiance of a Government ban on public gatherings.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A drive to persuade President-elect Nixon to pick Patrick Healy as his Secretary of Housing and Urban Development was under way today at the 45th annual convention of the National League of Cities.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 6 -- The thing that impressed William W. Scranton, the former Governor of Pennsylvania, most about Iran was its bubbling prosperity.
THE CRYING GAME. By John Braine. 302 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $5.95. THE INNOCENT. By Richard E. Kim. 384 pages. llifflin. $6.9.5.
The Consolidated Edison Company and union negotiators reached an agreement yesterday that they hoped would end a strike by 20,000 workers.
The New York Philharmonic concert conducted by Andre Kostelanetz at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday night was planned for easy listening.
THE CATHOLIC REVOLUTION. By Douglas J. Roche. David McKay. 325 pages. $6.50.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Sam Stayman's New York team, including Tobias Stone, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Mitchell and Paul Trent, burst into the lead in the Reisinger Open Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here this afternoon.
Representative Melvin R. Laird, Republican of Wisconsin, will be the Defense Secretary in the Nixon Administration, sources close to the President-elect said last night.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The mystery of the source of the heart for Israel's first transplant patient has started a dispute in Israel.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Dec. 8 -- The nine-day "World Series of rodeo" -- the tenth annual national finals, in which only the top 15 money winners in each event are eligible to compete -- ended today. A total of $71,250 in purses was distributed and the champions for the year crowned.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- Mariano Rumor, Italy's Premier-designate, is a man of the center who, like a good shortstop, can go to the left or the right.

Joan Singer, the pianist who gave a recital at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon, may have had good reasons for putting together the program she played, but the uninstructed listener can only wonder what they might have been.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 8 -- Minister of Interior Moshe Shapiro signed today a regulation requiring places of public assembly to prepare space where objects can be left for checks by bomb disposal units.

A new minister was installed yesterday at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, 30 East 31st Street. He is the Rev Dr. W. Wesley Shrader, who had been pastor of the First Baptist Church in Lewisburg, Pa., since 1960.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Reies Lopez Tijerina, who dismissed his lawyers early in his kidnapping trial to plead his own defense, will face his biggest challenge tomorrow in keeping alive a claim to a large amount of territory in the state under a Spanish land grant.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Forbes Kennedy's goal with 7:56 remaining in the third period enabled the Philadelphia Flyers to tie the St. Louis Blues, 4-4, tonight in a National Hockey League game at the Spectrum.

HOSTESSES depend on them, single girls lose sleep over them, friends and mothers chirp, "Have I got a girl for you!" Such is the life of a bachelor, and Wednesday night six of those who made it through Leap Year unscathed (read: without getting married) will be honored as the Bachelors of the Year.
While not exactly at the poverty level, the salaries of high public officials still fall dismally below those of corporate executives. Adjustments are overdue.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- In late October an underwriting syndicate composed of nearly a score of Swiss banks put before the Swiss public a new issue of bonds of the World Bank.
BEAUFORT, N. C., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Seven men drowned and seven were rescued when the fishing vessel Fenwick Island capsized and sank in rough seas off the coast here last night.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 8 -- Angel Cordero Jr. rode three winners today to raise his 1968 victory total to 310. But Junior, as Cordero is known on the racing circuit, was only the secondary hero of a red-letter day for Puerto Rican racing.

Angela Giordano presented a very correct New York debut recital program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Beginning with the required group of baroque arias, the soprano proceeded to thrice-familiar lieder selections by Schubert, Liszt and Strauss, made a bow to the contemporary with three songs by Raoul Pleskow and concluded with the traditional French items by Debussy and Poulenc.
Since 1954, Cleveland T. Washington had lived behind the bleak walls of Clinton Prison in Dannemora, serving 20 to 30 years on his second conviction for mugging.
TRENTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)--La Salle broke away from a shorter Rider team with an 11-point spurt midway through the second half tonight and posted a 79-59 victory.

Less than one-half of 1 per cent of Penn Central passengers are using its baggage and checking services, a vice president of the railroad testified yesterday in support of a proposed abandonment of such services on most of its routes.

It was too cold yesterday for an outdoor party, so Picasso's 60-ton sand-blasted concrete sculpture, "Bust of Sylvette," rising to the third-story level in University Plaza facing Bleecker Street just east of La Guardia Place, was dedicated nearby at New York University's Tishman Auditorium on Washington Square South.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -Many ordinary stock market investors are following the example of big-time criminals who traditionally have sought to hide their gains in numbered Swiss bank accounts, Congress was told today.

Villager Industries, Inc., and the Endicott Johnson Corporation might change the terms and form of their proposed merger, the two concerns said yesterday. The transaction will be presented to shareholders of both concerns next May.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Paul G. Hoffman was reappointed administrator of the United Nations Development Program today by Secretary General Thant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Nearly all major manufacturing industries queried by the Commerce Department say they expect sales to increase in the first quarter of 1969, but not at this year's rate.
McGRAW, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A gunman held up a branch of the First National Bank of Cortland today and escaped with $12,000 in cash.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Several hundred Cheyney State College students, protesting the expulsion of nine Negro militants, vandalized the school cafeteria, snack shop and library today and then invaded the office of the president, Wade Wilson.

The president of the Carnegie Corporation warned yesterday that responsible foundations must "put the foundation house in better order" or risk "hasty and clumsy" regulative legislation from Congress.

Louise Bogan, the 71-year-old poet, has been elected to membership in the American Academy of Arts and Letters, considered to be the nation's highest honor society of the arts, it was announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- Premier Eisaku Sato assured Chobyo Yara, new Chief Executive of the Ryukyu Islands, today of his Government's "hand-in-hand cooperation" in obtaining Okinawa's reversion to Japanese rule.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)--The Commerce Department issued a map today assessing the odds for snow on Christmas in various parts of the United States.
Nineteenth-century riverboat elegance has been priced out of existence in this country, officials of the Greene Line said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court ruling holding unconstitutional a South Carolina law that provides scholarship grants to students who want to attend private, non-parochial schools.

NEWARK, Dec. 9 -- The Newark Evening News became simply The Evening News today. A front-page announcement in today's editions said: "The publisher and editors of The Evening News believe the new name more properly reflects the regional character of the newspaper than does the old one.
Governor Rockefeller says he has decided to seek a fourth term in the 1970 election.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Following are excerpts from a discussion of the future of television contained in a draft report on the communications industry prepared by a special Presidential committee:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -President and Mrs. Johnson paid tribute tonight at a formal dinner to 23 Apollo astronauts and the man who directed the space program for most of its existence, James E. Webb.
MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -The Soviet news agency Tass reported in two paragraphs tonight the entry of the destroyers into the Black Sea.
NEW DELHI, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- India and North Korea signed an agreement today envisioning a total trade turnover of $9.4-million in 1969.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero, who shifted from New York to Florida in his quest for the I968 jockey championship, came up empty in his first day of riding at Tropical Park today and his total of winners for the season remained at 310.

In a bout replete with theatrics, Bruno Sammartino of Italy defeated The Sheik after 9 minutes 58 seconds last night in the feature heavyweight wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden. The Sheik, who is from Syria, was billed as the Arabian champion.
What's wrong with collegiate basketball at Madison Square Garden?
NEW DELHI, Dec. 9 -- The Congress party lost its majority in the Hariana State Assembly today and fears deepened that the politics of northern India have become incurably unstable.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Vote totals showing that Michigan voters rejected Daylight Saving Time by 1,501 votes were certified as official today by the Board of State Canvassers.
N.B.C.'s "Laugh-In" took the night off Monday to make room for a Timex special starring The Supremes (or, as they are now officially known, Diana Ross and The Supremes) and The Temptations.

Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, was named chairman of the editorial board of The New York Law Journal yesterday. Justice Botein will assume the position on Jan. 1, when he will resign from the bench to return to private practice.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk will return to the Rockefeller Foundation as its first Distinguished Fellow at the end of the Johnson Administration on Jan. 20.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.4 on Friday from a revised level of 98.1 on Thursday.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon declared last night that he would instruct the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare to seek a way to assist voluntary organizations in programs designed to help the young and old in the nation.

GENEVA, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -The program of International Committee of the Red Cross to provide relief for Nigeria and Biafra is financially safe until the end of the year, the head of the organization said here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The Economic and Financial Committee today voted to enlarge the economic committee of the Economic and Social Council from 18 to 27 members to prepare for the second Development Decade, a United Nations effort to assist poorer countries.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- The United States doubles team of Stan Smith and Bob Lutz blasted through the first round of the Queensland tennis championships in little more than a half hour today.
The League for Parent Education will have its 22d annual luncheon at the Voisin restaurant today. The event, which will include a fashion show, will aid the League's mental health program.
JERICHO, Dec. 9 -- William W. Scranton crossed the Allenby Bridge over the Jordan River today on the final leg of his Middle East fact-finding trip and caused a stir before he had gone 300 yards.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Treasury bill rate at today's auction rose sharply to the highest levels since May 20, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 9 -- Senator Charles H. Goodell said today that he would introduce legislation to establish national standards for welfare programs to discourage the migration of poor people from the South to states with higher relief payments.
DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Michigan outscored Duke, 11-1, midway in the second half tonight on its way to a 90-80 victory over the 16th-ranked Blue Devils.

State and local government could save as much as $35-million a year by 1975 if commercial banks were allowed to underwrite municipal revenue bonds, a study published by the office of the Controller of the Currency said yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Mayor Richard S Jackson announced today that he had hired Bernard Fulton as director of the city's new Model City Program. Mr. Fulton, who has been a director of operations for an antipoverty program in Washington for nearly three years, will assume the $22,500 city post Jan. 6

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Herve Filion equaled the world's record for harness-racing victories tonight when he drove Vicki's Kid, his own 7-year-old mare, to a triumph--Filion's 384th of the year--at Blue Bonnets race track.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9 -- The Robert F. Kennedy Youth Center is a $10-million prison for teen-agers. But it has neither bars nor fences and it looks more like a modern college campus nestled in the harsh hills of West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Justice Department announced tonight that it had concluded that available evidence on the alleged misuse of public funds by Adam Clayton Powell failed to warrant criminal prosecution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Daniel Jackson Oliver Wendell Holmes Morgan, a flamboyant impostor who served two prison terms for practicing law -- successfully but fraudulently -- was assured the right today to argue before the Supreme Court.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Gary Player of South Africa shot an eight under-par 64 today and won the sixth and final challenge match against Billy Casper of the United States, who had a 71.

The Fluor Corporation, builder of oil, gas and chemical plants, reported yesterday that earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 fell to $11,961,000, or $2.06 a share, from the year-earlier $12,062,000, or $2.17 a share.

Joe Cowan, a halfback from Johns Hopkins, and a quarterback, Don Weiss of Juniata, have been picked as the most valuable players in the College Division of the Middle Atlantic Conference for the second year in a row.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, Capt. Terence O'Neill, warned his countrymen tonight against right-wing Protestant extremists. He called them "lunatics."
THE SHADOW OF BLOOMING GROVE. Warren G. Harding in His Times. By Francis Russell. 691 pages. McGraw-Hill. $10 until Jan. 1, thereafter $12.50.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Some Government mental health experts are worried over signs that drug use may be spreading to grade-school children.
Lionel D. Edie Co., investment counselors, has leased a floor exceeding 24,000 square feet in the Bank of New York Building, 530 Fifth Avenue.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 7 -- "Within five to ten years I will lose everything I have," the Chinese-Malaysian businessman said. The businessman a big, hulking man of about 40 who owns one of Kuala Lumpur's most prosperous trading companies spoke in tones of angry finality.

The election of James T. McMillan as president and chief operating officer of the McDonnell Douglas Finance Corporation, was announced yesterday by James S. McDonnell, chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J. -- Shortly after the turn of the century, the property on the heights behind the Palisades fulfilled the late Upton Sinclair's "dreams of Utopia."
One of the most pressing tasks facing the new Administration will be that of reforming the State Department, a cumbersome bureaucracy whose shortcomings have exasperated a series of Presidents.

ROME, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski ended his one-month visit to the Vatican today and headed home. It was his first trip outside Poland since 1965, when he was banned from foreign travel by the Government because Polish bishops had sent West German bishops a letter of reconciliation.

The New York Knickerbockers, who had a four-game winning streak going in the National Basketball Association and hopes of extending it sagged a little in Cleveland Sunday night. Their 120-115 defeat, after they had led the Cincinnati Royals by 13 points, was a disappointing one.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Tenth-ranked Kansas had little trouble in defeating Xavier, 79-56, tonight. It was Kansas' third victory in four games. The taller Jayhawks, with the aid of an aggressive zone defense, took charge early. They led, 36-24, at half-time.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The French have rarely seen an Ambassador quite like Sargent Shriver. In the provinces, few have ever seen a United States Ambassador at all. But the 53-year-old Ambassador Shriver has seen more of France, and of the French, than any of his predecessors.
Eleven employes, including three top officials, were transferred out of the city's parking meter division yesterday following an investigation into the theft of $5-million in coins.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The ferment of youth was described here today as a hopeful indication that young people are determined to achieve the fundamental freedoms proclaimed 20 years ago in the Human Rights Declaration.
GENEVA, Oct. 9 -- The four-man crew was killed Saturday when a chartered plane on a mercy flight to Biafra crashed four miles from the Biafran air-strip at Uli, it was announced today.

CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 9 -- A California foursome held a big lead tonight going into the final session of the Reisinger Open Team Championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here.
BAMAKO, Mali, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Former President Modibo Keita has been transferred to a prison deep in the Sahara, a military source said Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Supreme Court opened the way today for tighter restrictions on discounts by wholesale distributors to retail food chains. It let stand a lower court order that the discounts must be made on a "store-by-store" basis.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 9 -- The basic telephone service supplied by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company requires that it be a monopoly, but competing concerns should be allowed to enter the business of supplying private line services, a Presidential study group has concluded.

The Yeshiva College Dramatic Society will give four performances over the weekend of "Billy Budd" at the college's 185th Street and Amsterdam Avenue campus. On Saturday, the curtain is 8:30 P.M.; on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. and at 8:30 P.M.
DENVER, Dec. 9 -- Mayor Tom G. Currigan has resigned to accept an airlines job at reportedly twice his $14,000 annual city pay.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A special Presidential committee has concluded that cable television offers promise of a new era in broadcasting, permitting a diversity in programs to appeal to all segments of the society.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Governor Rockefeller, after a round of golf with Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew, remarked: "Agnew is not only going to be a real asset to the new administration but he will also make a good golfer when he steadies down a bit."
Governors of the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange will meet next Tuesday to decide on trading hours for the big regional exchange in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Except for the relatively few of us who remain incorrigible baseball fans, it is not a large matter that the major league club owners have forced the resignation of their commissioner, a former Air Force general, and appointed a committee to revamp the organizational and administrative structure of the professional sport.
THERE is a lady I have never met who lives in a faraway place on the California coast.
DALLAS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, has announced that it is purchasing the newly completed One Main Place in downtown Dallas for $40.5-million.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -New York City's Circle in the Square Theater and Theodore Mann, its artistic director, were selected today to reopen productions at Ford's Theater, where Abraham Lincoln was shot.

THE last few weeks have seen a distinguished procession of pianists looking into Carnegie Hall. There was Vladimir Horowitz not long ago, and then Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli. Last night it was Alicia de Larrocha, and she was by no means the least.

The Roof of the St. Regis-Sheraton will be the setting for the 71st annual dinner dance of the North Carolina Society of New York on Friday at 8:30 P.M. There will be a cocktail party in the adjoining Penthouse at the hotel at 7:30.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit ordered Arkansas today to abolish use of the "bullhide" for disciplining prison inmates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The National Education Association said today it would conduct a conference next month to examine the future of American education. Elizabeth D. Koontz, the organization's president, said the meeting here would involve 300 leaders from Government, business, industry and the professions, as well as educators from all 50 states. It will be held Jan. 24-27.

" Lemonade" and "The Autograph Hound," two short plays by James Prideaux, which were to have opened last night at the Jan Hus Theater, have been set back to Friday night. The delay will give Jan Miner, who succeeded Sada Thompson, more rehearsal time.

FROM the long-range viewpoint, one of the most significant developments in the future of pro football has been created by the opportunity of the Buffalo Bills to select O. J. Simpson as the No. 1 choice in the combined college draft on Jan. 28.

Jerome A. Straka, chairman of the board of the Chesebrough-Pond's Corporation, has been elected to the board of directors of the Keuffel Esser Company, engineering equipment and supplies manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Chances seem to be fading for a liberal challenge to Senator Russell B. Long's bid for re-election as the assistant Democratic leader, or party whip, in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Prices of mortgages continued their steady downward drift at this week's Federal National Mortgage Association "auction," the agency disclosed today.

For failing to report the death of a girl and for dumping her body in the East River, a man and his woman friend were sentenced yesterday in Criminal Court to three years on probation.

The six National Football League officials who deprived the Rams of a down in Sunday's Chicago-Los Angeles game were suspeneded for the remainder of the season yesterday by Pete Rozelle, commissioner of pro football. The loss of further assignments will cost the officials pay ranging from $250 to a theoretical top of $1,650.

PENNSVILLE, N. J., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- A mother, Mrs. Louisa Toulson, 51 years old, and her son, Billy, 7, were killed today when a raging fire trapped them in the second floor bedrooms of their wood frame house. A neighbor, Wayne Poticher, entered the flaming structure and rescued the boy's younger brother, Teddy, 5.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 9 -- Mr. Scranton passed within 10 feet of the muzzles of Arab commandos' machine guns today and then ended his tour of Arab capitals by strolling across a makeshift span into Israeli-held territory.
The operator of an airliner that strayed into airspace over a Soviet-held island June 30 has paid a $5,000 civil penalty to the Federal Aviation Administration.

SHORTLY after the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy the baseball establishment was criticized in this space for the deplorable botch it had made of its part in the memorial tribute. It acted without direction where it acted at all and displayed a gross insensitivity to the national mood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President-elect Nixon's reported choice of Representative Melvin R. Laird as Secretary of Defense makes one thing safely predictable -- the Pentagon in the next Administration is going to be run in a way that bears no resemblance to the regime of Robert S. McNamara.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest plywood maker, ordered a rollback yesterday in some softwood plywood mill prices. It also is planning a rigid "hold the line" policy of other grades and strict limitations on mark-ups at the wholesale level.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Sterling held steady today at $2.3830, down from $2.3835 at the opening, but up from Friday's close of $2.3826.

The space agency said, "There is no reason to feel this will have any effect on our launch attempt for Dec. 21."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has apparently forfeited what may be her last chance to beat the United States in sending astronauts on a flight around the moon.

The engagement of Miss Collette D. Liantonio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Liantonio of Brooklyn, to Frank T. Keefe, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Keefe of Holbrook, Mass.. has been announced by the prospective bride's parents. THE Securities and Exchange Commission's crackdown on the misuse of insider information appears to have developed some undesirable side effects. Wall Street observers, who believe this to be the case, cite the Xerox-CIT Financial negotiations as an example of what can happen under the new ground rules.

A lawyer and an accountant who promoted a $2,140,000 cooperative housing project in Brooklyn that went into default two years ago were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiring to defraud the Federal Housing Administration, which insured the project.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Reserve's open market committee decided in early September to maintain monetary policy unchanged, despite evidence of rapid expansion of bank credit and few signs of a slowdown in the economy, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- President Johnson will make a posthumous presentation of the Medal of Honor tomorrow to Army Capt. Riley Leroy Pitts, the first Negro officer to be awarded the nation's highest decoration for heroic military action.

Gustave L. Levy, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, will be honored tomorrow at the New York State Chamber of Commerce when he is presented with the Haym Salomon Peace and Humanitarianism medal.

Retail toy sales are expected to reach a record of about $2.5-billion by the time the last Christmas present is bought on Dec. 24, the new president of the Toy Manufacturers of America said yesterday.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Hampshire College announced receipt today of a $1-million grant from the Charles E. Merrill Trust. The trust was established under the will of Mr. Merrill, founder of the brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.
Steel production declined slightly last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 9 -- A charge that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were questioning poor people for the House Appropriations Committee was heard today by the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

Four members of the management team of the Boeing Company have been elected vice presidents: Richard W. Taylor, general manager of the military airplane systems division; Oliver C. Boileau, Minuteman program manager, missile and information systems division of the aerospace group; Otis H. Smith, general manager of the Wichita division, and H. N. Stuverude, assistant manager of the vertol division.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The father of a crewman of the captured ship Pueblo, rebuffed by the North Korean Embassy here four times in five days, said today that he had given up hope in Moscow but that he would pursue "other avenues" in an effort to free his son and the 81 other crewmen who were seized last January.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A 9-point scoring spree by 6-foot-8-inch Bill Bunting broke open a tight intersectional basketball duel and second-ranked North Carolina sped from there to a 100-78 victory over Vanderbilt tonight.
Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, announced yesterday action programs in 21 Negro communities in 16 states and the District of Columbia.

MIAMI, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Sonny Wade, a quarterback, and Larry Bates, a flanker, of Emory and Henry College in Virginia signed today to play in the North-South College All-Star game Christmas Day in the Orange Bowl.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- James L. Alcock, Assistant District Attorney, said today that he thought the trial of Mr. Shaw would last at least six weeks and would probably begin in January.

Milovan Djilas completed a new book before his release from prison in Yugoslavia last January and has brought the manuscript to the West for publication, it was disclosed last night during a dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel at which he received the 1969 Freedom Award.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9--Activists of the Christian Democratic party danced in the hot streets here today in celebration of the election victory of Dr. Rafael Caldera.
BASEL, Switzerland, Dec. 9 -- One of Europe's most influential central bankers warns against trying to reform the monetary system by introducing flexible exchange rates or raising the price of gold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Depending on who is talking, Representative Melvin Robert Laird of Wisconsin is tough, shrewd, steely-eyed, aggressive, slippery, able, intelligent, hard-working, dedicated and affable. An opposition Democrat calls his apparent selection as Secre tary of Defense a good appointment."

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 7 -- Five months after five Central American chiefs of state met with President Johnson in an atmosphere of concern. Latin America's only working model of economic integration is once again in danger of breaking up.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Government is preparing to file suit against at least one manufacturer for allegedly failing to comply with safety standards for automobile tires.

Moore Schley, Inc., an investment concern, has leased 7,800 square feet of space on the 15th floor in the office building at 200 East 42d Street as headquarters of its institutional block-trading and research departments.

CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., Dec. 9 -- James A. O'Neill, the Cape May County prosecutor, announced today that a county grand jury would meet Dec. 18 on the case of a double murder in Tuckahoe, N. J., last month.

J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., has elected William C. Hayes as president and chief executive officer of the Gulistan Carpet division, succeeding Steele L. Winterer, who becomes chairman of the division, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The New Orleans Buccaneers routed Oakland, 145-139, tonight in American Basketball Association play as James Jones scored 48 points, a team record. The victory snapped the Bucs' five-game losing streak.

Frederick Chusid Co., the executive job counseling concern, has instituted a money-back guarantee policy. The company will consider refunds of fees to clients who have complained that they were misled, company officials testified yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 AP) -- The President's commission on violence hopes to make a progress report to the White House by the end of this month and has agreed on most of its contents, a spokesman said today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 9 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors adopted a 2 per cent sales tax today, and approved a record budget for next year. It also reduced one section of the property taxes, but the over-all bill to property owners still will go up.

A student-faculty group at the Lincoln Square campus of Fordham University began yesterday to hold classes that they said would continue around the clock to protest a university decision to end their experimental curriculum.
The rate of economic expansion is starting to slow, a leading investment banker said yesterday.
EVERY great football team has its share of outstanding players, one or two of whom are members of the "unsung hero" club. Usually they are interior offensive linemen or remote defensive backs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI)--Senator Strom Thurmond said today that President Johnson had toyed with the idea of calling a special session of Congress to nominate Arthur J. Goldberg as Chief Justice but abandoned it when it looked as though he would run into trouble.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refusal today to review a ruling that legal expenses paid for Joseph Glimco, a former teamster official, by the union in an extortion trial were subject to income taxes. He was acquitted at the 1957 trial.
Where are the new playwrights?
Penn State, which completed the best season in its 82-year history on Saturday, was named the winner of the 1968 Lambert Trophy as the outstanding major college football team in the East yesterday.
The Christmas Ball, a private subscription dance for post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples, will be held in the Astor Gallery at the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1968 cotton crop at 10,822,000 bales, down 90,000 bales from last month's forecast.
Interest rates continued to move higher yesterday but their climb was much less pronounced than the rise early last week.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Bob Lunn of Sacramento, Calif., and Mrs. Gerda Whalen of West Germany, were named the most improved professional golfers for 1968 today by Golf Digest magazine. Lunn won the Memphis open and the Atlanta Classic, and earned more than $100,000 on the tour.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Quiz time at auto-repair school:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9--Foot patrolmen drove more than 500 demonstrators off the San Francisco State College campus today, and mounted policemen then herded the protestors away.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- A grand jury began an investigation today of the seizure by black militants of the administration building at San Fernando Valley State College,
Mayor Lindsay talked with President-elect Richard M. Nixon yesterday about the problems of the cities, but said later that Mr. Nixon did not ask him to come to Washington to try solving them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Supreme Court refused today to bar Jim Garrison, New Orleans District Attorney, from prosecuting Clay L. Shaw on charges of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- After 16 years of study, the Government recommended today the first Federal standard to reduce coal dust, which causes an incurable lung disease blamed for more miners' deaths than accidents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 10 -- The enemy shelled three American positions and two provincial capitals near the Cambodian border last night and this morning, allied military spokesmen reported.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 9 -The United States Sixth Fleet destroyers Dyess and Turner sailed through the Bosporus early today and entered the Black Sea for a five-day cruise.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Mimi Aiken, 32 years old, of New York City, died today at St. Luke's Hospital of injuries suffered last night in an auto-truck collision on the New York Thruway five miles north of here.

Michael J. Scandifia, a reputed member of the Carlo Gambino Mafia family, has been reported missing from his home in Hillsdale, N. J., since last Thursday night, when he drove off in his new Cadillac convertible to buy some medicine at a drugstore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Piedmont Airlines, bidding to extend its system to Chicago, said today that the new flights would lead to $600,000 reduction in subsidy the first year of operation. Piedmont spokesmen appeared at a hearing of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United Arab Republic has told the United States that it will declare an end to the state of war with Israel when Israeli forces withdraw from the Sinai Desert to the demarcation line in effect June 5, 1967, before the Middle East war began.
Showing their concern for the misfortune of neighbors, 85 donors responded yesterday to the 57th annual Christmastime appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund with gifts totaling $16,245.33.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined yesterday. The continuing drop in British Government bonds was the main feature of trading.
A four-alarm fire destroyed the interior of a furnished rooming house on 14th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues yesterday.
Equipment trouble and a passenger's heart attack added to the problems of the Long Island Rail Road yesterday as it started another week of attempts to meet its new timeable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A series of $100-a-plate dinners in metropolitan centers is being planned by friends and associates of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy to help pay off the deficit from his Presidential campaign this year.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Mickey Lolich, the Detroit left-hander who pitched three victories for the Tigers in the World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals, was named today to receive the J. Roy Stockton Award at the St. Louis Baseball Writers' annual dinner Jan. 27.
Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury, urged yesterday that American corporations increase their present contributions to the arts to 10 per cent of their total philanthropic donations.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- The 118-year-old Parker House, well-known Boston hotel, has been sold to the Dunfey family, owners and operators of 10 hotels and motor inns in New England.
SOME notable gladiators were in National Hockey League fights over the weekend, and, true to their code, shrugged it off by Monday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- President Johnson called on the nation in a proclamation today to observe the week beginning tomorrow as Human Rights Week. The proclamation set tomorrow as Human Rights Day and Dec. 15 as Bill of Rights Day.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Leading members of the United States and South Vietnamese delegations to the peace talks here held their first long working session today to coordinate their strategy for the expanded negotiations with the Communist side.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today his Senate subcommittee would hold hearings early next year on proposed constitutional amendment to provide for elec tion of the President by popular vote or otherwise change the Electoral College system.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- Executives of the Christian Democratic and Socialist parties tonight ratified the Government program proposed by Premier - designate Mariano Rumor, assuring speedy formation of a new center-left coalition Cabinet.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 9 -- Charles B. Shuman, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, urged today a counter-boycott of stores that yield to union demands that they stop stocking California grapes.

OSAKA, Japan -- Although it has never been declared as such, the dish called sushi may be the national dish of Japan. Sushi is, of course, an assortment of small morsels of the freshest raw fish and sea food pressed onto cold rice lightly seasoned with vinegar.
A grand jury is investigating charges by a City College associate dean that five student radicals stole confidential files from his office and assaulted his secretary and a student aide.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 -- Vice President-elect Spiro T. Agnew tried today to assure the nation's city officials that they would have the cooperation of the new Republican Administration.

President-elect Richard M. Nixon will introduce the 12 members of his Cabinet -- and perhaps other key appointees -- on national television tomorrow night. Mr. Nixon's break with the tradition of naming members of the Cabinet over a period of a week or so was dictated by a desire for a big audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Sargent Shriver came here today to inform the Kennedy family of his intention to join the incoming Nixon Administration as chief United States representative at the United Nations.
Grain futures moved downward in price yesterday, in slow trading. The price declines were a cent or more a bushel, reflecting some liquidation in the face of uncertainty.
SOME of the poshest dog-houses in town went on view yesterday at James and Earline DeVrie's antiques and decorative furnishings shop, 175 East 63d Street.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 9 -- Four schoolgirls were killed and 17 persons were injured today when an express train smashed into a school bus at a level crossing near Kempsey, 300 miles north of here. The police charged the 18-year-old station assistant, who was in charge of the crossing gates, with four counts of manslaughter.
The city's first school budget designed for decentralization--a record request for $1,340,334,904 for the 1969-70 school year--was submitted yesterday by Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Although the college basketball season has barely started, resourceful Richie Regan of Seton Hall already seems to have a running start toward gaining the "Hard Luck Coach of the Year" award.

Spartans Industries Inc. which through its subsidiary, F. J. Korvelle stores holds a 38 per cent interest in Alexander's Department Stores Inc., expects to obtain about $20-million from the first public stock issue of Alexander this week

THE ANTA Matinee series at the Theater de Lys is often of surprising interest -surprising because elsewhere so much rubbish is put on for a run of eternity, and this series, planned for only two performances, is on occasion so much more rewarding.
REA Express, which was struck last Tuesday, said yesterday it would no longer accept any rail or truck cargo into New York, and would limit inbound air shipments to packages picked up by customers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Amusement and recreation "clubs" that admit whites freely to membership but reject Negroes will come under the scrutiny of the Supreme Court next year.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 9 (AP)--Gulf Western Industries, Inc., which is bidding for $1.7-billion worth of the stock of the Sinclair Oil Corporation, asked today in Federal District Court for a dismissal of Sinclair's petition for an order to halt the attempt.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Dec. 9 (AP) -- One man will be handed the authority to regulate the professional golf tour -- if and when the Professional Golfers' Association and the American Professional Golfers settle their dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- President Johnson received today a plaque from the Catholic College Coordinating Council for his efforts in helping high school students to continue their education.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)--The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Supreme Court left standing today a two-year prison sentence for Philip J. Stiles, 23 years old, of Kingston, R. I., who was convicted of disobeying an order to submit to Army induction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to hear the case of 11 Negro militants who are seeking to bar New York from prosecuting them under the state's 66-year-old criminal anarchy law.
JOHN H. SECONDARI and Helen Jean Rogers took viewers on "The Road to Gettysburg" last night as the latest of their "Saga of Western Man" programs for the American Broadcasting Company.
An 11-year-old boy, a student at Intermediate School 44 in Manhattan, has filed suit in Federal court here to protect his right to circulate a petition to oust his school's principal.

UDON, Thailand, Dec. 9 -- In the shack that is the headquarters of the 11th Tactical Reconnaissance Squadron here in northern Thailand, a sign over the operations door reads: "Caution -- flying over North Vietnam may be hazardous to your health."
Luther Green scored 24 points and led Long Island University to an 83-62 victory over Philadelphia Textile last night at the winner's court in Brooklyn.

The Consolidated Edison strike has been "settled," but New Yorkers will have to hold their breath until Friday to determine whether the menace to the city's supply of electric light and power is really over.

SYDNEY, Dec. 9 -- The Australian Government announced today the approval of a $336-million development plan for bauxite deposits at Gove in the Northern Territory, involving output of a million tons of alumina a year and the export of as much as two million tons of bauxite.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision that longshoremen injured on a pier were entitled to Federal compensation.
Loeb, Rhoades Co. announced yesterday that Grinnell Morris had joined its investment management department. Mr. Morris, a banker since 1932, had most recently been chairman of The Bank of New York.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a morning advance faded during the afternoon.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A robber disguised as a traffic policeman flagged down a bank car in suburban Tokyo today and escaped with 294.3 million yen -- $816,667. The police said it was the biggest highway robbery in Japanese history.

It still takes a certain amount of brass to open a piano recital with something as thorny as Schonberg's "Three Piano Pieces" (Op. 11). Of course, there is a nice, romantic rose buried beneath those thorns, but, as a prelude to Beethoven, Chopin and Mussorgsky it shows an original turn of mind.
United States companies with a stake in Latin America were urged yesterday to move faster in the development of their host countries.
DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The sharpshooting Dayton Flyers overwhelmed Portland, 95-56, tonight to record their 18th straight victory over two seasons.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 -- The world's first turbine-powered passenger trains will start the continent's first regularly scheduled high-speed service between Montreal and Toronto Thursday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- The General Assembly extended the scope of its disarmament deliberations today to include chemical and biological forms of warfare.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 10 -- Columbia's tight man-for-man defense held the Rutgers basketball team scoreless for long periods tonight and the Lions defeated the Scarlet Knights, 74-57, before a standing-room-only crowd of 2,800 in the Rutgers gym.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -- St. Peter's College outscored St. Louis University, 14-2, in overtive tonight and emerged with a 98-84 victory at the Jersey City Armory.

Six projects for disadvantaged pupils here, including the controversial More Effective Schools program, have been praised by a research study team for showing significant pupil achievement, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
Mark II, king of electronic music synthesizers, sits in a room on West 125th Street, blinking red eyes sadly and making strange, whirring, clicking sounds. The king is doomed to die.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus for another six months, expressing the hope that a settlement could be reached in that time.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Search and rescue operations continued today along the banks of the Mississippi River near White Castle for 17 missing Coast Guardsmen, while a hearing opened in New Orleans into the cause of a collision between a buoy tender and a freighter.

The Republican Governors did not let their opulent surroundings in Palm Springs last week cause them to lose sight of the problems of America's needy citizens. They unanimously adopted a resolution calling on President-elect Nixon to announce without delay that he would suspend measures the Johnson Administration has just initiated to take a little of the humiliation out of the country's degrading welfare system.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- France announced today a heavy trade deficit for November of 1-billion francs ($200-million).

The novelty in last night's Philadelphia Orchestra program in Philarmonic Hall was Virgil Thomson's "The Feast of Love," a work for baritone and orchestra. Although it is four years old, it had not previously been performed in New York.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Sonny Liston, the former heavyweight champion, battered his former sparring partner, Amos (Big Train) Lincoln, tonight and registered a second-round knockout.

Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said yesterday that the burden of maintaining the smooth working of the international financial system falls on countries running a balance-of-payments surplus as well as those running deficits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Transportation announced today a proposed requirement that manufacturers advise consumers of specific safety and performance characteristics of motor vehicles made after next Sept. 30.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- Denmark reported Monday that her birth rate has fallen sharply for the second year since the birth control pill was officially authorized. Figures for the first nine months of this year showed 57,289 births, compared with 62,907 in the same period of 1967 and 67,149 in 1966.

There is a new capital spending boom on the horizon, and some economists are concerned. They wonder if it can be sustained. Only 83.6 per cent of the nation's manufactur ing capacity was being utilized in the third quarter. Not since 1966 has utilization been higher than 90 per cent.

A major move to spur black ownership of Harlem business property was taken yesterday as the F. W. Woolworth Company sold the land and building occupied by its big 125th Street store to a community group, then leased it back for continued store use.
A collection of the old arts of rural Pennsylvania went on exhibition yesterday at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

Vice President Humphrey was hailed here last night by 1,000 labor leaders as he declared that, rather than worrying about "what could have been," he was going to keep up the fight for "brotherhood, understanding and trust" in America.
Recently an executive who had been born in the South remarked to an associate:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee says, that it would be senseless to drop the 10 per cent tax surcharge as long as continued heavy spending threatens to push the Government deeper into debt.
An agreement to grant a $4.2-million mortgage loan for renovation of slum housing in two sections of Boston has been made by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company.

TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- New Jersey authorities asked Union Township today to integrate its public schools, possibly by late January, as the Board of Education there sought a three-month delay of a Federal school integration order that becomes effective Saturday.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 -- The first Japanese recipient of the Nobel prize in literature hailed his award at a gala dinner tonight in the Gold Room of Stockholm's City Hall as "a symbol of understanding and friendship between East and West, of literature moving from today into tomorrow."

At 10:30 on a recent Saturday morning, a 39-year-old mother of six children was returning from the beauty parlor to her apartment in the Jackson Houses project in the South Bronx when a powerfully built man jumped into the elevator behind her and brandished a knife.

LISBON, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Herman Middlekoop, head of the Christian Council relief operation in Biafra, appealed to religious groups from Biafra today not to interrupt their mercy airlift after the crash of a relief plane last weekend.
Six free throws in the final 56 seconds gave the New York University basketball team a 64-58 victory over City College last night at the losers' Wingate Gym.
The National Steel Corporation announced yesterday a price increase of $4 a ton on continuous hot-dip galvanized steel sheets.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 -- Allied relief teams were at work today in three hamlets near the Cambodian border that were raided by Vietcong forces over the weekend.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 -- Negro students at Radcliffe College staged a sit-in today at the college's Administration Building to enforce demands for increased Negro enrollment and a change in admissions policy.

John Carneglia, the 24-year-old alleged mastermind of an interstate car theft ring, surrendered yesterday and was arraigned on charges that could make him liable, in consecutive terms, to 1,312 years in prison.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Joseph P. Kennedy, 80 years old, will leave Saturday to spend the winter in his home at Palm Beach, Fla., a source close to the family said today. The former Ambassador to Britain, ailing since having a stroke in 1961, will be accompanied by his niece, Miss Ann Gargan.
Teamsters Local 237, representing 5,800 employes of the New York City Housing Authority, threatened yesterday to call a strike on Jan. 2 if a new agreement is not reached by that date.
Although slipping slightly from Monday, volume continued heavy on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. A total of 8,139,000 shares changed hands compared with 8,485,000 shares the preceding day.
Crowell Collier Macmillan, Inc., announced yesterday the election of three directors, increasing the board membership to 21. The new directors are Joseph F. Bond, Jeremiah Kaplan and Henry T. Heald.

Marianne Moore, the 81-year-old poet who has received most of the highly rated American prizes given for poetry, and has been named in France a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor, yesterday received the National Medal for Literature.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- United States and North Vietnamese diplomats argued for two hours today without resolving the procedural differences that are delaying the opening of expanded talks on the Vietnam war.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today that the state tax collections for the first eight months of the current fiscal year were $2.969-billion, an increase of $484-million over the same period a year ago.
Three creative types -- Robert Levenson, William Taubin and Helmut Krone -- have been appointed senior vice presidents at Doyle Dane Bernbach.

Moscow has charged that the visit of two American destroyers to the Black Sea this week is a "provocative sortie." Washington says it is just a "routine" operation. Both positions have some justification.
William Inge, recipient of the Pulitzer Prize, the Drama Critics Circle award and an Oscar, will have a play of his done Off Broadway for the first time.
The major television networks, as well as some local stations in the metropolitan area, will provide live coverage of President-elect Nixon's announcement of his Cabinet tonight at 10 P.M.
While corporate merger moves continued at a rapid pace yesterday, there also were an increasing number of terminations of proposed offers and rejections by companies involved in take-over attempts.

The Girard Trust Bank, third largest bank in Philadelphia with about $1.6-billion in assets, announced yesterday that it was planning to form a one-bank holding company to diversify its operations into other financial businesses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States took another retaliatory action against the Common Market today by announcing a subsidy program for lard exports to Britain.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- Premier Suleyman Demirel announced a Cabinet shuffle tonight in the wake of differences in the ruling Justice party and the resignations of his labor and customs ministers.
The relentless drive toward higher interest rates continued throughout the money and capital markets yesterday, impelled this time by new evidence that economic activity is not slowing down at all.

VIENNA, Dec. 10 -- McGeorge Bundy, president of the Ford Foundation and a former White House aide, conferred secretly at a Vienna hotel Sunday night with Dzherman M. Gvishiani, the son-in-law of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, reliable sources said today.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 -- The Common Market cleared an obstacle to closer European technological cooperation today and began work on a plan that could revolutionize European agriculture over the next 10 years.
The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would protect physically handicapped persons against discrimination in jobs and housing and at bars, restaurants, resorts and theaters.
Prices in London staged a steady advance in moderately active trading.

GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- A Nigerian Air Force plane bombed and machine-gunned a Red Cross hospital in Biafra today, killing several persons and wounding others, a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross said tonight.
A resolution condemning mob violence "as just means for righting social wrongs" has been adopted by the committee on American citizenship of the New York County Lawyers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- "Look at this list," Thomas F. Eagleton of Missouri exclaimed as he waved two sheets of paper filled with names. "I'm deluged with job applicants. Everybody must know I'm in town."

President-elect Nixon's decision to establish a counterpart of the National Security Council to cope with the urban crisis does encourage the hope that action will get a higher priority than conversation in his approach to this most urgent of domestic problems.
The Hong Kong flu has swept thousands of New Yorkers off their feet this week.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 10 -- Bill Shoemaker's chances of returning to racing at Santa Anita Park this season appear mighty slim.

The president of Fordham University went to a basement reading room on the Lincoln Square campus yesterday to explain to 300 students, most of them bleary-eyed from an all-night protest, why their experimental curriculum was being discontinued.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- The world's first catamaran trawler, twin-hull fishing boat, has started her trials in the waters of the North Sea and the Norwegian Sea.

On a day in which statistics were of more than passing interest at Aqueduct, yesterday's most startling statistic was the figure 25,112. That was the number of fans who paid their way into the windswept race track to participate in the valedictory program of this year's thoroughbred racing in this state.
Thomas Merton, the Trappist monk who spoke from the world of silence to questing millions who sought God, died yesterday in Bangkok, Thailand. He was 53 years old.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Kathy Whitworth was named today as the player of the year by the Ladies Professional Golf Association.
LISBON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Portugal withdrew its invitation today to be the host for the world university games next summer. No reason was given.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The British Government today rejected Soviet allegations that it had used the invasion of Czechoslovakiais a pretext for worsening British-Soviet relations.

MOST sports fans were startled when the National Football League reached all the way out to right field to name Bert Bell as its commissioner in 1946. He had been the owner-coach of the poverty-stricken Philadelphia Eagles and seemed to have few qualifications for the job, outside of a passionate love for a game that had drained him financially.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The widow of the first Negro officer to win the Medal of Honor accepted the nation's highest award for military heroism at a private ceremony today in President Johnson's office.
Len Dawson, quarterback of the Kansas City Chiefs, was named offensive player of the week in the American Football League by the Associated Press yesterday for the second week in a row.

MOSCOW, Dee. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Union launched an unmanned satellite today into an orbit similar to those of four other Soviet satellites launched within the last month. It was announced that the craft, Cosmos 258, would continue "cosmic research."

TANPHUTRUNG, South Vietnam, Dec. 10 -- Even when he is the advance man on a patrol, the American soldier in Vietnam has the comforting knowledge that he is linked by an administrative umbilical cord to a vast, protective military machine.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif, looms as a possible replacement for his ailing Davis Cup teammate, Clark Graebner, if the New Yorker fails to recover sufficliently to compete in the Challenge Round against Australia.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- An earthquake jolted the Philadelphia area and adjacent parts of New Jersey and Delaware today, waking scores of persons, but causing little damage.
The election of Samuel H. Woolley, as chairman and chief executive officer, and of Elliott Averett, as president and chief administrative officer, of the Bank of New York was announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt tonight characterized Governor Rockefeller's timetable for major construction programs as "sheer madness."
COMMACK, L. I., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Lavern Tart scored 32 points tonight and led the New York Nets to a 117-102 American Basketball Association victory over the Indiana Pacers.

John H. Sidebottom was named yesterday to head a new executive organization that will direct contract definition studies on the Navy's advanced surface missile system for the Radio Corporation of America. He will coordinate activities of an executive committee composed of top-level management representatives of the Raytheon Company, the Bendix Corporation and Gibbs Cox, Inc.

LE SAM and Mrs. Elliott Gross were playing checkers recently in a cozy kitchen in Monsey, N. Y., about 30 miles north of New York City. Sam's face was alight with mischief as he suggested various moves his foster mother might make, all of which would have been suicidal.
ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Ralph Heck, a linebacker for the Atlanta Falcons, was placed on the inactive list today by the National Football League club.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday upheld unanimously the conviction of two hospital union officials for criminal contempt for their roles in the recent strike against four of the state's mental hospitals.
A $15-million grant to Hampshire College, a new four-year liberal arts school set to open in 1970 in Amherst, Mass., was announced yesterday.

" AMERICANA PASTORAL" is the worst title of the Off Broadway season -- you immediately think of some dreary program, possibly starring Vincent Price, at the local woman's club -- but it is by no means the worst play.

A breakthrough in future motion-picture production -making color pictures with a specially processed black-and-white film -has been achieved by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The method promises major savings in the processing, development and preservation of color films.

TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Gov. Richard J. Hughes, in Hawaii, has the flu and a temperature of 102 degrees, his office disclosed today. The illness forced the Governor to postpone his return to New Jersey until later this week. Mr. Hughes was in Hawaii to address a national legislative leaders' conference.
Cocoa futures, strong in some recent sessions, made another series of life-of-contract highs yesterday on news of a worsening supply situation.

Emerson Boozer, who represents much of the thrust in the Jets' offense, will start at halfback in the final regular-season game at Miami on Sunday against the Dolphins. Boozer, who has experienced the usual difficulties in the first season following knee surgery, was held out of the Jets' last two games against Cincinnati and Miami.

WOLVERHAMPTON, England, Dec. 10 -- The chorus of 30 children aged 7 to 11 stood in the front of the auditorium and sang a carol, "Jesus, Jesus, Sweetly Sleep." The boys were in uniform gray shorts, the girls in pinafores, both wearing the school tie.

It is encouraging, therefore, that four of the five brotherhoods representing train crews and other operating employes have decided to merge into a new United Transportation Union.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Ondine, the 73-foot ketch owned by Sumner A. (Huey) Long of New York, left Albany, 230 miles south of Perth for Sydney tonight.

MANILA, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- United States Navy jets killed a Filipino and injured two others during a bombing exercise Monday at Subic Bay, 50 miles northwest of Manila, an American Navy spokesman said today. The spokesman said it was not known how the three had gotten on the bombing range at the time of the exercise.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- A North Vietnam's spokesman here, in an oblique reply to hopes expressed by Defense Secretary Clark M. Clifford for a mutual troop cutback in South Vietnam, suggested today that, "if the United States would like to expound any ideas it only needs to state them at the four-party conference" in Paris.

Both the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra and Walter Susskind are familiar to New York concertgoers, but last night the ensemble and conductor appeared here together for the first time. Mr. Susskind took over the Midwestern orchestra this season, and he brought it to Carnegie Hall as part of the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored three times against Glenn Hall in 55 seconds in the second period tonight to defeat the St. Louis Blues, 6-3, ending the Blues' unbeaten streak at 12 games.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly higher yesterday. New trade figures will be released today, and traders appeared optimistic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The departure of Lieut. Gov. Robert H. Finch to become Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare will strengthen Governor Ronald Reagan's hold on the Republican party in California.

Directors of the Atlantic Richfield Company, in a surprise move yesterday, voted to offer to purchase up to 2,500,000 shares of Sinclair Oil Corporation common stock at $145 a share. This represents 20 per cent of the 12,498,568 outstanding shares of Sinclair and involves $362.5-million.

THE STRENGTH OF GOVERNMENT. By McGeorge Bundy. 113 pages. Harvard University Press. $3.75. 1976: AGENDA FOR TOMORROW. By Stewart L. Udall. Introduction by John W. Gardner. 173 pages. Harcourt, Brace World. $3.75.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 -- The Baltimore Bullets gave the New York Knickerbockers a vivid demonstration tonight of why they hold first place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association. They got the drop on the Knicks with a hot-handed second quarter and blithely went on to a 118-110 victory, their 18th in their last 22 games.

FORT-LAMY, Chad, Dec. 11 (Agence France-Presse) -- Minister of the Economy Abdoulaye Lamana said today that Chad was holding to her decision to leave the Customs Union of Central African States by the end of the year but was ready to cooperate in economic matters with her former partners.

The following table shows the new and old automobile insurance rates for $10,000 and $20,000 bodily injury and $5,000 property damage coverage for private passenger car owners in the metropolitan area who have clear records. These entitle them to a 10 per cent rate reduction.
SOLOTHURN, Switzerland, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Switzerland's Roman Catholic hierarchy said today that if couples used birth-control pills they would not necessarily be guilty before God.
Following are tributes to Arthur Hays Sulzberger from leaders in politics, diplomacy, journalism and other fields:
DR. LEE ALVIN DuBRIDGE will be the fifth man in a post created after the Soviet Union lofted its first earth satellite in 1957, shattering America's confidence in its own scientific domination.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- Pope Paul VI renewed his warning today to Roman Catholic clergymen against believing in "almost subversive novelties" and told them that "to do well what the church tells you to do" is the simplest answer to their problems.

The New School for Social Research has spent its first 50 years trying to cope with the problem of what to do for an encore. Founded by a group of professors in rebellion against what they considered the blindness of universities and of American society, the New School could maintain its momentum only by keeping alive the spirit of rebellion and innovation.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A $40-million road financed by the United States was dedicated today by Premier Thanom Kittikachorn and Ambassador Leonard Unger. The 180-mile road links the military port of Sattahip and the big American air base at Korat.
Anna Moffo gave a lesson in how to put across a recital last night in Philharmonic Hall.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Charlie Burns's rebound goal at 5:44 of the third period led Pittsburgh to a 4-2 victory over Minnesota tonight and lifted the Penguins to a fourth-place tie with the North Stars in the West Division of the National Hockey League.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Two Mundelein College girls were credited today with protecting themselves by using psychology on a convicted rapist who entered their North Side dormitory apartment through an unlocked door.

Dick Butkus, the Chicago Bears middle linebacker, was named defensive back of the week by the Associated Press yesterday for his outstanding play against the Los Angeles Rams last Sunday in a National Football League game won by the Bears, 17-16.
PARIS, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The French Government renewed its call today for joint action by the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France to restore peace to the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon's Inaugural Ball will be spread throughout much of Washington, with some 3,000 of the guests dancing among the locomotives at the Smithsonian Institution.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Howard Mitchell plans to step down as music director of the National Symphony Orchestra here in 1970.
Lawrence Bennett, who was listed in the program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall as a tenor, is the best ballad singer to come along in some time.

IT was the day before the crunch last August and there right in the middle of the high pressure steam bath that was Miami Beach sat John Newton Mitchell, the cool commander of the Nixon juggernaut who had helped to get his man to the brink of nomination.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon announced tonight he would nominate Walter E. Washington for a second term as Mayor of the City of Washington.

The Control Data Corporation filed a Federal Court suit yesterday in St. Paul, Minn., charging the International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest private enterprise in terms of market worth, with violations of antitrust laws and monopolistic practices. I.B.M. denied the charge.

The Life Insurance Association of America, a trade association representing the largest of the life insurance companies, elected Frederic M. Peirce chairman and Benjamin F. Small president at its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation called today for the expulsion from college of "student activists" and the dismissal of faculty members who support them.

Savings deposits at the nation's mutual savings banks rose by $285-million during November, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday. In the same month last year, savings deposits increased $273-million.
The Bulletin, the many-faceted monthly publication of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been published by the Arno Press in a reprint that covers the years 1905 to 1942.

Only the world's major ballet companies can offer alternate casts for the demanding roles in "Swan Lake," and American Ballet Theater has no trouble fitting into that category. Last night, at the company's second performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Eleanor D'Antuono and Royes Fernandez stepped into the ballet's leading parts.

An American expert on contraception said yesterday that the Soviet decision to concentrate on intrauterine devices was based on its own three-year study of the safety and effectiveness of IUD's, as the contraceptive devices are commonly called.
Screen rights to Murray Schisgal's newly opened play, "Jimmy Shine," starring Dustin Hoffman, have been sold to Columbia Pictures, which has an investment of $24,000 in the $200,000 stage production.

Floyd B. McKissick, former head of the Congress of Racial Equality, charged yesterday that he was not allowed to speak Tuesday night at a synagogue in Woodmere, L.I., although sponsors of a lecture series had contracted with him to talk on "Black Power and the Jewish Response."

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- The board of Reuters urged the Chinese Communist Government today to release Mr. Grey immediately. It called on newspapers and networks throughout the world to support its appeal.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania (AP) -- Y. A. Masha, a censor, banned the American film "Bonnie and Clyde" one week after it was screened at a charity premiere, on the ground that the movie's portrayal of outlawry was not consonant with Tanzania's fight against a rising crime rate.
Art Starrs, with 16 rebounds and 13 points, led Fordham to a 77-62 basketball conquest of Syracuse last night and the Rams' 17th consecutive home court victory.
The nation's electric power production rose 8.1 per cent in the week ended Dec. 7 from the level in the corresponding 1967 week, it was reported yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

IT might be said that this city needs another production of Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" like it needs another case of the Hong Kong flu. So we had one, last night at the Juilliard School of Music. It was Tito Capobianco's first production there.

HIS sociological reputation as an expert on race has produced political problems for Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who will be the principal staff officer of the Nixon Administration's Cabinet-level Council on Urban Affairs.

GEORGE PRATT SHULTZ'S first memorable economics lesson occurred when, at the age of 12, he tried to sell his own mimeographed newspaper to a neighbor for 5 cents. The neighbor "told me he could get The Saturday Evening Post for a nickel," Mr. Shultz recalls, and his newspaper promptly failed.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo requested $150-million in capital funds yesterday to begin construction of a wide range of project, for the borough, including a new hospital, a public library, a subway line, a community center, a public swimming pool parks and several new school.

DIENBAN, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 -- What may be one of the most significant encirclement operations of the Vietnam war is coming to an end in the rice paddies and tree lines just west of this village near Danang.
WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Tom Boisture, head football coach at Holy Cross College the last two years, has resigned, school officials said today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- District Attorney Jim Garrison today set Jan. 21 for the trial of Clay L. Shaw on charges of conspiring to assassinate President Kennedy.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, a member of the State Board of Regents, said last night that the arrest of Rhody A. McCoy could have been avoided if the state trustee of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district had agreed to a meeting early yesterday.
JOE NAMATH shaved his controversial Fu Manchu mustache yesterday with a Schick electric razor for a reported fee of $10,000. That's about $10 a hair.
AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 10 -- Jordan approaches the Christian and Moslem holidays grimly.
TORONTO, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- John Ferguson's late third-period goal gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-4 tie tonight with the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

BETHPAGE, L. I., Dec. 11 (UPI) -O'Dell Smith, 33 years old, of 50 Birch Street, Amityville, L. I., was killed early today when his stopped car was struck by a truck on the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway here.

A SIGNIFICANT milestone has been reached in the growth of recreational skiing. Windham, a popular, public snow-running center high in the northern Catskills for the last decade, is going private. The step is believed to mark a first in the United States for a major area.
HONG KONG, Dec. 11 -- A campaign is developing to turn over primary and secondary schools in the cities of Communist China to factories and other establishments.
DENVER, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A $3-million suit was filed in Federal court here today, accusing a baking subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation of acquiring too many companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- What is so sweet as the first cold night of winter? Outside, the temperature is ten degrees Fahrenheit; inside, a great fire crackling merrily in the fireplace. How it makes the heart leap as it springs to life at the first touch of the match and sends the flame roaring up the chimney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A spokesman for Richard M. Nixon tonight dissociated the President-elect from the call of William W. Scranton, his special envoy to the Middle East, for a "more evenhanded" American policy in the region.
Longshoremen from Searsport, Me., to Burnside, La., have voted 15 to 1 not to accept an employer proposal aimed at preventing a resumption of the dock strike.

A student-faculty group at Fordham University's main campus in the Bronx yesterday began circulating a petition that pledges students to withhold their tuition for the coming semester until the university meets nine demands.

VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Francoise Macchi, a French teen-ager, roared down the slopes to gain the lead in the women's World Cup Alpine ski competition today, by winning the giant slalom in the first big race of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The City of Philadelphia sought an injunction today to block new sea tariffs, charging they were prejudicial to the city.
TEL AVIV, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Two Arabs, said to be members of the Arab commando organization Al Fatah, were sentenced to life imprisonment today by an Israeli military court in Gaza

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Stuart List, 65-year-old publisher of Chicago's American the last 15 years, announced today that he will quit Jan. 31. He will become vice president in charge of public affairs for Ara Services, Inc., a food service company in Chicago.
The appointment of M. Lee Rice as president of the Ogden Corporation was announced yesterday. He replaces Ralph E. Ablon, who continues as chairman of the board and chief executive officer.
