WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Though four Republican Governors and one Lieutenant Governor are being drafted into the Nixon Administration, the party will maintain its dominance over the 50 statehouses.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- West Germany told a high-level economic conference today that it expected to show a "basic deficit" in its balance of payments next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Justice Hugo L. Black questioned today whether a state could make it a crime for a girl "to be tempted to do something wrong.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 11 -- Vincent Annarella's Jaikyl, from New York, outclassed five rivals in winning the featured $5,200 allowance race today at Laurel in track record time of 1:35 2/5 for the mile.

SAN JUAN, P. R. (UPI) -- A four-day strike by members of the American Newspaper Guild employes at The San Juan Stat. Puerto Rico's only English-language daily, ended today. The newspaper will resume publication tomorrow.

Sol Hurok, the 80-year-old Russian-born impresario who imports and exports cultural events the way others do rice, copper and jute, received the Golden Door Award of the American Council for Nationalities Service last night at a glittering banquet at the Pierre Hotel.

The election of Leslie Storyk as president of the American Institute for Imported Steel, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Storyk, who is executive vice president and managing director of Fehr Bros. Manufactures, Inc., succeeds Kurt Orban.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- Soviet public-health officials have decided to begin mass manufacture of intrauterine devices in preference to contraceptive pills.

A model of a portable theater, which can be set up in a park, vacant lot or town green in three days with the help of unskilled labor supervised by a few technologists, is now on display at the Lincoln Center Public Library and Museum, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, near 64th Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The White House will undergo its traditional holiday decoration this weekend while President and Mrs. Johnson visit their Texas ranch.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 11 -- Black Student Union members at Reed College barricaded the second floor of the administration building today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin said today that a Senate inquiry into the practices of credit bureaus would serve as the foundation for legislation to provide safeguards in credit reporting.
STILLWATER, Okla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Phil Cutchin was dismissed as head football coach at Oklahoma State University tonight.

A truck loaded with $50,000 worth of women's clothing was hijacked in Queens yesterday. The driver, Kenneth Whitton, 26 years old of Brooklyn, told the police the clothing belonged to the Fields Department Store at 37th Avenue and 82d Street in Jackson Heights, Queens.
Seventy-eight years old and living on a widow's pension in Cambridge, Mass., Mrs. Felix Bernstein is a firm advocate of the principle that charity begins at home.

MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- West Germans are sneaking across the Czechoslovak border to steal christmas trees the Czechoslovak authorities have complained to the Bavarian. Thie thefts were said to have taken place in a region without border fences.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Airplane hijackers in Mexico today became liable to prison sentences of up to 20 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President-elect Nixon, in making the principal appointments available to him, has demonstrated once again what extraordinary capacity for change and development there is in the American system of transferring the Executive power -- yet what strong pressures toward continuity underlie that process of transition.
The libraries' problem of pro-public libraries, and attacks on and thefts from persons using them, have caused the institutions to call on the city for more funds to increase security.

PARIS, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Britain, West Germany and France today announced a 250- seat airbus -- a revised version of their proposed 300-seat short-haul airliner -- to meet air-travel requirements in the nineteen-seventies.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- America's Orbiting Astronomical Observatory took its first look at the heavens today and astronomers liked what it saw -- a pair of bright, giant stars named Miaplacidus and Iota Carina.

ROME, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Thousands of Sicilian industrial workers, protesting against low wage scales on the island, marched off their jobs today. A new wave of strike calls threatened to keep Italy in turmoil throughout the Christmas season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Johnson held their final state dinner at the White House today to honor the ruler of Kuwait.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- The Soviet Union and its allies moved today to sidetrack an effort by black African countries to suspend South Africa from membership in a subordinate organ of the General Assembly.
The Florida Special will start its 81st season tomorrow with a new 24-hour schedule between New York and Florida, one hour shorter than in past seasons.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canada is withdrawing her last plane from the trouble-plagued Biafran relief operation, External Affairs Minister Mitchell Sharp announced today, because of the "failure" of the Biafran regime to agree to daylight flights.

THE new Secretary of Defense, Melvin Robert Laird, a conservative Republican Representative from Wisconsin, represents an innovation, disturbing to some in the executive branch, reassuring to others on Capitol Hill, in the management of the military establishment.

"OLIVER!" is an elaborate and faithful movie enlargement of the Lionel Bart operetta in which a wistful little Oliver Twist sings "Where is love?/ Does it fall from the skies above?" Although the program notes say that Oliver is yearning for a mother, one fully expects Alice Faye -- looking seductive and moon-faced -- to appear in a balloon over his head.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11 -- Yale erased a 15-point deficit and held Brown without a field goal for almost 12 minutes tonight to beat the Bruins, 63-59. It was the Ivy League opener for both teams.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that all but 252 of about 19,000 costume jewelry pins containing deadly poison beans had been recovered or accounted for.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The police control of the San Francisco State College campus was tightened today, while off-campus events made it appear that the talking stage was near at hand in the protracted dispute.

Andy Troutman scored 22 points and Jerry Meyers 18 in leading Herbert H. Lehman College to a 74-53 victory over Pratt Institute last night at the 13th Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

BONN, Dec. 11 -- The first major maneuver of Bundeswehr reserves got off to a woozy start today as more than a thousand part-time soldiers opened the action by laying in and consuming large reserves of schnapps.

A MEMBER of Winton Malcolm Blount's family recently mailed a letter franked with a trading stamp rather than postage, and the letter reached its destination. The prank led Mr. Blount to observe. "Maybe the solution to the postal deficit is to close the green stamp loophole."

BERLIN Dec. 11 -- Josef Bachmann, a West German who shot and severely wounded Rudi Dutschke, the radical student leader last April, won an indefinite postponement today of his trial after declaring that he refused to be tried by a court that had acquitted and freed a former Nazi judge on war-crimes charges.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation said yesterday that "initial consideration" was being given to a possible recapitalization. The company would not elaborate.
A taxpayer's suit seeking to bar payment to teachers to make up salary lost during their 35-day strike was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, in a major shift of policy, has called for "the immediate withdrawal of substantial numbers" of American troops and weapons from Vietnam as a unilateral move by the United States.
MIAMI, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Angel Cordero Jr., battling Alvaro Pineda for the national riding title, rode three winners at Tropical Park today and raised his total for the year to 315.

CAPE KENNEDY, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Engineers late today discovered a potentially serious problem in the Saturn 5 rocket that could disrupt plans to send Americans around the moon in the Apollo 8 spacecraft this month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The commission estimated the annual cost of the proposed raises at $34.7-million.

GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross has made a strong protest to the Nigerian Federal Government against bombing and macihne-gunning attack Monday on a Red Cross hospital in secessionist Biafra, in which three Biafrans were killed, it was disclosed today.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The latest upheaval in currency markets showed Britain that foreign confidence in her economic recovery was still fragile, the Bank of England said today.
Automobile owners in the state will pay up to $84 more for liability and comprehensive-collision insurance under a revision of rates approved yesterday by the State Insurance Department.

HONG KONG, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The British authorities today released five more alleged Communists held without charges in connection with last year's riots and terrorism. This brought to 11 the number released this month.

Roast chicken stuffed with brown rice, scrambled eggs with sausages and danish pastry will be served 700 teen-agers on Dec. 30 at the 12th annual Gold and Silver Ball. Proceeds from the dinner dance in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom will go to the Girls and Boys Service League.

GEORGE WILCKEN ROMNEY, who has been named Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Nixon Cabinet, once described himself as a "realistic idealist." The 61-year-old Governor of Michigan, who made an unsuccessful bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, sees himself bringing the idealism of his Mormon religion to business and politics in general.

Three men were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to violate the civil rights of persons to whom they falsely certified they had delivered court summonses. Those indicted were Nathan Lindsay, 75 years old, and Herman Rick, 61, of Brooklyn, and Robert Wiseman, 28, of 130 Macdougal Street. Pleading is set for next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President - elect Richard M. Nixon rejected the "meat ax" approach to budget reduction today but promised that his Administration would examine each Government spending program individually and cast aside "those that do not work."
WALTER JOSEPH HICKEL, who will become Secretary of the Interior next year, has a kind of "newness" that Alaskans admire.
Negotiations for a heavyweight championship showdown between the two titleholders, Joe Frazier and Jimmy Ellis, will await a medical examination of Ellis's nose next week.
United Air Lines gave details yesterday of one of the techniques it will use to speed the flow of passengers into and out of the Boeing 747 jumbo jets that will enter airline service next year.

The election of Herbert A. Leeds, president of Gimbelsi Pittsburgh, to the board of directors of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Pittsburgh was announced yesterday. Mr. Leeds als0 is a vice president and director of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., New York.
MADISON Wis., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- The Milwaukee Bucks hit from the foul line in the fourth quarter tonight and broke a seven-game losing streak by defeating the San Francisco Warriors, 106-96.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The poorest Americans will get more food for their money under a liberalization of the Federal Food Stamp Program announced today by Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 11 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon's three key appointments in the field of national security are viewed here as helping him to protect his flexibility and maneuverability on his key foreign policy problem -- Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon's choices for the top posts in urban affairs and social programs were seen here tonight as an indication that the new Administration would put a high priority on the problems of cities and race relations.

A Cabinet mirrors the personal qualities and political predilections of the President who puts it together. As a group, the men assembled by President-elect Nixon are, like their chief, intelligent, moderately conservative, competent and rather colorless. Some are stronger personalities than others and some are better matched to their respective jobs but, taken as a whole, they are striking in their uniformity.
It was put-up or shut-up time for the Rangers last night, and they did the former, ending their three-game losing streak while settling some unresolved scores with the Boston Bruins.

MARQUETTE, Mich., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- John X. Jamrich, president of Northern Michigan University, announced a "mutually satisfactory agreement" on new programs for Negro students at the college.

GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- A new step toward the adoption of a treaty to facilitate international cooperation in the handling of patents was completed here yesterday by a 40-nation conference of government delegates and industry representatives.

HOWARD SCHENKEN of New York added to his large collection of national tournament victories by winning the Reisinger Open Team Championship on Monday in Coronado, Calif. Both he and the event have a 40-year history, but it is only his third win.

Olin J. Stephens 2d, a naval architect noted as the designer of the wooden 12-meter yachts Columbia, Constellation and Intrepid, received the 1968 Marine Aluminum Ocean Racing Trophy yesterday at the Regency Hotel.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 11 -- Prime Minister Terence O'Neill dismissed his controversial Home Affairs Minister, William Craig, today in the wake of the struggle between Northern Ireland's Roman Catholic and extremist Protestant factions.

THE Providence star Herman Rose proved the best of a select group of 31 when he captured the recent South-Eastern New England Open, played in his home town. Kuhn, Loeb Co. announced yesterday that John Barry Ryan 3d, a great-grandson of Abraham Wolff, an early partner in the 101-year-old investment banking firm, will be admitted as a general partner on Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Exports of gold from the United States totaled $11.5-million and importes $21-million during October, the Commerce Department reported today.

The American Overseas Banking Corporation, the new international bank being formed by 11 major banks across the country, announced yesterday that it was changing its name to Allied Bank International.

William Greaves, executive producer of "Black Journal," National Educational Television's monthly magazine for black Americans, announced yesterday that the program has financing to carry it through March.

For the fifth time in the last six trading sessions cocoa futures jumped the 100 points or penny-a-pound limit. Yesterday's active trading of 4,609 contracts, however, was far different from Tuesday's volume of 636.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy was admitted to a hospital tonight in preparation for the birth of her 11th child sometime tomorrow. The delivery will be by caesarean section The widow of the late Senator is in Georgetown Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The day the nation had been waiting for, the day when President-elect Richard M. Nixon would announce and introduce his Cabinet selections over national television, began like any other day in the Shoreham Hotel here where the Great Presentation was to take place.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Premier Eisaku Sato, in a policy speech, before Parliament, declared today that the greatest problem Japan faced in her foreign relations was "the reversion of Okinawa to the motherland."
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that Edward R. Wallace, director of public relations, had been elected a corporate vice president.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Judge W. Preston Battle today granted Percy Foreman, the lawyer, until next Wednesday for his appearance in Criminal Court to say whether he will be ready by March 3 to defend James Earl Ray in his trial for murder.

The Equity funding Corporation of America said yesterday it would modify the mutual fund-insurance plan it sells to conform to a Federal Reserve proposal to extend margin requirements to such plans marketed after Jan. 31.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., disclosed today an ultra-microfilm process that it said would permit compression of 600-page volumes on a single 4-by-6-inch film card.

GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The Swiss Bankers Association said today that its members were fully aware that they served their own interests in abiding by the margin requirements governing stock trading in the United States.
HE throws things -- pencils and rulers -- not at anybody, but across the room or against the wall to indicate impatience with bureaucratic slowness or somebody's mistake.
The 25-day career of the Christmas "extra" in stores is filled with extremes and paradoxes. The job is exhilarating, exhausting, educational, tedious, warming and infuriating.
A Brooklyn produce store that advertised "We sell Arizona grapes only," when the grapes actually came from California, was called to account yesterday by the city.
DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 11 -- Mohammad Asghar Khan said today that he would like to see the choice of an opposition candidate in the presidential election next year left to East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Describing them as "new men with new ideas," Richard M. Nixon introduced to a nationwide television audience tonight the 12 men he has selected for his Cabinet. He pledged -- with their help -- to seek peace abroad and reconciliation at home.

PARIS, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The French cabinet awarded the Legion of Honor today to four gold medal winners in the Olympic games in Mexico. Colette Besson, Jean-Jacques Guyon, Daniel Morelon and Pierre Trentin received the medal.

HAVANA, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- A Trans World Airlines jetliner with 38 persons aboard, including the country music star Tex Ritter and Mason Rudolph, the professional golfer, was hijacked by an American Negro man and woman today and forced to fly to Havana.

Community leaders will gather with sports notables tonight in the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel, where the People-to-People Sports Committee will present the Col. Edward P. F. Eagan Sportsman's Award to Arnold Palmer.

JOHN ANTHONY VOLPE's Massachusetts hallmark is a grin as wide as the Charles River, a local stream of historic associations. His appointment as Secretary of Transportation should serve to stretch it to one as wide as the Potomac, a national counterpart of broader imagery.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Dec. 11 (Agence France-Presse) -- Newly independent Equatorial Guinea and the Soviet Union have decided to establish diplomatic relations, a joint communique announced here today. Equatorial Guinea consists of the island of Fernando Po and the Rio Muni mainland area, which together were the former Spanish Guinea.

Average interest rates on short-term business loans at major New York City banks declined to 6.4 per cent during the first half of November from 6.67 per cent in the comparable period in August, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The attorney for the Royal Globe insurance group charged yesterday afternoon that allegations of racial discrimination against the group were "monstrous" and "not supported by a scintilla of evidence."
IF Robert Porter Mayo finds the Federal budget less confusing than other new budget directors have, he has only himself to thank.
WHEN he was 34 years old, in 1957, Dr. Henry Alfred Kissinger won worldwide attention with his book, "Nuclear Weapons and Foreign Policy," which urged a flexible American military apparatus.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The Government announced today that deaths from traffic accidents since breath tests were introduced for drunken driving 12 months ago were 1,152 fewer than the preceding year, a reduction of one death in seven.

There was little friendliness between Arthur Hays Sulzberger and Harry S. Truman during Mr. Truman's occupancy of the White House. The Times was often critical of Mr. Truman and the President took this personally.

THE invitation to the "Ballad for a Firing Squad" sounded like the invitation to an execution in more than one sense. For this is an adaptation of the ill-fated musical "Mata Hari," which last season died on the road.
LIVINGSTON, N. J. -- St. Barnabas Medical Center is becoming known among knowledgeable people as "the place to go."
WITH mergers becoming a way of life for more and more corporations, the question arises: Is this approach to business success a profitable one?

WESTBROOK, Conn., Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Fire raged through a rambling frame building containing stores and an apartment on Route 1 near the Clinton town line early today, killing two boys. They were identified as Philip Einhorn 6 years old, and Joseph Snarelli, 9.

"FEW men in political life so combine vision with meticulous attention to detail." The time was a few months ago. The speaker was Presidential aspirant Richard M. Nixon. And the subject was the handsome, deep-voiced man he had known since his freshmen days in Congress -- Robert Hutchinson Finch.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 (AP) -Frank Howard of the Washington Senators will receive the Babe Ruth Crown here on Jan. 10 as baseball's 1968 Sultan of Swal. He led the major leagues in home runs last season with 44.

The McCrory Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration for a recapitalization tender offer. Thhe offer was originally announced Dec. 5 and calls for McCrory to reacquire 1 million shares of its common stock.

GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- Twenty-five young demonstrators broke into a joint session of the Swiss Parliament in Berne today to present their demands for separate status for the French-speaking Jurassians in the northwest corner of Switzerland.
Ken Foley scored 10 of his 20 points in a late spurt that guided Seton Hall to a 66-53 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn last night at the 69th Regiment Armors.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the election of two more executive vice presidents as part of its over-all reorganization plan that was initiated on Oct. 30, when David Rockefeller and Herbert P. Patterson were named chairman and president, respectively, effective March 1.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson scored 34 points, 20 in the first half, to spark the Cincinnati Royals to their third straight National Basketball Association victory, 116-110, over the San Diego Rockets tonight.
TRENTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An assistant state attorney general charged tonight that organized crime had infiltrated nearly every facet of life in New Jersey, including the State Legislature.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Queens College had a 15-point second-half lead dwindle to 2 before pulling away in the final 21/2 minutes tonight for an 87-77 Knickerbocker Conference victory over Pace College.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 11 -- W. W. Smith, winner of last week's Nassau Pace, and his stablemate, Hodgen Special, were installed as the 8-5 choice today in the $25,000 Au Revoir Pace, the closing night feature Saturday at Roosevelt Raceway.
Metals prices continued to churn yesterday and upward pressure spread for a number of chemical products.
The elections of William E. Kirschbaum and Philip H. Trout as vice presidents of the Bowery Savings Bank, were announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President-elect Nixon received 499,704 more popular votes than Hubert H. Humphrey in the Presidential election on Nov. 5, complete official totals showed today.
ROME, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Mr. Scranton, on his way back to the United States, said during a stopover here today that the Nixon Administration would draw up a new Middle Eastern peace plan.

Agents of the Soviet internal security forces, with the collaboration of associates in the Czechoslovak Interior Ministry, played a vital role in preparing the Soviet-led invasion of the country, according to an eyewitness account published by the Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A Cornell University research laboratory reported today that the Volkswagen sedan tended to roll over in accidents, thus increasing the danger of death or injury to its occupants.
OSLO, Norway, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Rene Cassin, of France, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1968, called today for urgent action to protect the lives of -interna tional Red Cross representatives.
Iona College's basketball team gained its third victory last night, beating Marist, 93-60, at Mount St. Michael High School, the Bronx.
ALBANY, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The legislative committee on education recommended today that the 1969 Legislature make no major increases in school aid.

THE former head of President Kennedy's Peace Corps and President Johnson's drive against poverty, Robert Sargent Shriver Jr., 53, is expected to be President-elect Nixon's nominee for chief representative to the United Nations.

Arthur Hays Sulzberger, fourth publisher of The New York Times, guided the newspaper from the depression years, through a great war and into an era of prosperity, world tension and scientific revolution. His leadership kept The Times abreast of the 20th century -in news coverage, in financial strength and in technology.

WILLIAM PIERCE ROGERS'S first official exploit in the realm of world diplomacy was a two-week goodwill tour of West Africa in 1960. By this deed alone, he has chanced to start his tenure as Secretary of State on the right foot as far as one continent, at least, is concerned.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The United States mission asserted today that 73.3 per cent of the population of South Vietnam was living in relatively secure areas controlled by the Saigon Government. It was the most optimistic report on the pacification program so far.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A boxing promoter announced today that Freddie Little of Las Vegas and Sandro Mazzinghi of Rome would fight here for the junior middleweight title in February.
HOUSTON, Dec. 12 -- Three State Representatives said today that they would inquire into the reasons for appointing Walt W. Rostow, the Presidential assistant, to the University of Texas faculty.

Carmen Czernik's debut piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last night suggested that Miss Czernik will have to alter her playing appreciably to win success on the concert stage. She has degrees from the Mannes College of Music and the Juilliard School, and is surely knowledgeable about music and piano technique, but her performance sounded as if she were not listening carefully to what she was doing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon's official family, introduced to the country on television last night, impressed many members of the outgoing Johnson Administration today as "a gray flannel cabinet," to use the description of one retiring public servant.

KINGS POINT, L. I., (AP) -- The athletic program at the United States Merchant Marine Academy has been canceled until Jan. 6, because about 75 per cent of the undergraduates are suffering from influenza, officials said today.
HONG KONG, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Hanoi radio today broadcast a recorded Christmas message from a United States Air Force pilot captured in North Vietnam to his wife and children.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Bobby Unser, the race driver escaped serious injury today when his Eagle Ford snapped a suspension bar on a turn and spun off the International Raceway.

FARMINGTON, Pa., Dec. 3 -- By the time our inch-thick steaks were done, the coals in the charcoal grill gleamed red in the night, a nearly full moon hung over the top of a tall pine and gleamed on the fast-moving waters of Beaver Creek.
Rhody A. McCoy yesterday ignored a state order removing him as administrator of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district and went to his office as usual.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia 76ers' hopes for a National Basketball Association title were dampened today with the loss of their 6-foot-9-inch center, Luke Jackson, for the season.
Joseph Schlanger of the Woodmere Club was re-elected president of the Metropolitan Golf Association at its 71st annual meeting held last night at the Biltmore Hotel.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The National Communicable Disease Center said today that the "attack rate" for influenza was running more than twice as high as the national average in many institutions, such as hospitals and colleges.

UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The United States paid the final, $9.5-million installment on its 1968 United Nations assessment of $41,062,673 today. The note accompanying the payment said: "Receipt for the enclosed check would be appreciated."

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- The Government won a parliamentary vote of confidence tonight over its handling of foreign affairs. The vote was 293 to 234. The test in Commons came on a protest to policy toward the Falkland Islands.

TRENTON, Dec. 12 -- Republican legislative leaders called today for an investigation of charges by an assistant state attorney general who said that he could "think of at least three legislators who are too comfortable with members of organized crime."

Five alleged members of a ring of swindlers, whose loot was said to have included $60,000 in cash obtained from six Westchester banks through the use of fraudulent checks, were arraigned yesterday in Criminal Court, the Bronx, on conspiracy and other charges.
The first 10 days of December brought good tidings to the nation's automobile industry.
J. Burch McMorran, the State Transportation Commissioner, yesterday announced approval of the controversial Long Island Sound bridge-causeway between Westchester and Nassau Counties.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Judge Richard B. Austin of Federal District Court described as "an amateurish job" today the preparation of a suit challenging city ordinances and state laws under which demonstrators were arrested here during the Democratic National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Federal Communications Commission was reported today to have agreed on proposals to restrict the expansion of cable television systems and to curtail their right to rebroadcast television programs.

BASEL, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- Dr. Ota Sik, architect of Czechoslovakia's economic-reform program, said today that the Prague Government acting "under orders from the Russians" had warned him he would be prosecuted if he returned to Czechoslovakia.

Opera in English? Or opera in whatever language it was written? It is an old argument over which many tempers have been lost. The best opportunity to examine the pros and cons of the matter is available at the Juilliard School of Music, which is alternating an English version of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" with the original Italian.

CARLO MARIA GIULINI, who will be guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic for a month, conducted his first concert last night. Unlike many conductors who want to enter riding the crest of a big tonal wave, Mr. Giulini devoted his entire program to Mozart.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Mike Montler, an offensive tackle from Colorado, was among 11 players selected today to play in the annual Blue-Gray game here on Dec. 28.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- George Christian, the White House press secretary, was asked today for President Johnson's opinion of the new Cabinet. He replied:
Tributes to Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times, who died in his sleep Wednesday, continued to be received yesterday.

A baritone from Lyndon, Kan., turned up on the stage of the Hunter College Playhouse last night and established himself in a debut appearance as one of the best song recitalists around. He is Barry McDaniel, and behind his artistic maturity and success lie 15 years of studying and performing abroad.

AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Four Israeli jets attacked a bridge and destroyed a house today in a 25-minute raid in Jordanian territory, Jordanian communiques said. It was the fifth reported air attack in 12 days.
The man who has been president of Brooklyn College since last Jan. 1. Dr. Harold C. Syrett, was officially invested as president yesterday at a ceremony in the college's Walt Whitman auditorium.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- The director of the United States Agency for International Development in South Vietnam said today that the country's economic recovery from the large enemy Tet offensive earlier this year was now "substantially complete."
Alexander's, Inc., the specialty store chain, held a sale yesterday and customers scrambled to buy $41.17-million worth of stock.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 12 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation strengthened today its already hard stand against the unionization of farm workers.

PARIS, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- French gold and convertible currency reserves rose by 378.6-million francs ($77-million) in the week ended Dec. 5, the Bank of France announced today. This increased the country's stockpile of physical monetary defenses to 19.7-billion francs ($4-billion).

A leading heart specialist said yesterday there was no sense in burying a person with a perfectly good heart, kidney or lungs -- or any of 14 other organs -- that might be used to save someone else's life.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 12 -- A subcommittee of the University of Illinois Committee on Student Discipline ruled today that 213 Negro freshmen involved in the Sept. 9 and 10 sit-in at the Illinois Union will receive reprimands of record, not to be included in their official university transcripts.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12 -- A special Harvard faculty meeting called to discuss motions to downgrade the status of the Reserve Officers Training Corps was canceled today after more than 100 student protestors insisted on remaining in the meeting hall to hear the debate.

The city of Denver along the Continental Divide his one of the most stunning views in the country -- but one of the most shortsighted views of its own affairs. This prosperous community will lose its Mayor at the end of this year. He is resigning for a job with an airline so that he can make a living and pay some college bills for his family.

Mayor Lindsay's announcement that he will seek state legislation to permit reorganization of the city's municipal health services under a public benefit corporation represents movement in the right direction, but not enough movement.
SYLVESTER, Ga., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Three predominantly Negro schools in Worth County were closed indefinitely today following a series of boycotts, school officials announced.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. -- Although Jascha Heifetz rarely performs in public these days, he has not wearied of music, the violin or the world, and his views are as crisp as his scales and his double-stopping.

Five days a week Bill Barron supervises the jazz instruction program at Muse, the Bedford Lincoln Neighborhood Museum, Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn. On Wednesday evenings he runs a jam session at Muse and on Thursdays he produces a jazz concert there.

"The Schaefer Award Theater," the series of major first-run motion pictures presented before major holidays with only four commercial interruptions, will televise its last film on Dec. 21. The series, which has been on WCBS-TV (Channel 2) for 10 years, will be discontinued because the sponsor, the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company, could not find enough first-run quality films.

An immediate halt to "the reign of criminal terror in Harlem," with remedial measures to include a mandatory five-year prison sentence for muggers, was demanded yesterday by the New York branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, has sounded out fellow Senate Republicans about a potential nomination of Arthur J. Goldberg to be Chief Justice of the United States.

HOW long is a musical? By which I mean, how long can you expect a musical to survive? The City Center Light Opera Company presented last night at the New York City Center their revival, for a Christmas season, of "Carnival!" And, for all its evident virtues, I wondered why.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Dec. 12 -- A military court here sentenced three Basque nationalist youths tonight to 48 years each in prison on charges of having burned down an empty house and having stolen dynamite.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The insistent question that found no answers here today was: "Is Sargent Shriver going to accept an appointment as chief United States Representative at the United Nations or isn't he?"
CAPETOWN, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Eighteen thoroughbreds imported from Kentucky have been refused entry into South Africa because authorities say the horses lack adequate veterinary health certificates.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The district attorney's office said today it was dropping murder charges against a man accused of slaying four elderly persons.
Warren Woodcock, a former Australian international star, was named yesterday head professional at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

In picking a Cabinet, President-elect Nixon had to choose between being bold and being comfortable, and he chose to be comfortable. He has picked a team of competent, decent, uncommitted men who owe their allegiance solely to him and should at least give him a feeling of personal security.
Two major financial deals were announced yesterday, involving proposals for the acquisition of substantial blocks of stocks of Williams Brothers Company and the Glen Alden Corporation.
Adelphi College and the Merchant Marine Academy, both on Long Island, suspended classes yesterday and sent their students home because of the ravages of the flu.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Embassy in Washington agreed to "censor" a magazine article defending the. Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia as a result of State Department objections, officials said today.
Cutting holes in the hull and deck of a British freighter docked in the East River, firemen battled a stubborn, smoky blaze in the ship's hold for more than five hours yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Army awarded the Distinguished Service Cross post-humously today to Maj. Gen. Keith L. Ware, who was killed in a helicopter crash in Vietnam Sept. 30. The medal was received by his widow of Alexandria, Va.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- North Vietnam agreed today to let captive American pilots receive Christmas packages from the United States for the first time in the Vietnam war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Lenore Romney never attended a board meeting while her husband, George, was president and chairman of American Motors.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Japan's balance - of - payments surplus in November was $210-million, her second largest so far, the Finance Ministry disclosed today. It was slightly below the $219-million record, set the month before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President-elect Richard M. Nixon discussed a wide range of foreign and domestic issues with President Johnson this evening in a White House meeting that lasted more than an hour and a half.

The Oxford and Cambridge Shakespeare Company, which recently performed at Hunter College, will present "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and a revue, "Strictly for Kicks," from Dec. 21 through Jan. 4 at the Wollman Auditorium, Broadway and 115th Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Publishers in 16 cities joined today in a plea to the Supreme Court to approve joint commercial operations by newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Paul W. McCracken, who will be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration, predicted today that prosperity would continue through 1969.

MONTREAL, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Two goals by Henri Richard enabled the Montreal Canadiens to defeat the St. Louis Blues, 5-4, in a meeting between the top divisional teams in the National Hockey League tonight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations Middle East mediator, arrived in Moscow tonight to resume for a month his post as Swedish Ambassador to the Soviet Union, a Swedish Embassy spokesman said.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- The police removed 30 university students who staged a sit-in at the House of Commons today to protest the British policy of supplying arms to help Nigeria in her war against secessionist Biafra.
ISTANBUL, Dec. 12 -- The Destroyers Dyess and Turner cut short an announced five-day cruise in the Black Sea and sailed early today through the Bosphorus to return to the Mediterranean.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The California Angels announced today the acquisition of the 45-year-old knuckleballing right-handed pitcher, Hoyt Wilhelm, from the new Kansas City Royals in exchange for a utility infielder, Ed Kirkpatrick, and a promising rookie catcher, Dennis Paepke.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Prime Minister Terence O'Neill, fighting for political survival, won a big vote of confidence tonight at a meeting of his ruling Unionist party.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Deaths from pneumonia and influenza have exceeded normal expectations, and the nation is in the midst of an epidemic of Hong Kong flu, the National Communicable Disease Center reported today.
MONTREAL, Dec. 12 -- Jet-plane glamor rode the rails today as the Canadian National Railways opened turbotrain service offering North America's fastest intercity schedule.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Lloyd Wendt was named publisher of Chicago's American today to succeed Stuart List, who will retire from that post Feb. 1. Mr. Wendt is editor and associate publisher of the newspaper.

PRAGUE, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Premier Oldrich Cernik told the policy-making Central Committee of the Communist party today that Czechoslovakia's economy declined further in 1968, partly because of the Soviet-led invasion. "The situation is very serious," he added.

George D. Woods, a former president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, took over yesterday as chairman of the board of the International Executive Service Corps, a nonprofit group that uses American management talent to help developing countries.
OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Goalie Gary Smith posted his second shutout in three games as the Oakland Seals overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wings tonight, 6-0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1,055,000,000, down 2 per cent from the year-earlier $1,072,000,000. Total retail store sales last week were about $7,662,000,000, up 5 per cent from $7,313,000,000.
WARSAW, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Two Warsaw University students, accused of organizing riots last March, were sentenced today to prison.

Loyal League Philanthropies, a nonsectarian organization that raises money for medical and educational projects for children, will hold its 36th annual dinner dance Dec. 21 in the Waldorf-Astoria's grand ballroom.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Total business inventories rose by $1.4-billion in October, the largest rise this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
AS they say in the ad game, the boys at Smith, Barney Co., Inc., ran this idea up the flagpole to see who would salute it:

Arthur Sulzberger was a dedicated man. We, who were his friends, know this. We have watched him at his work. We have seen how high he set his standards. We have found, in the seemingly endless pages of the great newspaper whose destiny he long directed, proof of his devotion to what was best and most valid in the traditions of American journalism.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Nicoline Locche of Argentina, won the world junior welterweight boxing title from Paul Fuji tonight when the Hawaiian-born defender failed to come out for the 10th round of the 15-rounder.

Directors of the Weyerhaeuser Company voted yesterday to propose a two-for-one split of the forest-products concern's shares. Stockholders of record Feb. 28 will consider the proposal at their annual meeting April. 17.

NYACK, N. Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A single-engine airplane with two persons aboard made an emergency landing at 8:30 A.M. today on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. The pilot, Carlos Garzon, 52 years old, of Fort Lee, N. J., said the engine failed over the Tappan Zee Bridge.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Premier-designate Mariano Rumor announced tonight that he had formed a new center-left Cabinet. He said the Cabinet was pledged to reform programs designed to avert worker and student revolts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Intercity truck tonnage for the week ended Dec. 7 was 2 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Freight traffic on United States railroads for the latest week was almost the same as in the comparable week last year.

Two of the many honors that will be going to Penn State's football team, players and coaches this winter were handed out yesterday when the undefeated Nittany Lions accepted the Lambert Trophy as the East's outstanding major team and Ted Kwalick, the Lions' tight end, was honored as the region's best major college player.

Young Rubicam announced yesterday it was resigning the Borden Company account after a 40-year relationship. Once the company's major agency, Y. R. is now handling about $3-million of Borden's estimated $35-million in annual billings.

The city's public schools will observe Open School Week from Jan. 13 to Jan. 17, Superintendent Bernard E. Donovan announced yesterday. Parent-teacher conferences will be scheduled and displays of students' work offered.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Jockey Club and the National Hunt Committee today merged into a new group that will have sole control of horse racing in Britain.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The 200-piece marching band of the State University at Buffalo will represent the state in the inaugural parade for President-elect Nixon Jan. 20 in Washington, the Republican state chairman, Charles Schoeneck, announced today. The band will be the only band from the state to participate in the parade, Mr. Schoeneck said. The band is led by Assistant Prof. Michael D. Sandgarten.

Following is the official summary of the recommendations by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education of the increased Federal support of students and institutions and for the expansion of medical education facilities:
A city plan to reorganize the Neighborhood Youth Corps and eliminate the director's post was criticized as an "administrative reprisal" yesterday by Willie J. Smith, director of the corps.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam joined today the search for a way to satisfy everyone in seating delegates to the expanded Vietnam talks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A national conference on the hazards of coal mining heard those most responsible for the safety of mine workmen concede today that they had not done enough to protect human life in the nation's most dangerous industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two young Negroes who tossed a fire bomb into a suburban city hall during racial disturbances here last April have received five-year prison sentences -- the stiffest riot-related penalties yet meted out in the area.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 -- Israeli military authorities have started to build on land in Jerusalem owned by the World Lutheran Federation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Ralph C. Body issued a temporary restraining order yesterday enjoining four groups of ocean carriers from acting to divert cargo from the Port of Philadelphia.
LAUREL, Md., Dec. 12 -- A pair of the longest priced horses in the ninth race at Laurel Race Course today combined for a $3,399.60 exacta. That payoff went to 14 lucky patrons in the crowd of 8,493.
Lieut. Arthur Ashe, the United States amateur and open champion, was ranked first in the nation yesterday by the men's ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Ascociation.
HONOLULU, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Heisman Trophy winner, O. J. Simpson of Southern California, was named today to play on the South team in the annual Hulu Bowl football game Jan. 4.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 12 -- A wayward diesel locomotive without an engineer at the throttle took a five-mile trip along a heavily traveled Long Island Rail Road line this morning before the railroad brought it to a halt by crashing it into five boxcars.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 12 -- The Yale College faculty today approved a broad, new program in Afro-American studies that will make the university one of the few in the country where an undergraduate can major in Negro culture.

Stern Stern Textiles, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Edwin M. Stern Jr. as president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds his father, who will continue as chairman. The board also named Alex Vermeersch vice president in charge of operations.
The Franklin National Bank announced yesterday the election of Joseph A. Beisler as a director. He is a partner of Cyrus J. Lawrence Sons, members of the New York Stock Exchange.

A total of 66,700 New Yorkers will receive long-delayed city income tax refunds next week, in time for Christmas shopping, the city's Finance Administrator, Fioravante G. Perrotta, announced yesterday.

The American Stock Exchange had its most active day since June yesterday, with 10,110,000 shares changing hands. On June 13, 10,809,000 shares were traded. Yesterday's volume was the fifth highest in exchange history.

WARSAW -- Even today, with East Europe still debating the Czechoslovak crisis, 1956 remains the annus mirabilis which began with Khrushchev's famous de-Stalinization and ended by almost blowing the lid off Poland and actually -- if temporarily -- blowing it off Hungary.
Money was tight during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A single-engined plane crashed at the intersection of New Highway and Gaza Boulevard here this afternoon, injuring the pilot, George Spiegel, 45 years old, of Lawrence, L. I., and demolishing the craft.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- The police arrested two radical student leaders today, and Gov. Ronald Reagan urged a continued "hard line" in suppression of a student strike at San Francisco State College.
KINGSTON, R. I., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Jim Larrangaga led Providence College to its third straight basketball victory tonight, an 86-76 triumph over Rhode Island. He scored 26 points.
Chuck Wepner, a security officer for an industrial firm in New Jersey, will trade punches with Jerry Tomasetti of Scranton, Pa., in a 10-round heavyweight fight at the Felt Forum tonight.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company recovered hundreds of the new Greater Austin telephone directories after customers complained. It seems that the first 96 pages of the Greater Houston phone book were included in place of the B, C, and D listings in many copies of the 837-page Austin directory.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Israeli authorities reported today that Jordanian forces had fired the first shots in the clash south of the Sea of Galilee, attacking an Israeli patrol in the area of the Maoz-Hayim settlement in the Beisan Valley.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Karl Schranz of Austria led a field of 122 competitors from 16 countries in the giant slalom today and won the first World Cup race for men of the ski season.
Arnold Palmer was hailed here last night as the year's No. 1 good-will ambassador for the United States in international sports.

GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 12 -- The director and the editor of the Guyana's only afternoon newspaper were charged with public mischief by the Government yesterday for an article criticizing the machinery of next Monday's general elections.

The Superintendent of New York City Schools announced yesterday the formation of a committee to recommend citywide guidelines for enlisting high school students in helping to make administrative and policy decisions in their schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Nixon forces have approached at least three prominent Negroes about top-level jobs in the incoming Administration, but no agreements have yet been reached.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Two mantelpieces designed by Benjamin H. Latrobe (1764-1820) have been recommended for use in the White House by the Committee for the Preservation of the White House.

ALGONAC, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP) -- An Army Corps of Engineers tugboat, the Anchor Bay, exploded today in the south channel of the St. Clair River off the Ontario shoreline. One man was reported killed and three others were hospitalized.
IT'S been said that nobody loves a a loser. Maybe so, but Mrs. William Dunham of Brooklyn has never felt so wanted since she lost the Mrs. America contest in Minneapolis last August.
CAIRO, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- An Egyptian long distance swimmer, Hanafi Mahmoud, drowned today while training in the Mediterranean at Salloum on the Egypt-Libya border.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- An attempt by a group of countries that have no nuclear weapons to create a new, permanent disarmament forum was shattered today by the opposition of the United States and the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Patricia Nixon led a sightseeing tour of Washington today for the children of the newly named members of her father's incoming Cabinet.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the nation's largest automobile financing company sold yesterday $100-million of debentures, and for the first time it had to pay a borrowing cost well above 7 per cent.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
New York City's record of building public improvements came under fire at a City Planning Commission hearing yesterday as one of "inefficiency, stagnation and bureaucracy."
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Billy Casper, prominent in the new American Professional Golfers, has told tournament officials that he will compete in the $100,000 Los Angeles Open, Jan. 8-12.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ethel Kennedy, widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, gave birth early today to their 11th child, an 8-pound 4-ounce girl described by a friend as "a real pretty baby with light brown hair."

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The Cabinet appointments of President-elect Richard M. Nixon brought mildly favorable reactions in European capitals today, with some concern voiced over the selection of William P. Rogers as Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Patent Office filed today with the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals a petition for a rehearing on the court's decision holding computer programs, or "software", to be patentable.

The spirit of seasonal giving was evident last evening when members of the Madison Square Boys Club presented gifts they had made in the club's workshops to guests at the second annual Christmas Tree Ball at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- With a team of moderate Republicans in his Cabinet, President-elect Richard M. Nixon appeared today to have laid the political foundations for bridging the sometimes stormy gap between Congress and the Executive branch on foreign and military policies.
HOWARD STREET. By Nathan C. Heard. 284 pages. Dial. $4.95. COMING OF AGE IN MISSISSIPPL By Anne Afoody. 348 pares. Dial. $$.95.
McGeorge Bundy, president of the Forld Foundation, will speak at a luncheon meeting of the Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club next Tuesday.

Persons who work in midtown Manhattan have less excuse not to save money than they had eight years ago. The number of banks in the area has grown by 34 per cent since 1960, a survey by the Cross Brown Company shows.
The head of the Long Island Rail Road trainmen's union called on the line's commuters yesterday to join his men in a "rebellion" against the railroad's management.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A rocket fuel leakage that threatened to disrupt plans for America's moon shot turned out today to be nothing more than a drainage peculiarity that will have no effect on Apollo 8's Dec. 21 launching.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Navy transport ship Hunter Victory, dubbed the Christmas Special, pulled into Danang harbor today and dropped off 1,100 tons of holiday mail and packages for Americans at war.

SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The United States military command today transferred six UH-1 helicopters and 10,000 M-16 rifles to the South Korean Army. They will be used to equip forces assigned to stop North Korean infiltration.
DALLAS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The nation's first law setting rules for organ transplants will be introduced in Texas, it was announced today.

MIAMI, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Ruxton Rose, ridden by the nation's leading jockey, Angel Cordero Jr., scored a front-running victory in the Suspicious Purse for fillies at Tropical Park today. Cordero also won the fifth race aboard Outdo, who returned $5.40, and has 317 winners for the year.
The London Stock Exchange closed firm yesterday following publication of improved trade figures for November.
The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York and the second largest in the world, announced yesterday agreement in principle on a major new international affiliation.

HAVANA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Air travelers reported today that as many as five armed guards, instead of two as in the past, are riding Cuban domestic flights. The increase apparently was designed to keep a plane from being hijacked to the United States.
BRASILIA, Dec. 12 -- The Brazilian Chamber of Deputies resisted Government pressure today and refused to permit the trial of a member on charges of having offended the army.
The finance committee of the City Council withheld a decision yesterday on the proposed new $60.5-million consolidated passenger terminal on the Hudson River between 46th and 49th Street.

The selection of one of the last open waterfront sites in Brooklyn for the relocation of the Fort Greene meat market is a clear illustration of New York's planning jinx at work. Every responsible official on the city's administrative and planning levels knows that putting the market on that potentially choice 13-acre stretch between the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges along the East River is the wrong use for waterfront land.

WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Carmine Abbatiello brought home four winners at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, and drew away to a 128-124 lead over Lucien Fontaine, who was blanked in the struggle for the year's dash-winning driving championship here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
A public corporation to manage the 19 municipal hospitals and all other city health facilities was proposed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
ALBANY, Dee. 12 -- The next Republican Speaker of the Assembly denied today the inevitablity of a state tax increase next year.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The American League president, Joe Cronin, and representatives of the Umpires Association met behind closed doors for more than 2 1/2 hours today to discuss the umpires' demands. Both sides agreed that the meeting had been cordial and considerable progress had been made.

The long-standing take-over fight between the United States Smelting Refining and Mining Company and the Clevite Corporation appeared headed toward a happy ending yesterday, as a similar fight warmed up over the American Smelting and Refining Company.
A renewed strike on the waterfront in Atlantic and Gulf ports after 7 P.M. next Friday seemed likely yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A strange attack of economic and political nerves that has gripped Britain for the last week was largely dispelled today by some happy figures.
Sarah Lawrence, the Bronxville women's college that stresses the humanities, has chosen a new president from the ranks of the International Business Machines Corporation, where technology is king.
Jacques Levy, director of "Scuba Duba," now in its second year, and co-director of "America Hurrah," which ran for 18 months, will write and stage two Broadway musicals.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. I2 (AP) -- Arthur Ashe and Stan Smith of the United States Davis Cup team gained the semi-finals but Charlie Pasarell was beaten in the quarter-finals today in the Queensland tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Plans for early hearings on why two major league umpires were dismissed may be expanded to include the labor problems of professional athletes generally, the chairman of a House Labor subcommittee reported today.

DANDY Don Meredith is having his best season ever. So are the Dallas Cowboys. Both happenstances seem slightly obscure for no accountable reason unless it could be that a couple of agonizing last-minute defeats in playoffs against the Packers of recent years have warped all perspective.

BRISTOL, England, Dec. 12 -- The first ballet of the young American choreographer Eliot Feld to be seen in Europe, "Meadow Lark," had a mixed reception when given last night by London's Festival Ballet on tour at the Hippodrome here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A low-yield nuclear test blast was set off underground today at the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site. A low-yield blast has a force less than 20,000 tons of TNT. It was the 27th weapons-related test to be announced this year.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation's board announced yesterday that it intends to recommend to shareholders at the annual meeting on April 23 that the charter be amended to increase the authorized common shares to 75 million from 25 million and that the common stock be split two-for-one.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Bertrand Russell has written to Wladislaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist party chief, condemning "the wave of anti-Semitism which has overtaken Poland."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Ralph Barnett scored on a layup, at the end of a fast break, to give George Washington a 74-73 overtime victory over Georgetown University tonight and keep the Colonials on the undefeated list.
The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education proposed yesterday that a multi-billion-dollar Federal program be set up to aid students, subsidize colleges and universities and expand medical education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois announced today his candidacy for the post of chairman of the House Republican Conference. The post is held by Melvin R. Laird of Wisconsin, who will become Secretary of Defense in the Nixon Cabinet.
TOKYO, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- A United States unmanned aircraft was shot down when it flew over Hanoi today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Friday, Dec. 13 -- A Pan American jetliner carrying 51 persons on a flight here from New York crashed in the Caribbean last night on its approach to Maiquetia International Airport.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 12 (AP) -- State officers, arrested today a former parole board chairman, Martin Fraley, of Corinth, under an indictment charging him with accepting money from a convict's wife seeking to free her husband.

One of two students who were suspended at New York University last week for having allegedly taken part in demonstrations against Nguyen Huu Chi, South Vietnam's observer at the United Nations, and James Reston, the executive editor of The New York Times, had his suspension substantially modifieed yesterday by Dr. James M. Hester, the university president.

The fashion revolution in men's apparel -- which has helped to spur sales in recent years for American and foreign designers as well as for a wide gamut of manufacturers and retailers -- is apparently continuing into 1969 at a faster pace than ever.

Mayor Lindsay outlasted a dozen radical hecklers at Columbia University yesterday and won the applause of 1,500 other students with a warning that "obscene names" and "shouting down speakers" would stop the social revolution that the hecklers say they want.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Ron Ellis scored late in the first period to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in the National Hockey League tonight.

Ned Rorem just has to be a happy man today. Last night a program of nothing but his songs was given at Town Hall, a capacity audience of "in" people attended and the singers were of a calibre that most composers wait a lifetime for and never get.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Kel Nagel of Australia shot a course-record 64 today and held a three-stroke lead after the first round of New Zealand international golf tournament at the Grange course.
Ice covered the stairs and hallways inside a heatless East Harlem tenement yesterday as about 30 Protestant. Roman Catholic and Jewish clergymen picked their way carefully through the building.
On Sunday, Jennifer Preston will celebrate her 23d birthday, so she deemed it fitting to enclose a check for $23 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Defense Department, seeking to compensate for the early release of reservists and National Guardsmen, said today that it would draft 33,700 men in February.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 12 -- Militant members of a Roman Catholic working-class parish here decided last night to boycott any mass said in their church until the Archbishop of Florence restored their parish priest, the Rev. Enzo Mazzi, whom he dismissed from the parish eight days ago.
A new tenants' organization has been formed to attack allegedly widespread rent gouging that the group says threatens to "socially bankrupt" New York City.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The office of Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, announced today that the Department of Housing and Urban Development had restored planning funds for Little Rock and had approved North Little Rock for the Model Cities program.

WASHINGTON Dec. 12 (AP) Secretary of Welfare Wilbur J. Cohen announced tonight that public hearings on ways to improve Medicaid will be held in nine cities around the country beginning Dec. 20. Medicaid is the Federal-state program, begun in 1966, which provides care for people, who cannot pay for it. This year, it is expected to aid 9.5 million people in 42 states and Federal jurisdictions.

GIANT fans at Yankee Stadium on Sunday will be seeing in the Dallas Cowboys one of the pro football teams with the best capability of winning the Super Bowl. The trouble with the Cowboys this season, however, is that they have no exact idea how good they are because the trip through their schedule was a joy ride.
American and Italian archeologists believe they have found the long-sought site of Sybaris, the seat of proverbial luxury in the ancient world.
The International Business Machines Corporation charged yesterday that the Control Data Corporation's antitrust suit against it was "baseless" and "inconsistent."
Stock prices went through another minor retreat yesterday. After a steady opening, prices slipped downward until mid-afternoon, then edged upward in late trading.

John R. Kirkkpatrick was elected president yesterday of EBS Management Consultants, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Ebasco Industries Inc. He succeeds Kemp W. Reece, who has retired after 43 years' service with the company and its predecessor, the Electric Bond and Share Company.

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 12 -- Lawyers for the Sinclair Oil Corporation and Gulf Western Industries, Inc., agreed in court today to inform shareholderso f both corporations that G. must take no action that would be irrevocable in its proposed offer to exchange its warrants and convertible debentures for Sinclair stock.

THE man who was named yesterday to be president of Sarah Lawrence College is known to his friends as Leonardo. "He really is the complete Renaissance man," said one of the friends yesterday, explaining the Da Vinci characterization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- United States Navy officials said today that the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean had been reduced approximately one-third in the last six weeks.
DETROIT, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Vito Giacalone, alleged Mafia leader, was given a 90-day jail sentence yesterday for failing to take his personal gun collection to the police for a safety inspection.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Carmen Salvino of Chicago held a 75-pin lead today after the first two rounds of the international open bowling tourney.

MADRID, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco today inaugurated Spain's first nuclear power plant at Zorita in the Guadalajara hills northeast of Madrid. Spain, which already produces her own uranium, expects to get a third of her electricity supplies from nuclear plants by 1980.
NOTTINGHAM, England, Dec. 12 -- The playwrighting partnership of Keith Waterhouse and Willis Hall has yielded a number of comedies that assail middle-class subjects with working-class derision.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz sent to Congress today the largest budget in Mexican history -- more than $5-billion. The proposed budget is more than $360-million higher than the present one.

"The Mad Show," the revue that opened in 1966 and had a run of 871 performances at the New Theater, will be brought back there Dec. 21 for 13 matinees. A similar repeat engagement took place at the New Theater during last year's holidays.

TRADITIONALLY, the approaching weekend is the one on which ski center operators used to focus for the grand opening. Coming just before Christmas, the pre-holiday weekend enabled them to give their facilities a last, timely checkup before the big rush.

Tallulah Bankhead, the star whose offstage performances often rivaled her roles in the theater, film and television, died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday of pneumonia, complicated by emphysema. She was 65 years old.
The General Electric Company is asking purchasers of television sets to bring them in for a free check against a possible safety hazard.
ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The state's highest court today dismissed an appeal by Ernest Hemingway's widow to block the sale of A. E. Hotchner's book, "Papa Hemingway."

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Kathy Whitworth has joined the late Babe Zaharias and Mickey Wright in becoming the third player in the Ladies Professional Golf Association to win four consecutive money-earning championships.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Johnson Administration is concerned over reports of a new enemy build-up in South Vietnam.
Western Kentucky's basketball team came to New York with five straight victories, overpowering height and a good public relations man who had been able to get them ranked 14th nationally.
"Hagashash of Israel,' a comedy and musical trio, will make its New York debut on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall. The performance will be given in English, Hebrew and Yiddish.
Jet fans looking ahead to the American Football League championship game on Dec. 29 can scout the Jets' opponent this weekend, but the job will take two days.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 12 -- Fresh outbreaks of fighting were reported at the demilitarized zone and northwest of Saigon today, and the United States command announced that American combat deaths in the war had passed the 30,000 mark.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Jim Grant of Wethersfield, Conn., and Bill Harvey of Greensboro, N. C., twice Carolina amateur champion, teamed to lead the first day's play in the ninth annual United States pro-amateur championship at the St. Lucie Country Club today.
BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 -- A new type of mechanism for monetary cooperation is being developed inside the European Economic Community, a month after the mark-franc currency war.

The ABC Television Network is consolidating its advertising, promotion and design functions into an expanded department -- advertising and promotion -- to be headed by Donald Foley, an ABC-TV vice president.
Cocoa futures rose to new life-of-contract and 10 - year highs again yesterday. As was the case last week, the rise was spurred by lower weekly Ghana central purchase figures.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 12 -- The acting chairman of United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that many of the migrant farm workers in the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas were living under conditions close to peonage or slavery.

Claes Oldenburg, the pop artist noted for his "soft sculpture," is going to work with Walt Disney Productions. Victor Vasarely, the Hungarian-born "father" of op art is joining forces with the International Business Machines Corporation.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Students and professors at the Nanterre campus of the University of Paris struck today to protest police attempts to interrogate students in connection with social strife.
The corporation operating Peter Pan Restaurants was fined $500 yesterday for advertising and selling Skinny Shakes with false claims of a low caloric content.
TO bid and make a slam while other players with the same cards are failing in a game contract is a not infrequent occurrence. But for this to happen in the same suit is rare indeed.

HAPPILY for the boating public, the Christmas market has been peppered this season with salty items for young and old. There are games, books, pictures, models, toys, jewelry, clothes and educational amusements that are perfect for the nautical-minded.

GLUCKSBURG, West Germany, Dec. 12 (AP) -- A West German F-104 Starfighter crashed into the North Sea today and the pilot is missing, the Glucksburg naval command reported. It was the 91st of the controversial West German Starfighters to crash.
BEATRICE WEBB. A Life, 1858-1943. By Kitty Muggeridge and Ruth Adam. 265 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- A University of Florida football coach said today the school would break the color line in sports with the recruiting of Willie Jackson, a Negro fullback from Sarasota. Jackson, who attends Valley Forge Military Academy at Wayne, Pa., will be enrolled when he comes home to Florida for Christmas, said the assistant head coach, Gene Ellenson.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Bill Melchionni, former Philadelphia 76ers player, will return to his alma mater, Villanova University, as an assistant to the head basketball coach, Jack Kraft, it was announced today by the athletic director, Art Mehan.

A $13.5-million contract for the construction of the first of a series of nine oceanographic ships of a radically new design has been awarded by the Naval Ship Command System to the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Members of Congress, business leaders and Negro militants met here today to push a bipartisan "community self-determination" bill that fits Richard M. Nixon's campaign promises to give Negroes "a piece of the action.
Jewish communities here and abroad will be asked to contribute $365-million to meet the urgent social, welfare and humanitarian needs of Israel's people next year.
GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Casey Stengel remained in the Glendale Memorial Hospital's intensive-care unit today for treatment of cuts and bruises suffered in a traffic collision.

The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that it had postponed until Jan. 15 the introduction of a new "flow control" system aimed at easing the aerial stack-up of airliners when New York's airports are jammed.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Drivers in the London-to-Sydney automobile marathon braced today for a rough 3,800-mile drive across the Australian continent.
The State Racing Commission approved yesterday a total of 234 racing days for 1969, with the season beginning March 10 and ending Dec. 6.
Blair Co., Inc., has agreed in principle to acquire Schwabacher Co., a San Francisco-based brokerage house that has been troubled by paperwork problems in its back office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The National Rifle Association, under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has now registered with Congress as a lobbying organization.

The Board of Elections will send letters today to approximately 350 of the 1,000 candidates for office in the city last month telling them they have violated the Election Law by failing to file reports on receipts and spending.
The 21st anniversary convention of the International Association of Concert Managers will take place at the New York Hilton Hotel for three days beginning next Thursday.

MAYWOOD, N. J., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Twenty-seven persons were injured, none seriously, today when a Short Lines bus ran into a disabled truck on Route 17. The bus was en route from upstate New York to New York City.

The New York Court of Appeals reversed by a 4-3 vote yesterday an order of the Appellate Division that had directed the Superintendent of Insurance to seize the Citizens Casualty Company of New York Citizens, which has maintained it had not been given a full hearing on the issue of its insolvency, will receive a new trial in State Supreme Court.

The American Jewish Congress yesterday called on Negro leaders "to repudiate the blatant resort to racial and religious hatred" contained in a leaflet distributed in Harlem last week declaring that "Zionists killed black people" in their own land in the Middle East.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Dr. Anthony Arco, a native of San Juan, P.R., has been appointed director of the State Mental Hygiene after-care clinic in New York City. Dr. Arce has been director of psychiatry at Lincoln Hall School in Westchester County.
>Eric Levin scored 30 points and three other players hit for double figures last night to lead Herbert H. Lehman College to an 85-64 victory over Hunter at the loser's Manhattan gym.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said yesterday that his union's support of decentralization in the next session of the Legislature would depend upon "what happens in Ocean Hill-Brownsville and at P.S. 39" in the I.S. 201 experimental district.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Dec. 6 -- Jutting out of a morass of brackish lagoons, the capital of the Ivory Coast is a tangible mirage of modernity: skyscrapers, divided highways, neon lights and daily traffic jams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Italian Historical Society of America placed a wreath today at the Justice Department building to mark the 60th anniversary of the creation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The Greenpoint Avenue bridge across Newtown Creek on the Brooklyn-Queens border will be closed from 6 P.M. tomorrow until 1 A.M. Monday for repairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A prize-winning 20-foot white pine Christmas tree, a gift to President and Mrs. Johnson, was delivered to the White House today by Don Goodwin, its grower, after a two-day trip from Indianapolis.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A coed at the State University at Albany was slightly injured early today when a sniper fired a shotgun blast into the headquarters of the Brothers, a local civil rights group. The pellets struck Miss Susan Levey, 20 years old, of Wantagh, L. I., on the face and right ear. She was admitted to the Albany Medical Center Hospital in satisfactory condition.
