WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- John W. Heffernan, Reuters chief representative in Washington, was elected president of the National Press Club tonight, the first non-American to be chosen for the post in the club's 60-year history.
IT'S THAT TIME of year again, when stores are locked in their annual battle of one-upmanship, each trying to outdo the others in offering outlandishly expensive Christmas gifts.

A man sent to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday $50 as "part of our Christmas present I give to my wife -- the part we each like best, to receive and to give, because we are so grateful that we can do it."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -The United States today gently urged Peru to begin discussions about "prompt, adequate and effective" compensation for the American oil properties taken over by the Peruvian military Government six days after it seized power last Oct. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The man who will be the next Secretary of Labor said today he believed in the least possible Government interference in labor disputes and conceded that this implied acceptance of strikes when the parties could not agree.
A suit to compel the 60 directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to meet and reconsider the ouster of a staff lawyer was dismissed yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Thousands of Protestant loyalists converged on the County Antrim port of Larne tonight to give a drum-beating, flag-waving welcome for the 82-year old historic gun-runner Clyde Valley.
DETROIT, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Water levels fell in the last month in all of the Great Lakes except Lake Ontario, which showed a three-inch rise, the United States Lake Survey said today.
Rex Chainbelt, Inc., has elected S. Bruce Smart, Jr., a director. Mr. Smart is a vice president of the Continental Can Company.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 13 -- An anti-Government demonstration by Mexican students was headed off today by about 2,000 soldiers and riot policemen.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 13 -- The Foreign Ministers of Malaysia and the Philippines met here last night and agreed to restore diplomatic relations between their two countries and shelve their dispute over the state of Sabah for at least a year.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- A diplomat watched the wintry wind strip the last leaves from chestnut trees along the Avenue Gabriel and remarked that he expected to be arguing about peace in Vietnam when April came and the chestnuts blossom "and very possibly we will still be here the spring after that."
LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- British officials tonight denied knowledge of a plan by Prime Minister Smith for a settlement of the dispute.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Scientists at the National Cancer Institute have found strong evidence that an unknown virus is closely associated with human bone cancer.
New York's top-level Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders have gone to "grass roots" clergymen in an effort to establish communication among disparate areas here.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- United States and North Vietnamese officials met privately for three hours tonight and considered variants of curved tables for the proposed broadened peace talks.

MIAMI, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Angel Cordero Jr.'s bid for the 1968 jockey championship suffered a setback today when the Puerto Rican rider failed to win at Tropical Park and his total for the year remained at 317 winners.

The present school crisis is a horror tale to instruct us how not to handle public affairs. There is no innocent party. There is no wholly guilty party. But the Board of Education, the Superintendent of Schools, the United Federation of Teachers, the Ocean Hill - Brownsville board and the Ford Foundation have each been right and wrong and all have contributed to confusion.

LISBON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, who has been recovering from a stroke for the last three months, will leave hospital for his Lisbon home next week, it was officially announced here tonight.
Croquet, that genteel but sometimes fierce sport, has become the latest object of controversy in Central Park.

IN her TV incarnation as Madge the Manicurist, Jan Miner has had no trouble convincing at least half of the people who watch her, including me, that a certain green liquid detergent makes a dandy hand lotion.

The dispute that had threatened to disrupt the ranks of professional golf ended yesterday with an amicable settlement. The 52-year-old Professional Golfers' Association and the American Professional Golfers, a group that was organized four months ago by most of the game's leading professional players, agreed to join forces under a new format.
SUGAR plums were known in Europe long before Clement C. Moore mentioned them in his poem "A Visit From St. Nicholas," written in 1822, and the Sugar Plum Fairy danced in the "Nutcracker" ballet.
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- A Communist court in East Berlin today sentenced Kurt Wachholz, 59-year old former Nazi prison guard, to die under the guillotine for war crimes and mass murder.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- America's Orbiting Astronomical Observatory 2 has raised doubts about a theory that radiation remains trapped in gas clouds around certain stars, an experimenter said today.

Laurance S. Rockefeller has been elected president of the New York Zoological Society by the trustees, the society announced yesterday. He succeeds Fairfield Osborn, who has retired after being president of teh organization since 1940.
BALBOA, Canal Zone, Dec. 13 -- A 365-foot Panamanian-flag tanker, Witwater, broke in two today as it was entering the Panama Canal channel off the port of Cristobal.

A run-through of "Mame," with Susan Hayward, which was to have been presented tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Winter Garden for the benefit of the Ben Irvin Memorial Fund, has been canceled because Miss Hayward has a cold.

A 250-foot construction crane crashed yesterday afternoon at Hillside Avenue and 175th Street, Jamaica, Queens, damaging a parked car only a few feet from the flow of traffic, the police reported.According to the police, the crane, owned by the Castaldi Equipment Corporation, was at an apartment building construction site.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Creighton hit a cold streak after a hot start and bowed to Kansas, 78-65, in the Sunflower basketball tournament tonight before 11,000 fans.
The University of Kentucky was named yesterday the host for the 1969 United States Track and Field Federation outdoor championships to be held June 13 and 14.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce C. R. Smith deferred action today on Maine's hotly contested application for a two-section foreign trade zone and turned the matter over to the incoming Republican administration.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Big Jim Gibbons scored 20 points and pulled in 15 rebounds tonight to lead Michigan State to a 70-60 victory over Butler.
PIKEVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The home of a young couple, long active in this area as antipoverty workers, was damaged slightly today by an explosion believed caused by dynamite.
A controversy has developed over the refusal of Actors Equity to permit the Lincoln Center Theater Company to stage a series of free Monday night workshop programs at the Forum Theater.
Sooner or later New Yorkers will have seen all the Mozart operas. The latest to arrive is "Lucio Silla," written just before the composer was 17 years old and given its premiere in Milan in 1772.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The United States will build a huge deep-space tracking installation near here, Australian officials said today. They said bids on the 210-foot wide facility would be taken soon.

GENEVA, Dec. 13 -- The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East announced today that West Germany had agreed "in principle" to provide $12.5-million for a special aid program.
ATHENS, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- The United States destroyers Turner and Dyess, which sailed into the Black Sea Monday despite Soviet protests over their missiles, arrived here tonight.

A $100-million plan for new buildings and the interior refurbishing of a group of 60-year-old buildings was presented yesterday at City College by its president, Dr. Buell Gallagher, and John Carl Warnecke, the project architect.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Navy decommissioned the U.S.S. Allegheny today, and she was quickly given to Northwestern Michigan College for use in a new Great Lakes maritime training course.

IF THE cigarette companies drop their broadcast advertising as some observers predict they'll do on their own or be forced to do by legislation, the loss of 8 per cent of the broadcaster's $3.1-billion market would hurt -- no doubt about it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Pentagon today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Oscar Robertson scored 9 points in overtime tonight to spark the Cincinnati Royals to a 130-123 victory over the Phoenix Suns in a National Basketball Association game.

The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway announced yesterday the election of Richard C. Grayson as president. Mr. Grayson, who is 48 years old, had been vice president-operations. He is succeeded in that position by J. H. Brown. J. E. Gilliland, who had been president, remains as chairman and chief executive officer.
College football's post-season bowl parade begins today with seven games packed into a coast-to-coast schedule that includes the University of Mississippi's 12th consecutive major bowl appearance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Shareholders of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad approved today a revised merger agreement with the Chicago North Western Railway.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- A move to make industrial spying illegal failed in the House of Commons today after the practice was declared not to be widespread. Penalties of up to two years' imprisonment and a fine of 1,000 ($2,400) had been sought for the theft of company secrets by photographic or electronic devices.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Government police arrested dozens of opponents of the oCsta e Silva Government tonight, including former President Juscelino Kubitschek, who was taken into custody as he left a theater.
In a few sentences, a respected Negro leader suggested yesterday the magnitude of Richard M. Nixon's problems in gaining the confidence of the nation's Negro community.

CORTLAND, N. Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Two kindergarten pupils were killed today when they apparently ran in front of a school bus that had just let them off near their homes, west of the city line. They were Eddie Genson, 6 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Genson, and Nacy Warfle, 5, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Waffle.

Marjorie Kellogg, a 46-year-old hospital social worker, has had a side job since July at which she earns $1,000 a week. She is writing the screen play of her novel. "Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon," which will appear on the best-seller list tomorrow for the first time.

Scott Singer and Ron Smalls made two free throws apiece in the closing minute tonight to give Long Island University a 60-57 victory over previously unbeaten Mount St. Mary's in the winners' gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Harold E. Stassen, who is best known in the role of Presidential aspirant, made his debut this week as an inventor. He was granted a patent for a visual aid to teach small children mathematics.

Charging that the Bronx District Attorney's office was a "reluctant dragon," a criminal lawyer obtained a court order yesterday requiring the prosecution to show cause why it should not immediately bring to trial a defendant charged with first-degree murder.
Aqueduct is closed for the year, but sports fans who miss the Big A will be able to go to the Big E tonight at Madison Square Garden.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Carmen Salvino of Chicago was leading today in the second International Bowling Tournament. The Chicagoan had a score of 5,417 after 22 games.
The London Stock Exchange turned mixed yesterday after a three-day rally.
WHITTIER, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A fire today destroyed Old Founder's Hall at Whittier College, from which President-elect Richard M. Nixon was graduated in 1934. There were no reports of injuries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Luke P. Carroll, associate editor of Chicago's American, has been appointed editor to succeed Lloyd Wendt, who was named publisher yesterday, it was announced today. Both appointments are effective Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -The State Department strongly denied today that the United States was taking any stand on whether the next West German presidential election should be held in West Berlin or not.

A Boston research team that says it has conducted the most carefully controlled study to date on the physical and psychological effects of smoking marijuana has concluded that the drug is a "relatively mild intoxicant with minor, real, short-lived effects."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Dec. 13 -- Representative Lester L. Wolff's office announced tonight that construction of the controversial Long Island Sound Bridge-Causeway between Westchester and Nassau Counties might be blocked because of Federal action today.

WASHINGTON Dec. 13 -- Last July 18, Richard M. Nixon received a staff memorandum warning that the Soviet Union was on a collision course with Czechoslovakia and would have to invade to crush the wave of liberalism in Prague.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Paul (The Waiter) Ricca, one of 13 persons summoned before a Federal grand jury investigating racketeering, was granted general immunity from prosecution today and ordered to answer all questions of the jury.

Two leaders of the recent strike at state mental hospitals entered Civil Jail yesterday to serve sentences for criminal contempt as hundreds of union officials and rank-and-file members protested outside.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press) -- A work-to-rule slowdown by 2,200 Air Canada passenger agents and communications personnel was resumed today following "misunderstanding" over a proposed new labor contract.
The members of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union, who struck the Consolidated Edison Company on Dec. 1, voted more than 3 to 1 yesterday to accept a new contract and return to work tomorrow.

Brenda Wilson, a 10-year-old fifth grader at Public School 87 in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district, stood yesterday in front of a class of bewildered kindergarten children in the school, a pointer held under her arm like an elongated swagger stick.
MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Al Ecuyer, a middle linebacker with the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, retired today.
"An Evening of James Agee," drawing on the works of the late author, will be performed Feb. 10 and Feb. 11 at the Theater de Lys.

COMMACK, L. I., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Bob Lloyd scored half of his 20 points in the final 4 1/2 minutes tonight in leading the New York Nets to a 112-107 American Basketball Association victory over the Houston Mavericks.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Otis Singletary of the University of Texas announced today that he had turned down an offer to become president of the University of Kentucky.
A $3-million air freight terminal, designed to handle containerized shipments swiftly, was opened last Wednesday on the West Coast by Pan American World Airways.
Landlords and tenants went to a public hearing yesterday to air an age-old dispute -- rents.

The Manhattan College five remained unbeaten, despite 38 points by the University of Bridgeport's Tony Barone, as the Jaspers defeated the Purple Knights, 101-89. last night at home. Manhattan, with a 3-0 won-lost record, has not bowed on its home court since 1947.

TOWSON, Md., Dec. 12 (UPI) -- Two men, both twice convited and sentenced to jail terms on charges of mutilating draft board records, were imprisoned today when they were unable to post $7,500 bail each after a hearing in Baltimore County Circuit Court.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Fourteen seamen were believed dead after explosions tore through a Liberian tanker as it unloaded crude oil here today.

The Maritime Administration has approved an application by Moore-McCormack Lines to make 47 cruises with the passenger liners Argentina and Brasil next year. Most of the cruises will be voyages to the Caribbean and to Bermuda.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Food and Drug Administration released today a scientific report that said the totally unrestricted use of artificial sweeteners was not warranted.

The governing board of the Intermediate School 201 complex in East Harlem announced yesterday the appointment of a new acting principal for Public School 39, where a parent boycott reduced the regular enrollment of 550 to a mere dozen pupils yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Mariano Rumor became Italy's 11th Postwar Premier today when he and his coalition Cabinet of Christian Democrats, Socialists and Republicans were sworn in by President Giuseppe Saragat.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Indiana Pacers withstood a last-period rally by the Kentucky Colonels to win an American Basketball Association game, 115-107, tonight.

The executive vice chairman of the United Jewish Appeal called yesterday for greater financial aid from Jewish communities here to cope with the needs of 40,000 new immigrants in Israel and to help absorb 350,000 earlier immigrants into the nation's economic and social life.

BENCAT, South Vietnam Dec. 13 (AP) -- This district capital astride two major enemy war zones -- C and D -- has been placed on full alert for an imminant attack, but there was little sign of any enemy today.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Peter Brandt, the 19-year-old son of Willy Brandt, West Germany's Foreign Minister was fined 400 marks ($100) today on two charges of ritoing in West Berlan. Both charges arose from political demonstrations, in November, 1967, and in April, 1968.

CLINTON, N. Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Four Norwich players scored two goals each as Norwich skated away with a fight-marred 10-4 victory over Hamilton in college hockey tonight. During a last-period fight, two players were ejected from the game.

"The Messiah" was made to be sung, not heard. On that arguable theory the National Choral Council, with the cooperation of practically everybody, threw open the doors of Philharmonic Hall last night and invited everyone who could -- or thought he could-- sing to come over and have a go at Handel's masterpiece.
The criminal contempt of court trial of the presidents of the teachers' union and the school supervisors' association ended here yesterday.

Those whose goal seems to be to submerge the natural beauties of the landscape beneath a blanket of concrete have just won a notable victory. Soon the bulldozers will be at work along the east bank of the Hudson in Westchester, destroying open green space and trees and homes so that more and more automobiles can pollute the atmosphere.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 13 -- Dr. Raymond B. Hoxeng resigned today as president of Interamerican University, Puerto Rico's largest private university with 8,000 students. Mr. Hoxeng, 47 years old, of South Dakota, said he planned to return to private industry in the United States when his resignation went into effect Feb. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- "The most remarkable thing about Howe is that never, never--no matter what happened or what anyone said--did he lose his temper."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The Department of Transportation today added 1,472 miles to the interstate highway system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- David M. Kennedy, who was named as President-elect Richard M. Nixon's Treasury Secretary, said today he believed in balanced Federal budgets but added there was such a thing as an "acceptable deficit."
Irish Pat Murphy was listed as a semi-final fighter, but the 19-year-old from West New York, N. J., was the classiest boxer in the Felt Forum ring last night.
Reaction of local cable television companies to the ruling yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission was generally optimistic.
The "Hello, Dolly!" company will be on vacation for one week, starting Monday. Performances will resume at the St. James Theater on Dec. 23.

TRENTON, Dec. 13 -- New Jersey's Department of Transportation is constructing an interstate highway link that could wind up under water if the state's Department of Conservation and Economic Development goes ahead with its present plans to build a dam on the Passaic River.

There are only five members of the Aeolian Chamber Players, but at the end of a concert by them one may well feel that he has heard a large and varied array of instrumentalists. This is because the group has a broad knowledge of the chamber -music repertory and plans its programs imaginatively.

KINGSTON, R. I., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Ten students from the University of Rhode Island barred a recruiter from the Dow Chemical Company from an interview room today in violation of an agreement with school officials that they would not obstruct the recruiting program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Otto F. Otepka, former chief security evaluator of the State Department, asked for and was granted another 60-day extension of his present status: on leave without pay, officials reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- An African and Asian drive to expel South Africa from an important United Nations trade agency failed today to win enough votes for approval in the General Assembly.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Sweden granted political asylum to nine more United States soldiers today but ordered the expulsion of two draft dodgers. The decision raised to 149 the number of Americans granted asylum because they opposed the Vietnam war.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- George Romney said today that he would not resign as Governor of Michigan until after the Senate confirms his appointment as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Nixon Cabinet.
STANFORD, Calif., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Darrell Hammarley, the world's first double heart transplant recipient, died today of a blood clot on the brain.

MICKEY MOUSE at the age of 40 has the right to wear any color gloves he chooses. Or so says Martin Proctor of Papier Mache, a furnishings shop at 55 Greenwich Avenue, where Walt Disney's rodent appears, not in the traditional yellow, but in red gloves, decorating the face of a French alarm clock.
SYDNEY, Australia (Religious News Service) -- A joint commission on union of the Congregational, Methodist and Presbyterian Churches in Australia has completed a plan for the merger.

Galsworthy, Inc., a New Jersey liquor wholesaler, has filed a $36-million damage suit charging that its exclusive distributorship of Cutty Sark Scotch whisky in that state was being illegally altered through the addition of other whole salers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Secretary General Thant made public today a letter from North Korea denouncing the United Nations for a resolution of Nov. 27 that invited Pyongyang to take part in current debate here on Korea on the condition that it recognize the authority of the United Nations.
The city found itself yesterday in the position of an unwilling landlord, with an increasing number of unwanted properties on its hands, many of which are in slum areas.

Four employes of the city's Finance Administration's parking meter division were suspended yesterday as the city continued its investigation of a ring of meter collectors and drivers that allegedly stole more than $5-million in coins during the last four years.

OSSINING, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Opponents of the Hudson River Expressway said yesterday that they would appeal the dismissal of a suit against the state's Hudson River Valley Commission, which approved the expressway.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- Two major executives of the H. J. Heinz Company's Venezuelan subsidiary, Alimentos Heinz C.A., were among those killed when a Pan American Boeing 707 jet crashed into the Caribbean north of Caracas last night.

Dr. Benjamin Spock was presented with the Thomas Paine Award at the Americana Hotel last night by the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee "for speaking common sense to America and for his courageous defense of humanrights."

The opportunity for the American viewing public to get a little more choice on its television dial will be increased as a result of new proposals of the Federal Communications Commission. Although technical and contractual problems are involved, not to mention pressure for maintaining the present structure of commercial broadcasting, the F.C.C. is at last making some hard decisions that could improve the television picture.

Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow for the Metropolitan Opera season's 17th week. The week, Jan. 6 to 11, will include the season's first performance of "Madama Butterfly" and final performances of "La Sonnambula" and "Il Barbiere di Siviglia."

The Stanley M. Isaacs Community Center, 415 East 93d Street, will benefit from a Christmas Fair to be held there today from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Hand-painted ceramic tiles and handmade holiday candles, decorations and crafts will be on sale.

SEATTLE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Boeing Company announced yesterday that the maiden flight of its giant 747 superjet had been postponed until early next month because bad weather delayed ground and other preflight tests.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 -- Israeli defense officials apparently have decided to withhold details of the extent of their military activities along the Jordan River border.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Harry Golden has paid $1,200 in an out-of-court settlement of a libel suit resulting from his book "A Little Girl Is Dead."
The International Paper Company has formed a new department of resources development which will be under the direction of Cornelius C. Rose Jr., who has been named a vice president.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Hungarian Communist party took reprisal today against liberal Communists in the Academy of Sciences, including a former Premier, for criticism of Hungarian participation in the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
PERTH, Australia, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- The S.S. Chusan, carrying cars on the London-to-Sydney Marathon, received a tumultuous welcome today at Fremantle Port.
ASIDE from Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, who had flu complicated by the hiccups, everything else about Julie Nixon's predominantly pink wedding seems to have been in relatively good shape this week.
Shareholders of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., made it official at their annual meeting here yesterday by voting to approve a tender offer for the Sinclair Oil Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Post Office Department issued today regulations on mailing master keys for motor vehicles, carrying out a new law aimed to curb car thefts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Representative Melvin R. Laird expressed hope today that the Vietnam war could be ended next year. He also said that he planned to visit the war zone after he was confirmed as Secretary of Defense.

THE expressionist impulse, which dominated the American art scene during the nineteen-fifties, has so fallen out of favor among the artists of the sixties that one is more than a little shocked to discover a new and very gifted artist drawing upon the resources of expressionism with a tremendous energy, confidence and wit.

There is a disturbing discrepancy between warnings from defense officials in Washington that enemy units in South Vietnam are preparing new attacks and reports from the field indicating that the Communists have been unusually quiescent in South Vietnam.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- "This Story of Yours," the latest production in the Royal Court Theater's new season, is the work of John Hopkins, a prolific television script writer best known for his contributions to the police series "Z Cars."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission warned the makers of Geritol today to stop "flouting" a previous cease-and-desist order by the commission against advertising found to be misleading.

One fragment of the 1,000-year page was in a library in Leningrad, another was in the library at Cambridge. It took a scholar who saw them both together on microfilm in uptown Manhattan to say what they really meant.
PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 13 -- The recount between Senator Wayne Morse and Robert W. Packwood began on a stormy note today as hundreds of ballots were challenged by both sides throughout the state.

The Hong Kong flu, spreading at an ever faster rate, led yesterday to restrictions on hospital visitors here, the closing of colleges throughout the country, a slowdown in the nation's business and industrial activity and a threat to Christmas mail deliveries.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 -- Mayor Teddy Kollek has brought many things to Jerusalem. A few weeks ago it was a tombstone, as hand luggage

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The United Nations Special Political Committee voted today against a proposal to establish a custodian of former Arab property in Israel to arrange its restoration to its original owners.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Ed Mikan has submitted his resignation as supervisor of officials for the American Basketball Association effective Jan. 1, 1969, according to his brother, Commissioner George L. Mikan.
The Water Transport Association has chosen Charles E. Walker, president of Union Barge Corporation of Pittsburgh, as chairman for 1969.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Dick Payne, a local professional, rallied from six strokes back today to overtake the stumbling 36-hole leader, Jerry Head of Visalia, Calif., and win the $10,000 Nevada open golf championship with a 54-hole score of 205.
The Queen Elizabeth 2 will resume technical trials on the River Clyde on Tuesday, the Cunard Line announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A fire here that looked spectacular to Manhattan residents was only a routine blaze of scrap lumber on Breezy Point, fire officials said tonight. The fire started at 10:50 P.M.
Speculators in potato futures scrambled to get out of the market yesterday after the Department of Agriculture issued new figures on the "disappearance" of potatoes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- While he was Governor of Pennsylvania from 1963 to 1967, William Warren Scranton's reputation as an independent man -- not a runner-to-form in matters political -- won him the nickname of "the Hamlet of Harrisburg."

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers, cashing in on five technical fouls and cold Chicago shooting, scored their third victory over the Bulls, 94-83, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
ATLANTA, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Gov. Lester G. Maddox said today that he would try to dismiss any state policeman who failed to strike back when attacked by rioters.

BONN, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Dr. Otakar Svercina, a correspondent here of C. T. K., the Czechoslovak press agency, has been officially cleared of alliegations of espionage activites, a Justice Ministry spokesman said today.

The United States Steel Corporation, traditionally the pricing leader in the steel industry as the nation's largest producer backed down yesterday on a price increase because competitors refused to follow it.

For the last four months the Better Business Bureau of Harlem has been gathering sworn testmony of deceptive practices and gouging by some furniture merchants catering to the low-income residents of the area.

William W. Scranton reported to Richard M. Nixon yesterday that tensions in the Middle East remained '"extremely explosive" and suggested that the President-elect adopt an "evenhanded approach" toward hostile factions in that part of the world.

THE Jets will complete their schedule tomorrow in Miami, while awaiting the American Football League championship game, and the Giants will conclude their season against the Dallas Cowboys at Yankee Stadium.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Trespassing charges have been lodged against James Hall, 19 years old, a Springfield Negro ordered to stay off the University of Massachusetts campus after allegedly helping stage a hoax that sparked student demonstrations.

WARSAW -- The beret has been around a long time and has experienced various cycles of popularity outside its native France. Now it has hit Poland and is to be seen everywhere in all shapes and sizes, at all hours of day and night, in all sorts of colors and materials, on men and women, young and old.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 13 -- Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian Smith said today that his Government had a "new plan" to end the struggle with Britain which began three years ago when Rhodesia declared independence.
UNGER BROTHERS is getting to be the most familiar manufacturer's name among collectors of American art nouveau silver.

HONG KONG, Dec. 13 (Agence France-Presse) -- Premier Chou En-Lai, at a Peking reception in Honour of Tran Buu Kiem, head of the Vietcong delegation at the Paris peace talks, today reaffirmed Communist China's "unshakeable militant solidarity" with the South Vietnamese people until complete victory in their struggle against U.S. aggression."

Volume on the American Stock Exchange yesterday eased to 9,151,000 shares, compared with the extremely heavy trading of 10,110,000 shares the day before. The exchange index rose 10 cents to $33.12, setting the seventh consecutive record.

PRINCETON, N. J. Dec. 13 (AP) -- Led by the radical Students for a Democratic Society, 400 Princeton University students held a rally yesterday to demand immediate abolition of the Reserve Officers Training Corps at the university.
Malcolm Frager, the pianist, will play a Beethoven and Mozart program for the benefit of the New York Committee of Young Audiences on Wednesday in the Council Chambers at City Hall.
MIAMI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Dr. Orlando Bosch, a former pediatrician, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for his part in shelling a Polish freighter docked in Miami.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Guy Rodgers scored three field goals and five free throws in the final two minutes tonight to spark a Milwaukee rally that gave the Bucks a 101-96 victory over the San Diego Rockets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Dr. S. I. Hayakawa, the acting president of San Francisco State College, closed the school today effective tomorrow night and explained that he was starting the Christmas vacation a week early as a safety measure.
GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Casey Stengel remained in satisfactory condition today in Glendale Memorial Hospital, recovering from injuries suffered in an auto accident.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- The Spanish police announced today the capture of a leader of the campaign for an independent Basque state in northern Spain. Jose Dorronsoro, a leader of the Basque nationalist movement, was overpowered in a street struggle after trying to pull a pistol on policemen, they said.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury returned a six-count indictment today against James H. Rand 3d in connection with the manufacture and publicity surrounding "a purported cancer vaccine" in 1966.

The Federal Reserve Board is being urged to authorize an increase in the discount rate by at least one, and perhaps two, of its district banks, informed bankers said yesterday. The banks were not identified.
The election of Thomas G. Madigan as president of the Valley National Bank of Long Island was announced yesterday. George Auslander will continue as chairman of the board and chief executive officer.

The General Host Corporation, one of the nation's largest commercial bakers, disclosed yesterday that it was considering making a tender offer for control of Armour Co., the second-largest meat packer.

The S.C.I. Line (Shipping Corporation of Indias, Ltd.) has announced that a direct service from the West Coast to Hong Kong will be started on Dec. 29. The Vishva Maya will make the first trip and thereafter service will be maintained on a monthly schedule.

The atmosphere of unreason in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville and the I.S. 201 demonstration school districts makes a return to orderly and constructive educational operations more difficult to achieve with every passing day.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Dec. 13 -- The Graduate School at the State University Center here has initiated a program to increase the number of Negro graduate students next year.
The stock market showed signs of getting ready for the traditional year-end rally yesterday, as prices scored their widest advance since a period of consolidation began two weeks ago.

SAN REMO, Italy, Dec. 13 -- Italian boxing has an odious image problem that tomorrow's world middleweight title bout between the native-born champion, Nino Benvenuti, and Don Fullmer of Utah may resolve once and for all.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Some 50 law students at Harvard demonstrated today against a New York law firm that was recruiting on campus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Federal Communications Commission formally announced today proposed changes in the permissible operations of community antenna television systems -- proposals that seem headed for fierce debate in Congress and probably legal challenges to prevent their implementation.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 13 -- Joanne Darakjy won the senior women's figures in the North Atlantic figure skating championships today at the new Frank Ritter Memorial Ice Arena on the Rochester Institute of Technology campus.

NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Unbeaten Villanova, the nation's eighth-ranked basketball team, controlled the boards and capitalized on turnovers in scoring a 78-68 victory over Boston College tonight.
Tadeuz Przedpelski, of the American Union Forwarding, Inc., has been elected president of The New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The voice of business in the formulation of basic economic policy in the Nixon Administration may be even stronger than is suggested by a reading of the biographies of the policy team.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- The Inter-American Bank announced today approval of two loans totalling $10-million to support the development of small and medium private industry in Colombia.

Ernie Merz scored 25 points to spark a brilliant Adelphi University team effort last night as the Panthers scored a 59-57 North-East Collegiate Basketball League victory over St. Michael's College in the opening league game for both teams.
Final preparations have been made for the memorial service tomorrow for Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board of The New York Times, who died in his sleep Wednesday.

WESTBURY, L.I. Dec. 13 -- The only wheel in town -- the Big A called it a year last Tuesday -- will come to a halt tomorrow night, when Roosevelt Raceway stages the year's final harness-racing program in this area.

The Eastern College Athletic Conference refused yesterday to permit freshmen at its larger member colleges to participate in varsity athletics, although the National Collegiate Athletic Association allows freshmen to take part in all varsity athletics except football and basketball.

The head of the 50,000-member National Maritime Union has announced his candidacy for re-election in a letter to members that warned against voting for opposition candidates who, he said, sought to weaken the union at a crucial juncture in its history.

For most of its seven decades of existence, Hess's, Inc., a full-line, highly profitable department store in Allentown, Pa., has loomed in the firmament of American retailing as a bright, but lonely star.

Peregrine Pollen, the president of Parke-Bernet Galleries, and William Schuman, who is resigning as president of Lincoln Center, were in the garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Thirty-two agents who at one time worked in the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics have resigned since the start of an investigation into August, 1967, that has indicated "significant corruption," Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today.
A state official occupied the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district office yesterday to prevent the return of Rhody A. McCoy, the ousted district administrator.
Yesterday was a good night for "Messiah," what with the sing-in at Philharmonic Hall and the jubilant singing out of the Masterwork Chorus at Carnegie Hall.
Mr. Humphrey will combine his teaching activities with writing books and occasional articles on a broad range of subjects relating to issues of national interest.

Directors of the H. J. Heinz Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock, an increase in the quarterly dividend and a more than doubling of the number of authorized common shares.

RYE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- City of Rye officials said today that they were still opposed to the proposed Long Island Sound bridge-causeway linking this area with Oyster Bay in Nassau County. They said they would do everything to oppose the construction.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Georg Solti, the 56-year-old Hungarian-born conductor of London's Covent Garden Orchestra, was reported today to have accepted an offer to conduct the Orchestre de Paris. Charles Munch, who died Nov. 6, had been the conductor.

CARACAS, Venezuala, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Fishing smacks, pleasure boats and Venezuelan Navy vessels searched the shark-infested waters north of Caracas today for the bodies of 51 persons who were aboard a Pan American World Airways jetliner that crashed last night.
President-elect Richard M. Nixon says he will move with the clothing fashions but refuses to wear narrow trousers.
THERE are probably few actors basically less like one another than George C. Scott and E. G. Marshall, yet twice in the space of about a year Mr. Marshall has replaced Mr. Scott on Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Army must permit the burial of a decorated World War II veteran in Arlington National Cemetery although he later was convicted of being a Communist working to overthrow the Government.
Major crimes reported in the city rose 13 per cent during October compared with major crimes reported in October, 1967, according to monthly figures released yesterday by the Police Department.
A famous 17th-century Swiss room, two other rooms and two mammoth galleries for northern Renaissance treasures have been opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art after four years of construction.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A jury found Reies Lopez Tijerina not guilty today of kidnapping and other charges stemming from an armed attack on a rural courthouse at Tierra Amarilla on June 5, 1967.
The major league baseball owners will meet on Friday in Chicago to discuss the replacement of a commissioner for baseball and other related matters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today that it had filed a suit in Norfolk, Va., asking a stop to the freedom of choice type of desegregation in the public schools of Southampton County, Va.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has set the start of the next school year as the deadline for all public schools in its jurisdiction to be open to integration or abandoned.
BONN, Dec. 13 -- Menocil, a Swiss-made reducing drug, has been withdrawn from sale in Switzerland, West Germany and Austria, following doctors' reports that it might have adverse side effects.
ST. LOUIS (AP) -- The leader of a black student demonstration said today that he bad received a written reply from Washington University Chancellor Thoms H. Eliot to a list of 10 demands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A proposal that the Federal Government provide direct financial aid to students has drawn opposition from an organization representing many of the nation's state universities and colleges.

ROME, Ga., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Three men were arrested on charges of theft last night when the police found a 400 - pound bull in the back seat of their slowly moving car. The three men were in the front seat and the bull was in the back.

The naming of Claude O. Stephens as general chairman of the 1969 cancer crusade of the American Cancer Society's New York City division was announced yesterday. Mr. Stephens is board chairman of the Texas Sulphur Company. The drive will be held next April for donations for programs to help control cancer through public and professional education, care for cancer patients and scientific research.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 13 -- The Presidents of the United States and Mexico today saluted the settlement of a century-old border dispute with a dynamite blast that shifted the Rio Grande into a new concrete-lined channel that now forms the boundary between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Oec. 13 -- A dramatic plan to fit a new airport and a new town into the Virgin Islands and preserve the natural, scenic, recreational and historical values of the territory has emerged from a conservation controversy.
BRIDGE players who are considering Christmas gifts for card-playing friends have a wide range of items available to them this year. The following are new and worthy of consideration:

COLOGNE, West Germany, Dec. 13 -- An authoritative diplomatic source said today that a proposal to hold the election for the West German Federal President in West Berlin next year had revealed differences between the Johnson Administration and the incoming Nixon Administration in Washington.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The University of Kentucky selected today John Ray, defensive coach at Notre Dame, as its head football coach.
NASHVILLE, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A 10-foot-tall statue of Sgt. Alvin York, the World War I hero, was unveiled today on the Tennessee State Capitol grounds.
VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- France is favored to take top honors in this year's first major international special slalom for women tomorrow.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- The Chinese legation here returned unanswered a letter from colleagues of Anthony Grey, a Reuters correspondent, appealing for help in securing Mr. Grey's release from house arrest in Peking.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 13 -- President Arthur da Costa Silva ordered a recess of Congress tonight and assumed emergency powers for one-man rule. His action was the latest development in a day-old political crisis that had sent special police patrols into the streets.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- United States B-52's have concentrated on bombing the northern approaches to Saigon in the last 24 hours in an apparent attempt to disrupt an expected new series of enemy attacks.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Wide publicity given abroad to a small group of militant dissidents in this country has tended to overshadow what appears to be a deeper and more widespread malaise in Soviet society -- a credibility gap.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Nate Thurmond, despite an injured leg, scored 27 points and pulled down 19 rebounds tonight to lead the San Francisco Warriors to a 108-98 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Three Long Island teen-agers were held today on charges of setting several fires on Nov. 11 that resulted in $150,000 damage to the general office and auditorium of Massapequa High School.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- An 18-year-old roofing worker was arrested early today and charged with setting a downtown hotel fire that took the lives of five men and a woman.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Five major drug manufacturing concerns have been accused in a $12.5-million United States District Court suit of conspiracy to control the prices of certain drugs.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- What may be this nation's mightiest nuclear test is scheduled for detonation next Wednesday beneath the Nevada desert. It will be felt as an earthquake tremor by people 250 miles distant.
PRAGUE, Dec. 13 -- A Government for the Czech-Slovak Federation, officially coming to life on Jan. 1, was created tonight by the Central Committee of the Communist party.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Winston Churchill, grandson of Britain's wartime Prime Minister, charged today that Rolf Hochhuth's play "Soldiers" was an "infamous libel."
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- A Federal judge expressed doubt today that courts were competent to rule on whether Army reservists were getting adequate training before being sent to Vietnam.

UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Twenty-seven persons were killed and more than 100 others wounded, many seriously, when four Nigerian jet planes strafed the Biafran administrative headquarters at Umuahiatoday, Biafran military authorities reported.
Spokesmen for several leading foundations have endorsed a call to all foundations to put their "house in better order," or risk harsh legislation by Congress.

Mayor Lindsay took the unusual step yesterday of denying that Jesse Gray, the Harlem rent strike leader, or his Tenants Rights party had any connection with the Lindsay administration or received city funds in any form.
Ruben Rodriguez, a former corrections officer at the Federal House of Detention here, was sentenced yesterday to serve six months in prison and be on probation for two years.
PARIS, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Premier Maurice Couve de Murville announced today that a national referendum would be held on major changes in the structure of the French administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13, (UPI) -- The United States has won Soviet agreement to further limit Russian fishing of four species off the mid-Atlantic coast, the State Department announced today.
SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Students raced across the campus of the College of San Mateo today, smashing windows, doors and television cameras in the second day of violence.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A University of Wisconsin administrator, Dr. Donald K. McNeil, was named today as the first chanceller of the expanded University of Maine. He will take over early in 1969 as administrative head of a school system with some 5,000 students on nine campuses.

Distillers Corporation Seagrams, Ltd., the big Montreal-based alcoholic beverage concern, reported yesterday a net income for the three months to Oct. 31, its first fiscal quarter. of $17,456,000. In the comparable period a year ago, net earnings were $17,288,000.
CHEYNEY, Pa., Dec. 13 (AP) -- About 50 per cent of the Cheyney State College student enrollment of 1,975 returned to classes today.
The head of the Long Island Rail Road complained yesterday that some trainmen were slow to open car doors after trains pulled into their stations.
The bond market advanced slightly yesterday -- nudging interest rates down from recent record levels -- in a rather eventful session for a Friday.
BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- East Germany today announced an increase in military expenditures for 1969 of 500 million marks (about $125-million) over this year's defense budget of 5.8 billion marks.

DACCA, Pakistan, Dec. 13 -- The police fired on crowds in the port of Chittagong today as East Pakistan observed a general strike called to protest what was termed repression by President Mohammad Ayub Khan's regime.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Pat Denoy, an American Basketball Association referee, has been fined and suspended for an indefinite period because of rule-interpretation errors in two league games.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- About 75 Negro students at Cornell University today dumped hundreds of books on library floors, danced on tables of the crowded main student cafeteria and overturned a cart of soft drinks, milk and rolls that the university's president had provided for them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service has reversed an earlier interpretation of the Gun Control Act of 1968, putting strong new teeth into the controversial measure four days before it becomes law.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The police began searching for hundreds of poisonous jequirity beans today after discovering preschool children from the Lansing area gluing them on Christmas decorations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department announced today revised school lunch program payments designed to provide more free or reduced price lunches for an estimated one million children from poorer families.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey was offered today the position of professor at his alma mater, the University of Minnesota, and Macalester College, where he taught 25 years ago.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UPI) -- Flat Nose, the richest cat in Chicago, died today of old age, and it was a day of mixed emotions for its keeper.

LARNE, Northern Ireland, Dec. 14 -- The Clyde Valley, a Belfast-built steamer that ran a gantlet of British warships more than 50 years ago to land a cargo of rifles for the Ulster Volunteers, who were fighting against home rule for Ireland, returned to Northern Ireland today.
